<p>Title: Latex</p>
<article class="question">
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7ga3way2da7hz%2F32265e6c6aa4a80a7910d982a70aaa71177824a819082f15091f64bfabe31573%2Fimage.png" alt="image.png" /></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>The actual text should be outside of math mode. Here is a simple analogous example:</p>
<p></p>
<pre>
Thus, $p \land q$ is true.</pre>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 32</p>
<p>Folder: hw1h</p>
<p>Title: HW 1H</p>
<article class="question">
<p>hi im just a little bit confused on the difference between the set &#39;belongs to&#39; another set and the set is a &#39;subset&#39; of another set</p>
<p></p>
<p>so the &#39;belongs to&#39; for a set is only referring to one element and whether that element is present in the set,</p>
<p></p>
<p>while for the &#39;subset&#39; part it is when you consider a whole set and see if that whole set is within another set?</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Your definition for &#34;belongs to&#34; is correct.</p>
<p></p>
<p>One way of thinking about &#34;subset&#34; is &#34;A is a subset of B if every element of A is also an element of B&#34;. So for example, if $$A = \{1, 2\}$$ and $$B = \{1, 2, 3\}$$, then $$A \subseteq B$$, because every element of A is also an element of B. But if $$A = \{1, 4\}$$ and $$B = \{1, 2, 3\}$$ then $$A \nsubseteq B$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:38</p>
<article class="question">
<p>ok that makes sense, i know for the set itself order does not matter, so for something to be considered a subset that order does not matter either as long as the elements are in the whole set</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>correct. So in my example, we can say $$\{1, 2\} \subseteq \{1, 2, 3\}$$ but it is also true that $$\{2, 1\} \subseteq \{1, 2, 3\}$$</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 68</p>
<p>Folder: hw1h</p>
<p>Title: Problem with intuition for HW1H Question 7?</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Currently, I&#39;m trying to explore possible ways to solve this question with the 2^9 = 512 hint in mind. </p>
<p></p>
<p>One avenue is powerset (P(S) with cardinality defined as 2^n), though I&#39;m not sure what using that would mean. The subsets would be all the possible combinations of elements in S. I thought about setting up the nine TAs as the nine elements, but that doesn&#39;t seem particularly useful.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The other option I&#39;m juggling at the moment is more of a Step 1, Step 2, etc. based approach like the one we saw in lecture on Thursday. I originally thought of constructing a binary tree (9 rounds and two options per round - faulty fork or no faulty fork which would&#39;ve come out to 512 total permutations). I quickly realized this also makes no sense (it&#39;s redundant - why do the 8 other TAs need to check the fork if TA #1 already determined its status?). </p>
<p></p>
<p>Am I missing something here or am I assuming something wrong with my current two approaches? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
For questions like this, we encourage you to attend office hours to have a better conversation with a TA one-on-one!
</article>
<p>Response Time: 1:20:45</p>
<article class="question">
<p>What should I do if there aren&#39;t any more office hour sessions until the submission deadline for this homework? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
I believe some TAs will be holding OH tomorrow. We will be making an announcement about this shortly, so be on the lookout for that!
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 69</p>
<p>Folder: hw1h</p>
<p>Title: HW 1H</p>
<article class="question">
<p>for 5) is the way chef chooses the noodles random</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
Unfortunately, we do not know what goes inside the mind of Saurabh.<div><br /></div><div>In other words, since the question is essentially asking if it is possible to get to a noodle of length 1, the randomness doesn’t really play much of a role (because you are considering all possible sequences of noodle selections that Saurabh can make). Hope this makes sense. If not, follow up, and I’ll be happy to try to further clarify.</div>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 1:04:07</p>
<article class="question">
<p>ok so Saurabh is unpredictable and randomness doesnt matter got it</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
Sure, but I think it’s best not to get hung up on the randomness of the situation, and rather focus more on the POSSIBILITY of yielding a length 1 noodle<p></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>im not sure man i have a reasoning here for why its not possible to get a length 1 noodle but thats about it i dont want to go out testing all the possible scenarios but i want to think my reason makes sense so we should be fine</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
It may be of interest for you to attend office hours then! Speaking with a TA one-on-one may help clear up any of your doubts
</article>

<p>Title: Q7 clarification</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For question 7, does the fork testing end once? ie when the TAs are testing the forks, they won&#39;t know whether they&#39;ve used the faulty fork until 8:59am, and does this limit the number of forks each can test to be sure?</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 80</p>
<p>Folder: hw1h</p>
<p>Title: Q1aii</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I am posting this just to instructors since I do not want to give away the answer.</p>
<p></p>
<p>How is it possible for a nonset to have cardinality? If the only element of the empty set is nothing then how can you even calculate the cardinality of nothing since nothing isn&#39;t even a set?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Yes, we can only take cardinality of sets. Use that fact in conjunction with the other information you know about $$x$$ to come up with an answer! you seem to have a lot of the facts nailed down. It&#39;s just about piecing them together, and for that, use the fact that we only take cardinality of sets.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:04:23</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 81</p>
<p>Folder: hw2t</p>
<p>Title: Quotation marks help</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I am using quotation marks in my answer but one of them is facing the wrong direction:</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7gbcpu0x18298%2Fd588f1b000f2f21fe488014757912faa8e46d3eab2ef5e1259ea17814741bf2f%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-05_at_2.45.40_PM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-05_at_2.45.40_PM.png" /></p>
<p>Here&#39;s my LaTex:</p>
<pre>
&#34;$i-j$ is even&#34;</pre>
<p></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>You can use tick marks (which is the button to the left of the 1 key on a standard keyboard) for the left quotations. Something like this:</p>
<p></p>
<pre>
`` Hi I&#39;m Ishaan&#34;</pre>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:12</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 82</p>
<p>Folder: hw1h</p>
<p>Title: problem 2</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For problem 2, when I use multiplication rule, do I have to write out all the steps explicitly or can I imply the steps by writing out step 1 and saying etc.? (at the end I do multiplication rule normally with all the outcomes)</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>You can &#34;imply&#34; the steps. But a brief justification of why you are making that implication would be nice.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:58</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 95</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: Procedure that&#39;s not multiplication rule</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In the Lecture example: &#34;How many odd numbers between 1000 and 9999 have distinct digits?&#34; </p>
<p>why does the multiplication rule still apply? For example, the number of ways performing step 4 depends upon whether a zero was chosen in the earlier steps.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Also in the president, secretary, treasurer question, the solution says multiplication rule does not apply because outcome of prior step changes later # outcomes. What&#39;s the logic that distinguishes the approaches to these two questions? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Is it that within a question with multiple ways of performing the steps, only one sequence of steps allows multiplication rule to be applied and other sequences of events do not? thank you.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Note that only Attempt 3 shows a correct solution for the &#34;odd numbers&#34; question. In that attempt, we can see that we will not select the number zero in steps 1 and 2. Only the second digit and the third digit can be zeroes, which is why they are placed last in our ordering of steps. But these steps also acknowledge the fact that, for example, the second digit cannot be the same as the first or fourth digit (whose digits have already been chosen), which is why there are 10 - 2 = 8 ways to perform step 3. And similar logic holds for step 4.</p>
<p></p>
<p>I&#39;m not sure I completely understand your second question, but I&#39;ll try my best to give some information that may clear things up. Steps within your process that you develop for counting CAN depend on each other, but we can only perform MR when each step has a CONSTANT number of ways of being performed. For example, in attempt 1 of the &#34;secretary&#34; question, the third step can be performed in 2 ways if, for example, Bob is President and Ann is Treasurer, 1 way if, for example, Bob is president and Clyde is secretary, or 0 ways if, for example, Clyde is president and Dan is secretary. Since this is NOT a constant value, the MR can&#39;t really be used.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Whereas, in attempt 2, since we chose the secretary first, the remaining two steps always have the same constant number of people to choose from.</p>
<p></p>
<p>For your last question, no. There can be many ways of ordering the steps. You just need to be sure that the ordering of the steps meets the above rule of that constant value for each step.</p>
<p></p>
<p>hope that made a bit of sense!</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:11:22</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 96</p>
<p>Folder: hw1h</p>
<p>Title: Q4</p>
<article class="question">
<p><strong>What does two stripes that have the same color cannot share a long edge means?</strong></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>You cannot have two adjacent stripes with the same color IF they share a long edge. Each stripe is a rectangle, and &#34;long edge&#34; refers to the long side of the rectangle.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:56</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 104</p>
<p>Folder: hw1h</p>
<p>Title: 1 B 3</p>
<article class="question">
For this question, is there a way to denote previous members of the set that you are trying to describe, like x1. This question seems recursive, so not sure how to &#34;access&#34; previous calculated x values in the set if that makes sense.
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>You should avoid doing this for sets. This is because sets are an unordered collection of values. For something like sequences (which is something we don&#39;t cover in this class), the elements have order and we can use a recursive definition.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:01</p>
<article class="question">
lets say we have set 2, 5, 10. Could I then just do something like x = y&#43;1 where y is a set {1, 4, 9}? I guess I&#39;m struggling how to define the given set mathematically because the numbers reference each other in their calculation.
</article>
<article class="answer">
instead trying to replicate the pattern of 1 &#43; 1 = 2, 2 &#43; 3 = 5, 5 &#43; 5 = 10, where each new set member depends on previous calculation
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>You wouldn&#39;t be able to do x = y &#43; 1 where y is that set, however, what is special about the set {1, 4, 9}? Maybe you could express that some other way.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Given my suggestion of avoiding the &#34;recursive&#34; definition, it may be helpful to try to think about a different way to define the set!</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 117</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: Setting up k</p>
<article class="question">
In one of the lecture problems today where <div>A = {2, 2^2, 2^3,…}</div><div>B = {2, 4, 6, …}</div><div>and we have to prove that A is an improper subset of B,</div><div><br /></div><div>Professor Gandhi’s solution was this:</div><div>Let x be an arb. part. element of A where  x = 2^k </div><div>but then proceeded with: there exists a k belonging to a positive integer, s.t. 2*2^(k-1)</div><div><br /></div><div>in order to prove that x = 2l, where l = 2^(k-1) where l is a positive integer</div><div>what makes the “k-1” component necessary? Is setting k as a positive integer greater than but not equal to 1 a valid alternative?</div><div>thank you.</div>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>No, we can&#39;t quite say that $$k > 1$$ because it overlooks the case where $$x = 2$$. Since $$2 \in A$$, it can be possible that we let $$x = 2$$, and in this case, we would have $$k = 1$$. </p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:18:34</p>
<article class="question">
ohh then how about setting k as a positive integer greater than or equal to 1? That would solve having to include x=2. Just don’t see where the k-1 comes from.<p></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Yes, that would be the more accurate constraint on $$k$$.</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 123</p>
<p>Folder: hw2t</p>
<p>Title: Q3</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I&#39;m a bit confused on the wording regarding the 59 shades and the 12 disjoint pairs of lipsticks. Does each of the 59 shades individually have 12 disjoint pairs of lipsticks, meaning altogether there are 59 * 12 disjoint pairs of lipsticks? Or do all 59 shades together have 12 disjoint pairs of lipsticks (but then I&#39;m not sure why we would need to know the number of shades)? And for each disjoint pair, does &#34;disjoint&#34; imply that all the variants of green and orange are unique / do not repeat across the pairs? Do the variants have any connection to the number of shades? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>You can think of it as there are 59 lipsticks, each a different shade. Within the 59, there are 12 disjoint pairs that satisfy the criteria. </p>
<p></p>
<p>&#34;Disjoint pairs&#34; mean that if lipstick A is in one pair, then A cannot be in another pair that contributes to the 12 total pairs.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:43:20</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 127</p>
<p>Folder: hw2t</p>
<p>Title: HW 2T 2d</p>
<article class="question">
<p>What does the vertical line mean in this question?</p>
<p></p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky9490c3bto6gt%2Fd0964fe5789f86fb71591b86131d7327460fa8c3e07b68002e4f93e50f6c7261%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-06_at_3.42.50_PM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-06_at_3.42.50_PM.png" /></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>&#34;s divides (qx &#43; ry)&#34;</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:33</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Can you clarify what that means? I can&#39;t find it anywhere in the lecture notes</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>If $$a \mid b$$ then $$a$$ is a divisor of $$b$$</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Essentially, if you do $$\frac{b}{a}$$, the remainder is 0</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<md>I think it's actually the other way around: if you do $$\frac{b}{a}$$, the remainder is 0. (I like to think of it as $$a \mid b \iff b = ak$$ for some $$k \in \mathbb{Z}$$).</md>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Oh yeah you&#39;re right. It is b/a. I&#39;ll edit my answer above.</p>
</article>
</article>

<p>Post: 134</p>

<p>Title: Question 2 (d)</p>
<article class="question">
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7gybisso1u3th%2F5d7114f1777f7ddccae9925a8246c3e187a5ed4d6beaf5891214dcc25c3c3c3b%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-06_at_8.39.11_PM.png" width="294" height="40" alt="" /></p>

</article>
<article class="answer">
No. The vertical line denotes “divides”. So it reads as “s divides q and s divides r implies…”
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:12:11</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Is &#34;“s divides q and s divides r implies…”&#34; different from what I provided in my question?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Yes. Because (s/q) is a number whereas &#34;s divides q&#34; is a statement.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I see. Thank you. </p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 136</p>
<p>Folder: hw2t</p>
<p>Title: 1b</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In the lecture from k ∈ N it is determined that k &#43; 2 ∈ N. Can we make such assumptions without a proof in the hwk like in 1b?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yes</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:38</p>
<article class="question">
<p>So even when we are transitioning from N to Z&#43; for example, we can just write that some expression with t in it is in Z&#43; with no explanation?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Well not quite. The reason we can say that if $$k \in \mathbb{N}$$ then $$k+2 \in \mathbb{N}$$ is because $$\mathbb{N}$$ is closed under addition. Since in your example, we are transitioning from $$\mathbb{N}$$ to $$\mathbb{Z^+}$$, we can&#39;t quite use the same reason, because they are different sets. The good news, however, is that you can usually write an explanation within a sentence or two!</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Can we assume that if t does not have an upper bound then expressions like t&#43;5, t-7 etc. also do not have an upper bound?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>no, this would be something that you would have to justify.</p>
</article>
</article>

<p>Post: 141</p>
<p>Folder: hw2t</p>
<p>Title: Q2</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For question 2d, does the vertical line mean such that? And if so, what does s such that q mean?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
No. The vertical line denotes “divides”. So it reads as “s divides q and s divides r implies…”
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:44</p>
<article class="question">
<p>So does s divides q mean that q / s = to a non-decimal value?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
yep
</article>
</article>


<article class="question">
<p>Also for this problem, do we need to prove that the expression is always positive or are negative numbers considered even/odd as well? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<md>The definition of odd and even, stated in 1T, 
$$n \text{ is even} \iff \exists k\in \mathbb{Z} \text{ such that } n=2k$$ and  $$n \text{ is odd} \iff \exists k\in\mathbb{Z} \text{ such that } n=2k+1$$. 
Hence, negative, positive as well as 0 can be classified as odd or even. For example, -12 is even as $$-12=2(-6)$$ and -9 is odd as $$-9=2(-5)+1$$.</md>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<md>Problem marked as resolved.</md>
</article>

<p>Title: Parallel lines in Q6</p>

<article class="answer">

<p>Response Time: 1:21:20</p>
<article class="question">

<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7g9ro8i6iv5ln%2F180acdddb37379f1a02edf63d9ad8adceeb42d54df2e14623ec9abd2e65b03b9%2Fimage.png" alt="image.png" width="380" height="328" /></p>
<p>But if the points form the vertices of a rectangle, then the number of intersection points fall to 1 (because another pair of lines are now parallel and never intersect):</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7g9ro8i6iv5ln%2F031c598c44d82d2f0a1512c5ae92ee4cbcef518eda40d939478376bafeb4f9ca%2Fimage.png" alt="image.png" width="348" height="331" /></p>

</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Are we also expected to geometrically prove that no line can intersect a circle at 3 points, or are we allowed to assume such properties?</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 178</p>
<p>Folder: hw2t</p>
<p>Title: Disproving Via Counterexample</p>
<article class="question">
<p>When disproving universal claims via counterexample, if I &#34;guessed and checked&#34; and found a counterexample out of luck/intuition, is it fine to say that I happened to find a counterexample, which disproved the claim? Or should I still resort to breaking down the claim into basic parts? (Example: the claim is that all (odd &#43; even) yields even integers. if I just try 3 &#43; 6 = 9, I have already found a counterexample. but I don&#39;t know if &#34;guessing and checking&#34; is a rigorous purpose for finding the counterexample, so should I go further and rewrite odd &#43; even with their definitions (2k &#43; 1) and (2m) and show how you always get an odd integer from 2(k &#43; m) &#43; 1, hence breaking the claim into basic parts?)</p>
<p></p>
<p>Maybe what I&#39;m really wondering is if I should reduce every claim to basic parts for every proof, or if proving by example is not strong enough.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>A counterexample is a counterexample. You do not need to explain how you came up with it, you just need to provide it.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 2:11:39</p>
</article>

<p>Title: expansion of intersections</p>
<article class="question">

<p>Title: #6</p>

<p>Between each of the n points, is there only one line?</p>
<p></p>
<p>i.e. if there were 2 points, I know that there&#39;d be one line between, but if there were 4 points, would there be two lines connecting or would there be like 6 lines connecting all the points (so that each point touches the other point)?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>For every pair of points, there is a line connecting them. So if there were 4 points, there would be 6 lines.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:12:01</p>
</article>

<p>Title: Q2a</p>
<article class="question">

</article>
<article class="answer">
Venn diagrams will not suffice for a proof. They are good, however, for gaining initial intuition.
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:38:21</p>
<article class="question">

</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I think this should be acceptable so long as your case-work is exhaustive. Though this often proves to be a long and arduous process, especially compared to other equality proof techniques.</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 214</p>
<p>Folder: hw2h</p>
<p>Title: Question done in Lecture</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Hi, </p>
<p></p>
<p>For the following question done in the last lecture, why can we not do 26^4 - 25^4?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Question: How many strings are there of four lowercase letters that have the letter x in them? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Thanks, </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>$$26^4 - 25^4$$ is the correct answer.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:06:21</p>
<article class="question">
<p>The lecture notes said the answer should be 4 x 26^3.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>That solution is meant to be the one referenced by the &#34;Incorrect Solution&#34; note.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Ahh! Thanks!</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Can you explain why 4 · 26^3 is incorrect? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Sure. The procedure to get this answer is as follows:</p>
<p> </p>
<p>Step 1: Choose one spot to place the x</p>
<p>Step 2: Choose a letter for one of the remaining spots</p>
<p>Step 3: Choose a letter for one of the remaining spots</p>
<p>Step 4: Choose a letter for the last available spot.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Let&#39;s consider two <strong>distinct</strong> &#34;paths&#34; through this procedure.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Suppose in step 1, I place the x in the first slot. Now, in step 2, let&#39;s suppose we are looking at the second slot, and suppose we happen to choose the letter x for that slot as well. In step 3, suppose we place a y in the third slot. And suppose in step 4, we place a z in the last slot. Then the string we have constructed is &#34;xxyz&#34;.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Now, suppose in step 1, I place the x in the <strong>second</strong> slot. Now, in step 2, we find an available slot and choose a letter for it. So suppose we look at the first slot and happen to choose the letter x. In step 3, suppose we place a y in the third slot. And suppose in step 4, we place a z in the last slot. Then the string we have constructed is again &#34;xxyz&#34;.<br /><br />So we see that we have constructed the same string twice by following <strong>distinct </strong>&#34;paths&#34; in the procedure. This is an indication that we have overcounted, and the answer is incorrect.</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 229</p>
<p>Folder: hw2h</p>
<p>Title: Q2: Can we use De Morgan&#39;s Laws in our proofs?</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In particular, does the equivalence $$\neg(p \lor q) \equiv (\neg p \land \neg q)$$ count as something already proven in class? Thanks.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yes, you can use De Morgan&#39;s laws (including the equivalence you specified) without proof. Though it would be nice to specify in your solution that you are using De Morgan&#39;s when you actually use it!</p>
<p></p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:03</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Does the set version of this also apply? $$A \setminus (B \cup C) = (A \setminus B) \ \cap (A \setminus C) \\$$ and $$A \setminus (B \cap C) = (A \setminus B) \ \cup (A \setminus C)$$</p>
<p></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Yes, you can use this without proof (as we covered it in recitation!)</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 230</p>
<p>Folder: hw2h</p>
<p>Title: 2H Question-6</p>
<article class="question">
How is the spacing between the n special points? Are the points evenly spaced or randomly spaced? <br /><div><div><br /></div></div>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>They are arranged in a way so as to not have multiple lines intersecting at the same point. So to answer your question, they are neither evenly spaced (because this would lead to multiple lines intersecting at the same point) nor are they randomly spaced (because this does not guarantee avoiding multiple lines intersecting at the same point).</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:57</p>
</article>

<p>Title: Homework 2H - Question 1</p>
<article class="question">
<p>If I am trying to prove this question using the contradiction method. I understand that I would have to prove d &lt; 1/d &lt; t &lt; 1/t and d &gt;= -1 --&gt; C. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Is it sufficient to show this leads to a contradiction when d = -1, or do I need two case: when d = -1 and when d &gt; -1. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Also, is it enough to show that d can&#39;t be &lt; 1/d if d &gt;= -1. Does this prove the original statement in the question? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 232</p>
<p>Folder: hw2h</p>
<p>Title: Disprove using one example</p>
<article class="question">
In one of the other questions, I saw that you can disprove a statement using one counterexample; does that also apply for disproving a set equality? I.e. If I wanna prove A = B have to prove that A and B are subsets of each other, then if I found one case in A \subseteq B where this isn’t true, is it sufficiently proving that A ≠ B? thanks.
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Yes, showing $$A \nsubseteq B$$ would prove that $$A \neq B$$. Often, the easiest way to do this is to find some $$x \in A$$ such that $$x \notin B$$.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:17</p>
</article>

<p>Title: Distributive properties of logical operators</p>
<article class="question">
<md>Are we allowed to use distributive properties of logical operators in our proofs without first proving the property? Or should we prove them first before applying them in our proofs?

E.g. $$P \land (Q \lor R) \equiv (P \land Q) \lor (P \land R)$$.</md>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yeah you should justify this</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 239</p>
<p>Folder: hw2h</p>
<p>Title: Trying to understand distinguishable vs indistinguishable</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Hi, I was wondering how question 3 from the homework would be different if the cars were indistinguishable. I&#39;m thinking that it would be 8 choose 3, but I&#39;m not too sure. Could I please get some insight? Thank you!</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>As an example, suppose three of the cars are called $$A$$, $$B$$ and $$C$$ (distinguishable), and suppose the three interests are called $$x$$, $$y$$, and $$z$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Then one possible distribution of these cars would be $$A$$ to $$x$$, $$B$$ to $$y$$ and $$C$$ to $$z$$. But clearly, there are many more ways to distribute the cars.</p>
<p></p>
<p>If, however, the cars were indistinguishable, then we could all give them the same name of $$A$$. And the <span style="text-decoration:underline">only</span> way to distribute the cars now would be $$A$$ to $$x$$, $$A$$ to $$y$$ and $$A$$ to $$z$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>As a reminder, <strong>ALL</strong> eight cars must be distributed amongst his interests.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:06:43</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Oh, interesting. The way in which i was doing it I don&#39;t think all the cars were being distributed?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Here&#39;s the procedure that I created for indistinguishable:</p>
<p></p>
<p>Contestant 1 gets a car: 8 possibilites</p>
<p>Contestant 2 gets a car: 8 possibilites</p>
<p>Contestant 3 gets a car: 8 possibilites</p>
<p></p>
<p>Contestant 1 gets 0 cars: 8^2 possibilites</p>
<p>Contestant 2 gets 0 cars: 8^2 possibilites</p>
<p>Contestant 3 gets 0 cars: 8^2 possibilites</p>
<p></p>
<p>Contestant 1 gets all cars: 1 possibility</p>
<p>Contestant 2 gets all cars: 1 possibility</p>
<p>Contestant 3 gets all cars: 1 possibility</p>
<p></p>
<p>So the total ways would be 8^3 - (3 x 8^2 - 3)?</p>
<p></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Unfortunately, we cannot comment on the correctness of your solution/answer. However, if you have any doubts regarding the problem and/or your solution, then it would be a good idea to go to office hours to speak with a TA in person!</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I understand that, but I was just wondering since this is a not exactly a homework problem as I have changed the conditions for the problem and created a new hypothetical scenario to clarify the difference between indistinguishable and distinguishable. No worries though, I appreciate it.</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 248</p>
<p>Folder: hw2h</p>
<p>Title: Use Basic Algebra on Homework?</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For question 1, am I allowed to use normal algebra to solve the inequality $$x<\frac{1}{x}$$ to get $$x\in(-\infty,-1)\cup(0,1)$$?</p>
<p></p>
<p>In other words, how much of high school algebra do I need to prove? Can I say something like $$x^2>1 \implies |x|>1$$ without explanation?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Yeah, you can say $$x^2 > 1 \implies |x| > 1$$ without explanation. Most algebraic steps can be done without proof.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 3:46:39</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 258</p>
<p>Folder: hw2h</p>
<p>Title: Distributive Property of Logical Operators</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Do need to prove the distribute properties of logical operators for each problem, or can we prove it once and use it for the rest of the psets.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Ex. $$A \cap (C \cup B) = (A \cap C) \cup ( A \cap B)$$</p>
<p>Ex. $$A \cup (C \cap B) = (A \cup C) \cap ( A \cup B)$$</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>You can prove it once and then use it for the rest of the psets (though you should cite where you proved it initially whenever you choose to use it in the future).</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:55</p>
<article class="question">
<p>can we explain this with words or does it elicit a formal proof</p>
<p></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>either is fine so long as it is logically sound and correct.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Would we also have to prove the logical equivalent</p>
<p>$$x \land (y \lor z) = (x \land y) \lor (x \land z)$$</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I believe this is what the original question is asking, no? Regardless, you should prove this.</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 260</p>
<p>Folder: hw2h</p>
<p>Title: Q2 approach clarification</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Hi! I have an approach for question 2 that I&#39;m not so sure about. I&#39;m pretty much representing a three-way venn diagram as sets. For example, let set A contain only silver dresses, set B contains only silver/tan dresses, set E contains only silver/tan/red dresses, and set D contains only silver/red dresses. Each of these sets can be empty. Then, let set S represent sets that contain tan dresses, so that S = {A, B, D, E}. Is this rigorous enough to go through the questions and do actual operations on?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>These Venn Diagram-esque approaches are good for gaining insight into what the sets will look like after the operations are performed on them, but do not suffice as a rigorous proof. For this, it may be a good idea to reference the lecture notes to see what a more rigorous proof would look like.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:06:40</p>
</article>

<p>Post: 264</p>
<p>Folder: hw2h</p>
<p>Title: Negative factorial</p>
<article class="question">
For proofs, if there is a negative factorial, do we have to prove why negative factorials are undefined? <div>ex: something like 3C10 </div>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>No. You can just assume that $$\binom{a}{b} = 0$$ for $$a < b$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:19:51</p>

<p>Title: Closed form with multiple combinations?</p>
<article class="question">
<p>If there are multiple combinations in our solution being multiplied, do you want us to cancel out terms baked into the combination formula or leave it as is?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>nah you don&#39;t need to cancel them out. So something like $$\binom{10}{3} \cdot \binom{5}{2} \cdot \binom{7}{6}$$ would be a fine final answer.</p>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 272</p>
<p>Folder: hw2h</p>
<p>Title: pictures/diagrams on latex</p>
<article class="question">
<p>is it possible to upload images to latex to aid with proofs?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yeah</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 2:06:11</p>
<article class="question">
<p>What would be the latex code required to add images?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>You&#39;ll have to upload the image to your overleaf project, then play around with the \includegraphics command. For example, the flag in HW1H was inserted using the following LaTeX:</p>
<p></p>
<pre>
\begin{figure}
	\centering
	\includegraphics[width=3in]{flag.png}
\end{figure}</pre>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 274</p>
<p>Folder: hw2h</p>
<p>Title: How many cases would you need to have to cover all numbers in R for Q1?</p>
<article class="question">
<p>After stating that I am proving the question by contradiction, would having 2 cases, where Case 1: d &gt; 0, and Case 2: 0 &gt; d &gt;= -1 cover all possible numbers in R? Or do I need to have more cases?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>there is no minimum or maximum value on the number of cases. You just need to make sure that the casework is exhaustive. one way of checking this is to take the union of values covered in each case, and ensure that it is equivalent to the domain.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:05:15</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 275</p>
<p>Folder: hw2h</p>
<p>Title: Associativity of logical operators</p>
<article class="question">
<md>Are we allowed to use associative properties of logical operators in our proofs without first proving the property? Or should we prove them first before applying them in our proofs?

E.g. $$P \land (Q \land R) \equiv (P \land Q) \land R$$.</md>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>if all operands in the expression are the same, then sure you can assume associativity</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 1:39:27</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 276</p>
<p>Folder: hw2h</p>

<p>Title: Q5 clarification</p>
<article class="question">
<p>To make it a bit easier, I am going to divide my question into 4 sub-questions:</p>
<p></p>
<p>(1) In 5a: we&#39;re going to send 10 people to each island, so 30 people in total</p>
<p>(2) In 5b: we&#39;re going to send 4 &#43; 5 &#43; 6 people on the islands, so 15 people in total</p>
<p>(3) The order in which we send the people does not matter in either (a) or (b).</p>
<p>(4) Part (b) says &#34;How many different arrangements are possible&#34;. By saying arrangements, does it mean groups of 15?</p>
<p></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>(1) Yes, 30 people of the $$n$$ are sent to islands.</p>
<p>(2) Yes, 15 people of the $$n$$ are sent to islands.</p>
<p>(3) This is something we&#39;d like you to think about.</p>
<p>(4) You can think of this as saying &#34;How many ways are there of sending the people to the islands given the constraints&#34;</p>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 285</p>
<p>Folder: hw2h</p>
<p>Title: Q6</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Could you provide an example of the case for n=7?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkbmhj6eluup47f%2F15aa843ffa01221f123f5a24efc86e269df960ad7bc0308456a15707ba304e9e%2FIMG_5853F5066899-1.jpeg" alt="IMG_5853F5066899-1.jpegNaN" /></p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 1:38:27</p>
<article class="question">
<p>My apologies, but could I get one for n = 8 as well? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>nah sorry man that&#39;s a bit too much for me! I&#39;d really encourage looking at the drawings you have for $$n \leq 7$$ and start to form a solution.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<md>If you really want it, for n-8, ![Screen_Shot_2022-09-13_at_22.17.29.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fl5yov8xpzt965n%2Fab0b1640fa1e6140233496170d7d004ef3b68949675b366f6df870d61d740258%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-13_at_22.17.29.png)

for n=9, ![Screen_Shot_2022-09-13_at_22.19.28.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fl5yov8xpzt965n%2F13f77abeca8dd7139e1c641c969032fbc58b2db5e8241a30ae16e090bfd4133b%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-13_at_22.19.28.png)

for n=10, ![Screen_Shot_2022-09-13_at_22.20.02.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fl5yov8xpzt965n%2F3d9834767db9a11b6c5ef9498f3d17ac3c3de98cc8e4558f0d0d84b782747931%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-13_at_22.20.02.png)

If that is not enough, you are probably on the wrong track. You don't have to consider too much about this...

If you need more you can generate them with this python code:

```python
from math import sin, cos, radians
from turtle import Turtle, done, tracer, update

turtle = Turtle()
radius = 300
sides = 10

def init():
    tracer(0, 0)
    turtle.speed(0)
    turtle.hideturtle()
    turtle.penup()
    turtle.pensize(5)
    turtle.goto(0,-radius)
    turtle.pendown()
    turtle.circle(radius)
    turtle.penup()
    turtle.pensize(10/sides)
def get_points(x):
    angles = [2**(-_)*360 for _ in range(x)]
    return [(sin(_)*radius,
             cos(_)*radius)
            for _ in angles]
def draw_line(point1,point2):
    turtle.penup()
    turtle.goto(*point1)
    turtle.pendown()
    turtle.goto(*point2)
    turtle.penup()
def draw_lines(x):
    points = get_points(x)
    for point1 in points:
        for point2 in points:
            if point1 != point2:
                draw_line(point1, point2)
def main():
    init()
    draw_lines(sides)
    update()
    done()

main()
```

Note: \<run code snippet\> might not work.

At about n=20 it is no longer useful.</md>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 287</p>
<p>Folder: hw2h</p>
<p>Title: Why is the word &#34;distinguishable&#34; important?</p>
<article class="question">
How does this word influence how we do counting?
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Let&#39;s consider two similar questions:</p>
<p></p>
<p>Question 1: How many ways are there to give two <strong>distinguishable</strong> watches to two distinguishable people such that each person gets a watch.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Solution: Let $$A$$ be the first watch and $$B$$ be the second watch. Let $$X$$ be the first person and let $$Y$$ be the second person. Then we have two distributions: $$((A, X), (B, Y))$$ and $$((A, Y), (B, X)$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Question 2: How many ways are there to give two <strong>indistinguishable </strong>watches to two distinguishable people such that each person gets a watch.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Solution: Now, we <strong>cannot</strong> call our watches $$A$$ and $$B$$ because they are indistinguishable. Instead, we will call them both $$A$$. If our people are $$X$$ and $$Y$$, then we only have one distribution: $$((A, X), (A, Y))$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>In a sense, &#34;distinguishable&#34; allows for more variety in our cases/distributions.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 1:19:55</p>
</article>

<article class="question">
<p>Do we need to prove that switching order of operations without parentheses is okay? For example, if X = A \cup B \cap C, X = A \cap C \cup B is also true? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">

</article>

<p>What if there are no parentheses?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Then it&#39;s ambiguous because you wouldn&#39;t know whether to perform the union or intersection first.</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 320</p>
<p>Folder: hw3t</p>
<p>Title: Product rational irrational</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Do we need to prove that the product of a rational and irrational number is irrational, and also that a natural number is also a rational number</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Yes, you should prove the product. </p>
<p></p>
<p>A one sentence justification for why a natural number is a rational number would suffice.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:46</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 323</p>
<p>Folder: hw2h</p>
<p>Title: Q5b</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For question 5b, do some of the n contestants move from the 3 indistinguishable islands to Singapore, Bajas, and Fiji and do the original islands have a different max capacity now so that those islands are able to be filled to their maximum capacity?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>You can think of it as that all $$n$$ people are reconvened (even the ones who were assigned islands in part a), and then those $$n$$ people should be used in part b. So yeah, I guess some people may &#34;move&#34;, but you should not think about the people/islands of part a when solving part b.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:59</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 326</p>
<p>Folder: hw2h</p>
<p>Title: q6</p>
<article class="question">
<p>if we find the formula for the number of intersecting lines, do we have to prove this inductively, or can we just write the formula and say we found it through a pattern?</p>
<p></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>you can provide the formula, but justifying by citing a &#34;pattern&#34; would not be rigorous. But you should still justify your answer (avoid induction since we haven&#39;t covered that in class yet.)</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:29</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 327</p>
<p>Folder: hw2h</p>
<p>Title: Contrapositive</p>
<article class="question">
<p>If you are writing the contrapositive of an implication with inequalities on each side, do you flip all the inequalities?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>My answer is a very hesitant yes, because I feel like there are examples in which you do not flip all the inequalities, but I can&#39;t think of one at the moment.</p>
<p></p>
<p>In general, it is best to simply individually negate both sides and if the negation requires the inequality sign to be flipped, then do that.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:11:11</p>
</article>

<p>Title: Do we need to prove this property of negation of multiple sets? And how would we if we do?</p>
<article class="question">

<p></p>
<p>And if we do how would we prove it?</p>
<p></p>

<p>those are de morgan&#39;s laws!</p>

I’m not sure this equality holds. Consider an element in $$A$$ but not in $$B$$.

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 330</p>
<p>Folder: hw3t</p>
<p>Title: Do we have to reprove lemmas that we&#39;ve proven in previous homeworks?</p>
<article class="question">
<p>There have been several homeworks thus far that have proofs that benefit from basic properties of even/odd numbers like</p>
<ul><li>the sum of two odd numbers is even</li><li>the sum of two even numbers is even</li><li>the sum of an odd number and an even number is odd</li></ul>
<p>as well as similar rules for the multiplication of even/odd numbers.</p>
<p></p>
<p>If I&#39;ve proven those properties in previous homework assignments, do I still need to prove them again?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>you do not need to prove them again. you can cite them from your previous hw</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:29</p>
</article>

<article class="question">

Sorry for making this private but i thought i should not be saying what i thought the answer for something was to the whole class.
</article>
<article class="answer">

<p></p>

</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I can&#39;t quite give you the answer you want, but I will say that a correct proof for an incorrect claim <em>should</em> make you suspicious of it...</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 347</p>
<p>Folder: hw3t</p>
<p>Title: Can we assume division of two rational numbers is rational?</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Ex. If p and q are both rational, p/q is also rational?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>No, you should prove this!</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:15</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Then could I prove it by saying it is rational as it results in the division of the product of integers? </p>
<p>Ex. If x = a/b and y =c/d, then x/y = ad/bc. Or would I then need to prove that the product of integers is rational?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>not quite. I would utilize the definition of rational, and morph the division of the two rational numbers into a form that matches the definition of a rational number.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>By definition, wouldn&#39;t rational numbers be expressed as a fraction of two integers so x = a/b and y = c/d (b/c not equal to 0).</p>
<p>Then dividing would give me ad/bc which is also a fraction of two integers, so it has to be rational</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yep that&#39;s exactly it</p>
</article>
</article>


<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 349</p>
<p>Folder: hw3t</p>
<p>Title: Question 1c Roles across groups</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Are the roles in subteam A distinguishable from the roles in subteam B? For example, would roles A 1-6 be the same or different from roles B 1-6?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>They are different in the sense that being on role 1 on team A is different from being on role 1 on team B.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 1:55:52</p>
</article>

<p>Title: Q3 HW 3T</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Just a clarifying question - if we are to say that a proof is invalid, do we need to correct their work and state a valid proof or does simply explaining why there&#39;s an issue suffice?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>You do not need to provide a valid proof. you should just indicate where the error is and justify why it is wrong</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:55</p>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 359</p>
<p>Folder: hw3t</p>
<p>Title: Division by 0 follow up</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Hi, just wanted to confirm that since dividing a rational number by 0 produces an undefined result, we cannot ever state that 0 divides a rational number. </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Well we don&#39;t really use the word &#34;divides&#34; when talking about rational numbers anyways, unless the rational number just so happens to be an integer. Like it is foreign to say &#34;$$2$$ divides $$\frac{3}{2}$$&#34;.</p>
<p></p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:01</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 366</p>
<p>Folder: hw3t</p>
<p>Title: 1C</p>
<article class="question">
<p>are islands A and B considered distincint, meaning if (1,2,4,5) on island A and (6,7,3,8) on island B is different from (6,7,3,8) on island A and (1,2,4,5) on island B</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Do you mean &#34;team&#34;? If so, then yes, teams A and B are considered distinct.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:41:00</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I mean like for example  if a subteam consisting of (1,2,4,5) on island A and subteam consistiing (6,7,3,8) on island B is different from a subteam containing (6,7,3,8) on island A and a subteam (1,2,4,5) on island B</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 367</p>
<p>Folder: hw3t</p>
<p>Title: Prime factorization</p>
<article class="question">
<p>From lecture, if a^2 = 2b^2, then why does the number of prime factors they have necessarily have to be equal? S (a^2) = S(2b^2)?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Because $$a^2$$ and $$2b^2$$ represent the same number. Suppose we let $$p=a^2$$ and $$p = 2b^2$$, which follows from the fact that $$a^2 = 2b^2$$. Then saying that &#34;$$a^2$$ and $$2b^2$$ must have the same number of prime factors&#34; is equivalent to saying &#34;$$p$$ and $$p$$ must have the same number of prime factors&#34;, which is true.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:16:46</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 414</p>
<p>Folder: hw3t</p>
<p>Title: Q2</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For my proof for Q2, I have shown that for every value of c, sqrt(a) is irrational. I am trying to state that proving this for every value of c is sufficient because every possible value that sqrt(a) can take on corresponds to a value of c. I am able to show that every possible value of a corresponds to a value of c, as a must necessarily be equal to 19c^2 for some value of c. Would I just be able to state that every possible value of sqrt(a) corresponds to some value a, to then transitively show that every possible value of sqrt(a) corresponds to some value of c, and thus showing that all values of c result in sqrt(a) being irrational is sufficient to show that all values of sqrt(a) are irrational? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>You are allowed to assume $$\sqrt{a} = \sqrt{b}$$ if and only if $$a = b$$. How you choose to use this fact in your solution is up to you.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:24</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Would I be able to assume that $$\sqrt{a}$$ never takes on some value that does not correspond to a?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>probably not, just because of how loosely defined &#34;correspond&#34; is. Try utilizing math to &#34;define&#34; the correspondence, and from there, potentially use the fact that I provided above, if needed.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Thank you! I think I understand what you&#39;re getting at.</p>
</article>
</article>

<p>Title: Q3 a</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For question 3a, do we say that -143 is divisible by 143? Or can we even say that negative numbers are divisible?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 429</p>
<p>Folder: hw3h</p>
<p>Title: Proving a &#34;there exists&#34; statement</p>
<article class="question">
<p>To prove a &#34;there exists&#34; statement, can we just provide 1 example that validates the statement?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>This only works when you have a specific instance of a problem. In most cases, problems are given in a &#34;general&#34; case with variables and abstract values. In these cases, you should avoid giving a single example, and prove that such an example always exists.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:03:51</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 430</p>
<p>Folder: hw3h</p>
<p>Title: Proven in class</p>
<article class="question">
<p>If part of what we need for a proof has been done in class (e.g. product of two odds is odd), can we simply state &#34;proven in class&#34; for that part of the proof without further justification?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
Yes
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:37</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 431</p>
<p>Folder: hw3h</p>
<p>Title: Q7</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I&#39;m a bit confused by Q7 because it seems to me that parts a and b are asking the same thing. My rationale is that if Max wants to have all the creatures in Justin&#39;s list, there is only one way to do that, plus the &#34;extra&#34; elements that he can add to his own list (the creatures in his list that aren&#39;t in Justin&#39;s list). So isn&#39;t the solutions for parts a and b the same or am I missing something? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>In part a, the creatures in Max&#39;s list can be identical to that of Justin&#39;s list. But in part b, this cannot happen since Max must have at least one more.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:07:18</p>
<article class="question">
<p>So all the &#34;extra&#34; creatures that Max can have only needs to be accounted for in part b? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Does that also mean that in part a, Max&#39;s set of creatures needs to be exactly identical to Justin&#39;s set of creatures?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>No. But they <strong>can </strong>be identical in part a. This suggests that you should also consider the extra creatures in part a.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I see, so they CAN&#39;T be exactly identical in part b? Also, is it okay to leave the answer in terms of n, because it doesn&#39;t seem to me that we can end up with some number value.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yeah that&#39;s fine</p>
</article>
</article>

<p>Title: Creatures Selected, Distinct</p>

</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:07:48</p>

Yes, Jus-tien has an unknown amount of creatures, but you are considering ALL possible lists Jus-Tien can have. You ca. introduce a new variable if that helps you, but your answer should not be in terms of it.

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 452</p>
<p>Folder: hw3h</p>
<p>Title: Multiset Question</p>
<article class="question">
<p>This is more related to lecture but I am confused about this phrase in the lecture notes: </p>
<p></p>
<p>&#34;In other words, we want to find the number of ways there are to choose a multiset of r elements from a multiset of n distinct elements with infinite copies of each of the n elements available&#34;</p>
<p></p>
<p>How are we choosing a multiset from another multiset? Can you provide an example if possible? Thanks. </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>A multiset is defined to be a set where elements can repeat. So if we are looking at a multiset that has repeats, and we want to select a subset of items, sometimes we would want repeats in that subset (hence, we would want to obtain a multiset).</p>
<p></p>
<p>A good example is the book example in the lecture notes, where in our 6 book selection, we will have repeats. </p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:29:49</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In that example I don&#39;t understand intuitevly where 6&#43;3-1 is coming from. </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>To clarify, I am asking why it makes sense that there are 8 possible locations to place a divider? I am counting only 5 (a divider in between two crosses). </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I think the best way to explain this is to consider an arrangement of sticks and crosses. So for example, let&#39;s look at **|*|***. Each &#34;section&#34; corresponds to a type of book (and there are three types of books). Each star represents a book (or rather, a count of the amount of books in the category). So the arrangement I provided says that there are 2 books of type 1, 1 book of type 2 and 3 books of type 3. A single arrangement of books can uniquely be represented by one of these strings.</p>
<p></p>
<p>We need 6 &#34;crosses&#34; to represent the 6 books that we need, and we need (3-1) = 2 dividers, so that&#39;s why we have $$\binom{6 + 3 - 1}{6}$$</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Sorry, but I am still confused about why intuitevly 8 choose 6 makes sense. We are trying to choose 6 books out of 8 of what? Why is it 8? Why are the dividers included in the total? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>8 is the total amount of books and dividers needed. In order to uniquely describe a selection of books, you need a &#34;string&#34; similar to the one I provided **|*|***, where there are 6 crosses and 2 sticks. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Instead of thinking of the 6 as &#34;choosing 6 books&#34;, it may be helpful to think of it as you have 8 spaces (where you need to place books and dividers), and you are choosing the locations to put the books.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Notice that $$\binom{6 + 3 - 1}{6} = \binom{6 + 3 -1}{3 - 1}$$, so in a similar mindset, we could instead choose the locations for the dividers, and the books will go in the remaining spaces.</p>
<p></p>
<p>We need to include the dividers, because otherwise, we have no separation of the books, because we would be treating all books as indistinguishable.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Makes sense now, thank you!</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="answer">

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 465</p>
<p>Folder: hw3h</p>
<p>Title: Is this a valid proof by contradiction?</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Let&#39;s say the claim is <strong>t</strong><strong>he sum is even. </strong>If I want to prove the claim by contradiction, we assume that the sum is odd. If my contradiction is that I showed that the sum will be even (contradicting the assumption), is this considered proof by contradiction? Or is this redundant/unnecessary because I am simply proving that the sum is even directly? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Basically, for a specific problem, I just think it&#39;s easier and clearer to understand if I prove a claim by initially assuming the opposite and thus everything that assumption implies. Then with those implications and the rest of the context of the problem show that the original claim is true. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Hopefully, my question is clear (I tried my best haha) and I can get some guidance! </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>This really depends on the proof. Most of the times when doing contradiction, we end up contradicting something true that was given in the problem, though in some instances, you may end up contradicting what you assumed.</p>
<p></p>
<p>If you find yourself often proving the opposite of what you assumed, then it may be best to just stick with a direct proof.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:52:48</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 469</p>
<p>Folder: hw3h</p>
<p>Title: Sum of prime factorization</p>
<article class="question">
<p>&#34;Let S(m) be the sum of the number of times each prime factor occurs in the unique factorization of m&#34;</p>
<p></p>
<p>What does this exactly mean? Is this the sum of all the prime factors?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Not quite. I&#39;ll give you an example: $$84 = 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 7$$. The prime factor $$2$$ appears $$2$$ times. The prime factor $$3$$ appears one time. The prime factor $$7$$ appears one time. So $$S(84) = 2 + 1 + 1 = 4$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:03:24</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 473</p>
<p>Folder: hw3h</p>
<p>Title: Q3 Is $$\sqrt14$$ known to be positive?</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Can we assume that $$\sqrt{14}$$ is positive?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>no</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 1:33:58</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Isn’t the square root operator conventionally defined as the positive root of the radicand?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>You can assume that the square root function is well-defined (i.e. produces a unique output for any input), but it doesn&#39;t have to always return the positive root of the radicand for this problem.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I’m sorry, I’m not following. You say it doesn’t always have to return the positive root, so wouldn’t that mean it’s not well-defined? (Unless of course we’re strictly defining the square root operator as the always the negative root). If one input directly corresponds to one output than sqrt(14) is either always positive or always negative, so which is it?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>After some thought, we&#39;ll let you assume that $$\sqrt{14} > 0$$ for this problem.</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 481</p>
<p>Folder: hw3h</p>
<p>Title: Q2</p>
<article class="question">
<p>When the question says &#34;for every integer m ≥ 2, if there is no prime number p such that p ≤ √ m and p | m, then m must be a prime,&#34; wouldn&#39;t the statement always be false because every prime number is evenly divisible by itself, so p | m always holds true and m would never be a prime number? Or am I interpreting the question wrong? Thanks</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>but you also need to consider that $$p \leq \sqrt{m}$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:12:33</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Don&#39;t both conditions (there is no prime number that fits both conditions) have to hold true for m to be prime? Or is it saying that as long as one of the conditions is false, then m is a prime?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>The problem states that if there is no prime p that satisfies both of these conditions, then $$m$$ is prime. What does it mean logically to not satisfy a conjunction statement?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Oh I see, so as long as 1 condition does not hold, the conjunction statement is not satisfied and thus m is prime, right?</p>
</article>
</article>

<p>Folder: hw3h</p>
<p>Title: Q7 Converting Summation to closed form</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I&#39;ve obtained an answer to Q7a that is a summation involving n, $$\sum_{k=0}^{n} \binom{n}{k} * 2^{n-k}$$. Is there a way I could proceed to turn this into a closed form answer using what we have learned in class, or should I take a different approach to the problem? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Maybe try substituting $$n = 1, 2, 3...$$ into your solution, see if you notice a pattern to convert the answer into closed form, and then justify why that equality is true.</p>
<p></p>
<p>If that proves to be too challenging, then perhaps try a different approach and/or modify some of your thought process.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:54</p>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 486</p>
<p>Folder: hw3h</p>
<p>Title: Prime and Composite Numbers</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Can we assume that if a number is not prime, it is composite? Or would we need to prove this?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>If you&#39;re looking at a number like $$7$$ or $$16$$, then you can just say whether or not it is prime or composite. But if it is some sort of expression with variables, then you should prove whether or not the evaluation will be prime or composite.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:00</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 489</p>
<p>Folder: hw3h</p>
<p>Title: Q2</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For the statement &#34;if there is no prime number p such that p ≤ √m and p | m&#34;, can I get a clarification on what this means. If the statement is saying &#34; (if there is no prime number p such that<br />p ≤√m) and p | m&#34; then it would be the same thing as that if there is a prime number p such that p &gt; √m <strong>and </strong>p evenly divides by m. If the statement is saying that &#34;if there is no prime number p such that (p ≤ √m and p | m),&#34; would that mean there is a prime number p such that p &gt; √m <strong>or</strong> p <strong>doesn&#39;t </strong>evenly divide by m by demorgan&#39;s laws right?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I don&#39;t think you can just negate that expression and have it be logically equivalent. You should also be considering the second part of the statement &#34;... then $$m$$ must be prime&#34;</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:07:30</p>
<article class="question">
<p>So would the statement &#34;if there is no prime number p such that p ≤ √m and p | m, then m must be a prime&#34; not be logically equivalent to &#34;if there is a prime number p such that p &gt; √m and p | m, then m must be a prime&#34;? I am trying to do contradiction (so I would only be changing the second part to then m must be composite) but I don&#39;t understand what the first part of the claim logically means so I am confused.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>$$p \implies q$$ is not logically equivalent to $$\neg p \implies q$$. In general, when doing contradiction, you assume $$\neg q$$ to be true. </p>
<p></p>
<p>One way of thinking about the first part is consider you have some value $$m$$. From there, you consider every single prime $$\leq \sqrt{m}$$. If none of these primes divide $$m$$, then (this is the second part of claim), $$m$$ must be prime.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I am confused on what the negation of p would actually be then. If I say, &#34;if there is a prime number p such that p &gt; √m and p | m, then m must be a prime&#34; would that not be a double negative because I am saying that there is a prime number rather than there is no prime number and that the prime number is greater than sqrt m rather than less than or equal to sqrt m.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>The opposite of &#34;there exists some prime p such that XYZ conditions hold&#34; is &#34;there <strong>does not</strong> exist some prime p such that XYZ conditions hold&#34;. You wouldn&#39;t necessarily negate the conditions.</p>
</article>
</article>

<p></p>
<p>As usual, I get to the step where I substitute the induction hypothesis and I have </p>
<p></p>
<p>(1&#43;2&#43;...&#43;k)^2 &#43; (k&#43;1)^3</p>
<p></p>
<p>I tried to show that it equals to (1&#43;2&#43;...&#43;k&#43;(k&#43;1))^2 algebraically for the last few hours but I can&#39;t do it. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Alternatively, If I use the lemma I get (k(k&#43;1)/2)^2 &#43;(k&#43;1)^3 and I know how to get the required form from there to finish the proof. </p>
<p></p>
<p>So my question is, are we expected to figure it out algebraically somehow or are we expected to just prove the lemma first and then prove the main claim using the lemma here? </p>
<p></p>
<p>My reasoning was that as there is nothing in question about doing it via proving 1&#43;...&#43;n = n(n&#43;1)/2 first, we should be able to do it without using this fact, but now after 4h of trying I am not sure anymore...</p>

You are allowed to use the fact that 1&#43;2&#43;…&#43;n =n(n&#43;1)/2 without proof, but it is not required to use it

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 505</p>
<p>Folder: hw3h</p>
<p>Title: WLOG and &#34;arbitrary but particular&#34;</p>
<article class="question">
<p>What is the different between saying &#34;without loss of generality&#34; and &#34;arbitrary but particular&#34;? When would we use each?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>&#34;Without loss of generality&#34; is commonly used when making a claim for some variables. For example, I would say something like &#34;suppose $$a, b \in \mathbb{Z}$$, and without loss of generality, let $$a < b$$&#34;. And then I would do whatever math needed. In the instance that $$b < a$$, I wouldn&#39;t have to do any math because the &#34;symmetric&#34; argument is covered with &#34;Without Loss of Generality&#34;. That is to say, we can&#39;t just be throwing around WLOG whenever we want. We should only use it when the argument truly is symmetric.</p>
<p></p>
<p>&#34;Arbitrary but Particular&#34; is usually used when describing an element of a set. We use this to indicate that there is &#34;nothing special&#34; about the element, and the argument for that element will hold for all elements of the set.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 10:14:30</p>
</article>


<article class="general-box">

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 508</p>
<p>Folder: hw3h</p>
<p>Title: How to negate the statement &#34;if there is no prime number p such that $$p \leq m$$ and $$p | m$$&#34;</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Hi, I am unsure of exactly how to negate statements in logic. What is the procedure for negating a statement like &#34;if there is no prime number p such that $$p \leq m$$ and $$p | m$$?&#34; Would I only negate the first part (i.e., there <em>is</em> a prime number p), or would I negate &#34;and&#34; between $$p \leq m$$ and $$p | m$$? Or is it something else entirely, such as negating the math expressions to $$\geq$$ and $$\nmid$$? Thank you for your help with this.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>The opposite of &#34;there is no prime such that XYZ conditions hold&#34; is &#34;there <strong>is </strong>a prime such that XYZ conditions hold&#34;</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 8:02:33</p>
</article>



<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 511</p>
<p>Folder: hw3t</p>
<p>Title: m must be a prime negation (q2)</p>
<article class="question">

</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Note that the question can be rephrased (without losing any meaning) as &#34;... if there is no prime $$p$$ such that $$p \leq \sqrt{m}$$ and $$p \mid m$$, <strong>then $$m$$ is prime&#34;</strong>.</p>
<p></p>
<p>How you choose to negate this is something we&#39;d like you to think about</p>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 532</p>
<p>Folder: hw3h</p>
<p>Title: Set Notation</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Is the notation &#34;C = C1 &#43; C2&#34; proper set notation to describe that the set C can be partitioned into two sets, C1 and C2?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Not quite. Something like $$C = C_1 \cup C_2$$ and $$C_1 \cap C_2 = \emptyset$$ would be more accurate</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:48</p>
<article class="question">
<p>But |C| = |C1| &#43; |C2| would be correct, right?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>If $$C_1$$ and $$C_2$$ partition $$C$$, then it is true that $$|C| = |C_1| + |C_2|$$. But just saying $$|C| = |C_1| + |C_2|$$ alone does not imply that $$C_1$$ and $$C_2$$ partition $$C$$</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">

</article>

<p>Title: Question 1B</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Does the cardinality of a set with repeated elements only account for the number of distinct elements? </p>
<p>For instance, is the cardinality of the set {0, 1, 0, 0} 4 or 2? </p>
<p>Also, in this question are we assuming that C can contain repeated elements or not? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>In this case, we allow $$C$$ to have repeated elements, and you can assume $$|C| = n$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:27:27</p>

<p>Title: Q3</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Would this be a logically valid statement? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Since every element in B is greater than $$2\bar{x}$$, the sum of the elements in $$B$$ must necessarily be greater than $$|B| * 2\bar{x}$$, which would be the sum of the elements in $$B$$ if every element in B was equal to $$2\bar{x}$$, and we know every element in B is greater than $$2\bar{x}$$. . </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yes that&#39;s fine</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:08:56</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 564</p>
<p>Folder: hw3h</p>
<p>Title: Q4</p>
<article class="question">
<p>What does it mean &#34;You must apply the basic definition of subset as done in lectures and recitations.&#34;</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>You are encouraged to use the fact that if $$A \subseteq B$$ then $$\forall x \in A$$ we have $$x \in B$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:17</p>
<article class="question">
<p>is this equivalent to showing that P(A∩Z) ⊆ P(A)∩P(Z) and P(A)∩P(Z) ⊆ P(A ∩ Z)?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>it&#39;s not equivalent, but it is something that you will probably use in showing those two facts.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Sorry i&#39;m still slightly confused. Then should we not prove P(A∩Z) ⊆ P(A)∩P(Z) and P(A)∩P(Z) ⊆ P(A ∩ Z)?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
You should still prove those. It’s just that you’ll be using the definition I supplied in proving those
</article>
</article>


<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 566</p>
<p>Folder: hw3h</p>
<p>Title: Question About Contrapositive</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Hi! I was wondering if we have P s.t. A and B implies Q, would the contrapositive be:</p>
<p></p>
<p>1. -Q implies -P s.t. A and B</p>
<p>or</p>
<p>2. -Q implies -P s.t. A or B</p>
<p></p>
<p>Because the statement is about P, and st A and B are descriptions of P, would it not use demorgans law? Im thinking of HW 3H question 2.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Thanks!</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Our solutions for 3H are now posted on Canvas, so you can take a look at them now.</p>
<p></p>
<p>But in general, you can try to simplify a complex statement. So for example, the &#34;if...then...&#34; statement in Q2 is quite complex, but it can be boiled down to: &#34;if there is no prime $$p$$ such that XYZ conditions hold, then $$m$$ is prime&#34;.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The contrapositive would be &#34;If $$m$$ is not prime, then there <strong>is</strong> a prime $$p$$ such that XYZ conditions hold.&#34;</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 2:28:03</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 571</p>
<p>Folder: hw4t</p>
<p>Title: Q7</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Can we show that an expression not in closed form is equal to a summation if the terms are in a different order?  This is the statement for reference:</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$\binom{m-1+r}{m-1} + \binom{m-1+r-1}{m-1} + \binom{m-1+r-2}{m-1} + ...... + \binom{m-1+r-r}{m-1} $$= $$\sum_{i=0}^{r} \binom{m-1+i}{m-1}$$</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yeah that&#39;s fine</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:39</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Additionally, when showing that the summation expression is the answer for the question asked, am I allowed to arithmetically manipulate the terms inside the summation? Ex. if I state that there are $$\binom{(m-1)+(r-2)}{m-1}$$ ways to choose $$m-1$$ objects from a set of size $$m+r-3$$ instead of $$\binom{(m+r-3}{m-1}$$ ways.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yeah that&#39;s fine</p>
</article>
</article>

<p>Title: Induction Hypothesis Assumptions</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I know that we stated that for our induction hypothesis, we assume n = k for some integer k, and in our inductive step we can use this assumption to help us prove or disprove the claim, but I wanted to know, can I also assume the claim holds for values less than n = k in the induction step (we haven&#39;t really had a homework question on this but I was just curious).</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
At this point, no. <div><br /></div><div>However, when we cover strong induction, you will see this idea arise.</div>

<p>Title: Q2 r &gt; 1, k = 1</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Can we assume that we will never have the situation where we need to pick more than 1 block, but there is only the gold brick available i.e. the situation where r &gt; 1, k = 1?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>The color gold is always included in the $$k$$ colors.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 6:36:55</p>
<article class="question">
<p>So if k = 1, we know the single color is gold. If k = 2, one of the colors is gold and the other color a color with infinite blocks. It&#39;s not possible for k = 2 and for both colors to be one of the colors with infinite block.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
Correct
</article>
</article>

<p>Title: Clarification of Q3</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In the question it said, &#34;You should not algebraically manipulate the expressions; i.e. your answers to your counting question should be equal to the expressions on the LHS and RHS of the equality as they are given, not different algebraic expressions even if they may be equivalent.&#34;</p>
<p></p>
<p>What if my question gives the answer $$\sum_{i=0}^{r}\binom{i+m-1}{m-1}= \binom{m+r}{r}$$ instead of $$\sum_{i=0}^{r}\binom{i+m-1}{m-1}= \binom{m+r}{m}$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>This is still correct right since $$\binom{m+r}{m} = \binom{m+r}{r}$$</p>
<p></p>
<p>Or would that count as &#34;algebraic manipulation&#34; and wont be allowed</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>you should try to adjust your question so that the RHS is $$\binom{m + r}{m}$$ instead of $$\binom{m+r}{r}$$</p>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 630</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: Changin from equal to greater than or less than sign</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In the lecture note for the proof that n! &lt; n^n, the induction step goes from using an equal sign to a less than sign. Why can we do this? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
Because the induction hypothesis says that $$k! &lt; k^k$$. So we’re substituting that in, which means we can’t use equality since the IH doesn’t have equality
</article>
<p>Response Time: 1:55:01</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 631</p>
<p>Folder: hw4h</p>
<p>Title: Any tips for designing a combinatorial proof</p>
<article class="question">
<p>How does one make a good counting question that can be used for a combinatorial proof, and what are some useful techniques? I noticed that the question is usually made from the simpler side of the identity to be proven, and the more complicated side is derived from partitioning the choices by some sort of scheme.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I&#39;m not the greatest at combo proofs, but I&#39;ll do my best to answer this and maybe another TA can provide their advice.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The way I approach combo proofs is exactly what you outlined: I look at the easier side, and formulate a counting question based off of that.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The &#34;harder&#34; side often requires a bit more creativity. There&#39;s usually some sort of system involved in counting the &#34;harder&#34; side, whether that be partitions or casework. It&#39;s also nice to do a bit of pattern recognition (like if I see a $$2^n$$ on the harder side, I might be thinking about subsets).</p>
<p></p>
<p>Really, a lot of it comes down to practice and creativity in developing different methods of solving the same counting question.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 5:49:17</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
