<p>Title: HW4H</p>
<article class="question">
<p>ishaan is it ok like for number 1 to use word rather than the symbols because i get the idea of how to describe the answer but once you tell me to use the symbols its too hard</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>it is not <em>necessary </em>to use mathematical symbols. However, I like to encourage students to use it because relying on words only tends to be less rigorous than using mathematical notation. but at the end of the day, it&#39;s up to you! choose whatever suits you best, and you&#39;ll receive credit as long as your answer is logically and mathematically sound and correct.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:51</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 651</p>
<p>Folder: hw4h</p>
<p>Title: Proof by contradiction</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I am proving by contradiction for #1. Would the negation of there exists at least 3 be there exists at most 2? I am confused because I thought when you negate &#34;there exists&#34; it becomes &#34;for all&#34; but that does not seem possible in this case.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
This is something we’d like you to think about. Usually we negate “there exists” to “for all” when the quantifier is referencing a variable, and the variable is being used in some expression to prove.<div><br /></div><div>Another hint is that the opposite of “there exists…” is “there does not exist…”</div>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 5:07:13</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 654</p>
<p>Folder: hw4h</p>
<p>Title: 2b Induction</p>
<article class="question">
<p>What would be the format for doing induction on 2 variables—would 1 base case, 1 IH, and 2 inductive steps be sufficient?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
This is something we’d like you to think about!
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:39:01</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Got it, but I&#39;m a little confused as to how to approach this as we haven&#39;t done a 2 variable induction proof in class.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
When doing any kind of induction proof, the most important thing to think about is making sure your induction covers all the values for the variable(s) you are inducting on.  It can take some time to find the correct strategy and it can come in different forms, but as long you cover everything you&#39;ll get the points for it.
</article>
</article>

</article>
<p>Response Time: 1:56:56</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Still not working for some reason - are there any commands that I can use?</p>
<p></p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky9490t2lnx6i5%2F4285bd533b44c66692ca4469888f3d15a38391e55e94aa4b8d4906224297a0c2%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-24_at_9.54.32_PM.png" width="1136" height="324" alt="" /></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I think if you use single dollar signs, it should fix the issue.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Alternatively, you can enter align mode, and then use \\ to create new lines.</p>
</article>

<p>Title: Question about proof methdology</p>
<article class="question">
<p>On exams will the question always say &#34;use induction/combinatorial&#34; proof or will we have to decide when to apply these methods? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 718</p>
<p>Folder: hw4h</p>
<p>Title: Naming in proofs</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Can we say something like <em>Let <strong>g</strong> be a grandmaster in the group of k players? </em>Does this affect the generality of the proof? Or do we have to say something like <em>Let <strong>g</strong> be an arbitrary but particular grandmaster in the group of k players (does that even make sense?)</em></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>This depends on the remainder of your proof, but most of the time, it is fine to just say &#34;let g be a grandmaster in the group&#34;</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:03:32</p>
</article>







<article class="question">
<md>What I am asking is in what kind of counting question could our answer be n or n-1 ways</md>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I&#39;m still not sure what you are asking here? If it is possible to have 2 answers of n and n-1 to one counting question?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<md>No i am saying could you say two different question with answer $$n$$ and $$n-1$$ respectively as i am not getting what that could be</md>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>One question with an answer of n could be how many ways can I pick a color of n colors. Then a question with an answer of n-1 could be how many ways can I pick a color out of n colors given that blue is one of the n colors and I cannot pick blue.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<md>Oh thanks i was silly to forget that</md>
</article>






<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 731</p>
<p>Folder: hw4h</p>
<p>Title: Q4</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Do I need to prove the statement that the number of $$n$$ subsets of a set of $$m$$ elements is equal to the number of ways to choose $$n$$ elements from the set.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>a one sentence justification would be nice</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:26</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Would this justification be valid? </p>
<p></p>
<p>The number of $$n$$ subsets of a set of size $$m$$ is equal to the number of ways to choose $$n$$ elements from the set. This is because each $$n$$ subset of a set is a unique set of $$n$$ distinct elements taken from the $$m$$ elements, which is what $$\binom{m}{n}$$ enumerates.<br />        </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Anything that is logically sound and correct would be deemed valid.</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 738</p>
<p>Folder: hw5t</p>
<p>Title: max(p,q) meaning</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I&#39;m a little confused about the notation for Q1 e) what does max(p,q) mean?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>It returns the maximum value between $$p$$ and $$q$$. So, for example, if $$p = 30$$ and $$q = 20$$, then $$max(p, q) = max(30, 20) = 30 = p$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:04:14</p>
</article>




<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 742</p>
<p>Folder: hw5t</p>
<p>Title: Strengthening the inductive hypothesis</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For some proposition Q, if we prove Q(0), Q(1), Q(2), and then for arbitrary but particular k&gt;=2, that [Q(k-1) AND Q(k)] ==&gt; [Q(k) AND Q(k&#43;1)], do we still have to explain how this modified form of induction shows that Q(n) is true for all natural n? (analogously, strong induction was not given a rigorous proof using weak induction in lecture)</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yes you should explain this, but this seems like some sort of variant of strong induction. So in instances like this, it is probably better to just use strong induction instead.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:09:59</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 743</p>
<p>Folder: hw5t</p>
<p>Title: Q2 Coeffecient</p>
<article class="question">
<p>When a term is in the form of (n choose k)5x^k * 5^(n-k), do we consider the coefficient to be (n choose k) or (n choose k)*5^(n-k)? Not sure which if the 5^(n-k) is a part of the coefficient, thanks.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yes, $$5^{n-k}$$ would be considered part of the coefficient, because $$5^{n-k} \in \mathbb{Z}$$, and is not a polynomial term.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:06</p>
</article>





<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 748</p>
<p>Folder: hw5t</p>
<p>Title: Question 3</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For question three I&#39;m putting that my induction hypothesis is Tn =4^k &#43; (-1) ^k. But for the induction step can I assume the formula that was given to me by the problem (meaning the first formula) or do I have to include it in the induction hypothesis?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>You may assume that the formula given in the problem holds true for all values of $$n$$. How/where you choose to incorporate this in your proof is up to you.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:25:59</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 749</p>
<p>Folder: hw5t</p>
<p>Title: For strong induction, which variable do we use for our hypothesis and induction step?</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Ex. if we are trying to make a hypothesis with values of n from 2 &lt;= j &lt;= k, would we use j or k in our induction hypothesis and induction step?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Usually, you need two variables in the induction hypothesis, so you would have $$j$$ and $$k$$. In the induction step, you should still be aiming to prove that the $$k+1$$ case is true.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:21</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 751</p>
<p>Folder: hw5t</p>
<p>Title: Q1d</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Are we allowed to assume that 5*1=5?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yes</p>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 785</p>
<p>Folder: hw5t</p>
<p>Title: Lecture Question</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For induction hypothesis, why do we say &#34;for some k&#34; instead of say &#34;for any k&#34;?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>great question. I think this comes down to how induction is built upon the idea of proving $$P(k) \implies P(k+1) \quad \forall k$$. Since it&#39;s hard to prove that implication for all values of k, if we show the implication to be true for an arbitrary value of $$k$$, then we don&#39;t have to worry about proving it for all $$k$$, because we would have already shown that since $$k$$ was arbitrary.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Since $$k$$ is arbitrary, we say &#34;for some k&#34;, since we don&#39;t really know what $$k$$ is, but we just want it to be arbitrary.</p>
<p></p>
<p>I can&#39;t quite put my finger on why &#34;for any k&#34; may be incorrect because I think there are valid arguments on both sides (for it to be logically acceptable or not). One such argument is that &#34;for any&#34; may be an implication of strong induction, but not in an accurate way. But one could also argue that &#34;for any k&#34; can mean the same thing as &#34;for some k&#34;</p>
<p></p>
<p>Given this, my recommendation is to stick with convention and to just use &#34;for some k&#34;.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 3:55:40</p>
</article>


<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 787</p>
<p>Folder: hw5h</p>
<p>Title: Divisibility lemma</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For Q5, do we need to prove that if a prime p divides N, but does not divide D, then if N/D is an integer, p divides N/D?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
You should justify this
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:54</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In the case of Q5, would the following argument be considered rigorous enough?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Since $$q\geq1$$, $$p\mid P(p,q)$$, so $$P(p,q)=q!\cdot\tbinom{p}{q}$$ is a multiple of $$p$$. It must then be true that $$p\mid\tbinom{p}{q}$$, since the only prime factor of $$p$$ (which is $$p$$) cannot divide $$q!$$ when $$q\leq p-1$$. This is because prime $$p$$ shares no common prime factors with any integers less than $$p$$. Thus, for any prime $$p$$ and integer $$q$$ s.t. $$1\leq q\leq p-1$$, $$p\mid\tbinom{p}{q}$$.</p>
<p></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
Sure
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 791</p>
<p>Folder: hw5h</p>
<p>Title: Q3 traveling through other nodes</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Suppose that we have nodes A, B, and C. A is one way to C, but C is one way to B and B is one way to A. If we ask &#34;Can we travel from C to A&#34; will the answer be yes (because we can go through B)?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>No. The answer will only be &#34;yes&#34; if there is a direct connection (i.e. you only need to take one walkway to get from the start location to the end location of the question)</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:34</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 792</p>
<p>Folder: hw5h</p>
<p>Title: Q1 n=1</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For n=1 in Q1 does the claim hold</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Yes, because $$1^a - 1^b = 0$$ and $$1000 \mid 0$$ because $$ \exists \, k$$ such that $$1000 \cdot k = 0$$.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:36</p>

<p>Can you explain why the claim also holds for n = 2.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Unfortunately not, because that would require revealing the solution.</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 797</p>
<p>Folder: hw5h</p>
<p>Title: Q3 Clarification</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Does there have to be at least one dead end?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>No. But if a dead end exists, Bethany must be able to find it.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:07:17</p>
<article class="question">
<p>So does that mean that if there are multiple dead ends, Bethany must be able to find all of them?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>is it possible for there to be multiple dead ends?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Wouldn&#39;t</p>
<p></p>
<p>    T</p>
<p>   ^ ^</p>
<p>  /    \</p>
<p>S     v</p>
<p> -&gt; U</p>
<p></p>
<p>have both T and U as dead ends, assuming S is the entrance?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Remember, all nodes must have a connection, either -&gt;, &lt;-, or &lt;-&gt;. Thus, in that example, either s -&gt; v, v-&gt; s, or s&lt;-&gt;v, and thus there exist no dead ends in that example.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I mean in the case where S-&gt;T, T&lt;-&gt;U, and S-&gt;U</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>There are zero dead-ends in that example</p>
</article>
</article>

<p>Title: Induction Question</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For induction proofs, do we necessarily need an expression to evaluate to equate the LHS to RHS, or can the induction step be logical, such that the only variable we have is n (the variable we are doing induction on?)</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>The induction step can be logical! The beauty of induction is that it doesn&#39;t just work for proving mathematical equalities; it can be used for much much more!</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 800</p>
<p>Folder: hw5h</p>
<p>Title: Q3 Adjacent/Neighbors question</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For Q3, does a dead end have 0 neighbors, or does there just need to be an edge connecting the two nodes and not necessarily the right direction between the two? For example, if S-&gt;T and U-&gt;T, does T have 0 neighbors (because there are no available walkways to leave section T) or does T have 2 neighbors (because there are 2 edges connecting S and T and T and U)?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>$$S$$ is a dead end if you cannot leave $$S$$ to go to a different section. If $$S \rightarrow T$$ and $$U \rightarrow T$$, then $$T$$ would be a dead end.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Since &#34;adjacent&#34; and &#34;neighbors&#34; are not defined in the problem, it is hard to accurately answer your question, because it depends on how you define these terms on your own.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:04:02</p>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 812</p>
<p>Folder: hw5h</p>
<p>Title: Q5</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I went to office hours earlier today regarding question five on the homework, but I am still a bit confused. I got to here in my induction step:</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7ggz0g8t3v4za%2F455e54c7b405c3cdff7da1df98f63fba2980547ca9fbb56806ddc0ffa694d242%2Fimage.png" alt="image.png" /></p>
<p>and the TA told me to try and show that $$p \choose j$$ is always a multiple of j, so i can write the expression as k&#43;1&#43;pm &#43; p(some other stuff) but I don&#39;t think that statement is even true? I&#39;m just a little lost on how to show that what is in the summation is an integer multiple of p. Not sure if its best to just go back to OH tomorrow, but I thought I would ask on here as well. </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>showing that $$\binom{p}{j}$$ is a multiple of $$j$$ would not imply that the summand is a multiple of $$p$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Instead, try showing that it is a multiple of $$p$$ if your goal is to rewrite it as $$k + 1 + pm + p(\text{other stuff})$$. Try expanding out the $$\binom{p}{j}$$ and use what you know about $$j$$ compared to $$p$$.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:11:11</p>
</article>

<p>Title: Binomial Theorem</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Does the binomial theorem include the possibility of applying it to something like (x&#43;0)^a or does that not work because it does not assume that 0^0 is 1? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>It would still work. Though it is very rare to see binomial theorem used for $$(a + b)^n$$ when, for example, $$b = 0$$, because then it&#39;s just usually easier to simplify to $$(a + 0)^n = a^n$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 1:02:13</p>
<article class="question">
<p>But does it work because 0^0 is assumed to be 1, else I do not see how the summation would give you the correct answer?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yeah that is the assumption that is made for it to work.</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 822</p>
<p>Folder: hw5h</p>
<p>Title: Q1 - Assuming # of Remainders</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Can we assume that the number of remainders possible when dividing $$x$$ by some other positive integer is $$\left\lceil\frac{x}{2}\right\rceil$$, or should we prove this?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I&#39;m not sure what you mean by this. If you divide $$x$$ by $$3$$, for example, the remainder is one of $$0, 1, 2$$, so there are $$3$$ remainders possible. And if, for example, $$x = 15$$, then $$3 \neq \lceil \frac{x}{2} \rceil$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:53</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Sorry, I rethought my process and I don&#39;t think I need this information anymore! I&#39;ll reach out again if I need clarification.</p>
</article>
</article>


<article class="question">
<p>For example, if we were to prove by induction that zoe can always get a winning startegy if she draws the lines, no matter how many, in a certain way, then would that work? I assume this would work because this means that Zoe always has a winning stargey, even though she draws the lines in a certain way.</p>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 827</p>
<p>Folder: hw5h</p>
<p>Title: Q3 &#34;getting out”</p>
<article class="question">
I don’t think I completely understand the definition of a dead end. What does it mean to get out of the store? If all the other stores are nodes then would there also be an additional node for exit / entrance to the store? thank you!
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Suppose there are only 3 sections, $$S$$, $$T$$, and $$R$$. Since there must exist a walkway between each pair of sections, one possible set of walkways is $$S \rightarrow T$$, $$T \rightarrow R$$ and $$S \rightarrow R$$. In this case, $$R$$ is a dead-end, because if you are in section $$R$$, you cannot go to any other section by following the walkways.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:51</p>
<article class="question">
The question says all the stores are (at least they should be if not a dead end) connected by a walkway but nothing in the problem about an exit or entrance. 
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Ignore the lore about finding Spooky Bats &amp; Cats Sour Gummy Candies and making it out. As long as you&#39;re not stuck in a single section, it&#39;s not a dead end. This means yes, even if you have two sections &#34;separated&#34; from the rest of the store, as long as you can ping-pong between them, neither is a dead end, even though you can&#39;t visit the rest of the store.</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">

<article class="answer">
<p>You can assume that there is an infinite supply of each snack at all times when Sneha is constructing the grid.</p>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 833</p>
<p>Folder: hw5h</p>
<p>Title: Assumptions about division and integers</p>
<article class="question">
<p>If we know that $$\frac{xy}{z}$$ is an integer and that $$\frac{x}{z}$$ is not an integer, can we simply conclude that $$\frac{y}{z}$$ is an integer?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Is this true? If $$x = 6, y = 3$$ and $$z = 9$$, then $$\frac{x}{z} = \frac{6}{9}$$ which is not an integer, and $$\frac{xy}{z} = \frac{18}{9} = 2$$, which is an integer, but $$\frac{y}{z} = \frac{3}{9}$$ is not an integer.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:19</p>
<article class="question">
<p>True, but if we knew that $$y \geq z$$, then it would be true, right? If it is true, then can we simply conclude that in our proofs?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>$$x = 6, y = 12, z = 9$$ would be a counterexample.</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 843</p>
<p>Folder: hw5h</p>
<p>Title: Question 4 Clarification</p>
<article class="question">
I don&#39;t really understand what question 4 is asking. Can it be restated in other words?
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Consider an infinite Cartesian plane. At each point $$(a, b)$$ where $$a, b \in \mathbb{Z}$$, Sneha places one of the three snacks. You need to prove that no matter how she places the snacks, there will always be four points that form a rectangle such that the same snack is placed at each of those points.</p>
<p></p>
<p>If this is still confusing, it would be a good idea to go to office hours so we can help clear up your confusions.</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 857</p>
<p>Folder: hw5h</p>
<p>Title: For strong induction is it OK not to use n=k in induction step?</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For example if my IH is the claim works for n = 0&lt;=h&lt;=k, is it ok if in my Induction Step I only use the claim working for some values of h and never use it for n=k?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yes that is okay</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:28</p>
<article class="question">
<md>Can I have IH that assume the proposition is true for $$1\leq i\leq k$$ but only use $$n=k$$ in the IS?</md>
</article>
<article class="answer">
You could, but at that point you should just do weak induction because it is bad technique to have a strong IH and do ordinary induction in the IS.
</article>
<article class="answer">
<md>But, could we still call it a proof using strong induction?</md>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yes, but for grading purposes, it would likely not receive full credit.</p>
</article>
</article>



<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 860</p>
<p>Folder: hw5h</p>
<p>Title: Q5</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Can i do the usual induction hypothesis but not use it.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>No. You should always be using the induction hypothesis in the induction step</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:27</p>
<article class="question">
<p>But what if I dont need do?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>then you might be better off doing a direct proof. A proof by induction requires the use of the induction hypothesis in the induction step.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Ya i know that but the question says, &#34;Help Brian prove this statement to be true for all n by using induction!&#34;. Is there a way to convert a direct proof into an induction proof.</p>
<p>PS - I already have a direct proof. Thus the question arises</p>
<p></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>sure, it probably is possible to do that conversion, but the way I would go about doing that is to just start an induction proof from scratch and during my induction step, try to use insights gained from my direct proof.</p>
<p></p>
<p>A question like this may be well suited for office hours, where a TA can see what you have thought of already.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Thanks, also in office hours how do i join i am not too sure</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>go to ohq.io, join the class if you haven&#39;t already, and then you&#39;ll be able to input your question.</p>
</article>
</article>

<p>Title: Valid Proof Format for Q2</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Would providing a valid construction be enough to prove this question? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>no, because you need to prove it for all possible sets of lines</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:53</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Sorry, I misphrased the question. Would the inductive step being drawing any arbitrary line and showing it leads to a valid construction be valid? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>hmmm maybe. If you are to do this, you need to ensure that you are still &#34;constructing&#34; all sets of $$k+1$$ or however many number of lines. </p>
<p></p>
<p>In general, for induction, it is best to start with the $$k+1$$ case instead of constructing it from something else.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>If I did this, would I be able to &#34;remove&#34; the k&#43;1&#39;th line, consider the figure, and then add it again? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>sure</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Thank you!</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 890</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: BFS/DFS and whether a graph is Connected</p>
<article class="question">
<p>This may be beyond the scope of this class but I was curious if BFS/DFS was the only way to check if a graph is connected or if there are other algos to check and see if a graph is connected.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>this is beyond the scope of this class. There are other ways of checking connectivity, but may be worse in terms of time efficiency. Stay tuned for CIS1210 where you&#39;ll cover graph connectivity in more depth.</p>
<p></p>
<p>That being said, you should not be using BFS/DFS in this course, as it would require a proof before using it.</p>

<article class="general-box">

<p>Title: Justification on Exam</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Hi! On the exams, how much justification is required for combinatorics questions or other questions that result in a numerical answer? Do we need to write out the procedure that we used to obtain the product? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Unless specified otherwise, you should provide justification. If we are looking only for a numeric value, we will specifically say something along the lines of &#34;only your final answer will be graded&#34; or &#34;you do not need to show work for this problem&#34;</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 917</p>
<p>Folder: midterm1</p>
<p>Title: Question from Lecture Notes</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For this question, why does it not work for even numbers? I keep getting the same answer as the number of odds. Thank you!</p>
<p></p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedd9r8n6wb3dq%2F10ecd317e241008ca50c038104fb57f22ab85e5dfbf777cb12a81285dff43eeb%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-06_at_4.31.02_PM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2022-10-06_at_4.31.02_PM.png" /></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Basically the issue arises from Steps 1 and 2.</p>
<p></p>
<p>In step 1, we can say that there are five options for the fourth digit (namely 0, 2, 4, 6, 8). But after that, we can&#39;t quite say that for step 2, in choosing the first digit, there are only 8 options. This is because, if the digit we chose in step 1 is 0, then we actually have 9 options for the first digit.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Since the amount of ways to perform a step is not constant based on previous steps, we would be unable to perform the multiplication rule following the same procedure outlined in Attempt 3.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:03:06</p>
<article class="question">
<p>To find the total number of even numbers with distinct digits, does it make sense to find the total number of distinct digits (odd or even) and then divide by 2?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Not quite, because that would be implying that the total number of even numbers with distinct digits is the same as the total number of odd numbers with distinct digits, and using the logic I provided above, it doesn&#39;t seem like these two values should be equal. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Instead, you could modify that approach by counting complementarily!</p>
</article>
<article class="question">
<p>For finding the total number of even numbers w/distinct digits, would it be accurate to consider two cases where 0 is the last number and 0 is not the last number? And then just use the Sum Rule and add them together?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
Yeah that works
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 921</p>
<p>Folder: midterm1</p>
<p>Title: Formal Definition of Rational Number</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Is it: Can be represented as a/b, where a is an int, and b is a non-zero int. Do they need to have no common factors? I know we used this definition sometimes with the fact that they have common factors, and sometimes without that fact.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Yeah, the definition is that if $$x \in \mathbb{Q}$$, then $$\exists a \in \mathbb{Z}$$ and $$\exists b \in \mathbb{Z} \setminus \{0\}$$ such that $$x = \frac{a}{b}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The definition does not require $$a$$ and $$b$$ to share no common factors, though we often include this constraint in our proofs for simplicity of the proof. </p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:05</p>
<article class="question">
<p>So for the proof of if sqrt(2) is irrational, we placed that constraint that a and b have not common factors to reach the contradiction faster / with less explaining?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Not necessarily for &#34;less explaining&#34;, but more so because that was actually the thing we contradicted. So you might be asking yourself, &#34;when should I add this &#39;constraint&#39;&#34;, and my answer to that would probably be most of the time.</p>
<p></p>
<p>This is because even though the definition with and without the constraint define the same term, without the constraint of $$a$$ and $$b$$ sharing no common factors, there are an infinite amount of choices for $$a$$ and $$b$$. Whereas, if we introduce the idea of $$a$$ and $$b$$ sharing no common factors, then there is only one such pair. </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Thank you!!</p>
</article>
</article>


<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 923</p>
<p>Folder: midterm1</p>
<p>Title: Lecture 3H question</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In lecture notes 3H, there is an example that asks, &#34;consider n distinct objects and k bins labeled B1, B2, . . . , Bk. How many ways are there to distribute the objects in the bins so that bin Bi receives ni objects the sum of all of the objects in the k bins is n?&#34;</p>
<p></p>
<p>Since both the bins and the objects are distinct, why would the answer not be k^n?</p>
<p></p>
<p>I got this answer bc S1 would be choose one of the k bins for object 1, S2 would be choose one of the k bins for object 2, and so on for all n objects. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Thanks!</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>This procedure does not guarantee bin $$B_i$$ gets exactly $$n_i$$ objects. For example, it is possible that you choose the same bin on every step here.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:40</p>
<article class="question">
<p>What does n_i objects mean? Does n_2 mean 2 objects?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
$$n_i$$ is the number of objects bin $$B_i$$ should get
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 928</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: Question 3 on Practice Problems</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I partitioned the number of sequences into:</p>
<p></p>
<p>S_1 (no 2&#39;s) = 5! ways, since all are unique</p>
<p></p>
<p>S_2 (one 2) = choose place for a 2 (5 choose 1), then choose remaining unique items (5!/(5-4)!) </p>
<p></p>
<p>S_3 (two 2&#39;s) = choose positions for two 2&#39;s (5 choose 2), then choose remaining unique items (5!/(5-3)!)</p>
<p></p>
<p>But this could get tedious if we are working with a large number of items that have repetitions. </p>
<p></p>
<p>I guess my question is, can I somehow work the standard way of permuting multisets into this like in the lecture 3H on multisets? The problem is that not every element needs to have a position on the string... the total number of positions on the string doesn&#39;t add up to the total multiplicity of all the elements.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Also, will we get solutions to these at some point?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Thanks</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yeah I think it&#39;s kind of hard to incorporate permuting multisets in this, because when we do those permutations, we have very few constraints. In this problem, we introduce a lot of constraints, and while it may be possible to incorporate these constraints by modifying how we permute the multisets, it gets (arguably) equally tedious.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Casing, though sometimes tedious, is usually quite effective, so you shouldn&#39;t rule it out immediately!</p>
<p></p>
<p>Also yeah, we&#39;ll be posting solutions sometime this weekend hopefully.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 2:28:26</p>
</article>

<article class="question">
<p>i also don&#39;t really understand the reasoning for there being only 1 way to order the numbers in step 2.... does non-decreasing imply strictly increasing?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
If you take any sequence of numbers, there will only be way to order them such that the permutation is non-decreasing (this is not the same as strictly increasing).  To get the intuition, try ordering some numbers with repeats and see how many ways there are to make the order non-decreasing.
</article>




<article class="question">
<p>If we get a question like the tile question on the exam from 4H, should we say that the claim cannot be proven as is, or should we come up with a stronger claim and prove that?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
If we ask you to prove something and you wish to prove it through a stronger claim, you would state what you are proving and why that implies what was originally asked.
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 934</p>
<p>Folder: midterm1</p>
<p>Title: Binomial Theorem</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In the Binomial Theorem, the notes say that a and b must be real numbers. With the 2^n example, I used (2 &#43; 0)^n and expanded using the binomial theorem. However, I didn&#39;t get the same answer as the lecture notes. Is that a fault in my calculation or should this work? </p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>you can still use $$(2 + 0)^n$$, but you will arrive at something different than $$\sum_{k=0}^n \binom{n}{k}$$, because when we did $$(1 + 1)^n$$, we were able to simplify nicely using the fact that $$1^m = 1$$ for any $$m$$, but we do not have that leverage when we do $$(2+0)^n$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>tldr: yeah it works, but it just gives you different information</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:04:51</p>
<article class="question">
<p>But if we do (2 &#43; 0)^n, we basically prove that 2^n = 0, which proves the claim false?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>not quite. You get the following:</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$(2+0)^n = \sum_{k=0}^n \binom{n}{k} 2^{n-k}0^k = \binom{n}{0} 2^{n-0}0^0 + \sum_{k=1}^n \binom{n}{k} 2^{n-k}0^k = 1 \cdot 2^n \cdot 1 + 0 = 2^n$$</p>
<p></p>
<p>so you really just prove that $$2^n = 2^n$$ which, admittedly, isn&#39;t very exciting :(</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 935</p>
<p>Folder: midterm1</p>
<p>Title: Lec 4H</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In the question in Lecture 4H, where we are proving that there exists a subsequence of consecutive integers whose sum is a multiple of n.</p>
<p></p>
<p>How did we conclude that we have n sums to apply PHP? Would the total number of possible sequences be n(n &#43; 1)/2? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>The total number of possible subsequences is indeed $$\frac{n(n+1)}{2}$$, but we only chose to look at a subset of them so that we could proceed with the later steps of the problem (i.e. generating a new subsequence from two of our $$n$$ subsequences).</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 1:11:08</p>
</article>



<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 938</p>
<p>Folder: midterm1</p>
<p>Title: midterm 1a</p>
<article class="question">
<p>for the practice midterm 1a, how can we get the 11 choose 3 term when it matters that katie and stephanie need to be in front of nishita</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>the first step is just arbitrary selecting the three positions where these three lovely humans will be placed. The second step handles ordering them by abiding to the constraints. </p>
<p></p>
<p>So the first step of just choosing <em>where</em> they could appear (ignoring who goes in which spot) can be done in $$\binom{11}{3}$$ ways.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:03:22</p>
<article class="question">
<p>oh ok so how does the times 2 account for the ordering rather would be a better question</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Either the relative ordering goes Katie, Stephanie, Nishita, or it is Stephanie, Katie, Nishita.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>but in the first step the 11 choose 3 is choosing where just appear no matter which spot but we cant have nishita be placed in front of either one of them so why must it not be like subtracting some choices</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>11 choose 3 is just choosing the spots that we are going to place the people. We haven&#39;t yet arranged them in any order in the first step.</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 945</p>
<p>Folder: midterm1</p>
<p>Title: Lecture 3T</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I am looking at the following question in Lecture 3T:</p>
<p></p>
<p>Example. Show that there exist irrational numbers x and y such that x^y is rational.</p>
<p></p>
<p>What is the purpose of Case II in this question? I am also confused how this question can be proven simply by giving an example.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Since the question is asking us to show existence, providing a true example would qualify as showing existence.</p>
<p></p>
<p>We break it up into two cases because we don&#39;t really know whether $$\sqrt{2}^{\sqrt{2}}$$ is rational or irrational. If it&#39;s rational, then great. But if not, then we can use this value to provide a different $$x$$ and $$y$$ where $$x^y$$ is rational.</p>
<p></p>
<p>In essence, we are &#39;pretending&#39; that we don&#39;t know whether or not $$\sqrt{2}^{\sqrt{2}}$$ is rational, but regardless of its status, we can use it as is, or use it to create new values.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:08:49</p>
</article>


<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 947</p>
<p>Folder: midterm1</p>
<p>Title: Writing &#34;in other words&#34; for the induction hypothesis</p>
<article class="question">
<p>When writing the induction hypothesis, do we need to restate the claim the way it is done in class? For example, do we need to say &#34;Assume that this claim is true for n = k, for some arbitrary but particular integer k. In other words, assume that.......&#34; or is &#34;Assume that this claim is true for n = k, for some arbitrary but particular integer k&#34; sufficient?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>It is not a necessity, but it is something I highly encourage to do. This is because without restating the claim, there is a higher chance of ambiguity. But if you restate the claim in your IH, it is clear to the proof reader exactly what you are assuming.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:27</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 949</p>
<p>Folder: midterm1</p>
<p>Title: Strong Induction Proof from Class</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Can this be proved using weak induction by saying in case 2 that according to the fundamental thm of arithmetic, a composite number is a product of primes?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Or is this the proof for the fundamental thm of arithmetic? <img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedd9r8n6wb3dq%2Fbefb2a9dce9d89052c0c9a80756efe0765623ddbe35cf95ccacca2027f2b67de%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_5.04.43_PM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_5.04.43_PM.pngNaN" /></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>This is not quite a proof for the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic because that theorem also mentions that the prime factorization is unique. That being said, strong induction is not needed for this proof. In fact, one can avoid induction completely by mentioning how the claim is just a corollary of the FTA, but for the purpose of example, we did a proof by strong induction.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Also using FTA in the IS doesn&#39;t really make it a weak induction proof because it&#39;s not really getting reduced to the $$k$$ case (where you would use your weak IH).</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:16:34</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 950</p>
<p>Folder: midterm1</p>
<p>Title: P()</p>
<article class="question">
<p>is P(6,5) the same as 6^5</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>No. $$P(6, 5) = \frac{6!}{(6-5)!} = 6! \neq 6^5$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:55</p>
</article>


<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 952</p>
<p>Folder: midterm1</p>
<p>Title: Lecture 3H</p>
<article class="question">
<p>1. In L3H, for the question that asks for a proof that the sum of the integers 1 to n = n (n&#43;1) /2, I do not understand the paritition when finding the LHS. What is the signfigance of &#34;i is the bigger element in the pair&#34;?</p>
<p>2. Also, just to confirm, can we use anything proved in lecture on the exam without a proof (ie. sum of odds/evens, Pascal&#39;s Formula, cardinality of power set)? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>1. Given two distinct elements, $$a$$ and $$b$$, one must be larger than the other. So we are partitioning the set of all pairs into groupings based on what the largest value in the pair is.</p>
<p></p>
<p>So if, for example, $$S = \{0, 1, 2, 3\}$$, then we would have $$S_1 = \{(0, 1)\}$$, $$S_2 = \{(0, 2), (1, 2)\}$$, and $$S_3 = \{(0, 3), (1, 3), (2, 3)\}$$. We partition like this because it is easy to calculate the cardinality of each $$S_i$$. Namely, $$|S_i| = i$$, but each $$S_i$$ is formed by the largest value in the pair.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>2. yes</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:06:07</p>
</article>


<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 954</p>
<p>Folder: midterm1</p>
<p>Title: If a square number is even</p>
<article class="question">
<p>We have proven in class that if a square number is even, then the number itself is even. So are we allowed to directly say: $$p^2=6q^2\implies 2|p^2\implies p=2k,k\in\mathbb{Z}$$? If not, what justification do we have to give?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I would give a one sentence explanation in between each of the implications. So I would say $$p^2 = 6q^2 \implies 2\mid p^2$$ because since $$6q^2 = 2(3q^2)$$ is even, $$p^2$$ must also be even.</p>
<p></p>
<p>And an explanation for $$2\mid p^2 \implies p = 2k$$ would be: &#34;we proved this in class&#34;</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:14:57</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 958</p>
<p>Folder: midterm1</p>
<p>Title: something</p>
<article class="question">
<p>what does it mean when an integer is relatively prime</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>$$x$$ and $$y$$ are relatively prime when $$x$$ and $$y$$ share no common factor other than $$1$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:37</p>
<article class="question">
<p>oh ok so in the problem where it is like</p>
<p>Assume for contradiction that √6 is rational. This implies that, for some relatively prime integers, m and n, where n 6= 0, we have to assume they are relatively prime why</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>we say that because the definition for a rational number is that if $$z \in \mathbb{Q}$$ then there exist relatively prime integers $$a, b$$ such that $$z = \frac{a}{b}$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>We include the detail on &#34;relatively prime&#34; because that is what we end up contradicting.</p>
</article>
</article>



<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 961</p>
<p>Folder: midterm1</p>
<p>Title: another thing</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Case 1 : m is even and n is even. This is impossible, since m and n are relatively prime.</p>
<p>for this line in the practice problems we can ignore 2 because it says for all integers right</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>wait what do you mean by &#34;ignore 2&#34;</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:19</p>
<article class="question">
<p>well i mean like 2 is prime and even but that&#39;s only like one case so we dont care about that one right</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>oh i guess because if m and n are 2 it doesnt really work anyways</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>evenness and relatively prime are two different things. Evenness describes a single value, whereas &#34;relatively prime&#34; describes two numbers. You can have an even integer be a part of a relatively prime pair. For example $$4$$ is relatively prime to $$5$$. Also, $$6$$ is relatively prime to $$25$$, for example. </p>
<p></p>
<p>The proof is enumerating all possibilities of the parities of m and n, but we skip over this particular case because of the assumption that $$m$$ and $$n$$ are relatively prime. It is impossible for $$m$$ and $$n$$ to both be even and both be relatively prime, because if both are even, then $$2 \mid m$$ and $$2 \mid n$$, but this would go against the definition of &#34;relatively prime&#34;.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>wait what </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>ok so 4 is relatively prime to 5 because it doesn&#39;t divide into 5 </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>ohhhhh like you are saying 2 and 2 are not relatively prime because 2 divides evenly by 2</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>but like 5 does not divide evenly by 4?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Remember the definition of &#34;relatively prime&#34;: $$x$$ and $$y$$ are relatively prime if and only if they share no common factors other than $$1$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>So $$4$$ and $$5$$ are relatively prime, because the factors of $$4$$ are $$1, 2$$ and $$4$$, and the prime factors of $$5$$ are only $$1$$ and $$5$$. Since the only common factor of $$4$$ and $$5$$ is one, we conclude that they are relatively prime.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>ohhhhhh lol</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>you can tell me im stupid</p>
</article>
</article>



<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 964</p>
<p>Folder: hw6t</p>
<p>Title: Strong Induction HW 6t</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Why do we need the n=4 base case in this problem?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Without it, k&#43;1 is greater than or equal to 4, since the induction hypothesis holds for k greater than or equal to 3. k&#43;1 can be expressed as 2 &#43; k-1, and k-1 is less than or equal to k and greater than or equal to two, which is a base case.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>@940</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:33</p>
</article>

<article class="question">
<p>I&#39;m also having issues with this problem. The solution states that there are 49 bars and 3,000,000 stars so there are 3,000,049 choose 49 arrangements. Am I mistaken or shouldn&#39;t it be 3,000,049 choose 3,000,000 arrangements?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 978</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: is 0 divisible by any number?</p>
<article class="question">
<p>might be dumb question but is 0 considered to be divisbly by every number or no number?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>we say that $$x$$ is divisible by $$y$$ if we can write $$x = yk$$ for some $$k \in \mathbb{Z}$$. So for $$x = 0$$, and any integer $$y$$, does there exist a value of $$k$$ such that $$yk = x = 0$$? (Hint: yes)</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:03:19</p>
</article>


<article class="question">
<p>As a followup:</p>

<p>I want to further clarify my understanding of multisets, specifically the part about the initial multiset n having infinite copies. </p>
<p></p>
<p>For Lecture 3H, Ex 6:</p>
<p></p>
<p>The multiset with infinite copies is: {infinity * 1, infinity *2 ... infinity*25} ?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Then we select any 10 crosses from this mutliset. We want to know how these crosses can be re-divided into 25 categories. So we have 10 crosses and 25-1=24 bars. Once they are divided into categories, there is only one way to order them. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Is this correct?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yeah</p>
</article>
<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 980</p>
<p>Folder: midterm1</p>
<p>Title: Lecture 3H Example 2</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I am unsure if my thinking is correct for this question.</p>
<p></p>
<p>1. Here is my understanding: there are n distinct objects. Once within a bin, these objects are indistinguisble. We get the multiset: {n_1*B_1, n_2*B_2 ...n_k*B_k}. The bins are like categories containing a bunch of indistinguisble n_i objects. We are trying to find how many ways we can order all n objects. This is simply the permutation of the multiset, so we can use the formula we derived in L3H. </p>
<p></p>
<p>2. For the formula being used in this problem--is this formula just the number of ways you can order elements of a multiset? Like if we had {a*2, b*3,c*4}, is this formula calculating the number of ways you can order a, b, and c (9!) and then dividing out the number of ways you can order the elements of type a, b, and c since they are indistinguisble (2!3!4!)? </p>
<p></p>
<p>3. What differentiates this from a sticks and crosses problem?</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>1. you should not think of the objects as &#34;indistinguishable&#34; when they are in the same bin.</p>
<p></p>
<p>2. yes</p>
<p></p>
<p>3. @1007</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 21:21:53</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1002</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: Practice Problems q2</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For case 2 (there is 1 2 in the sequence), I reasoned that we had to distribute 7 letters (P, E, R, M, 1, 2, and 3) among five spots, so the answer should be P(7,5). Why wouldn&#39;t this be the answer?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Because P(7, 5) does not guarantee that one of the five characters chosen is a 2.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:09:39</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1003</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: q4 practice problems.</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For part a, I first calculated the permutations: 13 ways to choose the value for a four of a kind, 4*3*2*1*48 (for the last card). Then, I divided away the repeats by dividing the expression 13*4*3*2*48 by 5!, but I&#39;m getting a different answer. Why is this?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Can you explain why you are multiplying $$4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1$$? If it&#39;s because there are &#34;four options&#34; for the first slot, and &#34;three options&#34; for the second slot, and so on, then you should be dividing by $$4!$$ because you&#39;ve already fixed the last card to be the non-four-of-a-kind.</p>
<p></p>
<p>If you are doing that multiplication because of the suits, then it is important to realize that the order of the cards within a hand doesn&#39;t matter.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:47</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I am multiplying 4*3*2*1 because once we have determined the value of the four-of-a-kind, there are 4 ways to choose the first card, 3 to choose the second (only three more of the target card exists within the deck), etc.</p>
<p></p>
<p>I thought we could get the combinations by dividing the permutations by the number of ways to order the elements chosen to get the combinations?</p>
<p></p>
<p>In this case, I found the permutations of the 5 desired elements, then divided by 5! to get rid of the effect of permutations</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Yeah dividing is totally okay, but only if you have actually considered all permutations of the five cards. In this case, you&#39;ve fixed the last card to be the non-four-of-a-kind, so you aren&#39;t able to divide by 5! since not all permutations have been considered.</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1004</p>
<p>Folder: midterm1</p>
<p>Title: Set equality proof</p>
<article class="question">
<p>How do we prove for arbitrary sets <strong>A and B that A=B iff A is a subset of B or B is a subset of A</strong>?</p>
<p></p>
<p>For the -&gt; direction proof, do we use a definition for A=B such as this?...</p>
<p></p>
<p>x is an element of A and x is an element of B And there is no y such that y is an element of A and y is not an element of B or vice versa.</p>
<p></p>
<p>in other words, can we just assume A=B is equivalent to (A\B = {} and B\A = {})</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yeah you can assume that. There isn&#39;t really too much to prove here because it is just a definition, but if you were to explain why the definition makes sense logically, the way you are approaching it is fine.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:40</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1014</p>
<p>Folder: midterm1</p>
<p>Title: Practice Problem 3</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For practice problem 3 why does (8 choose 5) * 5! not work? I understand it is the wrong answer but I mean more conceptually why it does not work. </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>because 5! would only work if all the characters were distinct, but that&#39;s not guaranteed to happen when you choose 5 from the 8 (because you could get repeat 2s)</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:44:49</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1020</p>
<p>Folder: hw4h</p>
<p>Title: What is $$\bigcup$$ mean in the 4H Answer key in Q6</p>
<article class="question">

</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>It&#39;s like a massive union of a bunch of sets.</p>
<p></p>
<p>So like $$\bigcup_{i=1}^k A_i = A_1 \cup A_2 \cup ... \cup A_k$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:08:26</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Ahhh makes sense thanks</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1025</p>
<p>Folder: hw7h</p>
<p>Title: Q2</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Since we&#39;re given that the probability of picking both red from n &lt; 9 is 1/2, I brute forced that there are 4 total ducks, 3 of which are red (3/4*2/3 = 1/2). Is there a more formal way to prove this other than trial and error? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
If you think your work is fully justified and exhaustive, then that’s fine
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:41</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In terms of trial and error, would an exhaustive solution be something like showing each combination of red/brown for n &lt; 9 and showing that there&#39;s only one where P(both red) is 1/2? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
We cannot comment on the correctness of a solution - just make sure your solution covers every case that is possible in the problem.
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1030</p>
<p>Folder: hw7h</p>
<p>Title: Q5 connection</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Since the question says the n birdhouses are connected by m bidirectional paths, can we assume that the graph is connected, or do we need to justify that?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>The question mentions nothing about a graph. However, it is not necessarily true that in the arrangement of birdhouses and paths, one can always travel from birdhouse $$a$$ to birdhouse $$b$$ via a series of paths.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:29</p>

</article>
<article class="answer">
Not necessarily.
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1059</p>
<p>Folder: hw7h</p>
<p>Title: General Question</p>
<article class="question">
<p>If you have something like P(A) U P(B) U P(C) U P(D) U P(E) U P(F) instead of writing out set operations on 6 terms can you break it down into P(A U B U C) U P(D U E U F) so u do two set operations on 3 terms and then one on 2 terms or is that not the same thing?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>What do you mean by P(A)? If you mean powerset, then no, because it is not true that $$P(A) \cup P(B) = P(A \cup B)$$ because $$\{a, b\} \in P(A \cup B)$$ but $$\{a, b\} \notin P(A) \cup P(B)$$</p>
<p></p>
<p>If $$P(A)$$ means something else, then it depends on what that &#34;something else&#34; is, which means you may not be able to safely break it down in the way you suggested.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:08:42</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Sorry it just meant Probability of even A, I forgot to do Pr(A), apologies</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>*event</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>But the probability of an event is a number, so I&#39;m not quite sure how you would do a set operation on a number.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Like in regards to this: &#34;P(A ∪ B ∪ C) = P(A) &#43; P(B) &#43; P(C) - P(A ∩ B) - P(A ∩ C) - P(B ∩ C) &#43; P(A ∩ B ∩ C)&#34;</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I see. Then such a &#34;simplification&#34; can only occur depending on the independence of the events.</p>
<p></p>
<p>What I mean by this is that $$Pr(A \cup B \cup C) = Pr(A) + Pr(B) + Pr(C)$$ only if $$A, B, C$$ are mutually independent.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>You couldn&#39;t make it like P(A ∪ B ∪ C) = P(A) &#43; P(B) &#43; P(C) - P(A ∩ B) - P(A ∩ C) - P(B ∩ C) &#43; P(A ∩ B ∩ C) </p>
<p>P(D ∪ E ∪ F) = P(D) &#43; P(E) &#43; P(F) - P(D ∩ E) - P(E ∩ F) - P(D ∩ F) &#43; P(D ∩ E ∩ F) then just do P(A U B U C) U P(D U E U F) = (P(A) &#43; P(B) &#43; P(C) - P(A ∩ B) - P(A ∩ C) - P(B ∩ C) &#43; P(A ∩ B ∩ C) ) &#43; (P(D) &#43; P(E) &#43; P(F) - P(D ∩ E) - P(E ∩ F) - P(D ∩ F) &#43; P(D ∩ E ∩ F))?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>$$Pr(A \cup B \cup C) + Pr(D \cup E \cup F)$$ <strong>is</strong> equal to what you have just provided.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>So would this work for something like question 6 where you have 6 different ways of choosing the bread ?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1065</p>
<p>Folder: hw7h</p>
<p>Title: Declaring Sample Spaces</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Am I misremembering or were we told in lecture that for any probability problem we must define the sample space explicitly. Will points be taken off if it’s not there?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Also, when we’re defining large sample spaces are we allowed to use … (dot dot dot) notation cause I think it might have been said that it’s too imprecise?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Also when we are doing it must it only be numeric and symbolic or can we also describe the sample space using words?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Thanks</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>You should always define your sample space explicitly. Otherwise, you do risk losing points.</p>
<p></p>
<p>You can use ... notation so long as clarity is maintained and no ambiguity is introduced.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Sample spaces can be defined using words only. Numbers and symbols are also always welcomed.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:42</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1108</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: Lecture Sept 29 question</p>
<article class="question">
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt0cz590wc77nm%2F443f05c6f3d035bd2a23f2d79972d8f88255a461900f70d788e874a0f22b6ebd%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" width="631" height="151" /></p>
<p></p>
<p>For this example, I&#39;m a bit confused about how we came up with the probabilities for the cases where w1 = w2 and w1 does not equal w2. Could you please explain? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>For the outcomes where $$w_1 = w_2 = i, i \in \{1, 2, 3\}$$, three things need to occur:</p>
<ol><li>The prize is assigned to door $$i$$</li><li>The contestant chooses door $$i$$</li><li>The host opens door $$j$$ where $$j \neq i$$</li></ol>
<p></p>
<p>Let&#39;s analyze the probability of each of these:</p>
<ol><li>Since the prize is equally likely to be assigned to any of the doors, and there are $$3$$ doors, there is a $$1/3$$ chance of the prize being assigned to door $$i$$</li><li>Since the contestant is equally likely to choose any of the doors, and there are $$3$$ doors, there is a $$1/3$$ chance of the contestant choosing door $$i$$</li><li>The $$2$$ remaining doors both do not contain the prize, so the host can choose either of them. Since there are $$2$$ remaining doors and both have an equal chance of being chosen, there is a $$1/2$$ chance of the host choosing door $$j$$</li></ol>
<p>How many outcomes are of this form? We can use multiplication rule:</p>
<ol><li>Choose what value $$i$$ is - $$3$$ ways</li><li>Choose what value $$j$$ is - $$2$$ ways</li></ol>
<p>So there are $$6$$ total outcomes of this form.</p>
<p></p>
<p>----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------</p>
<p></p>
<p>For the outcomes where $$w_1 = i$$ and $$w_2 = j$$ where $$i, j \in \{1, 2, 3\}$$ and $$i \neq j$$, three things need to occur:</p>
<ol><li>The prize is assigned to door $$i$$</li><li>The contestant chooses door $$j$$</li><li>The host opens door $$k$$ where $$k \neq i, j$$</li></ol>
<p>Let&#39;s analyze the probability of each of these:</p>
<ol><li>Since the prize is equally likely to be assigned to any of the doors, and there are $$3$$ doors, there is a $$1/3$$ chance of the prize being assigned to door $$i$$</li><li>Since the contestant is equally likely to choose any of the doors, and there are $$3$$ doors, there is a $$1/3$$ chance of the contestant choosing door $$j$$</li><li>There is only one remaining door the host can open that is not $$i$$ or $$j$$, so there is a $$1$$ chance of the hosting choosing this remaining door.</li></ol>
<p>How many outcomes are of this form? We can use multiplication rule:</p>
<ol><li>Choose what value $$i$$ is - $$3$$ ways</li><li>Choose what value $$j$$ is - $$2$$ ways</li><li>Choose what value $$k$$ is -  $$1$$ way</li></ol>
<p>So there are $$6$$ total outcomes of this form.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 1 day, 10:20:11</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1111</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: General question about connected components</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In the lecture notes, it says that a connected component must maximal, or not contained within any other subgraph. What does contained mean here - does this just mean that the connected component can&#39;t be a subgraph of any other subgraph in the graph?</p>
<p>If so, aren&#39;t all graphs a subgraph of themself (i.e. are all graphs contained by themselves)? Thanks!</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I think the lecture notes mention that if $$H$$ is a connected component in $$G$$, then $$H$$ is not contained in any other <strong>connected </strong>subgraph of $$G$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:53</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Ok thanks. But does the word &#34;contain&#34; just mean subgraph of here?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yeah</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1112</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: Lecture 6t Question</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For the last question about deleting a leaf, how do we know that the leaf we&#39;re deleting is not a part of any other walks besides the one its deleted from, so that the graph remains connected?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>A leaf $$v$$, which has degree 1, can only be a part of path $$P$$ if one of $$P$$&#39;s endpoints is $$v$$. If otherwise, then suppose we have a path $$P'$$ where $$v$$ is within the path, but not one of the endpoints, then $$P' = ... - u - v - w - ....$$ which would mean that $$v$$ would have two neighbors, and hence degree 2 (contradiction).</p>
<p></p>
<p>So when we remove $$v$$, the only paths we lose are those that have endpoint $$v$$. But since $$T' = T \setminus \{v\}$$ has all vertices of $$T$$ except $$v$$, all paths between non-$$v$$ vertices in $$T$$ remain in $$T'$$, so it&#39;s connected.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 6:52:04</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1123</p>
<p>Folder: hw8h</p>
<p>Title: n-m connected components</p>
<article class="question">
<p>We have proven that a graph will have at least n-m connected components. However, if n=m (like a triangle) then n-m=0, which means that a graph will have at least 0 connected components. What does this mean? What if m&gt;n, so n-m&lt;0? What does that mean then?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>That fact is basically saying if $$|V| = n$$ and $$|E| = m$$, then $$|CC| \geq n - m$$, where we use the notation $$|CC|$$ to denote the number of connected components.</p>
<p></p>
<p>In the case when $$n = m$$, then you can conclude that a graph has at least $$0$$ connected components, which is not too groundbreaking of a conclusion. In general, this fact does not give us much information when $$m \geq n$$, because you can always construct a connected graph with $$n$$ vertices and $$m$$ edges when $$m \geq n$$, and such a connected graph would only have $$1$$ connected component. This fact is more useful when $$m < n$$.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:08:10</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1127</p>
<p>Folder: hw8h</p>
<p>Title: Proof by construction</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In class we covered proof by construction, so can we use it for question 5? Would it prove both the forward and reverse implication? </p>
<p>Also, what is the exact procedure for proofs by construction?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>what was the proof by construction that you saw in class? In general, you need to be very careful when doing proofs by construction, especially with graph problems, as you need to ensure that you are constructing all possible graphs.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 1 day, 0:50:55</p>
<article class="question">
<p>The one in class was for a spanning tree</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yeah you would have to be careful in ensuring that you are constructing all graphs. That&#39;s why in general we try to avoid proofs by construction (when we have to &#34;build&#34; something larger&#34;) because of this uncertainty.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The proof by construction works decently well will spanning trees because we are &#34;building something smaller&#34; from something that already exists.</p>
<p></p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1154</p>
<p>Folder: hw8h</p>
<p>Title: Number 6 clarification on meaning of the summation</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For the summation, is it saying that we are only summing the degree of vertices whose degree is latest 3?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yes, you&#39;re summing on vertices whose degree is greater than or equal to 3</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:44</p>
<article class="question">
<p>If I have the following tree V = {A,B,C,D,E,F}, E = {(A,B), (B,C), (B,D), (A,E), (A,F)}, using the summation I get a result of 3 for the number of leaves, because A is the only vertex with a degree of at least 3 because 2 &#43; (3 - 2), however there are 4 leaves. I am not sure where I am going wrong in applying rule to this example</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>The degree of B is 3 in your example. So the number of leaves given by the equation would be 2 &#43; (3 - 2) &#43; (3 - 2) = 4</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">

<p>Title: Q1</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Is Q1 necessarily true? Suppose there are n=5 vertices like so:</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7gcywgetsa6wn%2Fcf684cb007a65dbd39ba82b63c976e7cc5ecbe636764af97a8b6ecba041b4cb4%2FScreenshot_2022-10-24_at_6.35.52_PM.png" alt="Screenshot_2022-10-24_at_6.35.52_PM.png" width="309" height="295" /></p>
<p>If Ryan goes in a cycle from A-&gt;B-&gt;C-&gt;D-&gt;E-&gt;A, he will visit an odd number of vertices in a loop. However, all these vertices have degree 4, so the claim would be false right? Or have I misunderstood the question?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yeah but something like A --&gt; B --&gt; C --&gt; E --&gt; A would have him visit an even number of vertices in a loop. You need <strong>all</strong> of these loops to visit an odd number of locations.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:08</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Where is that specified in the question? Don&#39;t we only have to see the odd loops?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>&#34;Suppose that <strong>no matter what route Ryan takes</strong> to watch a series of performances, he<br /><strong>always</strong> ends up watching an odd number of performances&#34;</p>
</article>
</article>


<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1174</p>
<p>Folder: hw8h</p>
<p>Title: phrasing of conditional probability</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Hello! I was wondering if we need to explicitly define events (like as variables) and then use the formula, or if just using words is okay. For example, I put this for a question:</p>
<p></p>
<p>&#34;We are trying to find Pr[both berries are Oran | at least one berry selected is Oran], which is the probability that both berries are Oran and at least one berry selected is Oran, divided by the probability that at least one berry selected is Oran.&#34;</p>
<p></p>
<p>Would this be acceptable? Thanks!</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yeah it&#39;s fine, but we really encourage to use mathematical notation for the sake of clarity and to avoid ambiguity.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:59</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Okay thanks! I typed mine this way already but will keep that in mind for future HW/tests.</p>

<article class="answer">
<p>this is something we&#39;d like you to think about</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:37</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Could I state that, since we can produce a minimally connected graph with n-1 edges, and we have a connected graph with n edges, there must be one edge that we are able to remove such that the graph is still connected, as removing this edge would result in a minimally connected graph? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>you would have to justify the existence of such an edge.</p>
</article>

<p>Could I use the fact that every connected graph contains a spanning tree (which by definition has n-1 edges), and thus this edge must exist? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>this is something you should think about</p>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1184</p>
<p>Folder: hw8h</p>
<p>Title: q5 exactly one cycle</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For q5, what does it mean for there to be <em>exactly</em> one such loop if and only if there are n routes? Like would the loops within V = {v_1, v_2 … v_n }, E = {(v_1, v_2), (v_2, v_3), (v_3, v_4)… (v_n, v_1)} and V = {v_1, v_2 … v_n } E’ = {(v_1, v_4), (v_4, v_2), (v_3, v_4)… (v_n, v_1)} be the same?</p>
<p></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>those would be different. but in that case, you have more than $$n$$ routes involved total</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:53:45</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I feel like i still don&#39;t fully understand. For both couldn&#39;t you pair each edge to exactly one vertex, like for this graph with 4 vertices |{(v_1, v_2), (v_2, v_3), (v_3, v_4), (v_4, v_1)}| = 4 = |{(v_1, v_3), (v_3, v_2), (v_2, v_4), (v_4, v_1)}</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>you have just enumerated <strong>two different </strong>graphs because the edge sets are different. Both of these graphs have $$n$$ vertices and $$n$$ routes, and they both have exactly one loop. But the main thing to note is that they are different graphs.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Oh that makes sense. Thanks!</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1190</p>
<p>Folder: hw9t</p>
<p>Title: Q1</p>
<article class="question">
<md>Does it mean that there are no cycles of even length in the graph $$G(V, E)$$ (with cities represented by vertices and there is an edge between $$u,v\in V$$ if and only if there is a two-way flight between the cities represented by $$u$$ and $$v$$)?</md>
</article>
<article class="answer">
Yeah
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:11:21</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Is it if and only if? Because there are graphs with vertices of degree less than two that do not contain odd length (or any) cycles. </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
Ah yeah good catch. In this question we’re just looking for a single implication (the forwards direction), not an “if and only if”
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1207</p>
<p>Folder: hw9t</p>
<p>Title: Problem 1</p>
<article class="question">
<p>What exactly does problem 5 mean by no two cities are connected by more than one flight?</p>
<p></p>
<p>If there is a flight between city A and B, and a flight between city B and C, would this be invalid because A and C are connected by more than two flights?</p>
<p></p>
<p>If there is also a flight between A and C, would this be valid because A and C are now connected by a single direct path, which takes precedence over the other route which is more than 1 flight?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>What we mean by this is that if there is city $$A$$ and city $$B$$ then there is at most one flight going directly between $$A$$ and $$B$$.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:25:23</p>
</article>




<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1211</p>
<p>Folder: midterm2</p>
<p>Title: Will the second midterm include topics introduced before midterm 1?</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Title</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>while the exam may not be entirely focused on content solely from before midterm 1, you should not forget about what you learned prior to the midterm. This is to say that it is not unlikely for you to see problems on the second midterm that require skills you obtained (such as proof techniques, counting techniques, PHP, PIE, etc, etc) from before the first midterm to solve them.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 1:49:28</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1212</p>
<p>Folder: hw9t</p>
<p>Title: definition of a leaf</p>
<article class="question">
<p>According to @1174 a vertex with degree 0 is not a leaf, but in one of the proofs in the 9t lecture notes it says a tree of height 0 &#34;has only one vertex [degree 0] which is a leaf.&#34;</p>
<p>Does the definition of a leaf change depending on rooted trees vs normal trees?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yeah I made a mistake in @1174. There exists some literature in which a leaf is defined as only having degree 1. But according to this class&#39;s lecture notes, &#34;A vertex of degree greater than 1 in a tree is called an internal vertex, <strong>otherwise it is called a leaf</strong>&#34;.</p>
<p></p>
<p>So we will let a leaf have degree 1 or 0.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:09</p>
</article>

<article class="answer">

</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:00:57</p>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1287</p>
<p>Folder: hw9h</p>
<p>Title: Question 6</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Question 6 asks us to prove that you can get from one store in A to another store in B if and only if you can get from any record store to any other record store. Isn&#39;t this just the definition of a connected graph? I&#39;m really confused about what this question is really asking, because it seems like by definition the claim is already satisfied.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>It&#39;s not just that &#34;you can get from one store in A to another store in B&#34;, but rather, &#34;you can get from one store in A to another store in B <strong>using a single road&#34;</strong>.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:36</p>
<article class="question">
<p>but doesn&#39;t that still follow from the definition of a connected graph? I&#39;m assuming a single road is equivalent to a single unique path</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>this depends on how you construct your graph.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>so could you clarify a bit on what &#34;a single road&#34; means? does it mean it could be either an edge OR a path?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Again, this depends on how you construct your graph. If edges represent roads, then &#34;a single road&#34; would mean a single edge. </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I&#39;m sorry but I&#39;m still a bit lost. If I chose to construct a road as a path instead of an edge, then wouldn&#39;t the proof automatically be satisfied? is there leeway in how paths/edges can be constructed? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I think it might be best for you to go to office hours to discuss this with a TA face-to-face.</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1301</p>
<p>Folder: hw9h</p>
<p>Title: Question 3</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Conceptually why are the following not equal? Because don&#39;t they both result in picking p&#43;1 objects from n objects?</p>
<p></p>
<p>expression 1: (n choose p) * (n-p choose 1)</p>
<p>expression 2: (n choose p&#43;1)</p>
<p></p>
<p>When I expanded both expressions out, they are not equal, but I&#39;m having a hard time understanding why this is the case.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>This overcounts. Consider the counting question: &#34;From $$n$$ distinct elements, choose $$p+1$$ of them&#34;. Expression 2 clearly answers this question. We would think that we could construct a counting procedure in that we &#34;select p elements&#34; in step one and then &#34;select 1&#34; in the second step. But this will overcount some cases.</p>
<p></p>
<p>For example, suppose $$n = 4$$ and $$p = 2$$. And suppose our elements are $$\{A, B, C, D\}$$. Then we have to select $$p + 1 = 3$$ elements. So suppose in step one, where we select $$p = 2$$ elements, we choose $$A$$ and $$B$$. And suppose in step two, where we &#34;select one&#34; of the remaining, we select $$C$$. Then, our collection is $$\{A, B, C\}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>But we could instead in step 1 select $$A$$ and $$C$$. And then in step $$2$$ we could select $$B$$, so our collection would be $$\{A, B, C\}$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>So we&#39;ve obtained the same collection in two different ways from the counting procedure which indicates that we overcounted.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:09:57</p>
</article>
