<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1328</p>
<p>Folder: hw9h</p>
<p>Title: Q6 question?</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Consider the graph with four vertices, 1, 2, 3 and 4. if A = {1, 2}, and B = {3, 4), but the only edge that exists ie between vertices 1 and 3, then wouldn&#39;t it be the case that there exists a in A and b in B s.t. there is a road between them, and the graph is not connected (cannot get from any record to another, as you cannot get from 2 to 4 by any path). Is there an error in the construction of my situation, or have I misunderstood the problem.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>But that is only for a specific partition. You must show the edge exists for all partitions. For example, with $$A = \{2\}$$ and $$B = \{1, 3, 4\}$$, then there does not exist an edge from an $$a \in A$$ to a $$b \in B$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:15:11</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1363</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: Eulerian Graph</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Is an eulerian graph just a graph containing a cycle that includes all the edges in the graph? Also, is a eulerian circuit a cycle?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>An Eulerian graph is a graph that contains an Eulerian circuit. An Eulerian circuit need not be a cycle.</p>
<p></p>
<p>for the last question, you should briefly justify this</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:57:14</p>

<p>see @1369</p>

<article class="question">
<p>I was told by the OH TA that to determine independence of two random variables, a good approach is to find a counterexample. I know that P(X=x and Y=y) = P(X=x)P(Y=y) if independent, and I know how to find P(X=x), but I&#39;m really stuck on finding P(X=x and Y=y). If the two dresses are from the same store, in my mind that would be like tossing two separate coins (which should be independent). Do you have any tips to get me started on finding the intersection here? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
uh I guess so, try approaching it similarly to how you approached the other probabilities
</article>
<p>Response Time: 19:03:23</p>
<article class="question">

The only thing I can think of doing for finding P(X=x and Y=y) is to multiply P(X=x)P(Y=y), but that&#39;s what we&#39;re trying to determine. What&#39;s a better way of determining whether the independence condition holds? Since they&#39;re two different hoods, I don&#39;t see how they are correlated, so it intuitively makes sense to just do P(X=x)P(Y=y) but then we&#39;re just using the targeted result to prove the targeted result.</p>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1424</p>
<p>Folder: hw5h</p>
<p>Title: HW5H #3</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Is it possible to represent the bi-directional walkway question from 5H using what we now know about graphs? What&#39;s the thing being proven here? Thank you!</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>We can&#39;t quite model it as a graph problem (yet) because the walkways could be either only in one direction or bidirectional. If you were to make the walkways your edges, you would somehow have to take into account the direction of edges, which is not something we can do quite yet with what we know about graphs.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:03:39</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1425</p>
<p>Folder: hw10h</p>
<p>Title: Q2</p>
<article class="question">
<p>To show independence, do we have to prove both var[X &#43; Y] = var[X] &#43; var[Y] and E[X * Y] = E[X] * E[Y]?</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>If so why? Is there ever a case where one equation is true but the other is not?</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
You should not be showing independence using those formulas. We’ve only shown in class that independence implies those two formulas but we haven’t shown the converse to be true.
</article>
<p>Response Time: 3:17:45</p>
</article>

<article class="question">
<p>In other words, just explaning how we would go about the problem work?</p>
</article>

<p>Folder: hw10h</p>
<p>Title: Notation for cardinality of indicator r.v.s</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Is |Xi = 1| a valid notation to use when calculating the cardinality of a set of all cases when the indicator random variable  = 1? Or should we always define a set, E, and let that be all the ways we can get our event of interest. This is in reference to Q4. </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Yeah I guess it&#39;s fine, but this notation is not very common. It&#39;s more common to define an event and then find the cardinality in terms of the variable you define for the event.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 9:16:06</p>
</article>


<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1443</p>
<p>Folder: hw10h</p>
<p>Title: Problem 2</p>
<article class="question">
Is there a way to use expectation on problem 2 to figure out independence?
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>at this point in time, no. We have only proven &#34;If $$X$$ and $$Y$$ are independent then $$\mathbb{E}[XY] = \mathbb{E}[X] \cdot \mathbb{E}[Y]$$&#34;. But we have not shown the converse to be true.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:38:38</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1484</p>
<p>Folder: hw10t</p>
<p>Title: Lecture 10T Question</p>
<article class="question">
<p>for the graph coloring proof, is the claim that the graph is only (k&#43;1) colorable if the max degree is k?</p>
<p></p>
<p>for example if I drew an eulerian graph w/6 edges, the max degree is 2 but can be 2-colorable</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>The claim is saying that if the max degree in a graph is $$k$$, then the graph <strong>can be </strong>colored using $$k+1$$ colors. This is not to say that this is the minimum number of colors needed to color the graph. </p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:55</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Thank you! Also to follow up, is the converse of this proof true?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Not quite. For example, let $$k = 3$$ and consider a graph with two vertices with a single edge between them. Then indeed, the graph can be colored using $$3 + 1 = 4$$ colors, but the max degree in the graph is not $$3$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>You then might be tempted to say something along the lines of &#34;If a graph can be colored using $$k+1$$ colors, then the max degree in the graph is <strong>at most </strong>k&#34;. But even that statement is false.</p>
<p></p>
<p>For example, consider a star graph with one central vertex $u$, and a set of vertices $$B$$ such that $$|B| = 2k$$, and there are $$2k$$ edges in the graph of the form $$(b_i, u)$$. So basically, one edge for each vertex in $$B$$ which connects that vertex to $$u$$. This graph can be colored using $$2$$ colors (basically color $$u$$ blue and all vertices in $$B$$ red). So that would mean that $$k = 1$$. But indeed, the max degree in the graph is not $$k = 1$$, it is $$2k$$ and $$1 < 2k$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>tl;dr: no, it&#39;s not true, and there isn&#39;t much of any conclusion that you can make.</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1485</p>
<p>Folder: hw11h</p>
<p>Title: Q1, d clarification</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For Q1, I am confused about what d represents. The question says that kyle must buy at least 2d shovels but each TA has a different number of alliances (d), so which d is the problem referring to?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>$$d$$ represents the least amount of alliances a TA can have. Think of it as a lower bound. You need to show that Kyle needs to buy at least 2d shovels</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:12</p>
</article>


<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1487</p>
<p>Folder: hw11h</p>
<p>Title: Q5 clarification</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I&#39;m confused about why the statement in Q5 would be true. What if you had a graph that looked like B -- I -- A ? Then the beginner vertex is not connected to and intermediate and an advanced. Also, can we assume that the number of vertices is greater than or equal to 3?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>The issue with the graph that you presented is that $$\chi(G) = 2$$, not $$3$$ as specified in the question. </p>
<p></p>
<p>You are <strong>not</strong> allowed to assume that the number of vertices is greater than or equal to 3.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:03</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Can you explain what that notation means? Does that mean the minimum degree is 3?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>$$\chi(G) = 3$$ means that the minimum number of colors needed to color $$G$$. Equivalently, $$G$$ cannot be colored using less than $$3$$ colors.</p>
</article>
<article class="question">
<p>Why can we not assume that there are at least 3 vertices when the question says that G is a connected graph with 3 or more vertices?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
My bad. You can assume this.
</article>
</article>

<p>Post: 1504</p>
<p>Folder: hw11h</p>
<p>Title: HW 11H Question 5</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I am not sure if I am understanding the question correctly. For example, if we have a connected graph of 3 vertices and there exists an edge if only they are friends with each other. So can&#39;t we have a graph that has a beginner node who is only friends with an intermediate node, and the intermediate node is friends with also the advanced node, making the graph 3-colorable? And in this graph it is not necessarily true the beginner node is adjacent to both an intermediate neighbor and an advanced neighbor, even though the graph is 3-colorable. Do we assume that there exists a beginner node whose degree is 2 in the graph?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>The graph you provided in your example does not have $$\chi(G) = 3$$, it has $$\chi(G) = 2$$. Note that $$\chi(G)$$ represents the <strong>minimum</strong> number of colors needed to color $$G$$.</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1507</p>
<p>Folder: midterm2</p>
<p>Title: Lecture expected value</p>
<article class="question">
<p>It&#39;s more of a counting question...</p>
<p>In the Linearity of Expectation lecture example: </p>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<p>(Example. Suppose that n people leave their hats at the hat check. If the hats are</p>
<p>randomly returned what is the expected number of people that get their own hat back?)</p>
<p>Why is E[X] = (n-1)!/(n)!    ?</p>
<p>That means that probability that ith person gets the hat is 99/100 * 98/99 * 97/98...* 1 / 2 right? </p>
<p>I don&#39;t see how the multiplying hundred times happens. Is it the probability that all 99 other people don&#39;t get their hats back?</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Thank you. </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Instead of thinking of $$\frac{(n-1)!}{n!}$$ being computed as the product of probabilities, it is probably better to think of it as being computed as $$\frac{|E_i|}{|\Omega|}$$. The sample space is all ways that the $$n$$ people can get their hats back which means $$|\Omega| = n!$$. The event $$E_i$$ is the event that the $$i$$th person gets their hat back.</p>
<p></p>
<p>So you can think of $$|E_i|$$ as computing the amount of permutations of $$\{1, ..., n\}$$ where $$i$$ is in the $$i$$th spot. This can be done in $$(n-1)!$$ ways.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Thus, $$Pr[E_i] = \mathbb{E}[X_i]= \frac{(n-1)!}{n!}$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:04:32</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1513</p>
<p>Folder: midterm2</p>
<p>Title: Random variables, counting</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Can we apply what we learned about random variables to formalize counting questions?</p>
<p>For example, let H be the random variable denoting # of heads obtained in n coin tosses, such that </p>
<p>|H = 0| &#43; |H=1| &#43; |H=2| ... |H = n| = |H| where |H| is the cardinality of the sample space, 2^n?</p>
<p>Can we do that since a random variable is an event or is this not commonly used?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>This does work mathematically, but is not super common. </p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:36</p>
<article class="question">
<p>What&#39;s a good alternative formalization, if I wanna solve complementary questions?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I guess it depends on the problem and the context, but what you have described above is fine to use!</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1514</p>
<p>Folder: hw11h</p>
<p>Title: HW 11H Question</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Is it safe to assume that if the graph is 4-colorable, it can be 3-colorable as well?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>A graph that is $$4$$-colorable is not always $$3$$-colorable.</p>
<p></p>
<p>However, a graph that is $$3$$-colorable is always $$4$$-colorable.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:45</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1534</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: Distinguisble vs Indistinguisble</p>
<article class="question">
<p>This is a basic question, but I want to make sure I am understanding this fully. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Say we roll 2 dice. I understand that Pr[doubles] is the same for both indistinguisble and distinguisble die.</p>
<p></p>
<p>But say we want to find the probability of rolling a 1 and 2. I don&#39;t see the dinstinction between indistinguisble and distinguisble here, as they both yield probabilities of 2/36 (the order of the 1 and 2 appearing doesn&#39;t matter for both). But I feel like these probabilities should be different. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Can someone clarify this concept I am looking at Lecture 5H)? Thank you.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Why do you feel like these probabilities should be different? Both ways should yield $$\frac{2}{36}$$. The difference between indistinguishable and distinguishable comes in how the sample space is defined, in that with the distinguishable case, our sample space is uniform, but in the indistinguishable case, it is not.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:03:07</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1553</p>
<p>Folder: midterm2</p>
<p>Title: Proof by Construction</p>
<article class="question">
<p>What exactly is proof by construction? I understand we can formulate certain graphs that fit the criteria of what we&#39;re trying to prove, but is construction a formal proof technique like induction or contradiction?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I think proof by construction is sometimes alright when proving existence of a graph. For example, if we were asked to prove that &#34;there exists a tree with exactly two leaves&#34;, I could provide a method of construction.</p>
<p></p>
<p>However, in general, proofs by construction aren&#39;t too great and can be finicky at times because we need to be considerate of generalization for all graphs within our procedure (i.e. not making any logical leaps that would not work for all graphs)</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 13:35:50</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1555</p>
<p>Folder: midterm2</p>
<p>Title: lecture 5t example proof clarification</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Hi there, I just had a question about this line of the proof in the Lecture 5t notes:</p>
<p></p>
<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7gesqko27j373%2F68ab122eb52c4f910fe68fb657d83383148133458d43c3fef5962a9a2ae63bcf%2FScreen_Shot_2022-11-17_at_4.40.32_AM.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Screen_Shot_2022-11-17_at_4.40.32_AM.png</a></p>
<p></p>
<p>The previous example that they reference is &#34;Prove that the sum of degrees of all nodes in a graph is twice the number of edges. Solution: Since each edge is incident to exactly two vertices, each edge contributes two to the sum of degrees of the vertices. The claim follows.&#34;</p>
<p></p>
<p>I don&#39;t really understand the reasoning for that line of the proof; how do we know that the LHS side is even? Do we know the number of edges in the graph? Thank you for the clarification!</p>
<p></p>
<p>-Angie</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>The left hand side is taking the sum of the degrees of all vertices of the graph. From the handshaking lemma, we know that $$\sum_{v \in V} deg(v) = 2|E|$$, and the proof for this is given in the example referenced.</p>
<p></p>
<p>We don&#39;t know the number of edges, but since the sum of the degrees is <strong>2 times</strong> the number of edges, we can conclude that the sum of degrees must always be even.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 7:19:40</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1558</p>
<p>Folder: midterm2</p>
<p>Title: Graph Coloring Lecture 10T</p>
<article class="question">
In the example, why is it that we are able to invoke IH after removing some vertex v? What if v was the vertex with max degree, wouldn’t the IH no longer hold because max degree could not be &lt;k?
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>After removing the vertex, the degree of the remaining vertices can only decrease (as we are also removing edges). Thus, the IH is still able to be invoked because the max degree of the remaining graph is <strong>at most k.</strong></p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:51:53</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1571</p>
<p>Folder: midterm2</p>
<p>Title: Directed graphs</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I have many questions about directed graphs in general. </p>
<p>Let $$u->v$$  be a directed graph with vertices $$u$$ and $$v$$, and the edge going from $$u$$ to $$v$$. </p>
<p>Is it that $$deg(u)=deg(v)=1$$, or that $$deg(u)=1,deg(v)=0$$ as the edge&#39;s &#39;source&#39; is $$u$$?</p>
<p>Is the only path in the graph from $$u$$ to $$v$$ because we can only traverse edges in one direction?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Also, I know that we can solve that chess tournament question using directed graphs, but I am not sure about how to represent</p>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<p>&#34;$$x$$ beat some third participant $$z$$ who beat $$y$$&#34; in the graph. Could someone please explain how that proof would work?</p>
<p></p>
<p>The question:</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7gcywgetsa6wn%2Fd4dfb746903ade6911bc08f1bf3cbb38a8184185c9baf63c6299553ecb843301%2FScreenshot_2022-11-18_at_3.01.44_PM.png" alt="Screenshot_2022-11-18_at_3.01.44_PM.pngNaN" /></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>We don&#39;t explicitly discuss directed graphs in the fall, but vertices have an indegree (number of edges coming in) and an outdegree (number of edges leaving). The only path in the graph would be $$u \rightarrow v$$ as you described. </p>
<p></p>
<p>For the chessmaster problem, we can rephrase it in directed graph terms: consider a graph $$G$$ on $$n$$ vertices, such that between every pair of vertices $$x, y$$ there exists edge either $$(x, y)$$ or $$(y, x)$$. Show that there exists some vertex $$v$$ such that the shortest path distance from this vertex to every other vertex is at most 2. </p>
<p></p>
<p>We can prove this claim by induction on the number of vertices similar to the proof given on the HW. </p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 1:04:59</p>
<article class="question">
<md>
Hmm even I did induction on the HW, but I was thinking about something slightly different. Would this proof by contradiction work?

Let the graph be $$G(V,E)$$, we want to prove that $$\exists g\in V s.t, \forall v\in V\setminus\{g\}, (g,v)\in E\lor ((g,u)\in E\land(u,v)\in E)$$. Assume for contradiction that $$\forall g\in V, \exists v\in V\setminus\{g\}, s.t, (g,v)\notin E\land \lnot ((g,u)\in E\land(u,v)\in E)$$.

The assumption means that for all vertices in $$V$$, there exists a vertex that it has neither directly beaten nor indirectly beaten. Let $$g\in V$$ be arbitrary but particular. Let $$F_g$$ be the set of all vertices $$g$$ has beaten directly ($$x\in F_g\iff (g,x)\in E$$). 

By the assumption, there is a vertex $$a\notin F_g$$. Since all vertices have edges going between them, $$(g,a)\notin E\implies (a,g)\in E\implies g\in F_a$$, where $$F\_a$$ is the set of all vertices $$a$$ beat directly ($$x\in F_a\iff (a,x)\in E$$). Moreover, by the assumption, no vertex that is in $$F_g$$ has beaten $$a$$ (because if $$x\in F_g\land (x,a)\in E$$, we would have that $$(g,x)\in E\land(x,a)\in E$$, which violates the assumption). If no vertex in $$F_g$$ has beaten $$a$$, that means $$a$$ has beaten all of them, so $$F_g\subset F_a$$. It is a proper subset as $$g\in F_a$$, and $$g\notin F_g$$ (clearly). Hence, we have that $$|F_a|>|F_g|$$.

By the assumption, there is a vertex $$b\notin F\_a$$, so we can repeat this exact same process again and obtain $$|F_b|>|F_a|$$ 

Since the assumption applies to all vertices, we can simply repeat this process again and again, and we would eventually go through all the vertices (if we cannot repeat this process for any one vertex, it would violate the assumption), and we would obtain that $$|F_g|<|F_a|<|F_b|<|F_c|...<|F_y|<...<|F_n|$$ (this inequality contains the $$'F'$$ sets for all vertices in $$V$$). This means that $$n$$ is the vertex that has beaten the most people directly, but by the assumption, there is a vertex $$y\notin F_n$$ that it has not beaten directly or indirectly, which means that we can repeat the above process with $$y$$, and get the inequality $$|F_n|<|F_y|$$. 
This is a contradiction, as we now have that $$|F_y|<|F_n|<|F_y|$$, which means $$|F_y|<|F_y|$$.  Hence, the assumption is wrong, and the claim is proven.

Would this be shorter or longer than induction? Also, if it doesn't work, then what changes would have to be made? </md>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I think this solution is basically same as the alternate solution provided below. The &#34;repeat the process again and again&#34; to obtain $$|F_g|<|F_a|<|F_b|<...<|F_n|$$ isn&#39;t my favorite, so I think it would be easier to say, &#34;Let $$g$$ be the vertex with the greatest outdegree,&#34; and continue with the first few paragraphs of your proof (excluding the last one, basically). This is basically what the alternate solution below does, and you know that there is a vertex with maximum outdegree because there are a finite number of vertices.</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkqib022iyb53z5%2F24d74e0f4d1b74938c83c1fb5a191d8af598e48a3ba5eb11964b4952c7f64b31%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" /></p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1585</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: Induction</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In general, should we be using induction on the edges in a graph rather than the vertices, and if so why?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>What you induct on really depends on the problem. Also, both induction on edges and induction on vertices have their own separate issues, so it just depends.</p>
<p></p>
<p>For example, inducting on vertices can sometimes be annoying because when you remove a vertex, you also have to remove all incident edges. But at the same time, inducting on vertices can be nice when you can guarantee existence of a specific type of vertex in a graph (i.e a leaf in a tree)</p>
<p></p>
<p>What&#39;s nice about edge induction is that when you remove an edge, you don&#39;t <em>have</em> to remove any vertices, but removing edges can disconnect the graph, and removing edges in general may not be as easy to generalize as removing vertices.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 1:14:20</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1592</p>
<p>Folder: midterm2</p>
<p>Title: Inequality Proof for tree with max degree delta has greater than or equal to delta leaves question</p>
<article class="question">
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt0cz590wc77nm%2Ffa8570b7e70e7d04b399e0068744295a2b4534e59355e58397519cd306ec2c8b%2FScreenshot_2022-11-20_at_12.55.18_AM.png" alt="Screenshot_2022-11-20_at_12.55.18_AM.pngNaN" width="398" height="254" /></p>

<article class="answer">

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1615</p>
<p>Folder: midterm2</p>
<p>Title: Practice Exam Question 2c</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Is $$B = \{c, d, e\}$$, or any other answer where there is overlap between $$A$$ and $$B$$ also a valid answer, or is $$A = \Omega$$ the only valid answer?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>$$B = \{c, d, e\}$$ does not work, because $$Pr[A] = \frac35 = Pr[B]$$ but $$Pr[A \cap B] = \frac15$$. And we see that $$Pr[A \cap B] \neq Pr[A] \cdot Pr[B]$$, so they would not be independent.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:22:44</p>
</article>

<p>Post: 1622</p>

<p>Title: Lecture 9T</p>
<article class="question">
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7gbfjq5c8s67p%2Fb97bd2cc5a31887f0f366dd839dca4a49540b24ab0fb200b3bf6305d68108bc7%2FScreenshot_2022-11-21_at_1.04.13_PM.png" alt="Screenshot_2022-11-21_at_1.04.13_PM.pngNaN" /></p>
<p>can someone explain how v is an ancestor of w and w is an ancestor of v, as stated in this diagram?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">

</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:18</p>
</article>



<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1625</p>
<p>Folder: midterm2</p>
<p>Title: question 2 on the practice exam</p>
<article class="question">
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7g61klqsf64vp%2F7e094b5f54b5f14bdacccb1f50f1e337a447ad195c4dbdc08194b16953cff520%2Fimage.png" alt="image.png" /></p>
<p>Why are these solutions true?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>For c, $$Pr[B] = \frac{|B|}{|\Omega|} = \frac{|\Omega|}{|\Omega|} = 1$$. To deem if $$A$$ and $$B$$ are independent, we need to check if $$Pr[A] \cdot Pr[B] = Pr[A \cap B]$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>We have $$Pr[A] = \frac{|A|}{|\Omega} = \frac{3}{5}$$. And we have that $$A \cap B = \{a, b, c\}$$ so $$Pr[A \cap B] = \frac{|A \cap B|}{|\Omega|} = \frac{3}{5}$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>So since $$Pr[A] \cdot Pr[B] = \frac35 \cdot 1 = \frac35 = Pr[A \cap B]$$, we have that $$A$$ and $$B$$ are independent.</p>
<p></p>
<p>For part d, &#34;pairwise independence&#34; means for any <strong>two </strong>events, they must be independent. You can verify independence in the same way as we did above. &#34;mutual independence&#34; means that for any <strong>subset</strong> of the events, the probability of their intersection must equal the product of the individual probabilities.</p>
<p></p>
<p>You can see that $$Pr[A] = Pr[B] = Pr[C] = \frac12$$. And we have that $$A \cap B \cap C = \{b\}$$, Thus, since $$Pr[A \cap B \cap C] \neq Pr[A] \cdot Pr[B] \cdot Pr[C]$$, we can conclude that A, B, and C are not mutually independent.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:31:31</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1629</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: Handshaking</p>
<article class="question">
<p>What is the formal definition of the handshaking lemma for graphs we can use for the exam? I can&#39;t find it in the lecture notes</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>For any undirected graph $$G(V, E)$$, the handshaking lemma tells us that $$\sum_{v \in V} deg(v) = 2|E|$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:56</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Can we also call the property that there are even number of odd degree vertices, Handshaking lemma?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>ehh it&#39;s not really exactly handshaking lemma -- it&#39;s more of a corollary of it. But for the purpose of the exam, you can just say &#34;from the handshaking lemma, we know that there are an even number of odd degree vertices.&#34; </p>
<p></p>
<p>Also we probably proved that fact somewhere in one of the hws if I recall correctly.</p>
</article>
</article>

<p>Title: Q1 &#34;distinct&#34; equivalence classes</p>
<article class="question">

Does this mean there are n-2 equivalence classes that do not have the same elements as any of the other equivalence classes, that 2 of the n cereal mascots do not have equivalence classes (empty sets?) or something else?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>There are $$n-2$$ equivalence classes that do not have the same elements as any other equivalence classes.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:22:14</p>
<article class="question">
<md>Sorry, just following up to clarify this. If, for example, we have two equivalence classes $$[a]$$ and $$[b]$$ such that $$[a] = [b]$$, does that count as one distinct equivalence class, or none?</md>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Those would be the same equivalence class. So it would be one distinct equivalence class.</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1649</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: M-augmenting path</p>
<article class="question">
<p>How do we know that an m-augmenting path is of odd length? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>An m-augmenting path must be of odd length. This is because an m-augmenting path <strong>is</strong> an m-alternating path. So if you consider an m-augmenting path that traverses the vertices in the following order: $$v_0, v_1, v_2, ..., v_{2k+1}$$, we have by definition that $$v_0$$ and $$v_{2k+1}$$ are unsaturated, which means that $$\{v_0, v_1\}$$ is not in the matching, but $$\{v_1, v_2\}$$ must be. And $$\{v_2, v_3\}$$ is not in the matching, but $$\{v_3, v_4\}$$ is. Note that in order for the endpoint of the path to be unsaturated, we need $$\{v_i, v_{i+1}\}$$ to not be in the matching (where $$v_{i+1}$$ is the endpoint), which means that (by our pattern), $$i+1$$ is odd. So that&#39;s why our vertices ended with $$v_{2k+1}$$, suggesting that our path is of odd length. </p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 3:14:32</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1653</p>
<p>Folder: hw13h</p>
<p>Title: Q4: What does &#34;any one type of milk&#34; mean?</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In the problem statement, we are given that &#34;for any given variety of cereal, the number of different types of milk that it tastes good with is always greater than or equal to the number of varieties of cereal that any one type of milk tastes good with&#34;.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Parsing the question, it seems to me that this means that every cereal goes well with at least $$x$$ types of milk. I&#39;m confused about what the problem says that $$x$$ is.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Is it the maximum number of varieties of cereal that go well with any type of milk? Or is it the maximum number of varieties of cereal that go well with the types of milk that go well with our given variety of cereal? Something else?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>If a cereal goes well with $$x$$ types of milk, then for <strong>every </strong>milk, it must go well with <strong>no more than </strong>$$x$$ types of cereal. So in a sense, $$x$$ is the &#34;minimum&#34; number of milks a cereal can go well with. But at the same time, we do not know the exact value of $$x$$.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 12:06:40</p>
</article>


<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1655</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: Hamiltonian Cycle</p>
<article class="question">
<p>A Hamiltonian cycle in a graph $$G$$ is a cycle in which each vertex of $$G$$ appears exactly once. A graph is Hamiltonian if it contains a Hamiltonian cycle.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Does the fact that it is a cycle not mean that one vertex will be present twice at the beginning and ending?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Yeah, a hamiltonian cycle <strong>is </strong>a cycle, so it will start and end at the same vertex</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 1:03:46</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Ya I got that but the definition has &#34;each vertex of $$G$$ appears exactly once&#34; but in a cycle the start and end vertex is same so it appears twice right which conrtadicts the definitions part saying &#34;exactly once&#34;</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yeah it&#39;s one of those things where we don&#39;t feel like specifying &#34;each vertex of $$G$$ appears exactly once except for the vertex that you start and end at&#34; because it&#39;s just unnecessary extra wording. We sort of incorporate that into the definition implicitly by noting that we are talking about cycles. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Tangentially, if we are being super careful, we can note that the definition of a hamiltonian cycle mentions that it is a <em>cycle</em>. And the definition of a cycle is a <em>closed path. </em>And a closed path is a <em>path</em> in which the start vertex and end vertex are the same. So I suppose the &#34;issue&#34; stems from the definition of path or closed path. But again, we sort of take this stuff for granted with these definitions and implicitly include these &#34;edge conditions&#34; when defining other terms.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Ok thanks for the detailed explanation I definitely get it now</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1658</p>
<p>Folder: hw13h</p>
<p>Title: Question about recitation solutions</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Hi! Could someone help me understand how we justify concluding the bolded portion below? This is from problem 2, recitation 10. Thanks! </p>
<p></p>
<p><em>Thus, there must be n|A| edges from A to NG(A). We also know that each column in NG(A) has at most n edges back to A, meaning that there are at most n|NG(A)| edges from NG(A) to A. <strong>This means that n|A| ≤ n|NG(A)|</strong>.</em></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>We&#39;re basically counting the number of edges that &#34;leave&#34; $$A$$ and enter $$N_G(A)$$. We first conclude that there must be $$n|A|$$ edges from $$A$$ to $$N_G(A)$$, but that can be upper bounded by the second sentence by shifting our focus to $$N_G(A)$$ and seeing that there are at most $$n|N_G(A)|$$ edges from $$N_G(A)$$ to $$A$$. Note that there must be the same amount of edges going from $$A$$ to $$N_G(A)$$ as there are going from $$N_G(A)$$ to $$A$$ (in fact, they are the same edges). Since we have <strong>at most</strong> that many edges, we have an upper bound, so composing the two results together, we get $$n|A| \leq n|N_G(A)|$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 2:00:32</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1663</p>
<p>Folder: hw13h</p>
<p>Title: Reflexive</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Could you please explain why R6 is not reflexive and R5 is?  </p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt0cz590wc77nm%2Fb369e9da125e024de209b8fae35a8f964fc0720761d80a51e0ebf29ce29f13ee%2FScreenshot_2022-11-27_at_6.12.41_PM.png" alt="Screenshot_2022-11-27_at_6.12.41_PM.png" width="377" height="106" /></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>$$\frac{0}{0}$$ is undefined, so that means that we <strong>do not have </strong>$$0 \mid 0$$, therefore, $$(0, 0) \notin R_6$$, so it is not reflexive. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Since $$0 \notin \mathbb{Z^+}$$, we do not run into this issue with $$R_5$$.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:30</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1673</p>
<p>Folder: hw14t</p>
<p>Title: Q2 Neighbors of a set of vertices</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Are vertices in a set excluded from the neighbors of the set?</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I guess this depends. Like if your graph had vertices $$u$$ and $$v$$, and the only edge in the graph was $$u - v$$, then for set $$S = \{u, v\}$$, we have $$N(S) = \{u, v\}$$, and so $$u \in N(S)$$ and $$v \in N(S)$$</p>
<p></p>
<p>But if the graph was just two isolated vertices $$u$$ and $$v$$, then for $$S = \{u, v\}$$, we have $$N(S) = \emptyset$$. And here we have $$u, v \notin N(S)$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 2:40:52</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1674</p>
<p>Folder: hw13h</p>
<p>Title: A subset S from a set of X vertices.</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In order to show for all subset S of X, in the context for Hall&#39;s Thm, which would be the correct terminology in proofs:</p>
<p></p>
<p>&#34;For an arbitrary but particular subset S of X&#34;</p>
<p></p>
<p>Or </p>
<p></p>
<p>&#34;For all subset S of X&#34;</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Both are fine, but they depend on what the remainder of the proof looks like. If what you are proving depends on the arbitrary-ness of $$S$$, then use the first one. But if what you prove works for all subsets, then the latter is fine.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 1:23:58</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1725</p>
<p>Folder: hw14h</p>
<p>Title: HW 14h q3</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In question 3, it says that Rajiv places the k pawns only on Row 0 but what if k (the number of pawns) is greater than n (the length of the row)? Then would some pawns be placed on other rows in the grid or is k bounded by n?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>You can assume that you can always fit $$k$$ pawns on each row. That is, it is not necessarily true that each pawn will occupy one square. So there could be many pawns on a single square, but they will always all fit on the row.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:27:18</p>
</article>

<article class="answer">

</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:10:29</p>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1728</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: Ramsey Number Clarification</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I&#39;m a bit confused about the definition of a Ramsey number; how can a complete graph be 2-colored? If every vertex has an edge from every other vertex, for say the example of R(3,3)&lt;=6, I don&#39;t see how it&#39;s possible for that graph to be 2-colored.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Here, the term &#34;coloring&#34; just means that we are assigning colors to the edges without the constraint of edges incident to the same vertex having different colors. So the Ramsey number is saying if $$R(k, l) = n$$, then for <strong>any</strong> assignment of colors (either red or blue) to the edges of the complete graph on $$n$$ vertices, you can find a red clique of size $$k$$ or a blue clique of size $$l$$.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 5:01:27</p>
</article>


<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1730</p>
<p>Folder: final</p>
<p>Title: lecture 10h notes question</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Hello, </p>
<p>I&#39;m looking over lecture notes to prepare for the final and I have a question about one of the examples. In lecture 10h, there is an example problem calculating the variance of the hat problem we did in lecture 9h. When we are calculating the variance, the problem calculates $$E[X^{2}]$$ as follows:</p>
<p>$$E[X^{2}]= \sum_{i=1}^{n} E[X_{i}^{2}] + 2 \sum_{i<j}E[X_iX_j]$$</p>
<p>Where $$X_{i}$$ is if the ith person gets their hat back. I&#39;m wondering why we split the one variable i into 2, i and j. Where does the second summation term come from? Thank you </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>We defined indicators in such a way that $$X = X_1 + X_2 + ... + X_n$$. So $$\mathbb{E}[X^2] = \mathbb{E}[(X_1 + X_2 + ... + X_n)^2] = \mathbb{E}[(X_1 + X_2 + ... + X_n)(X_1 + X_2 + ... + X_n)] $$</p>
<p></p>
<p>Multiply the two expressions to get: </p>
<p>$$\mathbb{E}[X_1X_1 + X_1X_2 + ... + X_1X_n + X_2X_1 + X_2X_2 + .... + X_2X_n + ... + X_nX_1 + X_nX_2 + ... + X_nX_n]$$</p>
<p></p>
<p>We&#39;ll &#34;group together&#34; terms of the form $$X_iX_i$$, so we have:</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$\mathbb{E}[X_1X_1 + X_2X_2 + ... + X_nX_n + X_1X_2 + X_1X_3 + ... + X_nX_{n-1}]$$ (just rearranging the terms in a friendly way here).</p>
<p></p>
<p>Use LOE: </p>
<p>$$\mathbb{E}[X_1X_1] + \mathbb{E}[X_2X_2] + ... + \mathbb{E}[X_nX_n] + \mathbb{E}[X_1X_2] + \mathbb{E}[X_1X_3] + ... + \mathbb{E}[X_nX_{n-1}]$$</p>
<p></p>
<p>The first $$n$$ terms can be grouped into one summation, and the last terms will have their own summation:</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$\sum_{i=1}^n \mathbb{E}[X_iX_i] + \sum_{i \neq j, 1 \leq i, j \leq n} \mathbb{E}[X_iX_j]$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Finally, we can just rewrite some terms to match the expression:</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$\sum_{i=1}^n \mathbb{E}[X_i^2] + 2 \sum_{i < j} \mathbb{E}[X_iX_j]$$. Note that the bounds of $$i$$ and $$j$$ are held implicitly in the second summation.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 5:42:16</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1738</p>
<p>Folder: midterm2</p>
<p>Title: Q2b</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In the TR b, it says G has max degree of delta. Then chromatic number of G = delta &#43; 1</p>
<p>How is this different from the lecture lemma &#34;graph with maximum degree at most k is k&#43;1 colorable&#34;?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Here delta = k: max degree delta is within the bounds of &#34;at most k&#34;, so wouldn&#39;t that make the graph delta&#43;1 colorable? Thank you!</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>The chromatic number refers to the <strong>minimum </strong>number of colors needed to color the graph. So while a graph with maximum degree $$\Delta$$ is $$\Delta + 1$$ colorable, there are some graphs with max degree $$\Delta$$ that can be colored in less than $$\Delta + 1$$ colors.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The discussion in @1497 may be of interest</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 1:01:15</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1786</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: Proof by contradiction that in any planar graph the minimum degree is at most 5</p>
<article class="question">
<p>In class today, we proved that in any planar graph with $$n$$ vertices $$\delta(G) \leq 5$$ by assuming for contradiction. In class, we assumed that $$\delta(G) \geq 6$$, after which the proof follows as such:</p>
<p></p>
<p>          $$\sum_{v \in V}deg(v) \geq 6n$$, and so by handshake lemma $$2|E| = \sum_{v \in V}deg(v) \geq 6n$$. or that $$|E| \geq 3n$$.</p>
<p>          Using the corollary proved in class that in a planar graph with at least 2 edges, $$|E| \leq 3|V| - 6$$, we have that $$3n \leq 3n - 6$$, or that $$0 \leq -6$$, a clear contradiction.</p>
<p></p>
<p>However, if you assume for contradiction that $$\delta(G) > 5$$, we have the following:</p>
<p></p>
<p>          $$\sum_{v \in V}deg(v) > 5n$$, and so by handshake lemma $$2|E| = \sum_{v \in V}deg(v) > 5n$$. or that $$|E| > \frac{5n}{2}$$.</p>
<p>          Using the corollary proved in class that in a planar graph with at least 2 edges, $$|E| \leq 3|V| - 6$$, we have that $$\frac{5n}{2} < 3n - 6$$, or that $$n > 12$$. This doesn&#39;t seem to be a contradiction.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Clearly, the proof doesn&#39;t follow when assuming $$\delta(G) > 5$$, so why does it work when assuming $$\delta(G) \leq 6$$ rather than $$\delta(G) > 5$$? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>It&#39;s mainly due to the strictness of the bound. While saying that $$\sum_{v \in V} deg(v) > 5n$$ is not false, the value of $$5n$$ is a weak lower bound. We can see this because (for non-trivial values of $$n$$) we would also be able to say $$\sum_{v \in V} deg(v) > 5n+1$$ or $$\sum_{v \in V} deg(v) > 5n + 2$$ and so on. And those claims would indeed be true. Since &#34;degree&#34; takes on an integer value, when considering the sum, it is best to lower bound by the absolute minimum value of the degree (that a vertex can have), which in this case is $$6$$. Then, we have a much stricter lower bound, which helps with the calculations</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:07:46</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1801</p>
<p>Folder: final</p>
<p>Title: Maximal versus longist versus maximum</p>
<article class="question">
<p>What is the difference between these (especially for paths)</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>&#34;Maximal&#34; usually refers to something that cannot be extended. &#34;Maximum&#34; means the largest value for a particular quantity. When it comes to paths, a <em>maximal path</em> is a path that cannot be extended. For <em>maximum path</em>, let $$P$$ denote the set of paths in the graph. A path $$Q \in P$$ is said to be <em>a maximum path</em> if the length of $$Q$$ is greater than or equal to the length of $$R$$ for all $$R \in P$$. </p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:19:03</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1802</p>
<p>Folder: final</p>
<p>Title: What is the exact formula for squaring the sum of random variables?</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I know it is something like</p>
<p></p>
<p>(sum X_i) ^2 = sum (X_i)^2 &#43; sum_i sum_j X_i X_j</p>
<p></p>
<p>is this correct?</p>
<p>Also, how do we find the amount of sums in the second part of the equation?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>$$(\sum_{i=1}^n X_i)^2 = \sum_{i=1}^n X_i^2 + \sum_{1 \leq i, j \leq n, i \neq j} X_i X_j$$</p>
<p></p>
<p>Or equivalently, $$\sum_{i = 1}^n X_i^2 + 2 \sum_{1 \leq i < j \leq n} X_iX_j$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>To calculate the number of terms in the second summation, let&#39;s view the first equation I provided. There are $$n$$ options for $$i$$. There are $$n-1$$ options for $$j$$ because we must have $$i \neq j$$. So the second summation has $$n \cdot (n-1)$$ terms.</p>
<p></p>
<p>It&#39;s a good exercise to verify that the two expressions I provided are equivalent, and even better to understand <strong>why</strong> they are equivalent.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:22:11</p>
</article>

<p>Title: Strictly increasing/decreasing proof Lecture 5h</p>

I know this is not true, so what am I missing about the ordering of the values in the sequence?</p>
</article>

<p>Title: Digraph terminology</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Is an arc only a self-loop, and edges cannot be a self-loop? Or are arcs and edges the same thing?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>edges and arcs are the same thing. A self-loop is when you have an edge $$u \rightarrow u$$ (an edge from a vertex to itself)</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1842</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: Linearity of Expectation Lecture Question</p>
<article class="question">
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkszbaubtqi02n7%2F0e944fdaede7b12a55aa9ef287389773393a5d5502e5a262adcb2f41c309306e%2FScreenshot_2022-12-17_at_2.27.06_PM.png" alt="Screenshot_2022-12-17_at_2.27.06_PM.pngNaN" width="322" height="32" /><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkszbaubtqi02n7%2Fbb6935a261151d34354709007c1d1b40e40b4a1bb75f688356d8ab8fe1891a50%2FScreenshot_2022-12-17_at_2.27.24_PM.png" alt="Screenshot_2022-12-17_at_2.27.24_PM.pngNaN" width="324" height="63" /></p>
<p></p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkszbaubtqi02n7%2Fa6c207e909f9e90843870ef1b1a71b41005fb34fee2be4b147dcc8106e00eddd%2FScreenshot_2022-12-17_at_2.27.47_PM.png" alt="Screenshot_2022-12-17_at_2.27.47_PM.png" width="222" height="134" /></p>
<p>How did we get from Pr[Xi=1] to (n-1/n)^n?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>$$X_i$$ is an indicator that is $$1$$ when the $$i$$th bin is empty. In other words, for each of the $$n$$ balls, we want them to land in a bin other than bin $$n$$. Thus, for a given ball, there are $$n-1$$ &#34;good&#34; bins that it can fall into (we subtract 1 to <strong>remove</strong> bin i). There are $$n$$ total bins. So the probability that a single ball does not fall into bin $$i$$ is $$\frac{n-1}{n}$$. Use independence to see that the probability that <strong>all $$n$$ </strong>balls do not fall into bin $$i$$ is $$(\frac{n-1}{n})^n)$$. Thus, $$Pr[X_i = 1] = (\frac{n-1}{n})^n$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:04:55</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1843</p>
<p>Folder: final</p>
<p>Title: Lecture 15H Example</p>
<article class="question">
<p>For the example where we prove that the complete bipartite graph of 3,3 is not planar could we use |E| &lt;= 3|V| - 6 or is there a reason we have to use |E| &lt;= 2|V| - 4</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Note $$K_{3, 3}$$ has $$|V| = 6$$ and $$|E| = 9$$. We use $$|E| \leq 2|V| - 4$$ to reach the contradiction (because it is tighter than $$3|V| - 6$$). If we were to use $$|E| \leq 3|V| - 6$$, then we get $$9 \leq 3 \cdot 6 - 6$$ which is a true statement and does not arrive at a contradiction</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:12:36</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1849</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: Digraphs</p>
<article class="question">
<p>How would you represent a symmetric and antisymmetric relation on a digraph?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>The lecture notes mention that $$R$$ is symmetric iff for each edge $$(a, b) $$ and $$a \neq b$$ in $$G$$, we have $$(b, a) \in G$$. So basically there will be a lot of &#34;back-and-forth&#34; edges between pairs of vertices.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The lecture notes also mention that $$R$$ is antisymmetric iff for vertices $$a, b \in G$$ we have both $$(a, b) \notin G$$ and $$(b, a) \notin G$$. </p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 3:02:13</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1850</p>
<p>Folder: hw9h</p>
<p>Title: HW 9H Q3</p>
<article class="question">
<p>To get the number of ways in which Selena can get a music drive, we had to multiply c*(n-1 choose p); in this procedure, we are first selecting one of c music drives for selena and then choosing p drives to be selected by the first person from the n-1 remaining drives. I&#39;m not sure how to reconcile this with the fact that the when the first person selects, they could have taken any number of music drives with their p, meaning there could be less than c options for Selena? Is there a reverse way of figuring out the cardinality of this event by partitioning it over the number of music drives that were taken by the first person?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>yeah the way around this would be to case based on the number of drives with music remaining, but this is quite challenging and time consuming to do, which is why we &#34;reverse&#34; the procedure. It probably still is possible to solve it by case work and just use the addition rule at the end. I&#39;ll think about this some more and maybe try to sketch up a solution if I find the time.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 2:46:43</p>
</article>


<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1852</p>
<p>Folder: other</p>
<p>Title: Random question about planar graphs and 3D objects</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Can every 3D object that doesn&#39;t have any holes in it (nothing topologically equivalent to a donut or other things) be converted into a planar graph and likewise, can every planar graph be converted into a 3D representation. Every corner where at least 3 edges meet can be a vertex. I have tried a few examples and it seems to hold so far. Every tree would just be a sphere like object. The version of the handshake lemma where you sum up the degree of the faces also works for the objects. The reason why I specified that the object should have no holes is because there ends up being extra faces in the planar graph. The space inside the hole, which should be counted as the out side graph face, becomes an inner face, so the lemma doesn&#39;t work. </p>
<p></p>
<p>I did try drawing the 3D equivalent of a k3,3 graph to see if it would break anything and I got this weird Mobius strip thing with twists that couldn&#39;t really be turned into an enclosed 3D object (I could have just drawn it wrong). I haven&#39;t tried doing it with a k5 graph, but I am assuming something similar will happen.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Anyone know anything about this or how one could prove something like this. </p>
<p>(sorry if this was poorly explained)</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>I think I&#39;ve heard something about planar graphs being related to a sphere in 3D space by triangulation. Haven&#39;t read up on this recently, but it might be something worthwhile to check out. I think I&#39;m just a little bit confused as to how you are translating the planar graph to 3D space. Can you go into the process of making the tree a &#34;sphere-like object&#34;.</p>
<p></p>
<p>There are many other TAs that have better expertise in this subject than myself, so they may be able to chime in. If explaining it via text proves to be too difficult, I am holding office hours on Monday evening and would love for you to come by and explain this to me. </p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:32:03</p>
<article class="question">
<p>The spherical shape is the only way to have the faces of the planar graph and the 3D object work. Since in a tree, there is only one face, it would translate to a object that only has 1 face. The edges of the tree would be sort of like a ridge, but since there is no cycle, this ridge doesn&#39;t fully wrap around the sphere. making two distinct faces. </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Ah I see. I&#39;ve thought about this quite a bit and am leaning towards the idea that every flat-faced 3D shape that is topologically equivalent to a sphere can be represented as a planar graph. And the idea is basically to cast it as a net in 2-space. I think there is probably some logical extension to make this hold true for non-flat-faced 3D solids, but I think there are some edge cases to handle and/or specify how to handle them. </p>
<p></p>
<p>The converse, however, seems to be much more difficult for me to conceptualize. I mostly think this because there is quite a bit of freedom in how you can transpose a 2-space figure into 3-space (admittedly, there is also quite a bit of freedom when reducing 3-space to 2-space, but I think in general, this transformation is a bit more constrained). I&#39;ll think about this some more though. Thank you for bringing up this question because it has been really fun to think about!</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1868</p>
<p>Folder: final</p>
<p>Title: Review Problems Question 7</p>
<article class="question">
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7g60heklx42q%2F4272c802f57dcf4f75c2988c265561e345722bfa52fa9537b03a3f2d70955fe4%2FScreen_Shot_2022-12-18_at_5.24.53_PM.png" width="2322" height="1160" alt="" /></p>
<p></p>
<p>Could I get some help on how this work was derived, especially the first two lines?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>The first line is using the law of total expectation. For the second line, we have that $$Pr[Y = 1] = p$$ because that is the probability of success on the first trial. In the case that the first trial was successful, we stop with the procedure, and we have $$X = 1$$. So that would mean $$E[X] = 1$$ and $$E[X^2] = 1$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>If the first trial was unsuccessful, then we have $$Y = 0$$, and this occurs with probability $$(1-p)$$. Then we &#34;ignore&#34; this trial, and consider the expected number of trials to get a success, but we add one for the failed trial that we just had, so we have $$E[X^2 | Y = 0] = E[(X+1)^2]$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Substitution of the above quantities gives the second line.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:41:29</p>
<article class="question">
<p>I know this was explained at some point, but could you explain again why it is (X&#43;1)^2 and not X^2 &#43; 1</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>We have $$E[ X^2 \mid  Y=0] = E[X\cdot X \mid Y=0]$$. By the memoryless property, $$E[X\mid Y=0] = E[X+1]$$, so $$E[X\cdot X \mid Y=0] = E[(X+1)(X+1)]$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>More intuitively, we want to &#34;add 1&#34; to the number of trials we have to perform, and the thing we are squaring is the &#34;number of trials&#34;.</p>
</article>
<article class="question">
<p>Can we just use the formula of Var[x] without proving it now that we have a referrence?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>You are allowed to cite the practice problems.</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1874</p>
<p>Folder: final</p>
<p>Title: Var calculation</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Why is the following procedure incorrect for HW 14h 4f</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7g8ls7ncf6tp%2Fa2db952ae49f06e21eae516fa841d8ec96bc6c838472f0bece1ddc5d24578bfc%2FE98DD684-9F81-4D70-87F1-B19D67C207B4.jpeg" width="1480" height="534" alt="" /><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7g8ls7ncf6tp%2Ff0b82e66c8aaecf7cd97c36100fa6a2f9355ec74c5a4a3f18b87e1cdf242808c%2F2689AB6B-4365-4332-BCB7-EB87C2D08B95.jpeg" width="1422" height="854" alt="" /></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>The algebra is a bit off. It should expand to $$E[A^2] -2E[AB] + E[B^2] - E[A]^2 + 2E[AB] - E[B]^2 = E[A^2] - E[A]^2 + E[B^2] - E[B]^2 \neq 0$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:02:00</p>
</article>


<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1876</p>
<p>Folder: final</p>
<p>Title: Midterm 1 Q8</p>
<article class="question">
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7glbo5bn7z3hf%2Fbd5add97d7673780ab2c1db69615393c7818861b5c938ca6bb1d1427cdb4cfae%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" /></p>
<p>Why is q1q2m &gt;= p^2 * m?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Because $$p$$ is defined to be the smallest prime factor of $$n$$. Since $$q_1$$ and $$q_2$$ are also both prime factors of $$n$$, we must have $$q_1 \geq p$$ and $$q_2 \geq p$$. So then $$q_1 \cdot q_2 \cdot m \geq p \cdot p \cdot m = p^2 \cdot m$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 6:50:58</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">

<p>#3: Could instead we say: A bipartite graph does not have odd length cycles so the Hamiltonian cycle is of even length. Every vertex is traversed and the colors alternate so |V1|=|V2|.</p>
<p>#8b: Is this recursive definition memoryless property or something else? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>3: sure. A bit of additional justification of why the colors alternate would also be good to include, but this type of approach would probably be okay.</p>
<p></p>
<p>9b: yeah it&#39;s essentially the memoryless property (very similar to what we did in HW14H Q2)</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 6:51:51</p>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1881</p>
<p>Folder: final</p>
<p>Title: Practice Problems Q2</p>
<article class="question">
<p>How are we getting that Var[H] is simply 100 x 0.5 x 0.5? I thought we had to break H up into indicators (Hi = 1 if the ith roll returns heads) and do a summation of the squared terms and the paired terms.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>$$H$$ is a binomial random variable and the variance of a binomial random variable $$X$$ is given by $$Var[X] = np(1-p)$$. So in the context of the problem we have $$n = 100$$ trials, and $$p = \frac12 = 0.5$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:47</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1882</p>
<p>Folder: final</p>
<p>Title: Review Q8</p>
<article class="question">
<p>How is Pr[n=k] always 1/11? Because there is no replacement, isn&#39;t Pr[n=1] = 1/11, Pr[n=2] = 2/10, Pr[n=3] = 3/9, etc.? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>$$Pr[n=2]$$ can be calculating the probability that you do not get the candy bar you like on the first trial multiplied with the probability that you get it on the second trial. </p>
<p></p>
<p>There is a $$\frac{10}{11}$$ chance of not getting the candy bar you like on the first trial. After this, the candy bar you have received has run out in the vending machine, so there are only 10 candy bars left, one of which is your favorite. So the probability that you get your favorite candy bar on the second trial is $$\frac{1}{10}$$. So we have $$Pr[n=2] = \frac{10}{11} \cdot \frac{1}{10} = \frac{1}{11}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>You can use this same process for all values of $$k$$, and see that it is always true that $$Pr[n = k] = \frac{1}{11}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Another way of arguing the probability is by considering the sample space being permutations of the candy bars. The event of interest is that the candy bar you like is in the $$k$$th position. The cardinality of the sample space is $$11!$$. The cardinality of the event set is $$1 \cdot (11-1)! = 10!$$. So the probability of the event is $$\frac{10!}{11!} = \frac{1}{11}$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:04:59</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1891</p>
<p>Folder: final</p>
<p>Title: Irrationality Proof</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Hi,</p>
<p></p>
<p>How would we go about the proof that root 40 is irrational using the argument p|ab implies p|a or p|b.</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
Yeah I think following the proof format of how we proved $$\sqrt{2}$$ is irrational for this problem would be kind of tough (mostly because the multiplicity of 2 in 40’s prime factorization is not 1). The way I would go about proving this is noting that $$\sqrt{40 = 2\sqrt{10}$$ and then showing that $$\sqrt{10} is irrational (which is easier to do). Finally you can conclude that an irrational multiplied with a non-zero rational is irrational.
</article>
<p>Response Time: 17:36:10</p>
</article>


<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1893</p>
<p>Folder: final</p>
<p>Title: What is the proof for this?</p>
<article class="question">
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7g9rwktr6b5x0%2F11b402f7299174843a520bf6cbe5ffa0c605994403a85086f5fbe485e5787063%2FScreen_Shot_2022-12-20_at_1.28.08_AM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2022-12-20_at_1.28.08_AM.pngNaN" /></p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>$$E[X] = \sum_{j=0}^{\infty} j \cdot Pr[X = j] = \sum_{j=1}^{\infty} \sum_{i=1}^j Pr[X = j] = \sum_{i = 1}^{\infty} \sum_{j=1}^{\infty} Pr[X = j] = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} Pr[X \geq i]$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 9:02:34</p>
</article>





<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1898</p>
<p>Folder: final</p>
<p>Title: Recitation10</p>
<article class="question">
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7glbo5bn7z3hf%2Fd1ee25a122adf0805371b79fb22422e6d208a54e1a9c16a0750cb6d026b74b84%2Fimage.png" alt="image.png" /></p>
<p>How is the conclusion n|A| &lt;= n (N(A)) reached? </p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
We’re counting the amount of edges two ways. In one way, we count the number of edges as $$n|A|$$. In the other way we show the number of edges is $$\leq n|N_G(A)|$$. So $$n|A| = edges \leq n|N_G(A)|$$ which means $$n|A| \leq n|N_G(A)|$$
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:06:35</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Why is it &lt;= and not =?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Because there could be edges leaving $$N_G(A)$$ that go to vertices outside of $$A$$.</p>
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1899</p>
<p>Folder: final</p>
<p>Title: midterm 2 question 5b</p>
<article class="question">
<md><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fktkpx1uxv5e33f%2F7effa32195e54b98e0b662d64c1eb4922428af35211f5f1e7735683cc00727fc%2FScreen_Shot_2022-12-20_at_11.49.22_AM.png" width="2104" height="1148" alt="" />

How did we get from the second to third line?</md>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>$$E[X_i]$$ was previously calculated to be $$\frac12$$, so the second term of $$E[X_i]^2 = (\frac12)^2$$. For the first term, we note that $$X_i$$ takes on the values of $$0, 1$$ or $$2$$. This means that $$X_i^2$$ takes on one of the values from the set $$\{0^2, 1^2, 2^2\} = \{0, 1, 4\}$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>We have $$E[X_i^2] = \sum_k k \cdot Pr[X_i^2 = k] = 0 \cdot Pr[X_i^2 = 0] + 1 \cdot Pr[X_i^2 = 1] + 4 \cdot Pr[X_i^2 = 4] = Pr[X_i^2 = 1] + 4 \cdot Pr[X_i^2 = 4]$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>For $$X_i^2 = 1$$, we need $$X_i = 1$$, and that occurs with probability $$\frac16$$. Similarly, for $$X_i^2 = 4$$, we need $$X_i = 2$$ and that occurs with probability $$\frac16$$. Plug back in, and you&#39;re good to go.</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:05:02</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1900</p>
<p>Folder: final</p>
<p>Title: Practice Problem 1b</p>
<article class="question">
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkszbaubtqi02n7%2F487d8cce269ad06b35596a198d3da8a69dc3f6bc0d8a33bd013bfa28cfae37f8%2FScreenshot_2022-12-20_at_12.17.46_PM.png" alt="Screenshot_2022-12-20_at_12.17.46_PM.pngNaN" width="419" height="93" /></p>
<p>Why is the geometric distribution&#39;s probability of success 2p(1-p)?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>$$Pr[HT] = p \cdot (1-p)$$. </p>
<p>$$Pr[TH] = (1-p) \cdot p$$</p>
<p></p>
<p>So $$Pr[HT \vee TH] = p\cdot (1-p) + (1-p) \cdot p = 2\cdot p \cdot (1-p)$$</p>
</article>
<p>Response Time: 0:01:35</p>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1901</p>
<p>Folder: final</p>
<p>Title: L12H</p>
<article class="question">
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7glbo5bn7z3hf%2F9bc084ac521b00f1931224aaf72b234ded902c47246cd690f427a9e22e40e09d%2Fimage.png" alt="image.png" /></p>
<p>I understand up until we remove an endpoint. Why do we do this and how does setting p=1/d give us the maximum?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
Removing an endpoint ensures that we have an independent set. You can find that p=1/d maximizes the quantity by taking the partial derivative with respect to p, and set that result equal to 0 and solve for p. We will not expect you to do something like this on the final.
</article>
<p>Response Time: 2:50:49</p>
<article class="question">
<p>Then why does S&#39; still have the same number of vertices left?</p>
</article>
<article class="answer">
The set S originally had np edges in expectation. The size of S’ is smaller than np.
</article>
</article>

<article class="general-box">
<p>Post: 1902</p>
<p>Folder: final</p>
<p>Title: Practice Problem 8</p>
<article class="question">
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkszbaubtqi02n7%2Fe77e3bafb936940610c13b73a853168952fb2fddb40bb87805249d425877779b%2FScreenshot_2022-12-20_at_2.11.48_PM.png" alt="Screenshot_2022-12-20_at_2.11.48_PM.pngNaN" width="399" height="262" /></p>

</article>
<article class="answer">
<p>Se @1899 for the first question. For the second question, $$\sum_{k=1}^11 k = 1 + 2 + 3 + ... + 11$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>The sum of the first $$n$$ positive integers is given by $$\frac{n \cdot (n+1)}{2}$$. So the sum is $$\frac{11 \cdot 12}{2}$$</p>
</article>

Piazza is a Q&A platform designed to get you great answers from classmates and instructors fast. We've put together this list of tips you might find handy as you get started:

<ol style="margin:0;padding:0;list-style-position:inside;"> <li style="margin:0;padding:0"><strong>Ask questions!</strong>

The best way to get answers is to ask questions! Ask questions on Piazza rather than emailing your teaching staff so everyone can benefit from the response (and so you can get answers from classmates who are up as late as you are).

</li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"><strong>Edit questions and answers wiki-style.</strong>

Think of Piazza as a Q&A wiki for your class. Every question has just a single <strong>students' answer</strong> that students can edit collectively (and a single <strong>instructors’ answer</strong> for instructors).

</li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>Add a followup to comment or ask further questions.</strong>

To comment on or ask further questions about a post, start a <strong>followup discussion</strong>. Mark it resolved when the issue has been addressed, and add any relevant information back into the Q&A above.

</li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>Go anonymous.</strong>

Shy? No problem. You can always opt to post or edit anonymously.

</li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>Tag your posts.</strong>

It's far more convenient to find all posts about your Homework 3 or Midterm 1 when the posts are tagged. Type a “#” before a key word to tag. Click a blue tag in a post or the question feed to filter for all posts that share that tag.

</li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>Format code and equations.</strong>

Adding a code snippet? Click the <strong>pre</strong> or <strong>tt</strong> button in the question editor to add pre-formatted or inline teletype text. 
Mathematical equation? Click the <strong>Fx</strong> button to access the LaTeX editor to build a nicely formatted equation.

</li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>View and download class details and resources.</strong> </li></ol>

Click the <strong>Course Page</strong> button in your top bar to access the class syllabus, staff contact information, office hours details, and course resources—all in one place!


Contact the Piazza Team anytime with questions or comments at <strong>team@piazza.com</strong>. We love feedback!

<md>Hi everyone and welcome to CIS 1600! The first homework will be posted later today, and as such we wanted to post the following information about office hours.

The important things to know are covered below, but for more detailed information about when office hours are, please consult the schedule found on the [course website](/cis1600.com).

Rajiv will host his office hours weekly on Tuesdays from 12-1PM as well as on Thursdays from 3-4PM in **Levine 512**.

The TAs will host all of their office hours in **Greenberg Lounge** (Skirkanich 114) Mondays, Tuesdays, and Wednesdays from 4-10PM, Thursdays from 4-6PM, and weekends from 12-2PM.

**Note:** For this coming week we have limited room availability in Greenberg Lounge due to Labor Day. As such, in person office hours will be available in Greenberg Lounge only on Tuesday from 8-10PM and Wednesday from 4-10PM. All other office hours posted on the course calendar will be conducted via Zoom (paste your zoom link in the question description)</md>
<p>Hi all,</p>
<p><br />Welcome to CIS 1600!</p>
<p><br />The first homework assignment is now available on the course website and will be due at 11:59 PM on Wednesday, August 31st. To submit the assignment, create <a target="_blank" href="https://www.gradescope.com/" rel="noopener noreferrer">a Gradescope account</a> and join our course (course code <b>E7VVGZ</b>). For all of the assignments, there is a strict policy on collaboration. <i>There is </i><b><i>no collaboration</i></b><i> on the homework assignments at all. The only materials you may reference when writing homework solutions are course materials (lecture notes, homework solutions, and recitation guides). </i></p>
<p></p>
<p><br />In CIS 1600, we require all homeworks to be typeset in<a target="_blank" href="https://www.latex-project.org/" rel="noopener noreferrer"> LaTeX</a> using the templates provided on the course website. We recommend using <a target="_blank" href="https://www.overleaf.com/" rel="noopener noreferrer">Overleaf</a>. One of our TAs Ishaan has recorded <a target="_blank" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vmQuOprb7Pc" rel="noopener noreferrer">a quick tutorial that should get you up to speed for working on homework 1T</a>, and we will do another overview in recitation this week. <b><i>For homework 1T only</i></b>, if you do not yet feel comfortable using LaTeX you may submit the homework problems as a <i>legible</i> PDF created however you feel most comfortable.  </p>
<p> </p>
<p dir="ltr">The first office hours are today from 4 PM to 10 PM. For a full list of office hours times and the location, see our website at <a target="_blank" href="http://cis1600.com/" rel="noopener noreferrer">cis1600.com</a>. See @6 for more infomation regarding Office Hours. </p>
<p> </p>
<p>Also released today is a short <i>graded</i> quiz on our course policies. The policies are all available at <a target="_blank" href="http://cis1600.com/" rel="noopener noreferrer">cis1600.com</a>, and the quiz just lets us know that you have read the course policies and understand what is and isn’t allowed when forming study groups with other students. <p>In problem 1, is there a difference between the statements &#34;The students want to make delicious pasta,&#34; and &#34;the students all want to make delicious pasta&#34; (from part b)?</p>
No. No difference.
<p>I want to confirm in question 2 part b that the first part of the proposition is supposed to say if p and not p.</p>
Yes. It is correct as written.
<p>Hi, I wonder how should I fill in my recitation number in the homework. Thanks.</p>
<p>In the template, you will see</p>
<pre>
\newcommand{\MyRecitation}{X}</pre>
<p>You should replace the X with your recitation number. For example, it could look something like this:</p>
<p></p>
<pre>
\newcommand{\MyRecitation}{202}</pre>
<p>For question one, do we have to distribute any expressions in parentheses or just leave them as is?</p>
<p>Either is fine.</p>
<p>How do we save our LaTeX file so that we can edit later (or does it autosave)?</p>
<p>The LaTeX file will auto-save on Overleaf.</p>
<p>For question 2a how am I supposed to state my final solution. In LaTeX when I create another &#34;\item&#34; after the first table, my answer has a &#34;(b)&#34; in front of it, and it offsets the next part of the question to (c) instead of (b)</p>
<p>You can write below the truth table and before part (b). So you can write in the space after the </p>
<pre>
\end{tabular}</pre>
<p>and before the</p>
<pre>
\item</pre>
<p>For Q3, do all the TAs have a single piece of pasta from the 5 total pieces?</p>
<p>Each of the TAs has exactly one piece of pasta. But each of those pieces of pasta come from the 5 total pieces.</p>
<p>Which symbol should we use for not: ˜ or ¬ ?</p>
<p>Either is fine, but in this class, we typically use $$\lnot$$</p>
<p>For necessary conditions should we write it as</p>
<p></p>
<p>¬p → ¬q or q → p</p>
<p></p>
<p>Or are both forms okay?</p>
<p>Any logically correct solution will receive credit.</p>

<p>just a question from lecture. if the empty set is always an element of a set, then why is it not counted in the cardinality of the set? like |{1,2,3}| = 3, not 4 because you don&#39;t count the empty set....</p>
<p>The empty set is <strong>not </strong>always an element of a set. For example, $$\emptyset \notin \{1, 2, 3\}$$ but $$\emptyset \in \{1, \emptyset\}$$. Perhaps you meant to be speaking about subsets (which is a bit different than just elements)!</p>
<p>Is there recitation this week?</p>
<p>yes</p>
<p>For problem 2a on the homework, are the 2 earrings in an &#34;earring pair&#34; necessarily identical?</p>
<p>Yes. The two earrings within a pair are identical.</p>
<p>In problem 1a iii) do y and z have to be different integers, or can they have the same value?</p>
<p>they can be the same!</p>
<p>In problem 1a iii) do y and z have to be different integers, or can they have the same value?</p>
<p>for the same problem, is zero in the set of positive integers?</p>
<p>In problem 1a iii) do y and z have to be different integers, or can they have the same value?</p>
No
<p>For problem 2, should the 7 grains of pasta in one earring be unique to each other or can there exist for example 2 linguine in one earing? Thanks.</p>
<p>they need not be unique. So an earring can have 2 linguini</p>
<p>for question 5, can two noodles of the same length be subtracted such that no new noodle is created (or noodle of length 0)</p>
<p>but can you use a noodle that has been created afterward?</p>
<p>for question 5, can two noodles of the same length be subtracted such that no new noodle is created (or noodle of length 0)</p>
<p>Yes, two noodles of the same length can be subtracted. In this case, we would remove those noodles and replace them with one noodle of length 0.</p>
<p>for question 5, can two noodles of the same length be subtracted such that no new noodle is created (or noodle of length 0)</p>
<p>i just want to clarify exactly what the question is asking. Is it asking whether Saurabh-violi can be sure that the final noodle will always be length 1 regardless of how the noodles are picked and subtracted?</p>
<p>for question 5, can two noodles of the same length be subtracted such that no new noodle is created (or noodle of length 0)</p>
<p>Does a noodle of length 0 still count as a noodle?</p>
<p>Can we leave our answers as a number to an exponent (say $$2^{17}$$), or do we need to calculate the exact numerical solution?</p>
<p>no need to reduce your answers to the exact value. So something like $$2^{17}$$ would be fine.</p>

<p>both earrings are the same within a pair.</p>
In question 4, does it mean that the colors can repeat for the vertical stripes but not the horizontal ones?
<p>Colors are allowed to repeat. As shown in the diagram, there are two black horizontal stripes (hence, in this case, the color black is repeated), and there are two red vertical stripes.</p>

For Q2, does F-P-P equal P-P-F?
<p>No. These would be considered different.</p>
<p>How can I type these i ii iii iiii in Latex?</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7ga3way2da7hz%2F76f3517ab03f9e17ff79873a2713802664f786266c7b3153f0348070ab1e1a83%2Fimage.png" alt="image.png" /></p>
<p>You get those from a &#34;nested enumeration&#34;. So something like this:</p>
<p></p>
<pre>
\begin{enumerate}
	\item 	this is a
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item 	this is i
		\item 	this is ii
		\item 	this is iii
		\item   this is iv
	\end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}</pre>

<p>you can include the braces.</p>

Correct

<p>You need to come up with a method to ensure that you have found the faulty fork. Keep in mind that if someone uses the faulty fork, they will lose their fingers at exactly 8:59.</p>

<p>sure, but you still need to come up with a method to assure that you have found the faulty fork.</p>

yeah

<p>In question 6 do we know the total number of dishes on the table?</p>
