<p>In question 6, what is the importance of there needing to be at least 1 meat dish and 1 veggie dish? Isn&#39;t it implied that a singular dish can&#39;t be a circle and that for there to be multiple meat dishes there needs to be multiple veggie dishes so the neighboring dishes are different types?</p>
The “importance” is somewhat subjective, I suppose. However, it is a critical piece of information for the problem. Think of it as a “constraint” on the set of all possible arrangements. How you choose to use this information is something we want you to think about, and something to argue in your solution/proof.
<p>In question 6, what is the importance of there needing to be at least 1 meat dish and 1 veggie dish? Isn&#39;t it implied that a singular dish can&#39;t be a circle and that for there to be multiple meat dishes there needs to be multiple veggie dishes so the neighboring dishes are different types?</p>
<p>Without the &#34;at least&#34; information, wouldn&#39;t the set all of arrangments still be the same? You can&#39;t have all meat or all veggie. What do you mean by contraint? </p>
<p>In question 6, what is the importance of there needing to be at least 1 meat dish and 1 veggie dish? Isn&#39;t it implied that a singular dish can&#39;t be a circle and that for there to be multiple meat dishes there needs to be multiple veggie dishes so the neighboring dishes are different types?</p>
Well the information about neighboring dishes being different can be considered as another “constraint”. What I mean by “constraint” is that we are limiting our view of all possible arrangements of dishes in a circle (i.e. we are looking at a “subset” of all possible arrangements ignoring the constraints)<p></p>
Can we use combinations in Q7 instead of the multiplication rule? Will I lose points?
And fully logically and mathematically correct solution will receive full credit no matter which techniques you use.
<p>How brief should we be with our justifications - should we err on the side of a thorough explanation or should we aim for a more concise explanation.</p>
<p>Giving advice on the length of justifications is tough. My general suggestion is to write as much to write enough to ensure that there are no large jumps in logic/mathematics in your solution. I guess the definition of &#34;large&#34; is different from person to person, so another way to approach this is that if you ever ask yourself the question &#34;should I explain this?&#34;, you should always assume the answer is yes. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Remember that any fully correct solution both mathematically and logically will receive full credit. So however long your proof is, as long as you fulfill the above, you should be good to go.</p>
<p>Is there an efficient timeframe needed to answer Q7? Or, in other words, would it be okay for the solution be realistically very time-consuming? </p>
<p>It differs from person to person. If you are finding the problem to be too challenging or time-consuming, it may be worthwhile to pay a visit to office hours to get some assistance from a TA.</p>
<p>Is there an efficient timeframe needed to answer Q7? Or, in other words, would it be okay for the solution be realistically very time-consuming? </p>
<p>To clarify what I meant - would it be okay for the solution to find the faulty fork to be very time-consuming for the TA&#39;s? </p>
<p>Is there an efficient timeframe needed to answer Q7? Or, in other words, would it be okay for the solution be realistically very time-consuming? </p>
<p>oh whoops, my apologies for the incorrect interpretation! But yes, it is totally okay for the solution to be time consuming, as long as it guarantees that they find the faulty fork.</p>

<p>hi im just a little bit confused on the difference between the set &#39;belongs to&#39; another set and the set is a &#39;subset&#39; of another set</p>
<p></p>
<p>so the &#39;belongs to&#39; for a set is only referring to one element and whether that element is present in the set,</p>
<p></p>
<p>while for the &#39;subset&#39; part it is when you consider a whole set and see if that whole set is within another set?</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>hi im just a little bit confused on the difference between the set &#39;belongs to&#39; another set and the set is a &#39;subset&#39; of another set</p>
<p></p>
<p>so the &#39;belongs to&#39; for a set is only referring to one element and whether that element is present in the set,</p>
<p></p>
<p>while for the &#39;subset&#39; part it is when you consider a whole set and see if that whole set is within another set?</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>Your definition for &#34;belongs to&#34; is correct.</p>
<p></p>
<p>One way of thinking about &#34;subset&#34; is &#34;A is a subset of B if every element of A is also an element of B&#34;. So for example, if $$A = \{1, 2\}$$ and $$B = \{1, 2, 3\}$$, then $$A \subseteq B$$, because every element of A is also an element of B. But if $$A = \{1, 4\}$$ and $$B = \{1, 2, 3\}$$ then $$A \nsubseteq B$$</p>
<p>ok that makes sense, i know for the set itself order does not matter, so for something to be considered a subset that order does not matter either as long as the elements are in the whole set</p>
<p>correct. So in my example, we can say $$\{1, 2\} \subseteq \{1, 2, 3\}$$ but it is also true that $$\{2, 1\} \subseteq \{1, 2, 3\}$$</p>
response time: -1 day, 23:26:54

<p>yeah</p>

<p>For question 7, does the fork testing end once? ie when the TAs are testing the forks, they won&#39;t know whether they&#39;ve used the faulty fork until 8:59am, and does this limit the number of forks each can test to be sure?</p>
<p>For question 7, does the fork testing end once? ie when the TAs are testing the forks, they won&#39;t know whether they&#39;ve used the faulty fork until 8:59am, and does this limit the number of forks each can test to be sure?</p>
Yes, they will not know whether they’ve used the faulty fork until 8:59. But there is no limit to the number of forks a TA can use.

<p>How is it possible for a nonset to have cardinality? If the only element of the empty set is nothing then how can you even calculate the cardinality of nothing since nothing isn&#39;t even a set?</p>
<p>I am posting this just to instructors since I do not want to give away the answer.</p>
<p></p>
<p>How is it possible for a nonset to have cardinality? If the only element of the empty set is nothing then how can you even calculate the cardinality of nothing since nothing isn&#39;t even a set?</p>
<p>Yes, we can only take cardinality of sets. Use that fact in conjunction with the other information you know about $$x$$ to come up with an answer! you seem to have a lot of the facts nailed down. It&#39;s just about piecing them together, and for that, use the fact that we only take cardinality of sets.</p>

<p>In the Lecture example: &#34;How many odd numbers between 1000 and 9999 have distinct digits?&#34; </p>
<p>why does the multiplication rule still apply? For example, the number of ways performing step 4 depends upon whether a zero was chosen in the earlier steps.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Also in the president, secretary, treasurer question, the solution says multiplication rule does not apply because outcome of prior step changes later # outcomes. What&#39;s the logic that distinguishes the approaches to these two questions? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Is it that in a question in which there are multiple ways of performing the steps, only one sequence of steps allows multiplication rule to be applied and other sequences of events do not? thank you.</p>
<p>In the Lecture example: &#34;How many odd numbers between 1000 and 9999 have distinct digits?&#34; </p>
<p>why does the multiplication rule still apply? For example, the number of ways performing step 4 depends upon whether a zero was chosen in the earlier steps.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Also in the president, secretary, treasurer question, the solution says multiplication rule does not apply because outcome of prior step changes later # outcomes. What&#39;s the logic that distinguishes the approaches to these two questions? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Is it that in a question in which there are multiple ways of performing the steps, only one sequence of steps allows multiplication rule to be applied and other sequences of events do not? thank you.</p>
<p>Note that only Attempt 3 shows a correct solution for the &#34;odd numbers&#34; question. In that attempt, we can see that we will not select the number zero in steps 1 and 2. Only the second digit and the third digit can be zeroes, which is why they are placed last in our ordering of steps. But these steps also acknowledge the fact that, for example, the second digit cannot be the same as the first or fourth digit (whose digits have already been chosen), which is why there are 10 - 2 = 8 ways to perform step 3. And similar logic holds for step 4.</p>
<p></p>
<p>I&#39;m not sure I completely understand your second question, but I&#39;ll try my best to give some information that may clear things up. Steps within your process that you develop for counting CAN depend on each other, but we can only perform MR when each step has a CONSTANT number of ways of being performed. For example, in attempt 1 of the &#34;secretary&#34; question, the third step can be performed in 2 ways if, for example, Bob is President and Ann is Treasurer, 1 way if, for example, Bob is president and Clyde is secretary, or 0 ways if, for example, Clyde is president and Dan is secretary. Since this is NOT a constant value, the MR can&#39;t really be used.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Whereas, in attempt 2, since we chose the secretary first, the remaining two steps always have the same constant number of people to choose from.</p>
<p></p>
<p>For your last question, no. There can be many ways of ordering the steps. You just need to be sure that the ordering of the steps meets the above rule of that constant value for each step.</p>
<p></p>
<p>hope that made a bit of sense!</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
response time: 0:10:18



<p><strong>What does two stripes that have the same color cannot share a long edge means?</strong></p>
<p><strong>What does two stripes that have the same color cannot share a long edge means?</strong></p>
<p>You cannot have two adjacent stripes with the same color IF they share a long edge. Each stripe is a rectangle, and &#34;long edge&#34; refers to the long side of the rectangle.</p>
response time: 0:00:56

<p>For all the questions that require justification is just a verbal explanation sufficient for justification? Or do we need mathematical proofs, diagrams, etc?</p>
<p>Any sort of proof/justification is allowed as long as it is both logically and mathematically sound and correct.</p>

<p>I have a question about set builder notation. <br /><br />Is the following valid for the squares of the integers greater than 1 and less than 10:<br />$$\{x^2\mid x\in \mathbb{Z}^+ \land 1<x<10\}$$<br /><br />Or, can I not put $$x^2$$ before the pipe and I need to do this?:<br />$$\{x\mid y\in \mathbb{Z}^+ \land 1<y<10\:s.t.\:x=y^2\}$$<br /><br />Or, is there some other way I need to do this?</p>
<p>I have a question about set builder notation. <br /><br />Is the following valid for the squares of the integers greater than 1 and less than 10:<br />$$\{x^2\mid x\in \mathbb{Z}^+ \land 1<x<10\}$$<br /><br />Or, can I not put $$x^2$$ before the pipe and I need to do this?:<br />$$\{x\mid y\in \mathbb{Z}^+ \land 1<y<10\:s.t.\:x=y^2\}$$<br /><br />Or, is there some other way I need to do this?</p>

For this question, is there a way to denote previous members of the set that you are trying to describe, like x1. This question seems recursive, so not sure how to &#34;access&#34; previous calculated x values in the set if that makes sense.
For this question, is there a way to denote previous members of the set that you are trying to describe, like x1. This question seems recursive, so not sure how to &#34;access&#34; previous calculated x values in the set if that makes sense.
<p>You should avoid doing this for sets. This is because sets are an unordered collection of values. For something like sequences (which is something we don&#39;t cover in this class), the elements have order and we can use a recursive definition.</p>
lets say we have set 2, 5, 10. Could I then just do something like x = y&#43;1 where y is a set {1, 4, 9}? I guess I&#39;m struggling how to define the given set mathematically because the numbers reference each other in their calculation.
<p>You wouldn&#39;t be able to do x = y &#43; 1 where y is that set, however, what is special about the set {1, 4, 9}? Maybe you could express that some other way.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Given my suggestion of avoiding the &#34;recursive&#34; definition, it may be helpful to try to think about a different way to define the set!</p>

In one of the lecture problems today where <div>A = {2, 2^2, 2^3,…}</div><div>B = {2, 4, 6, …}</div><div>and we have to prove that A is an improper subset of B,</div><div><br /></div><div>Professor Gandhi’s solution was this:</div><div>Let x be an arb. part. element of A where  x = 2^k </div><div>but then proceeded with: there exists a k belonging to a positive integer, s.t. x = 2*2^(k-1)</div><div><br /></div><div>in order to prove that x = 2l, where l = 2^(k-1) where l is a positive integer</div><div>what makes the “k-1” component necessary? Is setting k as a positive integer greater than but not equal to 1 a valid alternative?</div><div>thank you.</div>
In one of the lecture problems today where <div>A = {2, 2^2, 2^3,…}</div><div>B = {2, 4, 6, …}</div><div>and we have to prove that A is an improper subset of B,</div><div><br /></div><div>Professor Gandhi’s solution was this:</div><div>Let x be an arb. part. element of A where  x = 2^k </div><div>but then proceeded with: there exists a k belonging to a positive integer, s.t. x = 2*2^(k-1)</div><div><br /></div><div>in order to prove that x = 2l, where l = 2^(k-1) where l is a positive integer</div><div>what makes the “k-1” component necessary? Is setting k as a positive integer greater than but not equal to 1 a valid alternative?</div><div>thank you.</div>
<p>No, we can&#39;t quite say that $$k > 1$$ because it overlooks the case where $$x = 2$$. Since $$2 \in A$$, it can be possible that we let $$x = 2$$, and in this case, we would have $$k = 1$$. </p>
ohh then how about setting k as a positive integer greater than or equal to 1? That would solve having to include x=2. Just don’t see where the k-1 comes from.<p></p>
<p>Yes, that would be the more accurate constraint on $$k$$.</p>

<p>I&#39;m a bit confused on the wording regarding the 59 shades and the 12 disjoint pairs of lipsticks. Does each of the 59 shades individually have 12 disjoint pairs of lipsticks, meaning altogether there are 59 * 12 disjoint pairs of lipsticks? Or do all 59 shades together have 12 disjoint pairs of lipsticks (but then I&#39;m not sure why we would need to know the number of shades)? And for each disjoint pair, does &#34;disjoint&#34; imply that all the variants of green and orange are unique / do not repeat across the pairs? Do the variants have any connection to the number of shades? </p>
<p>You can think of it as there are 59 lipsticks, each a different shade. Within the 59, there are 12 disjoint pairs that satisfy the criteria. </p>
<p></p>
<p>&#34;Disjoint pairs&#34; mean that if lipstick A is in one pair, then A cannot be in another pair that contributes to the 12 total pairs.</p>

<p>In the lecture from k ∈ N it is determined that k &#43; 2 ∈ N. Can we make such assumptions without a proof in the hwk like in 1b?</p>
<p>In the lecture from k ∈ N it is determined that k &#43; 2 ∈ N. Can we make such assumptions without a proof in the hwk like in 1b?</p>
<p>yes</p>
<p>So even when we are transitioning from N to Z&#43; for example, we can just write that some expression with t in it is in Z&#43; with no explanation?</p>
<p>Well not quite. The reason we can say that if $$k \in \mathbb{N}$$ then $$k+2 \in \mathbb{N}$$ is because $$\mathbb{N}$$ is closed under addition. Since in your example, we are transitioning from $$\mathbb{N}$$ to $$\mathbb{Z^+}$$, we can&#39;t quite use the same reason, because they are different sets. The good news, however, is that you can usually write an explanation within a sentence or two!</p>
<p>So even when we are transitioning from N to Z&#43; for example, we can just write that some expression with t in it is in Z&#43; with no explanation?</p>
<p>Can we assume that if t does not have an upper bound then expressions like t&#43;5, t-7 etc. also do not have an upper bound?</p>
<p>So even when we are transitioning from N to Z&#43; for example, we can just write that some expression with t in it is in Z&#43; with no explanation?</p>
<p>no, this would be something that you would have to justify.</p>

<p>When disproving universal claims via counterexample, if I &#34;guessed and checked&#34; and found a counterexample out of luck/intuition, is it fine to say that I happened to find a counterexample, which disproved the claim? Or should I still resort to breaking down the claim into basic parts? (Example: the claim is that all (odd &#43; even) yields even integers. if I just try 3 &#43; 6 = 9, I have already found a counterexample. but I don&#39;t know if &#34;guessing and checking&#34; is a rigorous purpose for finding the counterexample, so should I go further and rewrite odd &#43; even with their definitions (2k &#43; 1) and (2m) and show how you always get an odd integer from 2(k &#43; m) &#43; 1, hence breaking the claim into basic parts?)</p>
<p></p>
<p>Maybe what I&#39;m really wondering is if I should reduce every claim to basic parts for every proof, or if disproving by counterexample is not strong enough.</p>

<p>Would it be true that given two sets A and B,  A \ B is equal to all of the elements in A minus the elements of A intersection B?</p>

<p>Yes, $$A \setminus (A \cap B)$$ would be good notation, and as Andrew said, $$A \setminus B = A \setminus (A \cap B)$$</p>
<p>Would it be ok to say that these are equal in the homework without any justification? i.e. would we have to prove it somehow before using it?</p>
<p>It would be nice to justify why this is true.</p>

<p>Can you expand intersection statements? For example is S∩(T-T∩R) = S∩T - S∩T∩R?</p>

<md>Hi all,  
  
Now that some of the exercises require mathematical expressions as answers, we need to clarify what forms of answer are acceptable.  
  
In CIS 1600, all final expressions (to questions requiring mathematical expressions as answers) should be in closed form unless explicitly stated otherwise. A closed form expression is essentially a term which can be evaluated in a fixed finite number of operations. For reference, many terms we will encounter are in closed form: $$12$$, $$x^2+1$$, $$k!$$,  $$2n$$, $$\binom{n}{k}$$, $$\sum_{i = 1}^{5} i^2$$.  
  
The most likely exceptions you will encounter are summations or products whose bounds are variables. For example, $$\sum_{i = 1}^{n} (2i - 1)$$ or $$1+3+5+⋯+(2n−1)$$ would not be considered closed form, since we have a variable bound $$n$$ (the number of terms we are adding is not fixed). However, the equivalent value $$n^2$$ is closed form (we haven’t yet proven this equality, so you can’t use this post as justification if we ask for this identity, but we will likely do so in due time). Similarly, if you have nested summations, e.g. $$\sum_{i = 1}^{100} \sum_{k = 1}^{i} k$$, we would not consider this closed form since the inner summation has variable bounds.  
  
Furthermore, if you simplify an open form expression to a closed form expression, you must prove their equivalence using only material we have learned in this course. We generally strongly advise against this as it almost always entails unnecessarily complex justification. All problems in this course can be answered without doing this.  
  
We require closed form for full credit, even if it is not explicitly asked for (we will try to include a reminder in most cases where an open form solution is viable). In general, if you’re not sure whether something is closed form, feel free to ask on Piazza (as always, if you’re worried about possibly giving away too much, you can post privately) or in office hours!

#pin</md>
Is listing one case that contradicts the statement sufficient as a proof?
Is listing one case that contradicts the statement sufficient as a proof?
<p>This would be a counterexample. When to use counterexamples is something you should think about!</p>

Venn diagrams will not suffice for a proof. They are good, however, for gaining initial intuition.
<p>Is proving section-by-section (as in a Venn diagram) acceptable for a proof then? </p>
<p>I think this should be acceptable so long as your case-work is exhaustive. Though this often proves to be a long and arduous process, especially compared to other equality proof techniques.</p>

For Q3, is there a difference between these two scenarios?<div><br /></div><div>contestant A has Orange, blue, black</div><div>contestant B has white, gray, purple</div><div>contestant C has green, brown</div><div><br /></div><div>contestant A has Orange, black, blue</div><div>contestant B has green, gray, purple</div><div>contestant C has white, brown</div><div><br /></div><div>although the contestants a, b, and c have 3, 3, 2 cars, respectively?</div>
<p>1. <strong>Lectures/Recitations</strong>: Please come to the lectures/recitations and don&#39;t hesitate to ask/answer questions in class. If you give an answer and if it is correct then you probably understand the material and if your answer is incorrect then it&#39;s good too as it not only gives you an opportunity to understand your mistake but also you will most likely not make the mistake in a homework or an exam.  Also, understand as much as you can in class as it will save you time outside of class and this is especially important in this course due to the fast-paced nature of the course. The sooner you lose the inhibition of speaking up in class, the better it is for you as then you can speak up in other classes too and overall this will help you get more out of the lectures in your courses.<br /><br />2. <strong>Recreating/Summarizing lectures:</strong> Soon after each lecture, try to re-create/summarize the lecture (repeating the lecture as if you are teaching someone and without looking at the notes). Note that each lecture introduces one or two key concepts and assuming that you understood what was covered in class, you should not have too much trouble re-creating what was covered. While doing so, try to figure out how you would solve the questions independently and if you have a different solution which is correct then that&#39;s great as you will then know a different way to solve the problem and more importantly, since you did it on your own, you are less likely to forget it. If your solution is not correct then it will help to understand your mistakes. <br /><br />3. <strong>Collaboration</strong>:  Please remember that unless specified otherwise,  absolutely no collaboration is allowed in homeworks. Like many other things in life, in this course, you will learn by<br />doing things on your own and not by watching others do it. You may not get a perfect score in the homeworks, but you will learn from working hard on the homework problems and that will prepare you well for the exams.  Note that you are strongly encouraged to collaborate to understand a concept.  You may want to present some lecture material to your study partner(s) and let them ask you hard questions when you are presenting the lecture or say, a solution to a homework (whose deadline has passed) solution. <br /><br />4. <strong>Homeworks</strong>: Start thinking on homework questions as soon as the homework is released. Some problems may take time and it will help if you get started early. Keep mulling on the problems while doing other chores.  Ideas will come at unexpected times, but a necessary condition for that to happen is that you have to keep thinking about the problem. Help is available -- CIS 160 staff is there to help you and we are more inclined to help if we see that you have already thought about the problem.</p>
<p></p>
<p>5. <strong>Typing up solutions</strong>: We strongly encourage you to type up your homework solutions soon after you think you have solved the question. It<br />happens many times that one finds mistakes when writing the solutions, so this will give you more time to fix your mistakes, if any. Also, spreading out the work of writing over a few days can save you a lot of time on the day/night before the homework is due. In short, don&#39;t leave typing the solutions until the very end.</p>
<p></p>
<p>6. <strong>History: </strong>If you are worried about how you will do in CIS 160, keep in mind that each year about 500 students complete CIS 160 successfully and eventually end up having great careers. You will too!</p>
<p></p>

<p>Hi, </p>
<p></p>
<p>For the following question done in the last lecture, why can we not do 26^4 - 25^4?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Question: How many strings are there of four lowercase letters that have the letter x in them? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Thanks, </p>
<p>Hi, </p>
<p></p>
<p>For the following question done in the last lecture, why can we not do 26^4 - 25^4?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Question: How many strings are there of four lowercase letters that have the letter x in them? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Thanks, </p>
<p>$$26^4 - 25^4$$ is the correct answer.</p>
<p>The lecture notes said the answer should be 4 x 26^3.</p>
<p>That solution is meant to be the one referenced by the &#34;Incorrect Solution&#34; note.</p>
<p>The lecture notes said the answer should be 4 x 26^3.</p>
<p>Ahh! Thanks!</p>
<p>The lecture notes said the answer should be 4 x 26^3.</p>
<p>Can you explain why 4 · 26^3 is incorrect? </p>
<p>The lecture notes said the answer should be 4 x 26^3.</p>
<p>Sure. The procedure to get this answer is as follows:</p>
<p> </p>
<p>Step 1: Choose one spot to place the x</p>
<p>Step 2: Choose a letter for one of the remaining spots</p>
<p>Step 3: Choose a letter for one of the remaining spots</p>
<p>Step 4: Choose a letter for the last available spot.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Let&#39;s consider two <strong>distinct</strong> &#34;paths&#34; through this procedure.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Suppose in step 1, I place the x in the first slot. Now, in step 2, let&#39;s suppose we are looking at the second slot, and suppose we happen to choose the letter x for that slot as well. In step 3, suppose we place a y in the third slot. And suppose in step 4, we place a z in the last slot. Then the string we have constructed is &#34;xxyz&#34;.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Now, suppose in step 1, I place the x in the <strong>second</strong> slot. Now, in step 2, we find an available slot and choose a letter for it. So suppose we look at the first slot and happen to choose the letter x. In step 3, suppose we place a y in the third slot. And suppose in step 4, we place a z in the last slot. Then the string we have constructed is again &#34;xxyz&#34;.<br /><br />So we see that we have constructed the same string twice by following <strong>distinct </strong>&#34;paths&#34; in the procedure. This is an indication that we have overcounted, and the answer is incorrect.</p>
response time: 0:06:21

How is the spacing between the n special points? Are the points evenly spaced or randomly spaced? <br /><div><div><br /></div></div>
How is the spacing between the n special points? Are the points evenly spaced or randomly spaced? <br /><div><div><br /></div></div>
<p>They are arranged in a way so as to not have multiple lines intersecting at the same point. So to answer your question, they are neither evenly spaced (because this would lead to multiple lines intersecting at the same point) nor are they randomly spaced (because this does not guarantee avoiding multiple lines intersecting at the same point).</p>

In one of the other questions, I saw that you can disprove a statement using one counterexample; does that also apply for disproving a set equality? I.e. If I wanna prove A = B have to prove that A and B are subsets of each other, then if I found one case in A \subseteq B where this isn’t true, is it sufficiently proving that A ≠ B? thanks.
In one of the other questions, I saw that you can disprove a statement using one counterexample; does that also apply for disproving a set equality? I.e. If I wanna prove A = B have to prove that A and B are subsets of each other, then if I found one case in A \subseteq B where this isn’t true, is it sufficiently proving that A ≠ B? thanks.
<p>Yes, showing $$A \nsubseteq B$$ would prove that $$A \neq B$$. Often, the easiest way to do this is to find some $$x \in A$$ such that $$x \notin B$$.</p>

<p>Hi, I was wondering how question 3 from the homework would be different if the cars were indistinguishable. I&#39;m thinking that it would be 8 choose 3, but I&#39;m not too sure. Could I please get some insight? Thank you!</p>
<p>Hi, I was wondering how question 3 from the homework would be different if the cars were indistinguishable. I&#39;m thinking that it would be 8 choose 3, but I&#39;m not too sure. Could I please get some insight? Thank you!</p>
<p>As an example, suppose three of the cars are called $$A$$, $$B$$ and $$C$$ (distinguishable), and suppose the three interests are called $$x$$, $$y$$, and $$z$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Then one possible distribution of these cars would be $$A$$ to $$x$$, $$B$$ to $$y$$ and $$C$$ to $$z$$. But clearly, there are many more ways to distribute the cars.</p>
<p></p>
<p>If, however, the cars were indistinguishable, then we could all give them the same name of $$A$$. And the <span style="text-decoration:underline">only</span> way to distribute the cars now would be $$A$$ to $$x$$, $$A$$ to $$y$$ and $$A$$ to $$z$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>As a reminder, <strong>ALL</strong> eight cars must be distributed amongst his interests.</p>
<p>Oh, interesting. The way in which i was doing it I don&#39;t think all the cars were being distributed?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Here&#39;s the procedure that I created for indistinguishable:</p>
<p></p>
<p>Contestant 1 gets a car: 8 possibilites</p>
<p>Contestant 2 gets a car: 8 possibilites</p>
<p>Contestant 3 gets a car: 8 possibilites</p>
<p></p>
<p>Contestant 1 gets 0 cars: 8^2 possibilites</p>
<p>Contestant 2 gets 0 cars: 8^2 possibilites</p>
<p>Contestant 3 gets 0 cars: 8^2 possibilites</p>
<p></p>
<p>Contestant 1 gets all cars: 1 possibility</p>
<p>Contestant 2 gets all cars: 1 possibility</p>
<p>Contestant 3 gets all cars: 1 possibility</p>
<p></p>
<p>So the total ways would be 8^3 - (3 x 8^2 - 3)?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Unfortunately, we cannot comment on the correctness of your solution/answer. However, if you have any doubts regarding the problem and/or your solution, then it would be a good idea to go to office hours to speak with a TA in person!</p>
<p>Oh, interesting. The way in which i was doing it I don&#39;t think all the cars were being distributed?</p>

<p></p>
<p>Contestant 1 gets a car: 8 possibilites</p>
<p>Contestant 2 gets a car: 8 possibilites</p>
<p>Contestant 3 gets a car: 8 possibilites</p>
<p></p>

<p>Contestant 2 gets 0 cars: 8^2 possibilites</p>

<p>For Q1, while proving by contradiction, could I also use an *example to show that the premises contradict each other? Or do I have to use some generalized procedures each time I prove by contradiction?</p>
<p></p>
<p>**To clarify, in class we proved that if 3n &#43; 2 is odd then n is odd is true by contradiction, where we assumed that 3n &#43; 2 is odd and n is even. We used some generalized procedures to show the premises contradict. However, could we have also said &#34;Let n = 2, 3(2) &#43; 2 = 8, which is even, so the premise that 3n &#43; 2 is odd is contradicted, so we proved the original claim to be true&#34;?</p>
<p>Do I have to prove why the sign changes when I divide/multiply by a negative number in an inequality? </p>
<p>Do I have to prove why the sign changes when I divide/multiply by a negative number in an inequality? </p>
<p>no</p>

<p>Is (S \cap T) - R = ((S - R) \cap (T - R)) a DeMorgan&#39;s Law? Can we use it by definition?</p>
<p>Is (S \cap T) - R = ((S - R) \cap (T - R)) a DeMorgan&#39;s Law? Can we use it by definition?</p>
<p>This is not considered to be one of De Morgan&#39;s Laws, so you would have to prove it to use it.</p>

<p>For question 1, am I allowed to use normal algebra to solve the inequality $$x<\frac{1}{x}$$ to get $$x\in(-\infty,-1)\cup(0,1)$$?</p>
<p></p>
<p>In other words, how much of high school algebra do I need to prove? Can I say something like $$x^2>1 \implies |x|>1$$ without explanation?</p>
<p>For question 1, am I allowed to use normal algebra to solve the inequality $$x<\frac{1}{x}$$ to get $$x\in(-\infty,-1)\cup(0,1)$$?</p>
<p></p>
<p>In other words, how much of high school algebra do I need to prove? Can I say something like $$x^2>1 \implies |x|>1$$ without explanation?</p>
<p>Yeah, you can say $$x^2 > 1 \implies |x| > 1$$ without explanation. Most algebraic steps can be done without proof.</p>

If d&lt;0 and t&gt;0 we get dt &lt; 0. Multiplying an inequality by dt means that we are multiplying it by a negative value. According to the general rules of inequality, if we multiply an inequality with a negative value, then the inequality sign changes/reverses. This is not something that was discussed in the lecture but I want to use it for my hw solution. Do I have to prove this too?
If d&lt;0 and t&gt;0 we get dt &lt; 0. Multiplying an inequality by dt means that we are multiplying it by a negative value. According to the general rules of inequality, if we multiply an inequality with a negative value, then the inequality sign changes/reverses. This is not something that was discussed in the lecture but I want to use it for my hw solution. Do I have to prove this too?
<p>no</p>
response time: 0:00:29



<p>For Q1, do we need to state anything about t being negative/positive? The question only asks about d.</p>
<p>For Q1, do we need to state anything about t being negative/positive? The question only asks about d.</p>
<p>This is something we&#39;d like you to think about. While you are proving that $$d < -1$$, you also know that $$t \in \mathbb{R} \setminus \{0\}$$. How you choose to handle this is up to you (and your solution).</p>
response time: 0:02:14

<p>the inequality sign doesnt flip when you divide or multiply by a positive number right</p>

Piazza is a Q&A platform designed to get you great answers from classmates and instructors fast. We've put together this list of tips you might find handy as you get started:

<ol style="margin:0;padding:0;list-style-position:inside;"> <li style="margin:0;padding:0"><strong>Ask questions!</strong>

The best way to get answers is to ask questions! Ask questions on Piazza rather than emailing your teaching staff so everyone can benefit from the response (and so you can get answers from classmates who are up as late as you are).

</li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"><strong>Edit questions and answers wiki-style.</strong>

Think of Piazza as a Q&A wiki for your class. Every question has just a single <strong>students' answer</strong> that students can edit collectively (and a single <strong>instructors’ answer</strong> for instructors).

</li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>Add a followup to comment or ask further questions.</strong>

To comment on or ask further questions about a post, start a <strong>followup discussion</strong>. Mark it resolved when the issue has been addressed, and add any relevant information back into the Q&A above.

</li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>Go anonymous.</strong>

Shy? No problem. You can always opt to post or edit anonymously.

</li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>Tag your posts.</strong>

It's far more convenient to find all posts about your Homework 3 or Midterm 1 when the posts are tagged. Type a “#” before a key word to tag. Click a blue tag in a post or the question feed to filter for all posts that share that tag.

</li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>Format code and equations.</strong>

Adding a code snippet? Click the <strong>pre</strong> or <strong>tt</strong> button in the question editor to add pre-formatted or inline teletype text. 
Mathematical equation? Click the <strong>Fx</strong> button to access the LaTeX editor to build a nicely formatted equation.

</li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>View and download class details and resources.</strong> </li></ol>

Click the <strong>Course Page</strong> button in your top bar to access the class syllabus, staff contact information, office hours details, and course resources—all in one place!


Contact the Piazza Team anytime with questions or comments at <strong>team@piazza.com</strong>. We love feedback!
<script type="text/javascript">PA.load("/dashboard/tips_tricks", null, function(data){ $('#' + 'questionText').html(data);});</script>
<script type="text/javascript">PA.load("/dashboard/get_familiar", null, function(data){ $('#' + 'questionText').html(data);});</script>
<script type="text/javascript">PA.load("/dashboard/introduce_piazza", null, function(data){ $('#' + 'questionText').html(data);});</script>

<md>Hi everyone and welcome to CIS 1600! The first homework will be posted later today, and as such we wanted to post the following information about office hours.

The important things to know are covered below, but for more detailed information about when office hours are, please consult the schedule found on the [course website](/cis1600.com).

Rajiv will host his office hours weekly on Tuesdays from 12-1PM as well as on Thursdays from 3-4PM in **Levine 512**.

The TAs will host all of their office hours in **Greenberg Lounge** (Skirkanich 114) Mondays, Tuesdays, and Wednesdays from 4-10PM, Thursdays from 4-6PM, and weekends from 12-2PM.

**Note:** For this coming week we have limited room availability in Greenberg Lounge due to Labor Day. As such, in person office hours will be available in Greenberg Lounge only on Tuesday from 8-10PM and Wednesday from 4-10PM. All other office hours posted on the course calendar will be conducted via Zoom (paste your zoom link in the question description)</md>
<p>Hi all,</p>
<p><br />Welcome to CIS 1600!</p>
<p><br />The first homework assignment is now available on the course website and will be due at 11:59 PM on Wednesday, August 31st. To submit the assignment, create <a target="_blank" href="https://www.gradescope.com/" rel="noopener noreferrer">a Gradescope account</a> and join our course (course code <b>E7VVGZ</b>). For all of the assignments, there is a strict policy on collaboration. <i>There is </i><b><i>no collaboration</i></b><i> on the homework assignments at all. The only materials you may reference when writing homework solutions are course materials (lecture notes, homework solutions, and recitation guides). </i></p>
<p></p>
<p><br />In CIS 1600, we require all homeworks to be typeset in<a target="_blank" href="https://www.latex-project.org/" rel="noopener noreferrer"> LaTeX</a> using the templates provided on the course website. We recommend using <a target="_blank" href="https://www.overleaf.com/" rel="noopener noreferrer">Overleaf</a>. One of our TAs Ishaan has recorded <a target="_blank" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vmQuOprb7Pc" rel="noopener noreferrer">a quick tutorial that should get you up to speed for working on homework 1T</a>, and we will do another overview in recitation this week. <b><i>For homework 1T only</i></b>, if you do not yet feel comfortable using LaTeX you may submit the homework problems as a <i>legible</i> PDF created however you feel most comfortable.  </p>
<p> </p>
<p dir="ltr">The first office hours are today from 4 PM to 10 PM. For a full list of office hours times and the location, see our website at <a target="_blank" href="http://cis1600.com/" rel="noopener noreferrer">cis1600.com</a>. See @6 for more infomation regarding Office Hours. </p>
<p> </p>
<p>Also released today is a short <i>graded</i> quiz on our course policies. The policies are all available at <a target="_blank" href="http://cis1600.com/" rel="noopener noreferrer">cis1600.com</a>, and the quiz just lets us know that you have read the course policies and understand what is and isn’t allowed when forming study groups with other students. This quiz is also due Wednesday at 11:59 pm, but if you are reading this after joining the course late, we have enabled late submissions with no penalty.</p>
<p> </p>
<p>Finally, we hope that everyone will have a great semester, and we look forward to interacting with all of you in person :)<br /><br /></p>

<p>In problem 1, is there a difference between the statements &#34;The students want to make delicious pasta,&#34; and &#34;the students all want to make delicious pasta&#34; (from part b)?</p>
No. No difference.
<p>I want to confirm in question 2 part b that the first part of the proposition is supposed to say if p and not p.</p>
Yes. It is correct as written.
<p>Hi, I wonder how should I fill in my recitation number in the homework. Thanks.</p>
<p>In the template, you will see</p>
<pre>
\newcommand{\MyRecitation}{X}</pre>
<p>You should replace the X with your recitation number. For example, it could look something like this:</p>
<p></p>
<pre>
\newcommand{\MyRecitation}{202}</pre>
<p>For question one, do we have to distribute any expressions in parentheses or just leave them as is?</p>
<p>Either is fine.</p>
<p>How do we save our LaTeX file so that we can edit later (or does it autosave)?</p>
<p>The LaTeX file will auto-save on Overleaf.</p>
<p>For question 2a how am I supposed to state my final solution. In LaTeX when I create another &#34;\item&#34; after the first table, my answer has a &#34;(b)&#34; in front of it, and it offsets the next part of the question to (c) instead of (b)</p>
<p>You can write below the truth table and before part (b). So you can write in the space after the </p>
<pre>
\end{tabular}</pre>
<p>and before the</p>
<pre>
\item</pre>
<p>For Q3, do all the TAs have a single piece of pasta from the 5 total pieces?</p>
<p>Each of the TAs has exactly one piece of pasta. But each of those pieces of pasta come from the 5 total pieces.</p>
<p>Which symbol should we use for not: ˜ or ¬ ?</p>
<p>Either is fine, but in this class, we typically use $$\lnot$$</p>

<p></p>
<p>¬p → ¬q or q → p</p>

<p dir="ltr"><strong>Q1:</strong></p>

<p>just a question from lecture. if the empty set is always an element of a set, then why is it not counted in the cardinality of the set? like |{1,2,3}| = 3, not 4 because you don&#39;t count the empty set....</p>
<p>The empty set is <strong>not </strong>always an element of a set. For example, $$\emptyset \notin \{1, 2, 3\}$$ but $$\emptyset \in \{1, \emptyset\}$$. Perhaps you meant to be speaking about subsets (which is a bit different than just elements)!</p>

<p>How can I type these i ii iii iiii in Latex?</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7ga3way2da7hz%2F76f3517ab03f9e17ff79873a2713802664f786266c7b3153f0348070ab1e1a83%2Fimage.png" alt="image.png" /></p>
<p>You get those from a &#34;nested enumeration&#34;. So something like this:</p>
<p></p>
<pre>
\begin{enumerate}
	\item 	this is a
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item 	this is i
		\item 	this is ii
		\item 	this is iii
		\item   this is iv
	\end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}</pre>

<p>In question 6, what is the importance of there needing to be at least 1 meat dish and 1 veggie dish? Isn&#39;t it implied that a singular dish can&#39;t be a circle and that for there to be multiple meat dishes there needs to be multiple veggie dishes so the neighboring dishes are different types?</p>
The “importance” is somewhat subjective, I suppose. However, it is a critical piece of information for the problem. Think of it as a “constraint” on the set of all possible arrangements. How you choose to use this information is something we want you to think about, and something to argue in your solution/proof.
<p>In question 6, what is the importance of there needing to be at least 1 meat dish and 1 veggie dish? Isn&#39;t it implied that a singular dish can&#39;t be a circle and that for there to be multiple meat dishes there needs to be multiple veggie dishes so the neighboring dishes are different types?</p>
<p>Without the &#34;at least&#34; information, wouldn&#39;t the set all of arrangments still be the same? You can&#39;t have all meat or all veggie. What do you mean by contraint? </p>
<p>In question 6, what is the importance of there needing to be at least 1 meat dish and 1 veggie dish? Isn&#39;t it implied that a singular dish can&#39;t be a circle and that for there to be multiple meat dishes there needs to be multiple veggie dishes so the neighboring dishes are different types?</p>
Well the information about neighboring dishes being different can be considered as another “constraint”. What I mean by “constraint” is that we are limiting our view of all possible arrangements of dishes in a circle (i.e. we are looking at a “subset” of all possible arrangements ignoring the constraints)<p></p>
Can we use combinations in Q7 instead of the multiplication rule? Will I lose points?
And fully logically and mathematically correct solution will receive full credit no matter which techniques you use.
<p>How brief should we be with our justifications - should we err on the side of a thorough explanation or should we aim for a more concise explanation.</p>
<p>Giving advice on the length of justifications is tough. My general suggestion is to write as much to write enough to ensure that there are no large jumps in logic/mathematics in your solution. I guess the definition of &#34;large&#34; is different from person to person, so another way to approach this is that if you ever ask yourself the question &#34;should I explain this?&#34;, you should always assume the answer is yes. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Remember that any fully correct solution both mathematically and logically will receive full credit. So however long your proof is, as long as you fulfill the above, you should be good to go.</p>
<p>Is there an efficient timeframe needed to answer Q7? Or, in other words, would it be okay for the solution be realistically very time-consuming? </p>
<p>It differs from person to person. If you are finding the problem to be too challenging or time-consuming, it may be worthwhile to pay a visit to office hours to get some assistance from a TA.</p>
<p>Is there an efficient timeframe needed to answer Q7? Or, in other words, would it be okay for the solution be realistically very time-consuming? </p>

<p>Is there an efficient timeframe needed to answer Q7? Or, in other words, would it be okay for the solution be realistically very time-consuming? </p>
<p>oh whoops, my apologies for the incorrect interpretation! But yes, it is totally okay for the solution to be time consuming, as long as it guarantees that they find the faulty fork.</p>

<p>Hi everyone! We&#39;re aware that with the traveling associated with the start of the semester that many students across the university are contracting COVID-19. Of course, we strongly encourage you to stay home from lectures and recitations when you are symptomatic, and would like to make it as easy as possible for you to do so.</p>
<p></p>
<p>For lectures, we are making course lecture notes available after each lecture on the course website (cis1600.com) under the `Lectures` tab. We encourage you to go through these at your own pace if you cannot attend, and to visit office hours with any questions that you may have when you are feeling better.</p>
<p></p>
<p>For recitations, we are setting up a way for you to make up attendance credit for when you are ill. Please email your recitation TAs and the course account before your recitation letting them know that you aren&#39;t feeling well, and please type up and email solutions to the recitation problems to your recitation TAs and the course account before 11:59PM on Friday night (as that&#39;s when we&#39;ll be posting solutions). Moreover, we just wanted to remind students that they have one free recitation attendance drop. </p>
<p></p>
<p>For this week, though, we are extending this deadline to 11:59PM Sunday due to the late notice. If you have emailed us already, you can just email your recitation TAs and the course email account your solutions and you&#39;ll be good to go!!</p>
<p></p>
<p>Lastly, we will not be giving extensions for HW due to illness, but remember that you have two H and two T drops throughout the semester. </p>
<p></p>
<p>If you have any questions feel free to email us at cis1600@seas.upenn.edu</p>
<p>hi im just a little bit confused on the difference between the set &#39;belongs to&#39; another set and the set is a &#39;subset&#39; of another set</p>
<p></p>
<p>so the &#39;belongs to&#39; for a set is only referring to one element and whether that element is present in the set,</p>
<p></p>
<p>while for the &#39;subset&#39; part it is when you consider a whole set and see if that whole set is within another set?</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>hi im just a little bit confused on the difference between the set &#39;belongs to&#39; another set and the set is a &#39;subset&#39; of another set</p>
<p></p>
<p>so the &#39;belongs to&#39; for a set is only referring to one element and whether that element is present in the set,</p>
<p></p>
<p>while for the &#39;subset&#39; part it is when you consider a whole set and see if that whole set is within another set?</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>Your definition for &#34;belongs to&#34; is correct.</p>
<p></p>
<p>One way of thinking about &#34;subset&#34; is &#34;A is a subset of B if every element of A is also an element of B&#34;. So for example, if $$A = \{1, 2\}$$ and $$B = \{1, 2, 3\}$$, then $$A \subseteq B$$, because every element of A is also an element of B. But if $$A = \{1, 4\}$$ and $$B = \{1, 2, 3\}$$ then $$A \nsubseteq B$$</p>
<p>ok that makes sense, i know for the set itself order does not matter, so for something to be considered a subset that order does not matter either as long as the elements are in the whole set</p>
<p>correct. So in my example, we can say $$\{1, 2\} \subseteq \{1, 2, 3\}$$ but it is also true that $$\{2, 1\} \subseteq \{1, 2, 3\}$$</p>
response time: -1 day, 23:26:54

<p>for 1a iii can x y and z be the same number</p>
<p>yeah</p>

<p>Currently, I&#39;m trying to explore possible ways to solve this question with the 2^9 = 512 hint in mind. </p>
<p></p>
<p>One avenue is powerset (P(S) with cardinality defined as 2^n), though I&#39;m not sure what using that would mean. The subsets would be all the possible combinations of elements in S. I thought about setting up the nine TAs as the nine elements, but that doesn&#39;t seem particularly useful.</p>

<p>for 5) is the way chef chooses the noodles random</p>
Unfortunately, we do not know what goes inside the mind of Saurabh.<div><br /></div><div>In other words, since the question is essentially asking if it is possible to get to a noodle of length 1, the randomness doesn’t really play much of a role (because you are considering all possible sequences of noodle selections that Saurabh can make). Hope this makes sense. If not, follow up, and I’ll be happy to try to further clarify.</div>

<p>For question 7, does the fork testing end once? ie when the TAs are testing the forks, they won&#39;t know whether they&#39;ve used the faulty fork until 8:59am, and does this limit the number of forks each can test to be sure?</p>
<p>For question 7, does the fork testing end once? ie when the TAs are testing the forks, they won&#39;t know whether they&#39;ve used the faulty fork until 8:59am, and does this limit the number of forks each can test to be sure?</p>
Yes, they will not know whether they’ve used the faulty fork until 8:59. But there is no limit to the number of forks a TA can use.

<p></p>
<p>How is it possible for a nonset to have cardinality? If the only element of the empty set is nothing then how can you even calculate the cardinality of nothing since nothing isn&#39;t even a set?</p>
<p>I am posting this just to instructors since I do not want to give away the answer.</p>
<p></p>
<p>How is it possible for a nonset to have cardinality? If the only element of the empty set is nothing then how can you even calculate the cardinality of nothing since nothing isn&#39;t even a set?</p>
<p>Yes, we can only take cardinality of sets. Use that fact in conjunction with the other information you know about $$x$$ to come up with an answer! you seem to have a lot of the facts nailed down. It&#39;s just about piecing them together, and for that, use the fact that we only take cardinality of sets.</p>

<p>I don&#39;t quite understand how we&#39;re supposed to identify the faulty fork individually... Do the TAs know immediately if they have eaten with the faulty fork? Or do they have to wait until 8:59 to know whether a fork they ate with was faulty? Is this question just asking about the most efficient way to iterate through the 509 forks with the TAs?</p>
<p>I don&#39;t quite understand how we&#39;re supposed to identify the faulty fork individually... Do the TAs know immediately if they have eaten with the faulty fork? Or do they have to wait until 8:59 to know whether a fork they ate with was faulty? Is this question just asking about the most efficient way to iterate through the 509 forks with the TAs?</p>
<p>The TA(s) who have eaten with the faulty fork will only know they have eaten with it at 8:59. The question is not asking you to find the most efficient way. You just need to come up with a way to successfully identify the faulty fork for certain.</p>

<p>In the Lecture example: &#34;How many odd numbers between 1000 and 9999 have distinct digits?&#34; </p>
<p>why does the multiplication rule still apply? For example, the number of ways performing step 4 depends upon whether a zero was chosen in the earlier steps.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Also in the president, secretary, treasurer question, the solution says multiplication rule does not apply because outcome of prior step changes later # outcomes. What&#39;s the logic that distinguishes the approaches to these two questions? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Is it that in a question in which there are multiple ways of performing the steps, only one sequence of steps allows multiplication rule to be applied and other sequences of events do not? thank you.</p>
<p>In the Lecture example: &#34;How many odd numbers between 1000 and 9999 have distinct digits?&#34; </p>
<p>why does the multiplication rule still apply? For example, the number of ways performing step 4 depends upon whether a zero was chosen in the earlier steps.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Also in the president, secretary, treasurer question, the solution says multiplication rule does not apply because outcome of prior step changes later # outcomes. What&#39;s the logic that distinguishes the approaches to these two questions? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Is it that in a question in which there are multiple ways of performing the steps, only one sequence of steps allows multiplication rule to be applied and other sequences of events do not? thank you.</p>
<p>Note that only Attempt 3 shows a correct solution for the &#34;odd numbers&#34; question. In that attempt, we can see that we will not select the number zero in steps 1 and 2. Only the second digit and the third digit can be zeroes, which is why they are placed last in our ordering of steps. But these steps also acknowledge the fact that, for example, the second digit cannot be the same as the first or fourth digit (whose digits have already been chosen), which is why there are 10 - 2 = 8 ways to perform step 3. And similar logic holds for step 4.</p>
<p></p>
<p>I&#39;m not sure I completely understand your second question, but I&#39;ll try my best to give some information that may clear things up. Steps within your process that you develop for counting CAN depend on each other, but we can only perform MR when each step has a CONSTANT number of ways of being performed. For example, in attempt 1 of the &#34;secretary&#34; question, the third step can be performed in 2 ways if, for example, Bob is President and Ann is Treasurer, 1 way if, for example, Bob is president and Clyde is secretary, or 0 ways if, for example, Clyde is president and Dan is secretary. Since this is NOT a constant value, the MR can&#39;t really be used.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Whereas, in attempt 2, since we chose the secretary first, the remaining two steps always have the same constant number of people to choose from.</p>
<p></p>
<p>For your last question, no. There can be many ways of ordering the steps. You just need to be sure that the ordering of the steps meets the above rule of that constant value for each step.</p>
<p></p>
<p>hope that made a bit of sense!</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
response time: 0:10:18



<p><strong>What does two stripes that have the same color cannot share a long edge means?</strong></p>
<p><strong>What does two stripes that have the same color cannot share a long edge means?</strong></p>
<p>You cannot have two adjacent stripes with the same color IF they share a long edge. Each stripe is a rectangle, and &#34;long edge&#34; refers to the long side of the rectangle.</p>
response time: 0:00:56

<p>Any sort of proof/justification is allowed as long as it is both logically and mathematically sound and correct.</p>

For this question, is there a way to denote previous members of the set that you are trying to describe, like x1. This question seems recursive, so not sure how to &#34;access&#34; previous calculated x values in the set if that makes sense.
<p>You should avoid doing this for sets. This is because sets are an unordered collection of values. For something like sequences (which is something we don&#39;t cover in this class), the elements have order and we can use a recursive definition.</p>

In one of the lecture problems today where <div>A = {2, 2^2, 2^3,…}</div><div>B = {2, 4, 6, …}</div><div>and we have to prove that A is an improper subset of B,</div><div><br /></div><div>Professor Gandhi’s solution was this:</div><div>Let x be an arb. part. element of A where  x = 2^k </div><div>but then proceeded with: there exists a k belonging to a positive integer, s.t. x = 2*2^(k-1)</div><div><br /></div><div>in order to prove that x = 2l, where l = 2^(k-1) where l is a positive integer</div><div>what makes the “k-1” component necessary? Is setting k as a positive integer greater than but not equal to 1 a valid alternative?</div><div>thank you.</div>
In one of the lecture problems today where <div>A = {2, 2^2, 2^3,…}</div><div>B = {2, 4, 6, …}</div><div>and we have to prove that A is an improper subset of B,</div><div><br /></div><div>Professor Gandhi’s solution was this:</div><div>Let x be an arb. part. element of A where  x = 2^k </div><div>but then proceeded with: there exists a k belonging to a positive integer, s.t. x = 2*2^(k-1)</div><div><br /></div><div>in order to prove that x = 2l, where l = 2^(k-1) where l is a positive integer</div><div>what makes the “k-1” component necessary? Is setting k as a positive integer greater than but not equal to 1 a valid alternative?</div><div>thank you.</div>
<p>No, we can&#39;t quite say that $$k > 1$$ because it overlooks the case where $$x = 2$$. Since $$2 \in A$$, it can be possible that we let $$x = 2$$, and in this case, we would have $$k = 1$$. </p>
ohh then how about setting k as a positive integer greater than or equal to 1? That would solve having to include x=2. Just don’t see where the k-1 comes from.<p></p>
<p>Yes, that would be the more accurate constraint on $$k$$.</p>

<p>I&#39;m a bit confused on the wording regarding the 59 shades and the 12 disjoint pairs of lipsticks. Or do all 59 shades together have 12 disjoint pairs of lipsticks (but then I&#39;m not sure why we would need to know the number of shades)? And for each disjoint pair, does &#34;disjoint&#34; imply that all the variants of green and orange are unique / do not repeat across the pairs? Do the variants have any connection to the number of shades? </p>
<p>I&#39;m a bit confused on the wording regarding the 59 shades and the 12 disjoint pairs of lipsticks. Does each of the 59 shades individually have 12 disjoint pairs of lipsticks, meaning altogether there are 59 * 12 disjoint pairs of lipsticks? Or do all 59 shades together have 12 disjoint pairs of lipsticks (but then I&#39;m not sure why we would need to know the number of shades)? And for each disjoint pair, does &#34;disjoint&#34; imply that all the variants of green and orange are unique / do not repeat across the pairs? Do the variants have any connection to the number of shades? </p>
<p>You can think of it as there are 59 lipsticks, each a different shade. Within the 59, there are 12 disjoint pairs that satisfy the criteria. </p>
<p></p>
<p>&#34;Disjoint pairs&#34; mean that if lipstick A is in one pair, then A cannot be in another pair that contributes to the 12 total pairs.</p>

is finding a case in which a proposition is false enough to disprove it? 
is finding a case in which a proposition is false enough to disprove it? 
Yes. This is what we call a counterexample

<p>In the lecture from k ∈ N it is determined that k &#43; 2 ∈ N. Can we make such assumptions without a proof in the hwk like in 1b?</p>
<p>In the lecture from k ∈ N it is determined that k &#43; 2 ∈ N. Can we make such assumptions without a proof in the hwk like in 1b?</p>
<p>yes</p>
<p>So even when we are transitioning from N to Z&#43; for example, we can just write that some expression with t in it is in Z&#43; with no explanation?</p>
<p>Well not quite. The reason we can say that if $$k \in \mathbb{N}$$ then $$k+2 \in \mathbb{N}$$ is because $$\mathbb{N}$$ is closed under addition. Since in your example, we are transitioning from $$\mathbb{N}$$ to $$\mathbb{Z^+}$$, we can&#39;t quite use the same reason, because they are different sets. The good news, however, is that you can usually write an explanation within a sentence or two!</p>
<p>So even when we are transitioning from N to Z&#43; for example, we can just write that some expression with t in it is in Z&#43; with no explanation?</p>
<p>Can we assume that if t does not have an upper bound then expressions like t&#43;5, t-7 etc. also do not have an upper bound?</p>
<p>So even when we are transitioning from N to Z&#43; for example, we can just write that some expression with t in it is in Z&#43; with no explanation?</p>
<p>no, this would be something that you would have to justify.</p>

<p>When disproving universal claims via counterexample, if I &#34;guessed and checked&#34; and found a counterexample out of luck/intuition, is it fine to say that I happened to find a counterexample, which disproved the claim? Or should I still resort to breaking down the claim into basic parts? (Example: the claim is that all (odd &#43; even) yields even integers. if I just try 3 &#43; 6 = 9, I have already found a counterexample. but I don&#39;t know if &#34;guessing and checking&#34; is a rigorous purpose for finding the counterexample, so should I go further and rewrite odd &#43; even with their definitions (2k &#43; 1) and (2m) and show how you always get an odd integer from 2(k &#43; m) &#43; 1, hence breaking the claim into basic parts?)</p>
<p></p>
<p>Maybe what I&#39;m really wondering is if I should reduce every claim to basic parts for every proof, or if disproving by counterexample is not strong enough.</p>
<p>When disproving universal claims via counterexample, if I &#34;guessed and checked&#34; and found a counterexample out of luck/intuition, is it fine to say that I happened to find a counterexample, which disproved the claim? Or should I still resort to breaking down the claim into basic parts? (Example: the claim is that all (odd &#43; even) yields even integers. if I just try 3 &#43; 6 = 9, I have already found a counterexample. but I don&#39;t know if &#34;guessing and checking&#34; is a rigorous purpose for finding the counterexample, so should I go further and rewrite odd &#43; even with their definitions (2k &#43; 1) and (2m) and show how you always get an odd integer from 2(k &#43; m) &#43; 1, hence breaking the claim into basic parts?)</p>

<p>Would it be true that given two sets A and B,  A \ B is equal to all of the elements in A minus the elements of A intersection B?</p>
<p>would I be able to write that as A \ B = {A} - {A **intersection sign** B} or is that incorrect notation?</p>
<p>Yes, $$A \setminus (A \cap B)$$ would be good notation, and as Andrew said, $$A \setminus B = A \setminus (A \cap B)$$</p>
<p>Would it be ok to say that these are equal in the homework without any justification? i.e. would we have to prove it somehow before using it?</p>
<p>It would be nice to justify why this is true.</p>

<p>Can you expand intersection statements? For example is S∩(T-T∩R) = S∩T - S∩T∩R?</p>
<p>Intersection does distribute over set minus, however, it is not immediately clear why. Thus, if you wish to use this in a solution, you should prove why it is true.</p>

<md>Hi all,  
  
Now that some of the exercises require mathematical expressions as answers, we need to clarify what forms of answer are acceptable.  
  
In CIS 1600, all final expressions (to questions requiring mathematical expressions as answers) should be in closed form unless explicitly stated otherwise. A closed form expression is essentially a term which can be evaluated in a fixed finite number of operations. For reference, many terms we will encounter are in closed form: $$12$$, $$x^2+1$$, $$k!$$,  $$2n$$, $$\binom{n}{k}$$, $$\sum_{i = 1}^{5} i^2$$.  
  
The most likely exceptions you will encounter are summations or products whose bounds are variables. For example, $$\sum_{i = 1}^{n} (2i - 1)$$ or $$1+3+5+⋯+(2n−1)$$ would not be considered closed form, since we have a variable bound $$n$$ (the number of terms we are adding is not fixed). However, the equivalent value $$n^2$$ is closed form (we haven’t yet proven this equality, so you can’t use this post as justification if we ask for this identity, but we will likely do so in due time). Similarly, if you have nested summations, e.g. $$\sum_{i = 1}^{100} \sum_{k = 1}^{i} k$$, we would not consider this closed form since the inner summation has variable bounds.  
  
Furthermore, if you simplify an open form expression to a closed form expression, you must prove their equivalence using only material we have learned in this course. We generally strongly advise against this as it almost always entails unnecessarily complex justification. All problems in this course can be answered without doing this.  
  
We require closed form for full credit, even if it is not explicitly asked for (we will try to include a reminder in most cases where an open form solution is viable). In general, if you’re not sure whether something is closed form, feel free to ask on Piazza (as always, if you’re worried about possibly giving away too much, you can post privately) or in office hours!

#pin</md>
Is listing one case that contradicts the statement sufficient as a proof?
Is listing one case that contradicts the statement sufficient as a proof?
<p>This would be a counterexample. When to use counterexamples is something you should think about!</p>

<p>1. <strong>Lectures/Recitations</strong>: Please come to the lectures/recitations and don&#39;t hesitate to ask/answer questions in class. If you give an answer and if it is correct then you probably understand the material and if your answer is incorrect then it&#39;s good too as it not only gives you an opportunity to understand your mistake but also you will most likely not make the mistake in a homework or an exam.  Also, understand as much as you can in class as it will save you time outside of class and this is especially important in this course due to the fast-paced nature of the course. The sooner you lose the inhibition of speaking up in class, the better it is for you as then you can speak up in other classes too and overall this will help you get more out of the lectures in your courses.<br /><br />2. <strong>Recreating/Summarizing lectures:</strong> Soon after each lecture, try to re-create/summarize the lecture (repeating the lecture as if you are teaching someone and without looking at the notes). Note that each lecture introduces one or two key concepts and assuming that you understood what was covered in class, you should not have too much trouble re-creating what was covered. While doing so, try to figure out how you would solve the questions independently and if you have a different solution which is correct then that&#39;s great as you will then know a different way to solve the problem and more importantly, since you did it on your own, you are less likely to forget it. If your solution is not correct then it will help to understand your mistakes. <br /><br />3. <strong>Collaboration</strong>:  Please remember that unless specified otherwise,  absolutely no collaboration is allowed in homeworks. Like many other things in life, in this course, you will learn by<br />doing things on your own and not by watching others do it. You may not get a perfect score in the homeworks, but you will learn from working hard on the homework problems and that will prepare you well for the exams.  Note that you are strongly encouraged to collaborate to understand a concept.  You may want to present some lecture material to your study partner(s) and let them ask you hard questions when you are presenting the lecture or say, a solution to a homework (whose deadline has passed) solution. <br /><br />4. <strong>Homeworks</strong>: Start thinking on homework questions as soon as the homework is released. Some problems may take time and it will help if you get started early. Keep mulling on the problems while doing other chores.  Ideas will come at unexpected times, but a necessary condition for that to happen is that you have to keep thinking about the problem. Help is available -- CIS 160 staff is there to help you and we are more inclined to help if we see that you have already thought about the problem.</p>
<p></p>
<p>5. <strong>Typing up solutions</strong>: We strongly encourage you to type up your homework solutions soon after you think you have solved the question. It<br />happens many times that one finds mistakes when writing the solutions, so this will give you more time to fix your mistakes, if any. Also, spreading out the work of writing over a few days can save you a lot of time on the day/night before the homework is due. In short, don&#39;t leave typing the solutions until the very end.</p>
<p></p>
<p>6. <strong>History: </strong>If you are worried about how you will do in CIS 160, keep in mind that each year about 500 students complete CIS 160 successfully and eventually end up having great careers. You will too!</p>

<p>Hi, </p>
<p></p>
<p>For the following question done in the last lecture, why can we not do 26^4 - 25^4?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Question: How many strings are there of four lowercase letters that have the letter x in them? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Thanks, </p>
<p>Hi, </p>
<p></p>
<p>For the following question done in the last lecture, why can we not do 26^4 - 25^4?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Question: How many strings are there of four lowercase letters that have the letter x in them? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Thanks, </p>
<p>$$26^4 - 25^4$$ is the correct answer.</p>
<p>The lecture notes said the answer should be 4 x 26^3.</p>
<p>That solution is meant to be the one referenced by the &#34;Incorrect Solution&#34; note.</p>
<p>The lecture notes said the answer should be 4 x 26^3.</p>
<p>Ahh! Thanks!</p>
<p>The lecture notes said the answer should be 4 x 26^3.</p>
<p>Can you explain why 4 · 26^3 is incorrect? </p>
<p>The lecture notes said the answer should be 4 x 26^3.</p>
<p>Sure. The procedure to get this answer is as follows:</p>
<p> </p>
<p>Step 1: Choose one spot to place the x</p>
<p>Step 2: Choose a letter for one of the remaining spots</p>
<p>Step 3: Choose a letter for one of the remaining spots</p>
<p>Step 4: Choose a letter for the last available spot.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Let&#39;s consider two <strong>distinct</strong> &#34;paths&#34; through this procedure.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Suppose in step 1, I place the x in the first slot. Now, in step 2, let&#39;s suppose we are looking at the second slot, and suppose we happen to choose the letter x for that slot as well. In step 3, suppose we place a y in the third slot. And suppose in step 4, we place a z in the last slot. Then the string we have constructed is &#34;xxyz&#34;.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Now, suppose in step 1, I place the x in the <strong>second</strong> slot. Now, in step 2, we find an available slot and choose a letter for it. So suppose we look at the first slot and happen to choose the letter x. In step 3, suppose we place a y in the third slot. And suppose in step 4, we place a z in the last slot. Then the string we have constructed is again &#34;xxyz&#34;.<br /><br />So we see that we have constructed the same string twice by following <strong>distinct </strong>&#34;paths&#34; in the procedure. This is an indication that we have overcounted, and the answer is incorrect.</p>
response time: 0:06:21

<p>Can we assume that the n special points are unique?</p>
Yes

How is the spacing between the n special points? Are the points evenly spaced or randomly spaced? <br /><div><div><br /></div></div>
How is the spacing between the n special points? Are the points evenly spaced or randomly spaced? <br /><div><div><br /></div></div>
<p>They are arranged in a way so as to not have multiple lines intersecting at the same point. So to answer your question, they are neither evenly spaced (because this would lead to multiple lines intersecting at the same point) nor are they randomly spaced (because this does not guarantee avoiding multiple lines intersecting at the same point).</p>

In one of the other questions, I saw that you can disprove a statement using one counterexample; does that also apply for disproving a set equality? I.e. If I wanna prove A = B have to prove that A and B are subsets of each other, then if I found one case in A \subseteq B where this isn’t true, is it sufficiently proving that A ≠ B? thanks.
In one of the other questions, I saw that you can disprove a statement using one counterexample; does that also apply for disproving a set equality? I.e. If I wanna prove A = B have to prove that A and B are subsets of each other, then if I found one case in A \subseteq B where this isn’t true, is it sufficiently proving that A ≠ B? thanks.
<p>Yes, showing $$A \nsubseteq B$$ would prove that $$A \neq B$$. Often, the easiest way to do this is to find some $$x \in A$$ such that $$x \notin B$$.</p>
response time: 0:02:17

<p>Hi, I was wondering how question 3 from the homework would be different if the cars were indistinguishable. I&#39;m thinking that it would be 8 choose 3, but I&#39;m not too sure. Could I please get some insight? Thank you!</p>
<p>Hi, I was wondering how question 3 from the homework would be different if the cars were indistinguishable. I&#39;m thinking that it would be 8 choose 3, but I&#39;m not too sure. Could I please get some insight? Thank you!</p>
<p>As an example, suppose three of the cars are called $$A$$, $$B$$ and $$C$$ (distinguishable), and suppose the three interests are called $$x$$, $$y$$, and $$z$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Then one possible distribution of these cars would be $$A$$ to $$x$$, $$B$$ to $$y$$ and $$C$$ to $$z$$. But clearly, there are many more ways to distribute the cars.</p>
<p></p>
<p>If, however, the cars were indistinguishable, then we could all give them the same name of $$A$$. And the <span style="text-decoration:underline">only</span> way to distribute the cars now would be $$A$$ to $$x$$, $$A$$ to $$y$$ and $$A$$ to $$z$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>As a reminder, <strong>ALL</strong> eight cars must be distributed amongst his interests.</p>
<p>Oh, interesting. The way in which i was doing it I don&#39;t think all the cars were being distributed?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Here&#39;s the procedure that I created for indistinguishable:</p>
<p></p>
<p>Contestant 1 gets a car: 8 possibilites</p>
<p>Contestant 2 gets a car: 8 possibilites</p>
<p>Contestant 3 gets a car: 8 possibilites</p>
<p></p>
<p>Contestant 1 gets 0 cars: 8^2 possibilites</p>
<p>Contestant 2 gets 0 cars: 8^2 possibilites</p>
<p>Contestant 3 gets 0 cars: 8^2 possibilites</p>
<p></p>
<p>Contestant 1 gets all cars: 1 possibility</p>
<p>Contestant 2 gets all cars: 1 possibility</p>
<p>Contestant 3 gets all cars: 1 possibility</p>
<p></p>
<p>So the total ways would be 8^3 - (3 x 8^2 - 3)?</p>
<p></p>

<p>Hi! I have an approach for question 2 that I&#39;m not so sure about. I&#39;m pretty much representing a three-way venn diagram as sets. For example, let set A contain only silver dresses, set B contains only silver/tan dresses, set E contains only silver/tan/red dresses, and set D contains only silver/red dresses. Each of these sets can be empty. Then, let set S represent sets that contain silver dresses, so that S = {A, B, D, E}. Is this rigorous enough to go through the questions and do actual operations on?</p>
<p>These Venn Diagram-esque approaches are good for gaining insight into what the sets will look like after the operations are performed on them, but do not suffice as a rigorous proof. For this, it may be a good idea to reference the lecture notes to see what a more rigorous proof would look like.</p>

<p>there is no minimum or maximum value on the number of cases. You just need to make sure that the casework is exhaustive. one way of checking this is to take the union of values covered in each case, and ensure that it is equivalent to the domain.</p>

<p></p>
<p>(1) In 5a: we&#39;re going to send 10 people to each island, so 30 people in total</p>

response time: 0:30:48



How does this word influence how we do counting?
How does this word influence how we do counting?
<p>Let&#39;s consider two similar questions:</p>
<p></p>
<p>Question 1: How many ways are there to give two <strong>distinguishable</strong> watches to two distinguishable people such that each person gets a watch.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Solution: Let $$A$$ be the first watch and $$B$$ be the second watch. Let $$X$$ be the first person and let $$Y$$ be the second person. Then we have two distributions: $$((A, X), (B, Y))$$ and $$((A, Y), (B, X)$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Question 2: How many ways are there to give two <strong>indistinguishable </strong>watches to two distinguishable people such that each person gets a watch.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Solution: Now, we <strong>cannot</strong> call our watches $$A$$ and $$B$$ because they are indistinguishable. Instead, we will call them both $$A$$. If our people are $$X$$ and $$Y$$, then we only have one distribution: $$((A, X), (A, Y))$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>In a sense, &#34;distinguishable&#34; allows for more variety in our cases/distributions.</p>
response time: 1:19:55

<p>are we allowed to use stirling partition numbers for question 3 given that we define S(n, k) and provide examples?</p>
<p>I would encourage you to avoid doing so, as it would require immense amounts of proofs (seeing as we have not covered this in lecture). We encourage you to stick to concepts covered in class. </p>

<p>Do we need to prove that switching order of operations without parentheses is okay? For example, if X = A \cup B \cap C, X = A \cap C \cup B is also true? </p>
<p>It is not always true that $$A \cup B \cap C = A \cap C \cup B$$ because parentheses are needed to avoid ambiguity.</p>

<p>Then it&#39;s ambiguous because you wouldn&#39;t know whether to perform the union or intersection first.</p>
