<p>For question 5b, do some of the n contestants move from the 3 indistinguishable islands to Singapore, Bajas, and Fiji and do the original islands have a different max capacity now so that those islands are able to be filled to their maximum capacity?</p>

<p>If you are writing the contrapositive of an implication with inequalities on each side, do you flip all the inequalities?</p>
<p>If you are writing the contrapositive of an implication with inequalities on each side, do you flip all the inequalities?</p>
<p>My answer is a very hesitant yes, because I feel like there are examples in which you do not flip all the inequalities, but I can&#39;t think of one at the moment.</p>
<p></p>
<p>In general, it is best to simply individually negate both sides and if the negation requires the inequality sign to be flipped, then do that.</p>

<p>Do we need to prove that $$\lnot (A \cup B) = (\lnot A \cap \lnot B) \vee \lnot (A \cap B) = (\lnot A \cup \lnot B)?$$</p>

<p></p>

<p></p>
<p>And if we do how would we prove it?</p>
<p></p>
<p>those are de morgan&#39;s laws!</p>

<p>those are de morgan&#39;s laws!</p>

<p>There have been several homeworks thus far that have proofs that benefit from basic properties of even/odd numbers like</p>

<p>From lecture, if a^2 = 2b^2, then why does the number of prime factors they have necessarily have to be equal? S (a^2) = S(2b^2)?</p>
<p>From lecture, if a^2 = 2b^2, then why does the number of prime factors they have necessarily have to be equal? S (a^2) = S(2b^2)?</p>
<p>Because $$a^2$$ and $$2b^2$$ represent the same number. Suppose we let $$p=a^2$$ and $$p = 2b^2$$, which follows from the fact that $$a^2 = 2b^2$$. Then saying that &#34;$$a^2$$ and $$2b^2$$ must have the same number of prime factors&#34; is equivalent to saying &#34;$$p$$ and $$p$$ must have the same number of prime factors&#34;, which is true.</p>
response time: 0:16:46

<p>no you cannot have more than one line for one possible way. Each &#34;line&#34; is a different rearrangement of the clones numbered 1 through 99, and if that line is formed in such a way that the sum of every pair is odd, then it adds one to the total count of lines.</p>

<p></p>
<p>when we select the consecutive pairs it has to be (1,2),(2,3),(3,4) only starting from 1 or it could be (2,3),(3,4) arrangement also? Do the arrangement have to necessarily start from 1 or can start from any clone number?</p>
<p></p>
<p>The first clone in line can be any number. But when considering consecutive pairs, the first pair is (first clone in line, second clone in line). the second pair is (second clone in line, third clone in line), and so on.</p>

<p>For question 3a, do we say that -143 is divisible by 143? Or can we even say that negative numbers are divisible?</p>
<p>For question 3a, do we say that -143 is divisible by 143? Or can we even say that negative numbers are divisible?</p>
<p>Yes, -143 is divisible by 143. More generally, we say that $$x$$ is divisible by $$y$$ if $$x = yk$$ for some $$k \in \mathbb{Z}$$</p>

<p>To prove a &#34;there exists&#34; statement, can we just provide 1 example that validates the statement?</p>
<p>To prove a &#34;there exists&#34; statement, can we just provide 1 example that validates the statement?</p>
<p>This only works when you have a specific instance of a problem. In most cases, problems are given in a &#34;general&#34; case with variables and abstract values. In these cases, you should avoid giving a single example, and prove that such an example always exists.</p>

My rationale is that if Max wants to have all the creatures in Justin&#39;s list, there is only one way to do that, plus the &#34;extra&#34; elements that he can add to his own list (the creatures in his list that aren&#39;t in Justin&#39;s list). So isn&#39;t the solutions for parts a and b the same or am I missing something? </p>
<p>I&#39;m a bit confused by Q7 because it seems to me that parts a and b are asking the same thing. My rationale is that if Max wants to have all the creatures in Justin&#39;s list, there is only one way to do that, plus the &#34;extra&#34; elements that he can add to his own list (the creatures in his list that aren&#39;t in Justin&#39;s list). So isn&#39;t the solutions for parts a and b the same or am I missing something? </p>
<p>In part a, the creatures in Max&#39;s list can be identical to that of Justin&#39;s list. But in part b, this cannot happen since Max must have at least one more.</p>
<p>So all the &#34;extra&#34; creatures that Max can have only needs to be accounted for in part b? </p>
<p>No. But they <strong>can </strong>be identical in part a. This suggests that you should also consider the extra creatures in part a.</p>
<p>So all the &#34;extra&#34; creatures that Max can have only needs to be accounted for in part b? </p>
<p>yeah that&#39;s fine</p>

<p>Is there a number for how many creatures Jus-Tien selects? Do we solve the question in terms of some arbitrary $$k$$ creatures picked? Also, are all the creatures we can pick from distinct?</p>
<p>Jus-Tien can select at most $$n$$ creatures, which suggests your answer may be in terms of $$n$$. Yes, the $$n$$ creature types are all distinct.</p>

<p>This is more related to lecture but I am confused about this phrase in the lecture notes: </p>
<p></p>
<p>&#34;In other words, we want to find the number of ways there are to choose a multiset of r elements from a multiset of n distinct elements with infinite copies of each of the n elements available&#34;</p>
<p></p>
<p>How are we choosing a multiset from another multiset? Can you provide an example if possible? Thanks. </p>
<p>This is more related to lecture but I am confused about this phrase in the lecture notes: </p>
<p></p>
<p>&#34;In other words, we want to find the number of ways there are to choose a multiset of r elements from a multiset of n distinct elements with infinite copies of each of the n elements available&#34;</p>
<p></p>
<p>How are we choosing a multiset from another multiset? Can you provide an example if possible? Thanks. </p>
<p>A multiset is defined to be a set where elements can repeat. So if we are looking at a multiset that has repeats, and we want to select a subset of items, sometimes we would want repeats in that subset (hence, we would want to obtain a multiset).</p>
<p></p>
<p>A good example is the book example in the lecture notes, where in our 6 book selection, we will have repeats. </p>
<p>In that example I don&#39;t understand intuitevly where 6&#43;3-1 is coming from. </p>
<p>I think the best way to explain this is to consider an arrangement of sticks and crosses. So for example, let&#39;s look at **|*|***. Each &#34;section&#34; corresponds to a type of book (and there are three types of books). Each star represents a book (or rather, a count of the amount of books in the category). So the arrangement I provided says that there are 2 books of type 1, 1 book of type 2 and 3 books of type 3. A single arrangement of books can uniquely be represented by one of these strings.</p>
<p></p>
<p>We need 6 &#34;crosses&#34; to represent the 6 books that we need, and we need (3-1) = 2 dividers, so that&#39;s why we have $$\binom{6 + 3 - 1}{6}$$</p>
<p>In that example I don&#39;t understand intuitevly where 6&#43;3-1 is coming from. </p>
<p>Sorry, but I am still confused about why intuitevly 8 choose 6 makes sense. We are trying to choose 6 books out of 8 of what? Why is it 8? Why are the dividers included in the total? </p>
<p>In that example I don&#39;t understand intuitevly where 6&#43;3-1 is coming from. </p>
<p>8 is the total amount of books and dividers needed. In order to uniquely describe a selection of books, you need a &#34;string&#34; similar to the one I provided **|*|***, where there are 6 crosses and 2 sticks. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Instead of thinking of the 6 as &#34;choosing 6 books&#34;, it may be helpful to think of it as you have 8 spaces (where you need to place books and dividers), and you are choosing the locations to put the books.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Notice that $$\binom{6 + 3 - 1}{6} = \binom{6 + 3 -1}{3 - 1}$$, so in a similar mindset, we could instead choose the locations for the dividers, and the books will go in the remaining spaces.</p>
<p></p>
<p>We need to include the dividers, because otherwise, we have no separation of the books, because we would be treating all books as indistinguishable.</p>
<p>In that example I don&#39;t understand intuitevly where 6&#43;3-1 is coming from. </p>
<p>Makes sense now, thank you!</p>
response time: 0:29:49

<p>Let&#39;s say the claim is <strong>t</strong><strong>he sum is even. </strong>If I want to prove the claim by contradiction, we assume that the sum is odd. If my contradiction is that I showed that the sum will be even (contradicting the assumption), is this considered proof by contradiction? Or is this redundant/unnecessary because I am simply proving that the sum is even directly? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Basically, for a specific problem, I just think it&#39;s easier and clearer to understand if I prove a claim by initially assuming the opposite and thus everything that assumption implies. Then with those implications and the rest of the context of the problem show that the original claim is true. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Hopefully, my question is clear (I tried my best haha) and I can get some guidance! </p>
<p>Let&#39;s say the claim is <strong>t</strong><strong>he sum is even. </strong>If I want to prove the claim by contradiction, we assume that the sum is odd. If my contradiction is that I showed that the sum will be even (contradicting the assumption), is this considered proof by contradiction? Or is this redundant/unnecessary because I am simply proving that the sum is even directly? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Basically, for a specific problem, I just think it&#39;s easier and clearer to understand if I prove a claim by initially assuming the opposite and thus everything that assumption implies. Then with those implications and the rest of the context of the problem show that the original claim is true. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Hopefully, my question is clear (I tried my best haha) and I can get some guidance! </p>
<p>This really depends on the proof. Most of the times when doing contradiction, we end up contradicting something true that was given in the problem, though in some instances, you may end up contradicting what you assumed.</p>
<p></p>
<p>If you find yourself often proving the opposite of what you assumed, then it may be best to just stick with a direct proof.</p>

<p>&#34;Let S(m) be the sum of the number of times each prime factor occurs in the unique factorization of m&#34;</p>
<p></p>
<p>What does this exactly mean? Is this the sum of all the prime factors?</p>
<p>&#34;Let S(m) be the sum of the number of times each prime factor occurs in the unique factorization of m&#34;</p>
<p></p>
<p>What does this exactly mean? Is this the sum of all the prime factors?</p>
<p>Not quite. I&#39;ll give you an example: $$84 = 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 7$$. The prime factor $$2$$ appears $$2$$ times. The prime factor $$3$$ appears one time. The prime factor $$7$$ appears one time. So $$S(84) = 2 + 1 + 1 = 4$$</p>

<p>For the statement &#34;if there is no prime number p such that p ≤ √m and p | m&#34;, can I get a clarification on what this means. If the statement is saying &#34; (if there is no prime number p such that<br />p ≤√m) and p | m&#34; then it would be the same thing as that if there is a prime number p such that p &gt; √m <strong>and </strong>p evenly divides by m. If the statement is saying that &#34;if there is no prime number p such that (p ≤ √m and p | m),&#34; would that mean there is a prime number p such that p &gt; √m <strong>or</strong> p <strong>doesn&#39;t </strong>evenly divide by m by demorgan&#39;s laws right?</p>
<p>For the statement &#34;if there is no prime number p such that p ≤ √m and p | m&#34;, can I get a clarification on what this means. If the statement is saying &#34; (if there is no prime number p such that<br />p ≤√m) and p | m&#34; then it would be the same thing as that if there is a prime number p such that p &gt; √m <strong>and </strong>p evenly divides by m. If the statement is saying that &#34;if there is no prime number p such that (p ≤ √m and p | m),&#34; would that mean there is a prime number p such that p &gt; √m <strong>or</strong> p <strong>doesn&#39;t </strong>evenly divide by m by demorgan&#39;s laws right?</p>
<p>I don&#39;t think you can just negate that expression and have it be logically equivalent. You should also be considering the second part of the statement &#34;... then $$m$$ must be prime&#34;</p>
<p>So would the statement &#34;if there is no prime number p such that p ≤ √m and p | m, then m must be a prime&#34; not be logically equivalent to &#34;if there is a prime number p such that p &gt; √m and p | m, then m must be a prime&#34;? I am trying to do contradiction (so I would only be changing the second part to then m must be composite) but I don&#39;t understand what the first part of the claim logically means so I am confused.</p>
<p>$$p \implies q$$ is not logically equivalent to $$\neg p \implies q$$. In general, when doing contradiction, you assume $$\neg q$$ to be true. </p>
<p></p>
<p>One way of thinking about the first part is consider you have some value $$m$$. From there, you consider every single prime $$\leq \sqrt{m}$$. If none of these primes divide $$m$$, then (this is the second part of claim), $$m$$ must be prime.</p>
<p>So would the statement &#34;if there is no prime number p such that p ≤ √m and p | m, then m must be a prime&#34; not be logically equivalent to &#34;if there is a prime number p such that p &gt; √m and p | m, then m must be a prime&#34;? I am trying to do contradiction (so I would only be changing the second part to then m must be composite) but I don&#39;t understand what the first part of the claim logically means so I am confused.</p>
<p>I am confused on what the negation of p would actually be then. If I say, &#34;if there is a prime number p such that p &gt; √m and p | m, then m must be a prime&#34; would that not be a double negative because I am saying that there is a prime number rather than there is no prime number and that the prime number is greater than sqrt m rather than less than or equal to sqrt m.</p>
<p>So would the statement &#34;if there is no prime number p such that p ≤ √m and p | m, then m must be a prime&#34; not be logically equivalent to &#34;if there is a prime number p such that p &gt; √m and p | m, then m must be a prime&#34;? I am trying to do contradiction (so I would only be changing the second part to then m must be composite) but I don&#39;t understand what the first part of the claim logically means so I am confused.</p>
<p>The opposite of &#34;there exists some prime p such that XYZ conditions hold&#34; is &#34;there <strong>does not</strong> exist some prime p such that XYZ conditions hold&#34;. You wouldn&#39;t necessarily negate the conditions.</p>

<p>Is 0 considered even? Using the given example, (1-1) in the first step would see the product = 0. </p>

<p>What is the different between saying &#34;without loss of generality&#34; and &#34;arbitrary but particular&#34;? When would we use each?</p>
<p>What is the different between saying &#34;without loss of generality&#34; and &#34;arbitrary but particular&#34;? When would we use each?</p>
<p>&#34;Without loss of generality&#34; is commonly used when making a claim for some variables. For example, I would say something like &#34;suppose $$a, b \in \mathbb{Z}$$, and without loss of generality, let $$a < b$$&#34;. And then I would do whatever math needed. In the instance that $$b < a$$, I wouldn&#39;t have to do any math because the &#34;symmetric&#34; argument is covered with &#34;Without Loss of Generality&#34;. That is to say, we can&#39;t just be throwing around WLOG whenever we want. We should only use it when the argument truly is symmetric.</p>
<p></p>
<p>&#34;Arbitrary but Particular&#34; is usually used when describing an element of a set. We use this to indicate that there is &#34;nothing special&#34; about the element, and the argument for that element will hold for all elements of the set.</p>
response time: 10:14:30

Or is it something else entirely, such as negating the math expressions to $$\geq$$ and $$\nmid$$? Thank you for your help with this.</p>

<p>Is the notation &#34;C = C1 &#43; C2&#34; proper set notation to describe that the set C can be partitioned into two sets, C1 and C2?</p>
<p>Is the notation &#34;C = C1 &#43; C2&#34; proper set notation to describe that the set C can be partitioned into two sets, C1 and C2?</p>
<p>Not quite. Something like $$C = C_1 \cup C_2$$ and $$C_1 \cap C_2 = \emptyset$$ would be more accurate</p>
<p>But |C| = |C1| &#43; |C2| would be correct, right?</p>
<p>If $$C_1$$ and $$C_2$$ partition $$C$$, then it is true that $$|C| = |C_1| + |C_2|$$. But just saying $$|C| = |C_1| + |C_2|$$ alone does not imply that $$C_1$$ and $$C_2$$ partition $$C$$</p>
response time: 0:00:48

<p>I have seen the acronym CFA on some of the returned gradescope homeworks and was wondering what it stood for.</p>
<p>Here are some common induction mistakes that you should avoid doing in your induction proofs, as they will incur a deduction on your score.</p>
<p></p>
<ul><li>No change of variables
<ul><li>i.e. using $$n$$ through out the proof instead of defining another variable (e.g. $$k$$) in the IH.</li></ul>
</li><li>Not defining a lower bound of $$k$$
<ul><li>(✕) Assume $$P(k)$$ for some $$k$$</li><li>(✓) Assume $$P(k)$$ for some $$k \geq0$$</li></ul>
</li><li>Assuming proposition is true <strong>for all</strong> $$k$$ in the IH
<ul><li>(✕) Assume $$P(k)$$ is true for <em>all</em> $$k\geq 0$$</li><li>(✓) Assume $$P(k)$$ is true for <em>some</em> $$k \geq 0$$</li></ul>
</li><li>Referencing $$P(n)$$ but not defining it</li><li>Not explicitly citing IH when you apply it in the IS</li><li>Assuming strong induction when you only use weak induction</li></ul>
<p>Do we have to say that k is an arbitrary but particular element in the induction hypothesis? Or can we just say for some k?</p>
<p>Do we have to say that k is an arbitrary but particular element in the induction hypothesis? Or can we just say for some k?</p>
<p>&#34;for some k&#34; is fine to use</p>
response time: 0:00:49

<p>Does the cardinality of a set with repeated elements only account for the number of distinct elements? </p>
<p>For instance, is the cardinality of the set {0, 1, 0, 0} 4 or 2? </p>

<p>Would this be a logically valid statement? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Since every element in B is greater than $$2\bar{x}$$, the sum of the elements in $$B$$ must necessarily be greater than $$|B| * 2\bar{x}$$, which would be the sum of the elements in $$B$$ if every element in B was equal to $$2\bar{x}$$, and we know every element in B is greater than $$2\bar{x}$$. . </p>
<p>Would this be a logically valid statement? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Since every element in B is greater than $$2\bar{x}$$, the sum of the elements in $$B$$ must necessarily be greater than $$|B| * 2\bar{x}$$, which would be the sum of the elements in $$B$$ if every element in B was equal to $$2\bar{x}$$, and we know every element in B is greater than $$2\bar{x}$$. . </p>
<p>yes that&#39;s fine</p>

<p>But in general, you can try to simplify a complex statement. So for example, the &#34;if...then...&#34; statement in Q2 is quite complex, but it can be boiled down to: &#34;if there is no prime $$p$$ such that XYZ conditions hold, then $$m$$ is prime&#34;.</p>

<p>The contrapositive would be &#34;If $$m$$ is not prime, then there <strong>is</strong> a prime $$p$$ such that XYZ conditions hold.&#34;</p>

<p>If k = 1, does the one color have to be the golden block? Can we have k = 3 colors and none of those colors be gold?</p>
<p>If k = 1, does the one color have to be the golden block? Can we have k = 3 colors and none of those colors be gold?</p>
<p>The color gold is always included in the $$k$$ colors.</p>
<p>So if k = 1, we know the single color is gold. If k = 2, one of the colors is gold and the other color a color with infinite blocks. It&#39;s not possible for k = 2 and for both colors to be one of the colors with infinite block.</p>
Correct

<p>I know this has been asked before, but in one post it was said that gold is not a mandatory color, and in others it said that gold must always be a part of the k colors- is k colors referring to the total amount of possibilities, or is gold actually a mandatory choice?</p>
<p>I know this has been asked before, but in one post it was said that gold is not a mandatory color, and in others it said that gold must always be a part of the k colors- is k colors referring to the total amount of possibilities, or is gold actually a mandatory choice?</p>
Q2
<p>I know this has been asked before, but in one post it was said that gold is not a mandatory color, and in others it said that gold must always be a part of the k colors- is k colors referring to the total amount of possibilities, or is gold actually a mandatory choice?</p>
<p>Nathan does not have to choose the gold block, that is, the gold block does not need to be an element of his set of blocks.</p>
<p><br />At the same time, there are k distinct colors, of which gold is one of them.</p>
<p>If you&#39;re manipulating the n and r variables, is it possible to have a negative number in an n choose r statement? What would it result in if n or r was negative?</p>
<p>That answers if $$k < 0$$, but what if simply $$n < k$$ is true?</p>
<p>you can assume that $$\binom{n}{k} = 0$$ for $$n < k$$</p>

<p>In the lecture note for the proof that n! &lt; n^n, the induction step goes from using an equal sign to a less than sign. Why can we do this? </p>
<p>In the lecture note for the proof that n! &lt; n^n, the induction step goes from using an equal sign to a less than sign. Why can we do this? </p>
Because the induction hypothesis says that $$k! &lt; k^k$$. So we’re substituting that in, which means we can’t use equality since the IH doesn’t have equality
response time: 1:55:01



<p>How does one make a good counting question that can be used for a combinatorial proof, and what are some useful techniques? I noticed that the question is usually made from the simpler side of the identity to be proven, and the more complicated side is derived from partitioning the choices by some sort of scheme.</p>
<p>How does one make a good counting question that can be used for a combinatorial proof, and what are some useful techniques? I noticed that the question is usually made from the simpler side of the identity to be proven, and the more complicated side is derived from partitioning the choices by some sort of scheme.</p>
<p>I&#39;m not the greatest at combo proofs, but I&#39;ll do my best to answer this and maybe another TA can provide their advice.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The way I approach combo proofs is exactly what you outlined: I look at the easier side, and formulate a counting question based off of that.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The &#34;harder&#34; side often requires a bit more creativity. There&#39;s usually some sort of system involved in counting the &#34;harder&#34; side, whether that be partitions or casework. It&#39;s also nice to do a bit of pattern recognition (like if I see a $$2^n$$ on the harder side, I might be thinking about subsets).</p>
<p></p>
<p>Really, a lot of it comes down to practice and creativity in developing different methods of solving the same counting question.</p>
response time: -1 day, 22:27:56

<p>Though we haven&#39;t proved strong induction yet, we did show in class that we can induct on a claim that is stronger than the claim we seek to prove (such as the problem with the removed square in the grid).</p>
<p></p>
<p>Thus, it is acceptable to induct on the following claim for this problem (given that we rigorously prove it for this specific claim): for a tournament with at most n participants, at least one of the participants will be a grandmaster? </p>
<p>Though we haven&#39;t proved strong induction yet, we did show in class that we can induct on a claim that is stronger than the claim we seek to prove (such as the problem with the removed square in the grid).</p>
<p></p>
<p>Thus, it is acceptable to induct on the following claim for this problem (given that we rigorously prove it for this specific claim): for a tournament with at most n participants, at least one of the participants will be a grandmaster? </p>
You can do that as long as you show that it will also answer the intended question

<p>I am proving by contradiction for #1. Would the negation of there exists at least 3 be there exists at most 2? I am confused because I thought when you negate &#34;there exists&#34; it becomes &#34;for all&#34; but that does not seem possible in this case.</p>
<p>I am proving by contradiction for #1. Would the negation of there exists at least 3 be there exists at most 2? I am confused because I thought when you negate &#34;there exists&#34; it becomes &#34;for all&#34; but that does not seem possible in this case.</p>
This is something we’d like you to think about. Usually we negate “there exists” to “for all” when the quantifier is referencing a variable, and the variable is being used in some expression to prove.<div><br /></div><div>Another hint is that the opposite of “there exists…” is “there does not exist…”</div>
response time: 5:07:13

<p>I might not be understanding the question correctly, but it seems like the claim is false for $$k \geq 2$$. Are we assuming that $$k \geq 2$$?</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$k = 0$$: $$(5x+5)^0 = 1$$, which has only one coefficient.</p>
<p>$$k=1$$: $$(5x+5)^1 = 5x + 5$$, which doesn&#39;t have two distinct coefficients.</p>

<p>Do I need to prove the statement that the number of $$n$$ subsets of a set of $$m$$ elements is equal to the number of ways to choose $$n$$ elements from the set.</p>
<p>Do I need to prove the statement that the number of $$n$$ subsets of a set of $$m$$ elements is equal to the number of ways to choose $$n$$ elements from the set.</p>
<p>a one sentence justification would be nice</p>
<p>Would this justification be valid? </p>
<p></p>
<p>The number of $$n$$ subsets of a set of size $$m$$ is equal to the number of ways to choose $$n$$ elements from the set. This is because each $$n$$ subset of a set is a unique set of $$n$$ distinct elements taken from the $$m$$ elements, which is what $$\binom{m}{n}$$ enumerates.<br />        </p>
<p>Anything that is logically sound and correct would be deemed valid.</p>
response time: 0:00:26

<p>I&#39;m a little confused about the notation for Q1 e) what does max(p,q) mean?</p>
<p>I&#39;m a little confused about the notation for Q1 e) what does max(p,q) mean?</p>
<p>It returns the maximum value between $$p$$ and $$q$$. So, for example, if $$p = 30$$ and $$q = 20$$, then $$max(p, q) = max(30, 20) = 30 = p$$</p>

<p>For some proposition Q, if we prove Q(0), Q(1), Q(2), and then for arbitrary but particular k&gt;=2, that [Q(k-1) AND Q(k)] ==&gt; [Q(k) AND Q(k&#43;1)], do we still have to explain how this modified form of induction shows that Q(n) is true for all natural n? (analogously, strong induction was not given a rigorous proof using weak induction in lecture)</p>
<p>yes you should explain this, but this seems like some sort of variant of strong induction. So in instances like this, it is probably better to just use strong induction instead.</p>

<p>yes, $$5^{n-k}$$ would be considered part of the coefficient, because $$5^{n-k} \in \mathbb{Z}$$, and is not a polynomial term.</p>

<p>Usually, you need two variables in the induction hypothesis, so you would have $$j$$ and $$k$$. In the induction step, you should still be aiming to prove that the $$k+1$$ case is true.</p>

<p>For the purposes of this class, may we assume zero is a positive integer.</p>
<p>In lecture we introduced a variable j for strong induction. Is j arbitrary but particular, is k arbitrary but particular, or both? </p>
<p>By the orders of Ishaan himself, I have been asked to post this meme I made.<img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7g64any4jp7cj%2F8f2a61ff72160184c4155603eee7c626da6fcfda427e00811bbc4a6d7c2f6827%2FIshaan_Meme.png" width="972" height="874" alt="" /></p>
<p>Can we assume that n is always an integer?</p>
<p>For induction hypothesis, why do we say &#34;for some k&#34; instead of say &#34;for any k&#34;?</p>
<p>For induction hypothesis, why do we say &#34;for some k&#34; instead of say &#34;for any k&#34;?</p>
<p>great question. I think this comes down to how induction is built upon the idea of proving $$P(k) \implies P(k+1) \quad \forall k$$. Since it&#39;s hard to prove that implication for all values of k, if we show the implication to be true for an arbitrary value of $$k$$, then we don&#39;t have to worry about proving it for all $$k$$, because we would have already shown that since $$k$$ was arbitrary.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Since $$k$$ is arbitrary, we say &#34;for some k&#34;, since we don&#39;t really know what $$k$$ is, but we just want it to be arbitrary.</p>
<p></p>
<p>I can&#39;t quite put my finger on why &#34;for any k&#34; may be incorrect because I think there are valid arguments on both sides (for it to be logically acceptable or not). One such argument is that &#34;for any&#34; may be an implication of strong induction, but not in an accurate way. But one could also argue that &#34;for any k&#34; can mean the same thing as &#34;for some k&#34;</p>
<p></p>
<p>Given this, my recommendation is to stick with convention and to just use &#34;for some k&#34;.</p>
response time: 3:55:40



<p>Do I need to prove that (-1)$$^x$$ equals -(-1)$$^{x+1}$$ or that (-1)$$^{x-1}$$ equals (-1)$$^{x+1}$$ when trying to substitute one for the other?</p>
<p>For Q5, do we need to prove that if a prime p divides N, but does not divide D, then if N/D is an integer, p divides N/D?</p>
<p>For Q5, do we need to prove that if a prime p divides N, but does not divide D, then if N/D is an integer, p divides N/D?</p>
You should justify this
<p>In the case of Q5, would the following argument be considered rigorous enough?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Since $$q\geq1$$, $$p\mid P(p,q)$$, so $$P(p,q)=q!\cdot\tbinom{p}{q}$$ is a multiple of $$p$$. It must then be true that $$p\mid\tbinom{p}{q}$$, since the only prime factor of $$p$$ (which is $$p$$) cannot divide $$q!$$ when $$q\leq p-1$$. This is because prime $$p$$ shares no common prime factors with any integers less than $$p$$. Thus, for any prime $$p$$ and integer $$q$$ s.t. $$1\leq q\leq p-1$$, $$p\mid\tbinom{p}{q}$$.</p>
<p></p>
Sure
response time: 0:00:54

<p>Suppose that we have nodes A, B, and C. A is one way to C, but C is one way to B and B is one way to A. If we ask &#34;Can we travel from C to A&#34; will the answer be yes (because we can go through B)?</p>
<p>Suppose that we have nodes A, B, and C. A is one way to C, but C is one way to B and B is one way to A. If we ask &#34;Can we travel from C to A&#34; will the answer be yes (because we can go through B)?</p>
<p>No. The answer will only be &#34;yes&#34; if there is a direct connection (i.e. you only need to take one walkway to get from the start location to the end location of the question)</p>

<p>For n=1 in Q1 does the claim hold</p>
<p>For n=1 in Q1 does the claim hold</p>
<p>Yes, because $$1^a - 1^b = 0$$ and $$1000 \mid 0$$ because $$ \exists \, k$$ such that $$1000 \cdot k = 0$$.</p>

<p>have both T and U as dead ends, assuming S is the entrance?</p>
<p>So does that mean that if there are multiple dead ends, Bethany must be able to find all of them?</p>
<p>Remember, all nodes must have a connection, either -&gt;, &lt;-, or &lt;-&gt;. Thus, in that example, either s -&gt; v, v-&gt; s, or s&lt;-&gt;v, and thus there exist no dead ends in that example.</p>
<p>So does that mean that if there are multiple dead ends, Bethany must be able to find all of them?</p>
<p>I mean in the case where S-&gt;T, T&lt;-&gt;U, and S-&gt;U</p>
<p>So does that mean that if there are multiple dead ends, Bethany must be able to find all of them?</p>
<p>There are zero dead-ends in that example</p>
response time: 0:07:17



<p>For induction proofs, do we necessarily need an expression to evaluate to equate the LHS to RHS, or can the induction step be logical, such that the only variable we have is n (the variable we are doing induction on?)</p>
<p>For induction proofs, do we necessarily need an expression to evaluate to equate the LHS to RHS, or can the induction step be logical, such that the only variable we have is n (the variable we are doing induction on?)</p>
<p>The induction step can be logical! The beauty of induction is that it doesn&#39;t just work for proving mathematical equalities; it can be used for much much more!</p>
response time: 0:07:43



<p>I&#39;m defining a value a to be equal to something in an open form and im stating that a is an integer, so would it be fine if I can define a in open form?</p>
<p>I&#39;m defining a value a to be equal to something in an open form and im stating that a is an integer, so would it be fine if I can define a in open form?</p>
<p>yeah that&#39;s fine. Only your answer needs to be in closed form.</p>
<p>So I have a defined to be the sum of multiple values which are all integers (where some values are the product of multiple integers and some values are an integer raised to an integer), so would this be a good enough explanation?</p>
<p>Christopher is correct. You can assume that $$\mathbb{Z}$$ is closed under addition and multiplication, so you can use that in your justification.</p>

<p>For Q3, does a dead end have 0 neighbors, or does there just need to be an edge connecting the two nodes and not necessarily the right direction between the two? For example, if S-&gt;T and U-&gt;T, does T have 0 neighbors (because there are no available walkways to leave section T) or does T have 2 neighbors (because there are 2 edges connecting S and T and T and U)?</p>
<p>For Q3, does a dead end have 0 neighbors, or does there just need to be an edge connecting the two nodes and not necessarily the right direction between the two? For example, if S-&gt;T and U-&gt;T, does T have 0 neighbors (because there are no available walkways to leave section T) or does T have 2 neighbors (because there are 2 edges connecting S and T and T and U)?</p>
<p>$$S$$ is a dead end if you cannot leave $$S$$ to go to a different section. If $$S \rightarrow T$$ and $$U \rightarrow T$$, then $$T$$ would be a dead end.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Since &#34;adjacent&#34; and &#34;neighbors&#34; are not defined in the problem, it is hard to accurately answer your question, because it depends on how you define these terms on your own.</p>

<p>I went to office hours earlier today regarding question five on the homework, but I am still a bit confused. I got to here in my induction step:</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7ggz0g8t3v4za%2F455e54c7b405c3cdff7da1df98f63fba2980547ca9fbb56806ddc0ffa694d242%2Fimage.png" alt="image.png" /></p>
<p>and the TA told me to try and show that $$p \choose j$$ is always a multiple of j, so i can write the expression as k&#43;1&#43;pm &#43; p(some other stuff) but I don&#39;t think that statement is even true? I&#39;m just a little lost on how to show that what is in the summation is an integer multiple of p. Not sure if its best to just go back to OH tomorrow, but I thought I would ask on here as well. </p>
<p>showing that $$\binom{p}{j}$$ is a multiple of $$j$$ would not imply that the summand is a multiple of $$p$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Instead, try showing that it is a multiple of $$p$$ if your goal is to rewrite it as $$k + 1 + pm + p(\text{other stuff})$$. Try expanding out the $$\binom{p}{j}$$ and use what you know about $$j$$ compared to $$p$$.</p>

<p>Does the binomial theorem include the possibility of applying it to something like (x&#43;0)^a or does that not work because it does not assume that 0^0 is 1? </p>
<p>It would still work. Though it is very rare to see binomial theorem used for $$(a + b)^n$$ when, for example, $$b = 0$$, because then it&#39;s just usually easier to simplify to $$(a + 0)^n = a^n$$</p>

<p>yeah that is the assumption that is made for it to work.</p>

<p>Can we assume that the number of remainders possible when dividing $$x$$ by some other positive integer is $$\left\lceil\frac{x}{2}\right\rceil$$, or should we prove this?</p>
<p>Can we assume that the number of remainders possible when dividing $$x$$ by some other positive integer is $$\left\lceil\frac{x}{2}\right\rceil$$, or should we prove this?</p>
<p>I&#39;m not sure what you mean by this. If you divide $$x$$ by $$3$$, for example, the remainder is one of $$0, 1, 2$$, so there are $$3$$ remainders possible. And if, for example, $$x = 15$$, then $$3 \neq \lceil \frac{x}{2} \rceil$$</p>

I don’t think I completely understand the definition of a dead end. What does it mean to get out of the store? If all the other stores are nodes then would there also be an additional node for exit / entrance to the store? thank you!
I don’t think I completely understand the definition of a dead end. What does it mean to get out of the store? If all the other stores are nodes then would there also be an additional node for exit / entrance to the store? thank you!
<p>Suppose there are only 3 sections, $$S$$, $$T$$, and $$R$$. Since there must exist a walkway between each pair of sections, one possible set of walkways is $$S \rightarrow T$$, $$T \rightarrow R$$ and $$S \rightarrow R$$. In this case, $$R$$ is a dead-end, because if you are in section $$R$$, you cannot go to any other section by following the walkways.</p>
response time: 0:01:51

<p>If we know that $$\frac{xy}{z}$$ is an integer and that $$\frac{x}{z}$$ is not an integer, can we simply conclude that $$\frac{y}{z}$$ is an integer?</p>
<p>If we know that $$\frac{xy}{z}$$ is an integer and that $$\frac{x}{z}$$ is not an integer, can we simply conclude that $$\frac{y}{z}$$ is an integer?</p>
<p>Is this true? If $$x = 6, y = 3$$ and $$z = 9$$, then $$\frac{x}{z} = \frac{6}{9}$$ which is not an integer, and $$\frac{xy}{z} = \frac{18}{9} = 2$$, which is an integer, but $$\frac{y}{z} = \frac{3}{9}$$ is not an integer.</p>
<p>True, but if we knew that $$y \geq z$$, then it would be true, right? If it is true, then can we simply conclude that in our proofs?</p>
<p>$$x = 6, y = 12, z = 9$$ would be a counterexample.</p>

If you are unable to take this midterm for health reasons and with <em>proper justification</em>, your score for Midterm I will be replaced with your Midterm II score. This should only be utilized in extenuating circumstances, and historically, students taking both exam 1 and exam 2 have had an edge over students who have had exam 2 counted towards both exams since generally students find the material tested in exam 2 significantly harder.</p>

In previous semesters, the time-limit has been 80 minutes (this year is 90 minutes), so we highly encourage you to take the practice exam under similar time constraints to get a feel for the general pacing. Lastly, we have found that the most effective way to study for the exam using lecture, recitation, or homework material is to recreate them. This involves covering up the solution and trying to rewrite the solution. If you get stuck, slowly uncover the solution until you are able to continue with your recreated proof again. It will also be beneficial if you think about how modifications of these questions can yield different proofs or can be counted differently, for example how might the solution differ if elements were distinguishable/indistinguishable?</p>

<md>With regard to Q3.

Is the graph (with walkways representing directed edges and sections representing nodes) being connected the same thing as the store having no dead-ends?

Does a dead-end mean that there is no walkway exiting the section? Or there is no path from the dead-end to the section where Bethany started?</md>
<md>With regard to Q3.

Is the graph (with walkways representing directed edges and sections representing nodes) being connected the same thing as the store having no dead-ends?

Does a dead-end mean that there is no walkway exiting the section? Or there is no path from the dead-end to the section where Bethany started?</md>
<p>A dead-end means that there is no walkway exiting the section. How that relates to connectivity is something you should think about.</p>

<p>For example if my IH is the claim works for n = 0&lt;=h&lt;=k, is it ok if in my Induction Step I only use the claim working for some values of h and never use it for n=k?</p>
<p>For example if my IH is the claim works for n = 0&lt;=h&lt;=k, is it ok if in my Induction Step I only use the claim working for some values of h and never use it for n=k?</p>
<p>yes that is okay</p>
<md>Can I have IH that assume the proposition is true for $$1\leq i\leq k$$ but only use $$n=k$$ in the IS?</md>
You could, but at that point you should just do weak induction because it is bad technique to have a strong IH and do ordinary induction in the IS.
<md>Can I have IH that assume the proposition is true for $$1\leq i\leq k$$ but only use $$n=k$$ in the IS?</md>
<p>yes, but for grading purposes, it would likely not receive full credit.</p>

<p>For this question, why does it not work for even numbers? I keep getting the same answer as the number of odds. Thank you!</p>
<p></p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedd9r8n6wb3dq%2F10ecd317e241008ca50c038104fb57f22ab85e5dfbf777cb12a81285dff43eeb%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-06_at_4.31.02_PM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2022-10-06_at_4.31.02_PM.png" /></p>
<p>For this question, why does it not work for even numbers? I keep getting the same answer as the number of odds. Thank you!</p>
<p></p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedd9r8n6wb3dq%2F10ecd317e241008ca50c038104fb57f22ab85e5dfbf777cb12a81285dff43eeb%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-06_at_4.31.02_PM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2022-10-06_at_4.31.02_PM.png" /></p>
<p>Basically the issue arises from Steps 1 and 2.</p>
<p></p>
<p>In step 1, we can say that there are five options for the fourth digit (namely 0, 2, 4, 6, 8). But after that, we can&#39;t quite say that for step 2, in choosing the first digit, there are only 8 options. This is because, if the digit we chose in step 1 is 0, then we actually have 9 options for the first digit.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Since the amount of ways to perform a step is not constant based on previous steps, we would be unable to perform the multiplication rule following the same procedure outlined in Attempt 3.</p>
<p>To find the total number of even numbers with distinct digits, does it make sense to find the total number of distinct digits (odd or even) and then divide by 2?</p>
<p>Not quite, because that would be implying that the total number of even numbers with distinct digits is the same as the total number of odd numbers with distinct digits, and using the logic I provided above, it doesn&#39;t seem like these two values should be equal. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Instead, you could modify that approach by counting complementarily!</p>
<p>For finding the total number of even numbers w/distinct digits, would it be accurate to consider two cases where 0 is the last number and 0 is not the last number? And then just use the Sum Rule and add them together?</p>
Yeah that works

<p>When defining P(n) in an induction proof, can we say, </p>
<p>&#34;Let P(n) be the truth of the claim for n&#34; </p>
<p>or do we have to be more specific and say,</p>
<p>&#34;Let P(n) be &#34;[actual words of the claim]&#34;?</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
You should be more specific 
<md>For induction, do we have to define it as P(n)? Is it unacceptable to say "assume that {specific words of the claim} holds true when n = k" in the IH instead of defining P(n) and saying "assume P(k)" to refer to the claim?</md>
<p>It is not required to define P(n). It is perfectly acceptable to not have it.</p>

<div>
<div>
<div>
<p>Consider n distinct objects and k bins labeled B_1, B_2, . . . , B_k. How many ways are there to distribute the objects in the bins so that bin B_i receives n_i objects and the sum from i=1  to k of n_i = n?</p>
</div>
</div>
<p></p>
<p>Why would the solution k^n not work. In other words, why does the following procedure not work:</p>
</div>
<p></p>
<p>Step 1: Determine the fate of object 1 (choose a bin: 1 to k). </p>
<p></p>
<p>Step 2: Determine the fate of object 2 </p>
<p>.</p>
<p>.</p>
<p>.</p>
<p>Step n: Determine the fate of object n</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>By MR, the total number of ways would be k^n.</p>
<p>In what type of proofs do we have to prove both ways? I know if we want to prove A = B, then we have to prove A is a subset of B and B is a subset of A. What other types of proof do we have to do this for? </p>
<p></p>
<p>On Lec 3T where we prove that the sqrt of 2 is irrational using the prime factorization method, why is S(a^2) even the contradiction? the notes say it is because the prime factorization of a positive integer must be unique. But I&#39;m not clear on how S(a^2) being even tells us this. Could you please explain?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Thank you! </p>
<p>Is it: Can be represented as a/b, where a is an int, and b is a non-zero int. Do they need to have no common factors? I know we used this definition sometimes with the fact that they have common factors, and sometimes without that fact.</p>
<p>Is it: Can be represented as a/b, where a is an int, and b is a non-zero int. Do they need to have no common factors? I know we used this definition sometimes with the fact that they have common factors, and sometimes without that fact.</p>
<p>Yeah, the definition is that if $$x \in \mathbb{Q}$$, then $$\exists a \in \mathbb{Z}$$ and $$\exists b \in \mathbb{Z} \setminus \{0\}$$ such that $$x = \frac{a}{b}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The definition does not require $$a$$ and $$b$$ to share no common factors, though we often include this constraint in our proofs for simplicity of the proof. </p>
<p>So for the proof of if sqrt(2) is irrational, we placed that constraint that a and b have not common factors to reach the contradiction faster / with less explaining?</p>
<p>Not necessarily for &#34;less explaining&#34;, but more so because that was actually the thing we contradicted. So you might be asking yourself, &#34;when should I add this &#39;constraint&#39;&#34;, and my answer to that would probably be most of the time.</p>
<p></p>
<p>This is because even though the definition with and without the constraint define the same term, without the constraint of $$a$$ and $$b$$ sharing no common factors, there are an infinite amount of choices for $$a$$ and $$b$$. Whereas, if we introduce the idea of $$a$$ and $$b$$ sharing no common factors, then there is only one such pair. </p>
<p>So for the proof of if sqrt(2) is irrational, we placed that constraint that a and b have not common factors to reach the contradiction faster / with less explaining?</p>
<p>Thank you!!</p>

<p>In lecture notes 3H, there is an example that asks, &#34;consider n distinct objects and k bins labeled B1, B2, . . . , Bk. How many ways are there to distribute the objects in the bins so that bin Bi receives ni objects the sum of all of the objects in the k bins is n?&#34;</p>

<p></p>

<p>This procedure does not guarantee bin $$B_i$$ gets exactly $$n_i$$ objects. For example, it is possible that you choose the same bin on every step here.</p>

<p></p>
<p>S_1 (no 2&#39;s) = 5! ways, since all are unique</p>
<p></p>
<p>S_2 (one 2) = choose place for a 2 (5 choose 1), then choose remaining unique items (5!/(5-4)!) </p>
<p></p>
<p>S_3 (two 2&#39;s) = choose positions for two 2&#39;s (5 choose 2), then choose remaining unique items (5!/(5-3)!)</p>

<p>But this could get tedious if we are working with a large number of items that have repetitions. </p>

<p>I partitioned the number of sequences into:</p>
<p></p>
<p>S_1 (no 2&#39;s) = 5! ways, since all are unique</p>
<p></p>
<p>S_2 (one 2) = choose place for a 2 (5 choose 1), then choose remaining unique items (5!/(5-4)!) </p>
<p></p>
<p>S_3 (two 2&#39;s) = choose positions for two 2&#39;s (5 choose 2), then choose remaining unique items (5!/(5-3)!)</p>
<p></p>
<p>But this could get tedious if we are working with a large number of items that have repetitions. </p>
<p></p>
<p>I guess my question is, can I somehow work the standard way of permuting multisets into this like in the lecture 3H on multisets? The problem is that not every element needs to have a position on the string... the total number of positions on the string doesn&#39;t add up to the total multiplicity of all the elements.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Also, will we get solutions to these at some point?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Thanks</p>
<p>yeah I think it&#39;s kind of hard to incorporate permuting multisets in this, because when we do those permutations, we have very few constraints. In this problem, we introduce a lot of constraints, and while it may be possible to incorporate these constraints by modifying how we permute the multisets, it gets (arguably) equally tedious.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Casing, though sometimes tedious, is usually quite effective, so you shouldn&#39;t rule it out immediately!</p>
<p></p>

<p>I will be hosting virtual OH on OHQ starting 10:30AM today!</p>
<p>I noticed in the solutions to HW6T Question 1, there were 3 base cases. Isn&#39;t the third base case (n=4) unnecessary so long as we change the bounds of k to k&gt;=3? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Would&#39;nt just one base case $$n=2$$ suffice?</p>
<p>Do we need to state the bounds for any variables in the induction step of the proof or are all the bounds defined in the induction hypothesis?</p>
<p></p>
<p>On the exam, would we be expected to provide a stronger claim in order to prove by induction for a claim that can&#39;t be proved as is (like the tile question in class)? </p>
<p>Similarly, would it possible for there to be bogus claims and instead of proving the claim, we would need to say the claim is false (like the sheep question)? Or would all &#34;prove ___&#34; questions have valid claims?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Thank you!</p>
<p>In the Binomial Theorem, the notes say that a and b must be real numbers. With the 2^n example, I used (2 &#43; 0)^n and expanded using the binomial theorem. However, I didn&#39;t get the same answer as the lecture notes. Is that a fault in my calculation or should this work? </p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>In the Binomial Theorem, the notes say that a and b must be real numbers. With the 2^n example, I used (2 &#43; 0)^n and expanded using the binomial theorem. However, I didn&#39;t get the same answer as the lecture notes. Is that a fault in my calculation or should this work? </p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>you can still use $$(2 + 0)^n$$, but you will arrive at something different than $$\sum_{k=0}^n \binom{n}{k}$$, because when we did $$(1 + 1)^n$$, we were able to simplify nicely using the fact that $$1^m = 1$$ for any $$m$$, but we do not have that leverage when we do $$(2+0)^n$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>tldr: yeah it works, but it just gives you different information</p>
<p>But if we do (2 &#43; 0)^n, we basically prove that 2^n = 0, which proves the claim false?</p>
<p>not quite. You get the following:</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$(2+0)^n = \sum_{k=0}^n \binom{n}{k} 2^{n-k}0^k = \binom{n}{0} 2^{n-0}0^0 + \sum_{k=1}^n \binom{n}{k} 2^{n-k}0^k = 1 \cdot 2^n \cdot 1 + 0 = 2^n$$</p>
<p></p>
<p>so you really just prove that $$2^n = 2^n$$ which, admittedly, isn&#39;t very exciting :(</p>
response time: 0:04:51



<p>In the question in Lecture 4H, where we are proving that there exists a subsequence of consecutive integers whose sum is a multiple of n.</p>
<p></p>
<p>How did we conclude that we have n sums to apply PHP? Would the total number of possible sequences be n(n &#43; 1)/2? </p>
<p>In the question in Lecture 4H, where we are proving that there exists a subsequence of consecutive integers whose sum is a multiple of n.</p>
<p></p>
<p>How did we conclude that we have n sums to apply PHP? Would the total number of possible sequences be n(n &#43; 1)/2? </p>
<p>The total number of possible subsequences is indeed $$\frac{n(n+1)}{2}$$, but we only chose to look at a subset of them so that we could proceed with the later steps of the problem (i.e. generating a new subsequence from two of our $$n$$ subsequences).</p>
response time: 1:11:08

<p>Are we allowed to use the distributive properties for logical operators on the exam without justifying it using a truth table as long as we clearly indicate where we are using it? That is, </p>
<p></p>
<p>X ∧ (Y ∨ Z) ≡ (X ∧ Y) ∨ (X ∧ Z)</p>
<p>X ∨ (Y ∧ Z) ≡ (X ∨ Y) ∧ (X ∨ Z)</p>

<p>Or is it required to prove it once using a truth table in the exam before using it?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Are we allowed to use the distributive properties for logical operators on the exam without justifying it using a truth table as long as we clearly indicate where we are using it? That is, </p>
<p></p>
<p>X ∧ (Y ∨ Z) ≡ (X ∧ Y) ∨ (X ∧ Z)</p>
<p>X ∨ (Y ∧ Z) ≡ (X ∨ Y) ∧ (X ∨ Z)</p>
<p> </p>
<p>Or is it required to prove it once using a truth table in the exam before using it?</p>
<p>I think we&#39;ve proven this in a homework, so you don&#39;t have to justify it via a truth table on the exam.</p>

<p>From the post: &#34;<strong>Wu &amp; Chen&#34;</strong> (This is located near the entrance of Levine Hall)</p>
<p>I am looking at the following question in Lecture 3T:</p>
<p></p>
<p>Example. Show that there exist irrational numbers x and y such that x^y is rational.</p>
<p></p>
<p>What is the purpose of Case II in this question? I am also confused how this question can be proven simply by giving an example.</p>
<p>I am looking at the following question in Lecture 3T:</p>
<p></p>
<p>Example. Show that there exist irrational numbers x and y such that x^y is rational.</p>
<p></p>
<p>What is the purpose of Case II in this question? I am also confused how this question can be proven simply by giving an example.</p>
<p>Since the question is asking us to show existence, providing a true example would qualify as showing existence.</p>
<p></p>
<p>We break it up into two cases because we don&#39;t really know whether $$\sqrt{2}^{\sqrt{2}}$$ is rational or irrational. If it&#39;s rational, then great. But if not, then we can use this value to provide a different $$x$$ and $$y$$ where $$x^y$$ is rational.</p>
<p></p>
<p>In essence, we are &#39;pretending&#39; that we don&#39;t know whether or not $$\sqrt{2}^{\sqrt{2}}$$ is rational, but regardless of its status, we can use it as is, or use it to create new values.</p>
response time: 0:08:49



<p>Can everything that is proved by a contrapositive also be proved by contradiction?</p>
<p></p>
<p>I’m wondering because contrapositive proves p-&gt;q by proving not q implies not p. However, wouldn’t be proving that not p and q, which is impossible if the contrapositive is true, leads to a contradiction be equivalent?</p>
<p>When writing the induction hypothesis, do we need to restate the claim the way it is done in class? For example, do we need to say &#34;Assume that this claim is true for n = k, for some arbitrary but particular integer k. In other words, assume that.......&#34; or is &#34;Assume that this claim is true for n = k, for some arbitrary but particular integer k&#34; sufficient?</p>
<p>When writing the induction hypothesis, do we need to restate the claim the way it is done in class? For example, do we need to say &#34;Assume that this claim is true for n = k, for some arbitrary but particular integer k. In other words, assume that.......&#34; or is &#34;Assume that this claim is true for n = k, for some arbitrary but particular integer k&#34; sufficient?</p>
<p>It is not a necessity, but it is something I highly encourage to do. This is because without restating the claim, there is a higher chance of ambiguity. But if you restate the claim in your IH, it is clear to the proof reader exactly what you are assuming.</p>
response time: 0:01:27

<p>Can this be proved using weak induction by saying in case 2 that according to the fundamental thm of arithmetic, a composite number is a product of primes?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Or is this the proof for the fundamental thm of arithmetic? <img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedd9r8n6wb3dq%2Fbefb2a9dce9d89052c0c9a80756efe0765623ddbe35cf95ccacca2027f2b67de%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_5.04.43_PM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_5.04.43_PM.pngNaN" /></p>
<p>Can this be proved using weak induction by saying in case 2 that according to the fundamental thm of arithmetic, a composite number is a product of primes?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Or is this the proof for the fundamental thm of arithmetic? <img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedd9r8n6wb3dq%2Fbefb2a9dce9d89052c0c9a80756efe0765623ddbe35cf95ccacca2027f2b67de%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_5.04.43_PM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_5.04.43_PM.pngNaN" /></p>
<p>This is not quite a proof for the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic because that theorem also mentions that the prime factorization is unique. That being said, strong induction is not needed for this proof. In fact, one can avoid induction completely by mentioning how the claim is just a corollary of the FTA, but for the purpose of example, we did a proof by strong induction.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Also using FTA in the IS doesn&#39;t really make it a weak induction proof because it&#39;s not really getting reduced to the $$k$$ case (where you would use your weak IH).</p>
response time: 0:16:34



<p>is P(6,5) the same as 6^5</p>
<p>is P(6,5) the same as 6^5</p>
<p>No. $$P(6, 5) = \frac{6!}{(6-5)!} = 6! \neq 6^5$$</p>

<p>1. In L3H, for the question that asks for a proof that the sum of the integers 1 to n = n (n&#43;1) /2, I do not understand the paritition when finding the LHS. What is the signfigance of &#34;i is the bigger element in the pair&#34;?</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7glbo5bn7z3hf%2F2bcff7441a25a5fc1067a4b7ee6e18d8f53a7ca0e77f8710b063fd52764daef7%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" /></p>
<p>2. Also, just to confirm, can we use anything proved in lecture on the exam without a proof (ie. sum of odds/evens, Pascal&#39;s Formula, cardinality of power set)? </p>
<p>1. In L3H, for the question that asks for a proof that the sum of the integers 1 to n = n (n&#43;1) /2, I do not understand the paritition when finding the LHS. What is the signfigance of &#34;i is the bigger element in the pair&#34;?</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7glbo5bn7z3hf%2F2bcff7441a25a5fc1067a4b7ee6e18d8f53a7ca0e77f8710b063fd52764daef7%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" /></p>
<p>2. Also, just to confirm, can we use anything proved in lecture on the exam without a proof (ie. sum of odds/evens, Pascal&#39;s Formula, cardinality of power set)? </p>
<p>1. Given two distinct elements, $$a$$ and $$b$$, one must be larger than the other. So we are partitioning the set of all pairs into groupings based on what the largest value in the pair is.</p>
<p></p>
<p>So if, for example, $$S = \{0, 1, 2, 3\}$$, then we would have $$S_1 = \{(0, 1)\}$$, $$S_2 = \{(0, 2), (1, 2)\}$$, and $$S_3 = \{(0, 3), (1, 3), (2, 3)\}$$. We partition like this because it is easy to calculate the cardinality of each $$S_i$$. Namely, $$|S_i| = i$$, but each $$S_i$$ is formed by the largest value in the pair.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>2. yes</p>
response time: 0:04:46



<p>I will be holding office hours today from 9-10:15pm in Lev 307.</p>
<p>We have proven in class that if a square number is even, then the number itself is even. So are we allowed to directly say: $$p^2=6q^2\implies 2|p^2\implies p=2k,k\in\mathbb{Z}$$? If not, what justification do we have to give?</p>
<p>We have proven in class that if a square number is even, then the number itself is even. So are we allowed to directly say: $$p^2=6q^2\implies 2|p^2\implies p=2k,k\in\mathbb{Z}$$? If not, what justification do we have to give?</p>
<p>I would give a one sentence explanation in between each of the implications. So I would say $$p^2 = 6q^2 \implies 2\mid p^2$$ because since $$6q^2 = 2(3q^2)$$ is even, $$p^2$$ must also be even.</p>
<p></p>
<p>And an explanation for $$2\mid p^2 \implies p = 2k$$ would be: &#34;we proved this in class&#34;</p>

<md>![Screenshot_2022-10-10_at_7.50.08_PM.pngNaN](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fl7gcywgetsa6wn%2F2d663cb69546a50a64550c11fb5eca51f5be7b89aece10678ae399c6cfe769cd%2FScreenshot_2022-10-10_at_7.50.08_PM.png)

For this question, instead of using induction can we just use basic arithmetic to telescope the answer? Since the product is $$s_n = \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{2}{3}\times … \times\frac{n-2}{n-1}\times \frac{n-1}{n}$$, we can just cancel out all the numbers except 1 and $n$, so we would immediately get $$\frac{1}{n}$$.</md>

<p>what does it mean when an integer is relatively prime</p>

<p>Q5: Prove that between any two distinct rational numbers, there exist infinitely many rational numbers.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The solution uses contradiction to prove this, but wondering if the following direct proof works as well:</p>
<p>Let x and y be the 2 distinct rational numbers</p>
<p></p>
<p>x = a/b, y = c/d, where b and d are not 0. WLOG suppose x &lt; y</p>
<p></p>
<p>a/b &lt; c/d</p>
<p></p>
<p>We can find a rational number between the two fractions by doing the following:</p>
<p></p>
<p>ad/bd &lt; cb/bd (multiply both sides by d and b respectively)</p>
<p></p>
<p>add one to smaller fraction on the numerator:</p>
<p></p>
<p>ad/bd &lt; (ad &#43; 1) / bd &lt; cb/bd</p>
<p></p>
<p>We know that this is true because multiplying the top and bottom by d and b respectively adds a gap between the two numbers, such that the number generated by adding 1 to the numerator is still smaller than cb/bd.</p>
<p></p>
<p>We can keep repeating this process to generate more fractions between x and y.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The answer to question 11 in M1_practice_problems  lists the contradictions for all cases. However, since we are proving the statement through proof by contradiction would just one of these cases be enough? Or do we need to show contradictions for all possible cases?</p>
<p>Case 1 : m is even and n is even. This is impossible, since m and n are relatively prime.</p>
<p>for this line in the practice problems we can ignore 2 because it says for all integers right</p>
<p>Case 1 : m is even and n is even. This is impossible, since m and n are relatively prime.</p>
<p>for this line in the practice problems we can ignore 2 because it says for all integers right</p>
<p>wait what do you mean by &#34;ignore 2&#34;</p>
<p>well i mean like 2 is prime and even but that&#39;s only like one case so we dont care about that one right</p>
<p>evenness and relatively prime are two different things. Evenness describes a single value, whereas &#34;relatively prime&#34; describes two numbers. You can have an even integer be a part of a relatively prime pair. For example $$4$$ is relatively prime to $$5$$. Also, $$6$$ is relatively prime to $$25$$, for example. </p>
<p></p>
<p>The proof is enumerating all possibilities of the parities of m and n, but we skip over this particular case because of the assumption that $$m$$ and $$n$$ are relatively prime. It is impossible for $$m$$ and $$n$$ to both be even and both be relatively prime, because if both are even, then $$2 \mid m$$ and $$2 \mid n$$, but this would go against the definition of &#34;relatively prime&#34;.</p>
<p>well i mean like 2 is prime and even but that&#39;s only like one case so we dont care about that one right</p>
<p>wait what </p>
<p>well i mean like 2 is prime and even but that&#39;s only like one case so we dont care about that one right</p>
<p>ok so 4 is relatively prime to 5 because it doesn&#39;t divide into 5 </p>
<p>well i mean like 2 is prime and even but that&#39;s only like one case so we dont care about that one right</p>
<p>ohhhhh like you are saying 2 and 2 are not relatively prime because 2 divides evenly by 2</p>
<p>well i mean like 2 is prime and even but that&#39;s only like one case so we dont care about that one right</p>
<p>but like 5 does not divide evenly by 4?</p>
<p>well i mean like 2 is prime and even but that&#39;s only like one case so we dont care about that one right</p>
<p>Remember the definition of &#34;relatively prime&#34;: $$x$$ and $$y$$ are relatively prime if and only if they share no common factors other than $$1$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>So $$4$$ and $$5$$ are relatively prime, because the factors of $$4$$ are $$1, 2$$ and $$4$$, and the prime factors of $$5$$ are only $$1$$ and $$5$$. Since the only common factor of $$4$$ and $$5$$ is one, we conclude that they are relatively prime.</p>

<p>Why do we need the n=4 base case in this problem?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Without it, k&#43;1 is greater than or equal to 4, since the induction hypothesis holds for k greater than or equal to 3. k&#43;1 can be expressed as 2 &#43; k-1, and k-1 is less than or equal to k and greater than or equal to two, which is a base case.</p>
<p>Why do we need the n=4 base case in this problem?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Without it, k&#43;1 is greater than or equal to 4, since the induction hypothesis holds for k greater than or equal to 3. k&#43;1 can be expressed as 2 &#43; k-1, and k-1 is less than or equal to k and greater than or equal to two, which is a base case.</p>

<p>For Question 7, is it sufficient to show the procedure to create two create a partition of the string that meets these conditions, rather than proving that it is possible?</p>
<p></p>
<p>For example my solution was that in a string of n characters, we have x 0s, and thus n-x 1s, where $0 \leq x, n-x \leq n$. Thus, if the first substring is of length m and contains a 0s, we want to find where the number of 0s in the first substring equals the number of 1s in the second substring. As an equation, we get a = (n-x) - (m-a). -&gt; a = n - m - x &#43; a -&gt; m = n-x.</p>

<p>I am unsure if my thinking is correct for this question.</p>
<p></p>
<p>1. Here is my understanding: there are n distinct objects. Once within a bin, these objects are indistinguisble. We get the multiset: {n_1*B_1, n_2*B_2 ...n_k*B_k}. The bins are like categories containing a bunch of indistinguisble n_i objects. We are trying to find how many ways we can order all n objects. This is simply the permutation of the multiset, so we can use the formula we derived in L3H. </p>
<p></p>
<p>2. For the formula being used in this problem--is this formula just the number of ways you can order elements of a multiset? Like if we had {a*2, b*3,c*4}, is this formula calculating the number of ways you can order a, b, and c (9!) and then dividing out the number of ways you can order the elements of type a, b, and c since they are indistinguisble (2!3!4!)? </p>
<p></p>
<p>3. What differentiates this from a sticks and crosses problem?</p>

<p>I am unsure if my thinking is correct for this question.</p>
<p></p>
<p>1. Here is my understanding: there are n distinct objects. Once within a bin, these objects are indistinguisble. We get the multiset: {n_1*B_1, n_2*B_2 ...n_k*B_k}. The bins are like categories containing a bunch of indistinguisble n_i objects. We are trying to find how many ways we can order all n objects. This is simply the permutation of the multiset, so we can use the formula we derived in L3H. </p>
<p></p>
<p>2. For the formula being used in this problem--is this formula just the number of ways you can order elements of a multiset? Like if we had {a*2, b*3,c*4}, is this formula calculating the number of ways you can order a, b, and c (9!) and then dividing out the number of ways you can order the elements of type a, b, and c since they are indistinguisble (2!3!4!)? </p>
<p></p>
<p>3. What differentiates this from a sticks and crosses problem?</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>1. you should not think of the objects as &#34;indistinguishable&#34; when they are in the same bin.</p>
<p></p>
<p>2. yes</p>

<p>On the exam, even if we haven&#39;t defined P(n), would it be acceptable for us to say &#34;we want to prove the claim&#34;? For example, could we just say in the IH that &#34;we assume the claim is true for n=k,&#34; instead of saying &#34;we assume [the entire expression] is true for n=k&#43;1&#34;?</p>

Strike out the ones you don&#39;t want us to grade. If it is not clear, we will pick an arbitrary, but particular solution to grade.</li><li>As I have said multiple times in class, we try to make questions that are &#34;$$\epsilon$$-away&#34; (for a small $$\epsilon$$ :)) from what you may have seen in class, hws, and recitations. <p>For permutations of a multiset, should we explain the logic or can we directly use the formula <br /><br />$$\frac{n!}{n_1! ... n_k!}$$.</p>
<p>Can you explain when to use this formula vs sticks/crosses? </p>
Sticks and crosses is for counting the amount of ways to distribute indistinguishable objects into distinguishable bins.<div><br /></div><div>Permutations of a multiset is for counting the the number of distinct arrangements of a set of items with potentIal repeats.</div><div><br /></div><div>There is no “distribution” in permutations of a multiset</div>

<p>For case 2 (there is 1 2 in the sequence), I reasoned that we had to distribute 7 letters (P, E, R, M, 1, 2, and 3) among five spots, so the answer should be P(7,5). I understand the way of getting to the answer in the solutions, but what&#39;s wrong with this approach?</p>
<p>For case 2 (there is 1 2 in the sequence), I reasoned that we had to distribute 7 letters (P, E, R, M, 1, 2, and 3) among five spots, so the answer should be P(7,5). I understand the way of getting to the answer in the solutions, but what&#39;s wrong with this approach?</p>
<p>Because P(7, 5) does not guarantee that one of the five characters chosen is a 2.</p>
<p></p>
<p>To further clarify, note that $$P(7, 5) = \binom{7}{5} \cdot 5!$$ which can be thought of as a two step procedure:</p>
<p></p>
<p>Step 1: choose the five elements</p>
<p>Step 2: permute the five elements.</p>
<p></p>
<p>But step 1 does not guarantee we choose the character 2.</p>
<p>Because P(7, 5) does not guarantee that one of the five characters chosen is a 2.</p>
<p>I wrote out the three cases, and got the same answer for the other two cases. I&#39;m saying in the case that only 1 2 is included, why wouldn&#39;t this be the answer?</p>
<p>yeah but in the specific case you inquired about, we want exactly one 2 to appear.</p>

<p>For part a, I first calculated the permutations: 13 ways to choose the value for a four of a kind, 4*3*2*1*48 (for the last card). Then, I divided away the repeats by dividing the expression 13*4*3*2*48 by 5!, but I&#39;m getting a different answer. Why is this?</p>
<p>For part a, I first calculated the permutations: 13 ways to choose the value for a four of a kind, 4*3*2*1*48 (for the last card). Then, I divided away the repeats by dividing the expression 13*4*3*2*48 by 5!, but I&#39;m getting a different answer. Why is this?</p>
<p>Can you explain why you are multiplying $$4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1$$? If it&#39;s because there are &#34;four options&#34; for the first slot, and &#34;three options&#34; for the second slot, and so on, then you should be dividing by $$4!$$ because you&#39;ve already fixed the last card to be the non-four-of-a-kind.</p>
<p></p>
<p>If you are doing that multiplication because of the suits, then it is important to realize that the order of the cards within a hand doesn&#39;t matter.</p>
<p>I am multiplying 4*3*2*1 because once we have determined the value of the four-of-a-kind, there are 4 ways to choose the first card, 3 to choose the second (only three more of the target card exists within the deck), etc.</p>
<p></p>
<p>I thought we could get the combinations by dividing the permutations by the number of ways to order the elements chosen to get the combinations?</p>
<p></p>
<p>In this case, I found the permutations of the 5 desired elements, then divided by 5! to get rid of the effect of permutations</p>
<p>Yeah dividing is totally okay, but only if you have actually considered all permutations of the five cards. In this case, you&#39;ve fixed the last card to be the non-four-of-a-kind, so you aren&#39;t able to divide by 5! since not all permutations have been considered.</p>

<p></p>
<p>in other words, can we just assume A=B is equivalent to (A\B = {} and B\A = {})</p>
<p>How do we prove for arbitrary sets <strong>A and B that A=B iff A is a subset of B and B is a subset of A</strong>?</p>
<p></p>
<p>For the -&gt; direction proof, do we use a definition for A=B such as this?...</p>
<p></p>
<p>x is an element of A and x is an element of B And there is no y such that y is an element of A and y is not an element of B or vice versa.</p>
<p></p>
<p>in other words, can we just assume A=B is equivalent to (A\B = {} and B\A = {})</p>
<p>yeah you can assume that. There isn&#39;t really too much to prove here because it is just a definition, but if you were to explain why the definition makes sense logically, the way you are approaching it is fine.</p>

<p>Hey everyone! <br /><br /></p>
<p>Congratulations on completing the first midterm! For the remainder of the course, there will be limited collaboration allowed on homeworks. <strong>Please carefully read this post and complete the Collaboration Quiz on Gradescope</strong><strong>. You are responsible for understanding what is allowed/not allowed – if you have any questions feel free to ask. </strong></p>
<p></p>
<p>If you wish, for each assignment going forward (starting with 7H), you may organize into collaboration teams of 2 or 3 current students (you can use @5 to search for teammates).</p>
<p></p>
<p>You may only be part of one team and must list all team members on your homework submission, whether or not you specifically spoke with them for each homework assignment. You may have different teams for different assignments. See examples below.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Collaboration can only consist of discussions. After you have discussed ideas with your collaborators, you must write your solutions on your own. You are not allowed to write up the solutions together. Sharing of solutions essentially as they are written in a LaTeX file, an email, a PDF, over Zoom, or elsewhere is not allowed. This includes submitting solutions that you might obtain from the web or from people not enrolled in CIS 160. The result will be penalties that may go as far as failing the course and/or being reported to the Office of Student Conduct. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Our suggestion is to discuss the problems together, but if you made any notes or worked out something with another person while you were discussing the homework, erase or destroy those notes as soon as the discussion is over. You shouldn&#39;t use those notes while writing up your answer, however tempted you may be to do so. This will force you to write up the solutions yourself and to make sure that you genuinely and fully understand them.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The only materials you may reference when writing homework solutions are course materials (lecture notes, homework solutions, and recitation guides), but no other resources are allowed. This policy extends to the Internet. Posting homework questions and/or course materials to online forums such as Stack Overflow, Chegg, Course Hero, etc. is both a violation of this collaboration policy and copyright infringement on the materials authored by the course staff.</p>
<p></p>
<p>If you would like to use part of a solution from a problem presented in lecture, recitation, or past homework solutions you may do so with attribution; i.e., provided you add a comment in which you make clear you copied it from these sources. It&#39;s especially important to tell us if you use our words because if multiple students do it for the same words, it looks the same as if you copied each other. Using our words with citation is fine, but copying each other is not.</p>
<p>Although this is obvious, it bears repeating: submitting solutions that you have not written by yourself is directly detrimental to your performance in the exams.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Example 1: ALLOWED</p>
<ul><li>Rajiv lists Swap and Sampath as collaborators.</li><li>Sampath lists Swap and Rajiv as collaborators.</li><li>Swap lists Rajiv and Sampath as collaborators.</li></ul>
<p>Example 2: NOT ALLOWED</p>
<ul><li>Rajiv lists Sanjeev and Sampath as collaborators.</li><li>Sanjeev lists Sampath and Swap as collaborators.</li><li>Sampath lists Swap and Rajiv as collaborators.</li><li>Swap lists Rajiv and Sanjeev as collaborators.</li></ul>
<p>Example 2 is a violation of the policy since the size of the team is 4 (which is bigger than the maximum of 3 allowed). Sanjeev would have to list Rajiv, which would give him 3 collaborators.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Example 3: NOT ALLOWED</p>
<ul><li>Rajiv lists Sanjeev as a collaborator.</li><li>Sanjeev lists Rajiv and Sampath as collaborators.</li><li>Sampath lists Sanjeev as a collaborator.</li></ul>
<p>Example 3 is a violation of the policy since Rajiv does not list Sampath. Even if Rajiv and Sampath never directly spoke to each other, they are considered part of the same &#34;team.&#34;</p>
<p></p>
<p>Some examples of collaboration which are NOT permitted include:</p>
<ul><li>Discussing and/or solving homework problems with friends not enrolled in the course</li><li>Posting homework questions to the Internet</li><li>Searching for homework solutions on the Internet</li><li>Borrowing your friend&#39;s homework solutions from last year</li><li>Giving your homework solutions to a friend (this includes screen-sharing documents)</li></ul>
<p>If you are unsure of whether or not something is allowed under this policy, please don&#39;t hesitate to speak with a member of the course staff or make a private post on Piazza.</p>
<p>Any violation of the collaboration policy will be dealt with severely.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Some penalties that have been given in the past are:</p>
<ul><li>A 0 on all homeworks submitted before and including the one in which a violation was found</li><li>A referral to the Office of Student Conduct (OSC)</li></ul>
<p>This policy supersedes all previous collaboration policies.</p>
<p></p>
<p>#pin</p>
<p>@5 linked on the post seems to lead nowhere for me.</p>
<p>Working, thank you!</p>

As long as it’s legible to at least one of us, you should be good. Shouldn’t be something to worry about.

<p>If you have something like P(A) U P(B) U P(C) U P(D) U P(E) U P(F) instead of writing out set operations on 6 terms can you break it down into P(A U B U C) U P(D U E U F) so u do two set operations on 3 terms and then one on 2 terms or is that not the same thing?</p>
<p>If you have something like P(A) U P(B) U P(C) U P(D) U P(E) U P(F) instead of writing out set operations on 6 terms can you break it down into P(A U B U C) U P(D U E U F) so u do two set operations on 3 terms and then one on 2 terms or is that not the same thing?</p>
<p>What do you mean by P(A)? If you mean powerset, then no, because it is not true that $$P(A) \cup P(B) = P(A \cup B)$$ because $$\{a, b\} \in P(A \cup B)$$ but $$\{a, b\} \notin P(A) \cup P(B)$$</p>
<p></p>
<p>If $$P(A)$$ means something else, then it depends on what that &#34;something else&#34; is, which means you may not be able to safely break it down in the way you suggested.</p>
<p>Sorry it just meant Probability of even A, I forgot to do Pr(A), apologies</p>
