<p>Sorry it just meant Probability of even A, I forgot to do Pr(A), apologies</p>
<p>I see. Then such a &#34;simplification&#34; can only occur depending on the independence of the events.</p>
<p></p>
<p>What I mean by this is that $$Pr(A \cup B \cup C) = Pr(A) + Pr(B) + Pr(C)$$ only if $$A, B, C$$ are mutually independent.</p>
<p>Sorry it just meant Probability of even A, I forgot to do Pr(A), apologies</p>
<p>You couldn&#39;t make it like P(A ∪ B ∪ C) = P(A) &#43; P(B) &#43; P(C) - P(A ∩ B) - P(A ∩ C) - P(B ∩ C) &#43; P(A ∩ B ∩ C) </p>
<p>P(D ∪ E ∪ F) = P(D) &#43; P(E) &#43; P(F) - P(D ∩ E) - P(E ∩ F) - P(D ∩ F) &#43; P(D ∩ E ∩ F) then just do P(A U B U C) U P(D U E U F) = (P(A) &#43; P(B) &#43; P(C) - P(A ∩ B) - P(A ∩ C) - P(B ∩ C) &#43; P(A ∩ B ∩ C) ) &#43; (P(D) &#43; P(E) &#43; P(F) - P(D ∩ E) - P(E ∩ F) - P(D ∩ F) &#43; P(D ∩ E ∩ F))?</p>

<p>Am I misremembering or were we told in lecture that for any probability problem we must define the sample space explicitly. Will points be taken off if it’s not there?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Also, when we’re defining large sample spaces are we allowed to use … (dot dot dot) notation cause I think it might have been said that it’s too imprecise?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Also when we are doing it must it only be numeric and symbolic or can we also describe the sample space using words?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Thanks</p>
<p>You should always define your sample space explicitly. Otherwise, you do risk losing points.</p>
<p></p>
<p>You can use ... notation so long as clarity is maintained and no ambiguity is introduced.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Sample spaces can be defined using words only. Numbers and symbols are also always welcomed.</p>

response time: 0:00:43



<p>On the first exam, I got a few points below one standard deviation below the mean (so a little below a 30 I think). I remember feeling lost on the exam, finding myself not having any idea how to go about<br />solving a problem, or solving it completely wrong. I decided to stay in the class because Rajiv assured me that if I continued to work hard, it was highly unlikely that I would fail.</p>
<p>After the first exam, I made more of an effort to come to Rajiv&#39;s office hours every week, ask for clarification every time I didn&#39;t understand something in class, and understand the homework problems as well as possible. These three things (particularly asking questions in class and in Rajiv&#39;s office hours), and staying in touch with Rajiv over email, kept me from giving up. However, I continued to struggle just as much in the second exam, getting approximately the same score<br />as the first.  </p>
<p>I think the pressure and time constraint of the 160 exams hurt my performance dramatically on the first two exams. Looking back afterwords at the problems, I realized that they were much simpler than I thought. So, before the final, I talked with my parents, and made them (and by extension myself) okay with the idea of failing. This alleviated the pressure of the exam, and led me to do much better on the final-- getting a few points above average, and passing in the course. Although 160 with Rajiv was the hardest academic experience I have ever had, it was also the most meaningful. I was pushed to redefine my self-worth to not be in terms of academic success, and I learned so much more than I thought I could.</p>
<p>So, for you, I would recommend first looking back at the exam and thinking about whether you understand the problems given unlimited time. It&#39;s okay if some still don&#39;t make sense, I remember feeling that way because I hadn&#39;t figured out how to learn in 160 at this point. I would also think about how you have been learning so far, and if there might be ways you can improve (such as the ways I mentioned above). If you feel that there are, this is a sign that you can improve your performance in the class. Additionally, I would recommend working on reducing the stress you have related to this class-- if you can get to a point where you are not worried about your performance you will have a much easier time learning and doing well on exams. </p>
<p>Is the outcome of the ducks having bread of type a on day 1 and having bread of type b on day two different from having  bread of type b on day 1 and having bread of type a on day 2?</p>
<p>Hi all,</p>
<p></p>
<p>I have been receiving many emails from students who are concerned about their performance in CIS 1600 exam 1. I suggest the following for most students:</p>
<p></p>
<p>You should evaluate as to why you may have got the score that you received in exam 1. Was it exam pressure, or lack of understanding of some of the material, or a combination of the two? Whatever it is, be honest to yourself and if there are holes in your understanding of the material, fix them as soon as possible as the material will only get more challenging. CIS 1600 staff will be more than happy to help you with that.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The questions that you should ask yourself is why did you lose points (if you did) on Questions 1,2,3,4,5? We feel that most of these questions were straightforward, for example, Q.5 was a simpler version of NIM, which was done in the lecture. Q.8 was similar to the question from Hw 3H. </p>
<p></p>
<p>More general advice:</p>
<p>1.  A lot of grade is still open and it is not hard to bounce back from a low exam 1 grade. In the past people have got in 30s (avg being in mid 50s) and have still managed to get an &#39;A&#39;.</p>
<p>2. If you don&#39;t follow something in class, stop me and ask questions in class. The more you understand in class, the less you will have to work outside of class. If you come to class and not understand, you waste 90 minutes and then you spend more time outside of class understanding the material and hence start working on homework late and as a consequence always feel short of time.</p>
<p>3. Attend my office hours as we go over material covered in lecture multiple times.</p>
<p>4.  Re-create lecture notes soon after the lecture is over; you should not be leaving that for days before the exam. If you understood most of what is covered in class this should not take much time.</p>
<p>5. While collaboration is allowed on the rest of the homeworks this semester, it will be a huge mistake to be dependent on your partners. Collaboration can be very beneficial, if used well, but it can be very detrimental if not used the way it is intended. Our hope is that after the first half of the semester and after you have seen how CIS 1600 exams are, you will know what is the &#34;right&#34; way to collaborate. If you are unsure, ask any of the CIS 1600 staff.</p>
<p>In summary, CIS 1600 staff is there to help you. If you need something let us know, but you will have to work hard. You have just over amonth for exam 2 and about two months until the end of the semester! All the best!</p>
<p>See @1064.  If you have time, you may want to attend this talk.</p>

<p>Hey everyone, as collaboration starts, we wanted to clarify some OH expectations. You should still be asking questions as an individual, not as a group. We want you to still attempt to solve problems by yourself, as that process/experience will be valuable for exams.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>To get most out of tomorrow&#39;s lecture, please review the following.</p>
<ul><li>all terminology related to graphs</li><li>theorems that we proved in class (it&#39;s alright to not know the proofs)</li><li>Trees and the related terminology</li></ul>
<p>The above should not take more than 15 mins or so, but it will really help you understand the lecture tomorrow.</p>
<p>Should we leave our answer in exact form or round? </p>
<p>Should we leave our answer in exact form or round? </p>
Don’t round. Exact.

<p>For this example, I&#39;m a bit confused about how we came up with the probabilities for the cases where w1 = w2 and w1 does not equal w2. Could you please explain? </p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt0cz590wc77nm%2F443f05c6f3d035bd2a23f2d79972d8f88255a461900f70d788e874a0f22b6ebd%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" width="631" height="151" /></p>
<p></p>
<p>For this example, I&#39;m a bit confused about how we came up with the probabilities for the cases where w1 = w2 and w1 does not equal w2. Could you please explain? </p>
<p>For the outcomes where $$w_1 = w_2 = i, i \in \{1, 2, 3\}$$, three things need to occur:</p>
<ol><li>The prize is assigned to door $$i$$</li><li>The contestant chooses door $$i$$</li><li>The host opens door $$j$$ where $$j \neq i$$</li></ol>
<p></p>
<p>Let&#39;s analyze the probability of each of these:</p>
<ol><li>Since the prize is equally likely to be assigned to any of the doors, and there are $$3$$ doors, there is a $$1/3$$ chance of the prize being assigned to door $$i$$</li><li>Since the contestant is equally likely to choose any of the doors, and there are $$3$$ doors, there is a $$1/3$$ chance of the contestant choosing door $$i$$</li><li>The $$2$$ remaining doors both do not contain the prize, so the host can choose either of them. Since there are $$2$$ remaining doors and both have an equal chance of being chosen, there is a $$1/2$$ chance of the host choosing door $$j$$</li></ol>
<p>How many outcomes are of this form? We can use multiplication rule:</p>
<ol><li>Choose what value $$i$$ is - $$3$$ ways</li><li>Choose what value $$j$$ is - $$2$$ ways</li></ol>
<p>So there are $$6$$ total outcomes of this form.</p>
<p></p>
<p>----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------</p>
<p></p>
<p>For the outcomes where $$w_1 = i$$ and $$w_2 = j$$ where $$i, j \in \{1, 2, 3\}$$ and $$i \neq j$$, three things need to occur:</p>
<ol><li>The prize is assigned to door $$i$$</li><li>The contestant chooses door $$j$$</li><li>The host opens door $$k$$ where $$k \neq i, j$$</li></ol>
<p>Let&#39;s analyze the probability of each of these:</p>
<ol><li>Since the prize is equally likely to be assigned to any of the doors, and there are $$3$$ doors, there is a $$1/3$$ chance of the prize being assigned to door $$i$$</li><li>Since the contestant is equally likely to choose any of the doors, and there are $$3$$ doors, there is a $$1/3$$ chance of the contestant choosing door $$j$$</li><li>There is only one remaining door the host can open that is not $$i$$ or $$j$$, so there is a $$1$$ chance of the hosting choosing this remaining door.</li></ol>
<p>How many outcomes are of this form? We can use multiplication rule:</p>
<ol><li>Choose what value $$i$$ is - $$3$$ ways</li><li>Choose what value $$j$$ is - $$2$$ ways</li><li>Choose what value $$k$$ is -  $$1$$ way</li></ol>
<p>So there are $$6$$ total outcomes of this form.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Citing Pham &#39;21</p>
<p>For the outcomes where $$w_1 = w_2 = i, i \in \{1, 2, 3\}$$, three things need to occur:</p>
<ol><li>The prize is assigned to door $$i$$</li><li>The contestant chooses door $$i$$</li><li>The host opens door $$j$$ where $$j \neq i$$</li></ol>
<p></p>
<p>Let&#39;s analyze the probability of each of these:</p>
<ol><li>Since the prize is equally likely to be assigned to any of the doors, and there are $$3$$ doors, there is a $$1/3$$ chance of the prize being assigned to door $$i$$</li><li>Since the contestant is equally likely to choose any of the doors, and there are $$3$$ doors, there is a $$1/3$$ chance of the contestant choosing door $$i$$</li><li>The $$2$$ remaining doors both do not contain the prize, so the host can choose either of them. Since there are $$2$$ remaining doors and both have an equal chance of being chosen, there is a $$1/2$$ chance of the host choosing door $$j$$</li></ol>
<p>How many outcomes are of this form? We can use multiplication rule:</p>
<ol><li>Choose what value $$i$$ is - $$3$$ ways</li><li>Choose what value $$j$$ is - $$2$$ ways</li></ol>
<p>So there are $$6$$ total outcomes of this form.</p>
<p></p>
<p>----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------</p>
<p></p>
<p>For the outcomes where $$w_1 = i$$ and $$w_2 = j$$ where $$i, j \in \{1, 2, 3\}$$ and $$i \neq j$$, three things need to occur:</p>
<ol><li>The prize is assigned to door $$i$$</li><li>The contestant chooses door $$j$$</li><li>The host opens door $$k$$ where $$k \neq i, j$$</li></ol>
<p>Let&#39;s analyze the probability of each of these:</p>
<ol><li>Since the prize is equally likely to be assigned to any of the doors, and there are $$3$$ doors, there is a $$1/3$$ chance of the prize being assigned to door $$i$$</li><li>Since the contestant is equally likely to choose any of the doors, and there are $$3$$ doors, there is a $$1/3$$ chance of the contestant choosing door $$j$$</li><li>There is only one remaining door the host can open that is not $$i$$ or $$j$$, so there is a $$1$$ chance of the hosting choosing this remaining door.</li></ol>
<p>How many outcomes are of this form? We can use multiplication rule:</p>
<ol><li>Choose what value $$i$$ is - $$3$$ ways</li><li>Choose what value $$j$$ is - $$2$$ ways</li><li>Choose what value $$k$$ is -  $$1$$ way</li></ol>
<p>So there are $$6$$ total outcomes of this form.</p>

<p>In the lecture notes, it says that a connected component must maximal, or not contained within any other subgraph. What does contained mean here - does this just mean that the connected component can&#39;t be a subgraph of any other subgraph in the graph?</p>
<p>If so, aren&#39;t all graphs a subgraph of themself (i.e. are all graphs contained by themselves)? Thanks!</p>

<p>For the last question about deleting a leaf, how do we know that the leaf we&#39;re deleting is not a part of any other walks besides the one its deleted from, so that the graph remains connected?</p>
<p>For the last question about deleting a leaf, how do we know that the leaf we&#39;re deleting is not a part of any other walks besides the one its deleted from, so that the graph remains connected?</p>
<p>A leaf $$v$$, which has degree 1, can only be a part of path $$P$$ if one of $$P$$&#39;s endpoints is $$v$$. If otherwise, then suppose we have a path $$P'$$ where $$v$$ is within the path, but not one of the endpoints, then $$P' = ... - u - v - w - ....$$ which would mean that $$v$$ would have two neighbors, and hence degree 2 (contradiction).</p>
<p></p>
<p>So when we remove $$v$$, the only paths we lose are those that have endpoint $$v$$. But since $$T' = T \setminus \{v\}$$ has all vertices of $$T$$ except $$v$$, all paths between non-$$v$$ vertices in $$T$$ remain in $$T'$$, so it&#39;s connected.</p>
response time: 6:52:04

Piazza is a Q&A platform designed to get you great answers from classmates and instructors fast. We've put together this list of tips you might find handy as you get started:

<ol style="margin:0;padding:0;list-style-position:inside;"> <li style="margin:0;padding:0"><strong>Ask questions!</strong>

The best way to get answers is to ask questions! Ask questions on Piazza rather than emailing your teaching staff so everyone can benefit from the response (and so you can get answers from classmates who are up as late as you are).

</li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"><strong>Edit questions and answers wiki-style.</strong>

Think of Piazza as a Q&A wiki for your class. Every question has just a single <strong>students' answer</strong> that students can edit collectively (and a single <strong>instructors’ answer</strong> for instructors).

</li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>Add a followup to comment or ask further questions.</strong>

To comment on or ask further questions about a post, start a <strong>followup discussion</strong>. Mark it resolved when the issue has been addressed, and add any relevant information back into the Q&A above.

</li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>Go anonymous.</strong>

Shy? No problem. You can always opt to post or edit anonymously.

</li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>Tag your posts.</strong>

It's far more convenient to find all posts about your Homework 3 or Midterm 1 when the posts are tagged. Type a “#” before a key word to tag. Click a blue tag in a post or the question feed to filter for all posts that share that tag.

</li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>Format code and equations.</strong>

Adding a code snippet? Click the <strong>pre</strong> or <strong>tt</strong> button in the question editor to add pre-formatted or inline teletype text. 
Mathematical equation? Click the <strong>Fx</strong> button to access the LaTeX editor to build a nicely formatted equation.

</li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>View and download class details and resources.</strong> </li></ol>

Click the <strong>Course Page</strong> button in your top bar to access the class syllabus, staff contact information, office hours details, and course resources—all in one place!


Contact the Piazza Team anytime with questions or comments at <strong>team@piazza.com</strong>. We love feedback!

<div><br />All office hours will be held in Skirkanich 114 (Greenberg Lounge). We will use <a href="https://ohq.io/courses/556" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">ohq.io</a> to manage the office hours queue.Office hours are held <strong>in person.</strong> However, if you are sick/exposed to COVID-19 please do not come to office hours in person. We reserve the right to request formal proof if we feel that this policy is being abused.</div>
<div><br />Further, here are some notes about joining office hours on OHQ and general etiquette we ask that you abide by:</div>
<ul><li>All questions should include the following:

<div>If your question does not contain these <strong>we will skip you until it does. If the queue is long you may be removed.</strong></div>
<ul><li>Questions should not be about validating your solution (such as “I’m confused about whether my solution is right.” or “Not sure if I have the right intuition.“). <strong>TAs have been instructed not to answer questions like these. </strong>We expect that you have <strong>already worked on the problem</strong> prior to asking for help.</li><li>When the queue is sufficiently long (i.e., wait time is over 20 minutes), we will only be able to spend up to 5 minutes with each student to better ensure we help students make progress on the assignment and reduce wait times. <strong>This means that you may only be able to ask one question at a time.</strong></li></ul>

<p>Hii I just want to check which symbols in Latex should we use for subset, proper subset, and improper subset</p>

<p>How do we prove that a number is an integer?</p>
<p>How do we prove that a number is an integer?</p>
<p>If you&#39;re just looking at a number, say 7, you can just say that it is an integer. But if it is a more abstract quantity (such as the product/sum of other numbers/variables), then some sort of justification based on the closure of integers would suffice.</p>
<p></p>
<p>For example, suppose I want to show that $$k = 2x + y$$ is an integer. And suppose we know that $$x$$ and $$y$$ are integers, then you could just say that $$k$$ is an integer because $$x$$ and $$y$$ are integers and the integer set is closed under addition and multiplication.</p>
response time: 0:04:26

<p>Eg if I have A = {1,2} and B = {3, 4), then does A x B contain the term (4, 2)? I&#39;d imagine no, but am not totally sure.</p>
<p>Eg if I have A = {1,2} and B = {3, 4), then does A x B contain the term (4, 2)? I&#39;d imagine no, but am not totally sure.</p>
<p>No. The definition of cross product is $$A \times B = \{(a, b) \mid a \in A \wedge b \in B\}$$. Since $$4 \notin A$$ and $$2 \notin B$$, then it must be that $$(4, 2) \notin A \times B$$</p>
response time: 0:02:17





<p>you should justify this.</p>

<p>Since x and y are positive integers, are they elements of Z&#43; / N or should it include 0 for the case with either 0 pools or 0 DJs?</p>
<p>Since x and y are positive integers, are they elements of Z&#43; / N or should it include 0 for the case with either 0 pools or 0 DJs?</p>
<p>$$x$$ and $$y$$ are positive integers. So that means $$x, y \in \mathbb{Z^+}$$. This means that neither $$x$$ nor $$y$$ can be 0.</p>

<p>2^183 &#43; 1 = (2 &#43; 1)(2^182 − 2^181 &#43; · · · − 2 &#43; 1).<br />Let’s denote (2 &#43; 1) by r and (2^182 − 2^181 &#43; · · · − 2 &#43; 1) by s. Then both r and s are factors<br />of 2^183 &#43; 1. Since 1 &lt; r &lt; s and they are both positive integer factors which are neither 1<br />nor equal to 2^183 &#43; 1, we can see that 2^183 &#43; 1 is a composite number</p>
<p></p>
<p>In the proof above, do we have to prove that r&lt;s? </p>
<p>2^183 &#43; 1 = (2 &#43; 1)(2^182 − 2^181 &#43; · · · − 2 &#43; 1).<br />Let’s denote (2 &#43; 1) by r and (2^182 − 2^181 &#43; · · · − 2 &#43; 1) by s. Then both r and s are factors<br />of 2^183 &#43; 1. Since 1 &lt; r &lt; s and they are both positive integer factors which are neither 1<br />nor equal to 2^183 &#43; 1, we can see that 2^183 &#43; 1 is a composite number</p>
<p></p>
<p>In the proof above, do we have to prove that r&lt;s? </p>
This is something you should think about
<p>Thank you. Also, for composite numbers can we say that the definition of a composite number is a positive integer greater than 1 with factors other than 1 and itself?</p>
sure
<p>Do we need to write 1&lt;r&lt;s to prove the composite number though? It seems like it doesn&#39;t matter which one is greater than which if they are both just factors...</p>
think about the definition you came up with for composite. Does it matter how the factors compare to one another?

<p>Hi, I was wondering if we are allowed to use complementary counting on question 2?</p>
<p>For the question on lecture notes 1.6, they mention that three sets have an &#34;empty intersection.&#34; Does this just mean that all three of the sets contain the empty set? What is an &#34;empty intersection&#34;?</p>
<p>For the question on lecture notes 1.6, they mention that three sets have an &#34;empty intersection.&#34; Does this just mean that all three of the sets contain the empty set? What is an &#34;empty intersection&#34;?</p>
<p>Three sets $$A, B, C$$ have an <em>&#34;empty intersection&#34;</em> if $$A \cap B \cap C = \emptyset$$</p>

<p>1. Can we make a proof assuming the selection of balls will follow some pattern (or, at least it is possible that a pattern occurs- regardless of probability)? The question says the selection is random. However, that technically means any &#34;pattern&#34; of selection is possible. And if we are simply trying to prove something is possible to happen, then this seems valid? I struggle to see how we can make a conclusive mathematical proof through a random process without taking this liberty.</p>
<p>2. Can we prove by example? Say we prove that it is possible when the number of balls is labeled 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 (e.g. literally writing out the process on the page). Then we prove that you can get the labeling 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 from larger collections. Would that be valid? </p>
<p>Is it necessary/suggested to download Latex and the text editor? Can we just use the web browser version? Or do we need more than the web browser version&#39;s tools. Thanks!</p>
<p>Is it necessary/suggested to download Latex and the text editor? Can we just use the web browser version? Or do we need more than the web browser version&#39;s tools. Thanks!</p>
<p>We highly encourage you to use <a href="https://overleaf.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">overleaf</a>. It is a free, online tool for writing up LaTeX projects and requires no extra downloads. Visit <a href="https://overleaf.com/edu/upenn" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">overleaf.com/edu/upenn</a> for information of how to set up your account and have it linked to your upenn email.</p>

so the answer for (AxB)XC would be a tuple inside a tuple?
<p>@Val Tannen Thanks for the elaboration, but I&#39;m a bit confused by this answer, because it sort of implies that they&#39;re *not* canonically isomorphic by a unique isomorphism. The associator between (AxB)xC and Ax(BxC) is a canonical functorial isomorphism, which is both covariant in all variables and unique. If you say they&#39;re not *associative*, then you&#39;re sort of denying an equivalence invariance which feels *morally* wrong. </p>

<p>In short, a closed form expression is essentially a term which can be evaluated in a fixed finite number of operations. Some examples would be $$1, x^2 + 1$$ or $$2n$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Examples of expressions that are not closed form usually involve summations with non-constant bounds such as $$\sum_{i=1}^n i$$. We&#39;ll be posting a more in-depth description of what closed form is on piazza very soon. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Update: @138</p>
<p>In short, a closed form expression is essentially a term which can be evaluated in a fixed finite number of operations. Some examples would be $$1, x^2 + 1$$ or $$2n$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Examples of expressions that are not closed form usually involve summations with non-constant bounds such as $$\sum_{i=1}^n i$$. We&#39;ll be posting a more in-depth description of what closed form is on piazza very soon. </p>
response time: 0:02:06



<p>Hi all,</p>
<p></p>
<p>Now that some of the exercises require mathematical expressions as answers, we need to clarify what forms of answer are acceptable.</p>
<p></p>
<p>In CIS 1600, all final expressions (to questions requiring mathematical expressions as answers) should be in closed form unless explicitly stated otherwise. A closed form expression is essentially a term which can be evaluated in a fixed finite number of operations. For reference, many terms we will encounter are in closed form: $$12$$, $$x^2+1$$, $$k!$$,  $$2n$$, $$\binom{n}{k}$$, $$\sum_{i = 1}^{5} i^2$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The most likely exceptions you will encounter are summations or products whose bounds are variables. For example, $$\sum_{i = 1}^{n} (2i - 1)$$ or $$1+3+5+⋯+(2n−1)$$ would not be considered closed form, since we have a variable bound $$n$$ (the number of terms we are adding is not fixed). However, the equivalent value $$n^2$$ is closed form (we haven’t yet proven this equality, so you can’t use this post as justification if we ask for this identity, but we will likely do so in due time). Similarly, if you have nested summations, e.g. $$\sum_{i = 1}^{100} \sum_{k = 1}^{i} k$$, we would not consider this closed form since the inner summation has variable bounds.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Furthermore, if you simplify an open form expression to a closed form expression, you must prove their equivalence using only material we have learned in this course. We generally strongly advise against this as it almost always entails unnecessarily complex justification. All problems in this course can be answered without doing this.</p>
<p></p>
<p>We require closed form for full credit, even if it is not explicitly asked for (we will try to include a reminder in most cases where an open form solution is viable). In general, if you’re not sure whether something is closed form, feel free to ask on Piazza (as always, if you’re worried about possibly giving away too much, you can post privately) or in office hours!</p>
<p></p>
<p>#pin</p>
<p></p>
<p>I love all the puns by the way</p>
<p>Are the word docs posted anywhere?</p>

Even though there&#39;s an explanation stated when I reviewed it, I didn&#39;t understand the concept. Can someone please explain." /></p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Flcsc5hbf3sr11e%2F54ca330329dd3641de9815bb025b114b7e0159c81bf035d46646816cb78cab08%2FScreen_Shot_2023-01-20_at_1.53.06_PM.png" width="1188" height="148" alt="The question on the quiz on module 2.6 asked that. Even though there&#39;s an explanation stated when I reviewed it, I didn&#39;t understand the concept. Can someone please explain." /></p>
<p>what exactly do you have a question about here?</p>
<p>The explanation given wasn&#39;t clear. Can someone please explain how to determine that? </p>
<p>There are more partial permutations of 2 elements out of 4 elements than there are combinations of 2 elements out of 4 elements.</p>
<p></p>
<p>One way to argue this is numerically: The amount of combinations of 2 elements out of 4 elements is $$\binom{4}{2} = 6$$. The number of partial permutations of 2 elements is $$\frac{4!}{2!} = 12$$ and we clearly see that $$12 > 6$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>For a more qualitative argument, we can think of constructing a partial permutation as a two step procedure where in the first step, we select 2 of the four elements, and then in the second step, we arrange those two elements. Note that the number of ways the first step can be performed is equivalent to the number of combinations of 2 elements. And for each of those combinations, there are $$2!$$ ways to arrange the two elements within the permutation.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Lastly, another thing I will highlight is that the main difference between combinations and permutations is that with permutations, the order of the values matters. That is, if we had four elements $$\{1, 2, 3, 4\}$$ and we wanted to find a valid combination of 2 elements, the two elements $$\{1, 2\}$$ would suffice. However, when considering combinations, $$\{1, 2\}$$ would <strong>be the same </strong>as $$\{2, 1\}$$ (because order doesn&#39;t matter. With permutations, these would be different cases.</p>
response time: 0:12:24

<md>Do I need to explicitly state "such that" ($$s.t.$$) when using set-builder notation with $$\exists$$? For instance, is it valid to rewrite the following:

$$\{ x\ \vert\ \exists k \in \mathbb{N}\ s.t. x = 2k \}$$

as:

$$\{ x\ \vert\ \exists k \in \mathbb{N}\  x = 2k \}$$
?</md>
<md>Do I need to explicitly state "such that" ($$s.t.$$) when using set-builder notation with $$\exists$$? For instance, is it valid to rewrite the following:

$$\{ x\ \vert\ \exists k \in \mathbb{N}\ s.t. x = 2k \}$$

as:

$$\{ x\ \vert\ \exists k \in \mathbb{N}\  x = 2k \}$$
?</md>
<p>no, it is not necessary, but it is nice to include for clarity.</p>

<md>Is this a valid way to say for all integers from $$1$$ to $$100$$?

$$\forall k \in \{1, 2, ..., 100\}$$</md>
<md>Is this a valid way to say for all integers from $$1$$ to $$100$$?

$$\forall k \in \{1, 2, ..., 100\}$$</md>
<p>this reads as &#34;for all k in the set 1, 2, ..., 100&#34;. As a standalone statement, it doesn&#39;t really mean too much, so typically this would be followed by some other condition/fact about $$k$$</p>

<p>When disproving something, is it sufficient to follow the regular proof pattern and then just point out when something goes wrong? In other words, should we always &#34;attempt&#34; to prove something and then if something goes wrong call it disproved? Or is there a separate approach that we use specifically for disproving something? </p>
<p>When disproving something, is it sufficient to follow the regular proof pattern and then just point out when something goes wrong? In other words, should we always &#34;attempt&#34; to prove something and then if something goes wrong call it disproved? Or is there a separate approach that we use specifically for disproving something? </p>
<p>no, this would not be sufficient. This is because there may be multiple ways of proving something, so just finding something wrong in one proof pattern may not cover all possible proofs. </p>
<p></p>
<p>One way of disproving is in the case where you are proving a universal property and provide a counterexample.</p>

<p dir="ltr"></p>
<p dir="ltr">FemmeHacks is back in person  at <a href="https://pennovation.upenn.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Pennovation Center</a> for its 9th year on Feb 10-11th, 2023! And we would love to see you and your students there. FemmeHacks is a collegiate hackathon hosted by Women in Computer Science at the University of Pennsylvania and is meant for students in the greater Philadelphia area. Our event is a great way for women* of all skill levels to learn new programming skills, network with each other, and collaborate in making awesome apps. We aim to inspire, teach, and empower young women in the Philly tech community by hosting educational workshops and providing a fun environment where they can create lasting bonds.</p>
<br />
<p dir="ltr">In recent hackathons, we’ve had a hacker-to-mentor ratio of 4-to-1. We’ll also be handing out FemmeHacks swag, such as t-shirts, to all eligible participants. We also have an abundance of in-person workshops this year, such as arts and crafts stations and more!<br /><br /></p>

<p>Is it appropriate/ is there a way to use summation notation to run through the elements of a set?</p>
<p>ex:</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$\sum_{n=z}^{S} ({2^{|z|} -1}) = ....$$</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>S is a set of sets (like a power set)</p>
<p>z is an element of S (meaning z is a set)</p>
<p>|z| is the cardinality of z</p>
<p></p>
<p>Please let me know if I can clarify this question.</p>
<p>Is it appropriate/ is there a way to use summation notation to run through the elements of a set?</p>
<p>ex:</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$\sum_{n=z}^{S} ({2^{|z|} -1}) = ....$$</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>S is a set of sets (like a power set)</p>
<p>z is an element of S (meaning z is a set)</p>
<p>|z| is the cardinality of z</p>
<p></p>
<p>Please let me know if I can clarify this question.</p>
<p>Yeah, the notation would be as follows: $$\sum_{z \in S} (2^{|z|} - 1)$$</p>
<p>Just a quick follow up.... this iterates through a set in the same way we could loop through a list in java? Like it just starts at the first element and ends at the last element???</p>
<p>No. The notation I provided <strong>does not</strong> impose an ordering on the way elements are processed. But it does process every element. The order is just arbitrary.</p>
<p>Also would the above in the initial question be considered closed form???</p>
<p>So in the context of question 8..... any if set S = $$2^n$$...... this notation would be closed form...... because n is SOME positive integer as opposed to every positive integer?</p>
<p>Also would the above in the initial question be considered closed form???</p>
<p>Sorry... I am still a bit confused based on the definition of closed form pinned in piazza.... &#34;In CIS 1600, all final expressions (to questions requiring mathematical expressions as answers) should be in closed form unless explicitly stated otherwise. A closed form expression is essentially a term which can be evaluated in a fixed finite number of operations. For reference, many terms we will encounter are in closed form: 12, x2&#43;1, k!,  2n, $$n \choose k$$,..... &#34;</p>
<p></p>
<p>..... I understand that the bound of a summation cannot be n and that this would not be closed form.... but why would the equivalent $n^2$ be considered closed form? ie: if we are doing an operation on n or defining a set using n.... would the summation be considered closed form.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Ex: </p>
<p>$$\sum_{z \in S} ({2^{|z|} -1}) = ....$$</p>
<p></p>
<p>where S = $$2^n$$</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>Also would the above in the initial question be considered closed form???</p>
<p>$$n^2$$ requires a fixed, finite number of operations. It always requires one operation (the operation being a single multiplication between two values). No matter the value of $$n$$, evaluating $$n^2$$ will always require one operation.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The summation with a variable bound does <strong>not</strong> have a fixed number of operations, because the value of the variable changes the amount of additions we are doing, and is hence not closed form.</p>
response time: 0:00:48



<p>What does this symbol mean?</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$\subsetneq$$</p>
<p>What does this symbol mean?</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$\subsetneq$$</p>
Proper subset
response time: 0:00:14

<p>Hey everyone!</p>
<p></p>
<p>Now that y’all have had a chance to try out the multiplication rule on your own in homework one, we wanted to put out a document containing a list of common errors that students make when using the multiplication rule. This document also has some tips and tricks that might help you come up with your proofs, so make sure to check it out!</p>
<p></p>
<p>We&#39;ll be putting out these common errors documents for every large proof technique/topic that we cover, so keep an eye out for these! </p>
<p><br />Link: <a target="_blank" href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1XAPGiILIAGhjFQbhaKpzboKj_2FFlWdE/view?usp=sharing" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://drive.google.com/file/d/1XAPGiILIAGhjFQbhaKpzboKj_2FFlWdE/view?usp=sharing</a></p>

<div>
<p>(a) S\(T \R)=(S\T)\R</p>
</div>
<p>For example, if there is some x that is in S, T, and R, it would not be in (T/R) since it is in R, so it would be in S / (T / R). However, this element would not be in (S\T)\R because it is in S and T.</p>

<div>
<p>(a) S\(T \R)=(S\T)\R</p>
</div>

<p>5d states &#34;if there exists such a y..., then there exists such an x such that...&#34; For this question, could we assign values to the sets in the premise (such that it is true) and then make logical steps until we can reach our conclusion? Or should we think of another approach </p>
<p>that would not be valid because then you would be proving/disproving the claim for a <strong>specific</strong> group of sets.</p>
<p>What if we assigned variables instead to make them general and not specific?</p>
<p>for considering an arbitrary element, sure, variables are fine. But if you should not define a set by enumerating its elements using variables.</p>
<p></p>
<p>For example, something like $$A = \{x, y, z\}$$ would not be a good thing to do.</p>
response time: 0:00:57



<p>Hi!</p>
<p><br />I just got a bit confuse on the way that the proof on 2.sp2 was done for ((A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B) ⊆ A ). I understood all the mathematical computations on why x (an arbitrary element) belongs to A, but got stuck on the reasoning why by given that x ∈ A and x ∈ (A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B),  (A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B) ⊆ A  must be true. Why couldn&#39;t it be the other way around where A ⊆ (A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B) ? <br /><br />Thanks in advance! </p>
<p>Hi!</p>
<p><br />I just got a bit confuse on the way that the proof on 2.sp2 was done for ((A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B) ⊆ A ). I understood all the mathematical computations on why x (an arbitrary element) belongs to A, but got stuck on the reasoning why by given that x ∈ A and x ∈ (A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B),  (A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B) ⊆ A  must be true. Why couldn&#39;t it be the other way around where A ⊆ (A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B) ? <br /><br />Thanks in advance! </p>
<p>Well that conclusion is being made because we are under the case of showing that $$(A \setminus B) \cup (A \cap B) \subseteq A$$. Remember, to show equality, we show inclusion in both directions. So focusing on the direction $$(A \setminus B) \cup (A \cap B) \subseteq A$$, we would want to show that for any element that appears in the left hand side, it must also appear in the right hand side. 2.sp2 argues that for any element $$x \in (A \setminus B) \cup (A \cap B)$$, we have $$x \in A$$, so we have that any element in the left hand side also appears in the right hand side (since x was arbitrary), and by definition of subset, we conclude that the left hand side is a subset of the right hand side. </p>
<p></p>
<p>We then go on to show the inclusion in the other direction. And to show that, we would go about taking an arbitrary element of $$A$$ and show that it appears in $$(A \setminus B) \cup (A \cap B)$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>I think the key thing to note is the definition of subset. We have $$A \subset B$$ if and only if for every element $$a \in A$$, we also have $$a \in B$$. That&#39;s what we are doing in the set proofs; we consider an element $$a \in A$$ and then show that it must be that $$a \in B$$ and then conclude that $$A \subseteq B$$</p>
response time: 0:01:05



<p>Is this multiplication? Can you multiply 2 sets?</p>
<p>I am writing proofs and I am not sure what to call this</p>
<p>I am writing proofs and I am not sure what to call this</p>
<p>set difference</p>
<p>Thank you. Can we just call &#34;or&#34; &#34;or&#34; operators or union? Does the naming not matter</p>
<p>There is a difference between $$\vee$$ and $$\cup$$. We use $$\vee$$ to denote logical OR. We use $$\cup$$ to denote union.</p>
<p>Thank you. Can we just call &#34;or&#34; &#34;or&#34; operators or union? Does the naming not matter</p>
<p>I am confused. What is the difference between them? A or B would still be A U B, doesn&#39;t it?</p>
<p>Thank you. Can we just call &#34;or&#34; &#34;or&#34; operators or union? Does the naming not matter</p>
<p>$$\vee$$ is an operation used on two propositions. $$\cup$$ is an operation used on two sets. So, for example, if $$A = \{1, 2\}$$ and $$B = \{3, 4\}$$, then $$A \vee B$$ would not mean anything. However, $$A \cup B$$ would denote the union of the two sets and we have $$A \cup B = \{1, 2, 3, 4\}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Similarly, if we let $$p = \text{My name is Ishaan}$$ and $$q = \text{I am a CIS1600 TA}$$. Then $$p \vee q = \text{My name is Ishaan OR I am a CIS1600 TA}$$, but $$p \cup q$$ means nothing.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The way the two relate is that if you have an element $$x \in A \cup B$$, then you could say that $$x \in A$$ OR $$x \in B$$. Written symbolically, we have $$x \in A \cup B \implies x \in A \vee x \in B$$.</p>

<p>Am I allowed to define a set using set-builder notation that relies upon the current member of x itself (i.e is the line x=x&#43;3y legal as I am defining x in terms of itself plus something else)? </p>

<md>i.e. can I say

$$\neg (x \in T \wedge x \notin R) = (x \notin T \vee x \in R)$$</md>
<p>Or are they the same</p>
<p>Or are they the same</p>
<p>$$\subseteq$$ (subseteq) is used for subset. $$\subset$$ (subset) is used for <strong>proper</strong> subset. They are not the same thing.</p>

<ul><li>Per @331, in part c, the question should read, &#34;how many ways can you distribute these elements to 5 disjoint, distinguishable <strong>bags</strong> such that each <strong>bag </strong>contains at least one element and the elements b, i, t are distributed to different <strong>bags</strong>&#34;.</li><li>In part c, the bags are <strong>already </strong>distinguishable-- having the same letter makeup doesn&#39;t change that. (i.e. having {r, r} in bag 1 and {r, r} in bag 2 is fine). </li><li>In part c, &#34;disjoint bags&#34; for indistinguishable letters <strong>does not </strong>mean that two bags cannot both have the letter &#34;r&#34;. It means that the <strong>total number of r&#39;s </strong>in all of the bags added up must be 23. </li></ul>

<p>How is there only one way? Isn&#39;t putting different amounts of books in each bin a different way each time to sort the indistinguishable books into distinguishable bins?</p>
<p></p>
<p>I mean to say, even if the elements are indistinguishable, isn&#39;t it two different ways if I put 3 of them in a bin vs 7 in a bin?</p>
<p>Well there is still the constraint that bin $$B_i$$ needs $$n_i$$ books. Since the books are indistinguishable, each bin $$B_i$$ can only be filled with $$n_i$$ books in exactly 1 way.</p>

From now on, if someone states that either A or B, does this just imply that it&#39;s an exclusive OR?</p>
<p>For the interactive session in Thursday class, the professor described exclusive OR as &#34;either odd or even&#34;. However, I believe we did not learn that &#34;either&#34; can be only used for exclusive ORs before the deadline of HW2. Will points be deducted for this? From now on, if someone states that either A or B, does this just imply that it&#39;s an exclusive OR?</p>
<p>yeah unfortunately there is a difference between &#34;exclusive or&#34; and $$\lor$$. Just try to be as clear as possible when you are writing. We will assume $$\lor$$ is the logical OR, and &#34;exclusive or&#34; will always mean &#34;exclusive or&#34;.</p>
<p>The professor said he should&#39;ve told us about the distinction last class but didn&#39;t - we did not learn about the specific terminology about OR and exclusive OR. Do we still get points deducted for terminology difference that we did not learn for this assignment? I am confused.</p>
<p>you will almost assuredly not lose points for confusing OR and exclusive OR. If we have not covered exclusive OR in class, then you should not worry about it. We take this into account when grading.</p>

<md># WLOG and Arbitrary
Hi everyone! Over the course of grading, we noticed that there may be some confusion as to the meaning of the phrases "without loss of generality" and "arbitrary," which potentially changed the intended meaning of solutions from one that was correct to one that was potentially incorrect. As such, we thought it'd be good to explain these phrases so you can use them in your proofs (as both are really helpful)!

## Without Loss of Generality (WLOG)
Without loss of generality is useful when there are symmetries in a problem. Consider the following statement that we might want to prove:

>Consider $$x$$ and $$y$$, where one is even and one is odd. Show that $$x + y$$ is odd.

Without WLOG, we might write the following:

> Case 1: $$x$$ is even, $$y$$ is odd. Then $$x = 2k, y = 2l + 1$$ for some integers $$k,l$$. Then, $$x + y = 2(k + 1) + 1$$, which is odd.

> Case 2: $$x$$ is odd, $$y$$ is even. Then $$x = 2k + 1, y = 2l $$ for some integers $$k,l$$. Then, $$x + y = 2(k + 1) + 1$$, which is odd. 

Notice how we duplicated a lot of our logic! Ideally, we'd love *not* to do that. And luckily, with WLOG, we can! Since addition commutes ($$x + y$$ = $$y + x$$), both of these cases are basically the same. I could basically **switch the names of the variables** and the proof is exactly the same. Therefore, I can say *without loss of generality* that $$x$$ is even, since the other case ($$x$$ odd) I can just switch the names of the variables and the order of addition and I would have the exact same case! So **we use WLOG when we have symmetries in the problem that can help us avoid casework**.

## Arbitrary
Arbitrary is used in a different setting. To illustrate the usage of this phrase, let's consider any proposition we want to prove using a universal quantifier (i.e., $$\forall x \in \mathcal{S}, P(x)$$ for some predicate $$P(\cdot)$$ and some set $$\mathcal{S}$$). I think of these as a conversation with an adversary -- the adversary chooses some value $$x$$ to give you from the set $$\mathcal{S}$$, and your job is to show that $$P(x)$$ is true. Your job, as the prover, is to do this for every single $$x$$ that the adversary could give you. That is, you need to give some procedure, on any $$x$$, which shows $$P(x)$$. This any $$x$$ we can say is an **arbitrary** value of $$x$$. So, we might say that for any *arbitrary* value the adversary gives us, do this procedure to show that $$P(x)$$ is true.

It's important to note that once you say something specific about $$x$$, (e.g., if you have a list $$l$$ and you say $$x$$ is the first element in the list), then it's no longer an arbitrary element of the list.
</md>

<p>Hi, in relation to the stars and bars problem with the donuts in lecture 3.1, let&#39;s say we had </p>
<p>CCC || EEEEEE | FFF | and DDD || FFFFFF | GGG. These are two different ways to choose donuts, but the bars are in the same location, so wouldn&#39;t 16 choose 4 be undercounting the ways to choose donuts?</p>
<p>Hi, in relation to the stars and bars problem with the donuts in lecture 3.1, let&#39;s say we had </p>
<p>CCC || EEEEEE | FFF | and DDD || FFFFFF | GGG. These are two different ways to choose donuts, but the bars are in the same location, so wouldn&#39;t 16 choose 4 be undercounting the ways to choose donuts?</p>
<p>The second arrangement is missing a bar; moreover, the second arrangement is not possible. We define the C donuts to be those that appear before the first bar, the D donuts to be those in between the first bar and second bar, etc.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Your second arrangement would be accurately represented as |DDD||FFFFF|GGG</p>

<ul><li>You may assume that if $$p$$ is prime, then the only positive integer factors of $$p^2$$ are $$1, p, \text{and } p^2$$.</li><li>@465_f1 You may assume $$a, b, c$$ are real numbers. There are no other restrictions on what $$a, b, c$$ can be.</li></ul>

<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7z0k627zdd6aj%2Fc9079e251667b51d1a980d39a3b88985017c0476299f72b6eeefecbe3001ae5d%2FScreen_Shot_2023-02-02_at_12.39.47_PM.png" alt="" width="612" height="320" /></p>
<p>Which sets are they referring to when they say the sets are pairwise disjoint? I thought if the sets were pairwise disjoint they could not have any elements in common.</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7z0k627zdd6aj%2Fc9079e251667b51d1a980d39a3b88985017c0476299f72b6eeefecbe3001ae5d%2FScreen_Shot_2023-02-02_at_12.39.47_PM.png" alt="" width="612" height="320" /></p>
<p>Which sets are they referring to when they say the sets are pairwise disjoint? I thought if the sets were pairwise disjoint they could not have any elements in common.</p>
<p>Each $$S_i$$ is <strong>a set of sets, </strong>and it is true that the $$S_i$$&#39;s are pairwise disjoint with respect to one another.</p>
<p></p>
<p>This is because, consider any two of these sets $$S_i$$ and $$S_j$$, for an arbitrary $$x \in S_i$$, we have $$|x| = i$$. However, we know that for any $$y \in S_j$$ we have $$|y| = j$$. So it always holds that $$x \notin S_j$$. This means that $$S_i \cap S_j = \emptyset$$ and thus are pairwise disjoint.</p>
response time: 0:02:55

<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Flcslq4hc8982lu%2F8ffbb8f25ea7e389f02de1d91e627f38ad8263728ff6d9df98e384df5f2c5a7a%2Fimage.png" alt="image.png" /><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Flcslq4hc8982lu%2Fd6b683dcc286fc0bc779de41be10ba9a3157e2dd873eaf877bf174a20a9406c3%2Fimage.png" alt="image.png" /><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Flcslq4hc8982lu%2F27f81c4695d3a593842a23fe79e455287cbabc0c7a65d79e3f332226515e77b7%2Fimage.png" alt="image.png" /></p>


<p>In one sentence: Stars and bars is an <strong>application</strong> of simple combinations.</p>
<p></p>
<p>For more detail, with simple combinations, such as $$\binom{n}{r}$$, we are simply considering a set of $$n$$ distinct items and determining how many ways can we choose $$r$$ of these items. Equivalently, this counts the number of subsets of size $$r$$ from our original set.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Stars and bars can be thought of as a two step procedure. We see a direct correlation between distributing indistinguishable items to distinguishable containers with an arrangement of stars and bars. So to count the number of ways to distribute, we count the number of arrangements of stars and bars. Suppose we have $$n$$ stars and $$r-1$$ bars, then our procedure would begin by choosing $$n$$ locations to put the stars. Since the remaining open slots <strong>must</strong> be filled with bars, they can only be filled in one way. So by MR, you get the familiar equation for stars and bars which is $$\binom{n + r - 1}{n}$$, or equivalently, $$\binom{n+r-1}{r-1}$$</p>
response time: -1 day, 23:58:43



<p>If we do a proof by contradiction, do we need to explain that we learned in lecture that the statement $p \implies q$ is logically equivalent to the statement $(p \land \neg q) \implies F$. We have shown that $g(a) = g(b)$ and $a \neq b$ is false, and thus its logically equivalent statement is true: $g(a) = g(b) \implies a = b$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>or can we just go straight from $g(a) = g(b)$ and $a \neq b$ is false to saying that by contradiction we have shown that $g(a) = g(b) \implies a \neq b$.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>If we do a proof by contradiction, do we need to explain that we learned in lecture that the statement $p \implies q$ is logically equivalent to the statement $(p \land \neg q) \implies F$. We have shown that $g(a) = g(b)$ and $a \neq b$ is false, and thus its logically equivalent statement is true: $g(a) = g(b) \implies a = b$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>or can we just go straight from $g(a) = g(b)$ and $a \neq b$ is false to saying that by contradiction we have shown that $g(a) = g(b) \implies a \neq b$.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>you don&#39;t need to explain how a proof by contradiction works. You can just provide the contradiction statement.</p>

<p>Consider functions $$f: A \rightarrow B$$ and $$g: A \rightarrow B$$. We say that $$f$$ and $$g$$ are <strong>not distinct</strong> if $$\forall a \in A$$ we have $$f(a) = g(a)$$</p>

<p>&#34;If we choose 2 points that are adjacent to each other within the 4 points, the other 2 points will also be adjacent to each other within the 4 points, and the 2 lines that are created will intersect outside the shape.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The only way to create 2 lines that intersect within the shape is to choose 2 points that are opposite each other within the 4 points (there is 1 point between them on either side), because then their lines will cross each other at 1 intersection point.&#34;</p>

<p>Hey everyone,</p>
<p></p>
<p>Recently we’ve been receiving a number of requests to accept late HW. We just wanted to reiterate that we <b>cannot</b> accept late submissions <b>under any circumstances.</b> We give 2 HW drops (~20% of the HWs) in order to account for health, tech issues, busy schedules, etc. We strongly encourage students to keep these drops in hand so that when unexpected circumstances arise you are able to take a drop without affecting your grade. As for technical issues, it is your responsibility to submit your HW on time. If you wait until 11:50pm on Wednesday to submit your HW, you may not be able to submit on time. In the case where Gradescope (for whatever reason) is not working, you can email a pdf of your submission to <a target="_blank" href="mailto:cis1600@seas.upenn.edu" rel="noopener noreferrer">cis1600@seas.upenn.edu</a> <b>before</b> the HW deadline.</p>
<p></p>
<p>If you have a longer term health issue that may prevent you from submitting multiple HWs, please reach out to us and we can try to find a solution. We are unable to give extensions for one-off illnesses, as we need to release solutions for the entire class to review from.</p>
<p></p>
<p>As always, feel free to reach out to us if you have any concerns – but know that we have limited flexibility when it comes to accepting late HW (and that you should plan accordingly). In a class of 250 students, this is critical to ensure fairness across the class.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Best of luck as you begin studying for Midterm One,<br />CIS1600 Staff</p>

<p>In the first slide you provided, it is discussing the tree obtained by following the procedure in the <em>first attempt</em>. The first attempt was an incorrect procedure in the sense that MR could not be used. The second slide you provided outlines a <strong>correct </strong>procedure in which MR can be applied. </p>
<p></p>
<p>In general, the word &#34;independent&#34; may be misleading. MR can be applied when <em>the amount of ways to perform a step</em> is <strong>constant</strong> regardless of how previous steps were performed. For further reading, check out the doc in @176</p>

<p></p>
<p>I don&#39;t really understand what example 1,2  means - is there a more concrete explanation/example for this? Also, what is g(f) and h(f) for the question below?</p>
<p></p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedxgblvppr1vj%2F3e0c087d6ac9d5f44ba84ba756b03953c3c099173f7c5d1a9c50555a85258cb8%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" width="547" height="256" /></p>
<p></p>
<p>g and h are examples of functions that have the domain $$B^A$$ and codomain $$2^C$$. So the domain of g and h are <strong><em>functions</em></strong> and the codomain of g and h are <strong>subsets of [1..n].</strong></p>
<p></p>
<p>A good question is what is the size of the domain? And what is the size of the codomain? </p>
<p></p>
<p>The domain has size $$n^n$$ and the codomain has size $$2^n$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>To understand the function $$g$$, consider an arbitrary function $$\phi: [1..n] \rightarrow [1..n]$$. Note that $$\phi \in [1..n]^{[1..n]}$$, so it is in the domain. Note that $$\phi$$ takes as input $$x \in [1..n]$$ and outputs some $$y \in [1..n]$$. That is, $$\phi(x) = y$$ where $$x, y \in [1..n]$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>When evaluating $$g(\phi)$$, we note that the mapping is defined by $$\{x | f(x) = 1\}$$ where $$x \in [1..n]$$. Therefore, the mapping is looking at all elements of $$[1..n]$$ such that when $$\phi$$ acts on that element, the output is $$1$$. These elements form a subset of $$[1..n]$$. How exciting! Let&#39;s call this subset $$A$$. That is, we have $$A \subseteq [1..n]$$ and $$\forall a \in A$$, we have $$\phi(a) = 1$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Then, $$g(\phi) = A$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>For function $$h$$, we do something similar, but now $$h$$ maps $$\phi$$ to its range (which is also a subset of $$[1..n]$$). </p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>For the last part of the question, we are given $$f$$ as the identity function. This means, $$\forall x \in [1..n]$$ we have $$f(x) = x$$. We want to compute $$g(f)$$. This is equivalent to asking: &#34;What is the set $$A \subseteq [1..n]$$ such that $$\forall a \in A$$ we have $$f(a) = 1$$?&#34;. Well, if $$f$$ is the identity, then it must be that $$A = \{1\}$$. Therefore, $$g(f) = \{1\}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>For $$h(f)$$ we ask ourselves, &#34;if $$f$$ is the identity function, what is $$Ran(f)$$?&#34;. Well, this is just $$[1..n]$$. So, we have $$h(f) = [1..n]$$</p>
response time: 17:18:22



<p>What is the difference between Q19 and Q29 that makes us use complementary counting for 19 and direct method for 29? If you use similar logic in Q19 that you do in Q29, you get different answers?</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Flcply0liip97hz%2Fd0758b46ce21a2839183ab821b608d208b1c8e0f99cb04a039881f3329a090b7%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" />Aren&#39;t all three of the following expressions logically equivalent? How, then, is the answer true (exactly two aren&#39;t logically equivalent, exactly three are)?</p>
<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fk9sryn4at7u4fo%2Fbf0cdc637d3b675e2091a5cc61f0d3c24562fd740b3d54a0e577540c7b5b26d2%2FScreen_Shot_2023-02-13_at_9.37.20_AM">Screen_Shot_2023-02-13_at_9.37.20_AM</a></p>
<p></p>
<p>What is the set J? Is this the set that we&#39;re finding the intersections for when we&#39;re counting using PIE? Also, can you explain the RHS - why are we placing elements in the other n-k positions?</p>
<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fk9sryn4at7u4fo%2Fbf0cdc637d3b675e2091a5cc61f0d3c24562fd740b3d54a0e577540c7b5b26d2%2FScreen_Shot_2023-02-13_at_9.37.20_AM">Screen_Shot_2023-02-13_at_9.37.20_AM</a></p>
<p></p>
<p>What is the set J? Is this the set that we&#39;re finding the intersections for when we&#39;re counting using PIE? Also, can you explain the RHS - why are we placing elements in the other n-k positions?</p>
<p>J is just an arbitrary subset of $$[1..n]$$. It basically narrows down which values we are focusing on (of whether or not they are in the right position) in the permutation. </p>
<p></p>
<p>For the RHS, recall that elements of $$\bigcap_{j \in J} B_j$$ will be those permutations such that the elements of $$j$$ are in the right position. So we can compute the cardinality of this via a procedure where in the first step, we fix the elements of $$J$$ in their correct position (of which there are $$k$$ elements) and then we permute the remaining elements. The first step occurs in just 1 way, and the second step occurs in $$(n-k)!$$ ways.</p>
response time: 1:07:22

<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Flcply0liip97hz%2F4787d6d1bb17b9affa0d1d867a6f7072fb4e93b2401d01a486bd0e0664e32a51%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" />Would this answer still receive full points, even though it is labeled as &#34;incomplete&#34;?</p>
<p>I was doing some practice questions I found online and one was about proving that some set operations equaled the empty set.</p>
<p></p>
<p>In this class, we learned double inclusion to prove equality between two sets, but I figure you can&#39;t do that for empty sets because there is no abp element of an empty set.</p>
<p></p>
<p>So how would we approach proving this rigorously? Just show that the operations limit the scope of the set to nothing?</p>
<p>I was doing some practice questions I found online and one was about proving that some set operations equaled the empty set.</p>
<p></p>
<p>In this class, we learned double inclusion to prove equality between two sets, but I figure you can&#39;t do that for empty sets because there is no abp element of an empty set.</p>
<p></p>
<p>So how would we approach proving this rigorously? Just show that the operations limit the scope of the set to nothing?</p>
<p>I suppose you could do the normal double inclusion method. Suppose you were asked to prove $$LHS = \emptyset$$. You could go about showing $$LHS \subseteq \emptyset$$ by considering an arbitrary element of the LHS and reach some sort of verdict based on that. And then when you show $$\emptyset \subseteq LHS$$, you would not have to consider an arbitrary element, because $$\emptyset \subseteq A$$ for any set $$A$$. So this side would just follow as fact.</p>
response time: 0:03:24

<p>I feel that if P =&gt; Q, they both start out by using not Q anyway. Then, contrapositive goes to prove not P is true while the contradiction goes on to show that there is a conflict with P. Is this it?</p>
<p>I feel that if P =&gt; Q, they both start out by using not Q anyway. Then, contrapositive goes to prove not P is true while the contradiction goes on to show that there is a conflict with P. Is this it?</p>
<p>Contrapositive is proving $$\lnot q \implies \lnot p$$. Contradiction is proving $$p \land \lnot q \implies F$$</p>

<p>Just like the answer considered $$n = k+1$$ to show that $$a \geq b$$, they do a similar thing by considering when $$k = 1$$. In this case, we have $$a = 1$$ and $$b = n-1$$, so we have $$a \leq b$$. </p>

<p>When a = 1, b = n - 1 = 1, so this case is when b=a, not when a &lt; b. I don&#39;t believe there is a case where a  &lt; b. Can we just read statements like these as b=a? <p>When a = 1, b = n - 1 = 1, so this case is when b=a, not when a &lt; b. I don&#39;t believe there is a case where a  &lt; b. Can we just read statements like these as b=a? Or, will points be taken off because we didn&#39;t put a is less than or equal to b? And in the case where points are taken off, is there an example where a &lt; b?</p>
<p>When $$k = 1$$, we have $$a = 1$$ and $$b = n-1$$. But it is <strong>not </strong>the case that $$b = n-1 = 1$$. We can say that $$b = n - 1 \geq 1$$ because this comes from $$n \geq 2$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>So for example, take $$k = 1$$ and $$n = 3$$ and we have $$a = 1$$ and $$b = 2$$ so we have a case where $$a < b$$.</p>

<p>For 36, can you explain how we can remove the ordering of certain things (in this case amongst pairs and within pairs) by simply dividing? I thought we accounted for bad cases by subtracting them using complementary counting. </p>
<p>What&#39;s our definition of real numbers, natural numbers, and integers?</p>
<p>What&#39;s our definition of real numbers, natural numbers, and integers?</p>
<p>$$\mathbb{N} = \{0, 1, 2, 3, ... \}$$. It is the set of all counting, whole numbers starting from 0.</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$\mathbb{Z} = \{... -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, ... \}$$. It is the set of all counting, whole numbers.</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$\mathbb{R}$$ contains all positive or negative whole numbers, fractions or decimals. </p>
<p></p>
<p>This yields the following relationships: $$\mathbb{N} \subseteq \mathbb{Z}$$, $$\mathbb{N} \subseteq \mathbb{R}$$, $$\mathbb{Z} \subseteq \mathbb{R}$$</p>
response time: 0:03:18

<p>$$2\leq k \leq n$$</p>

<p>Is there a formula for counting surjective functions?</p>
<p>How does Case 1 correspond to the RHS? Is it using some permutation identity? </p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Flcslq4hc8982lu%2F2036ae0bba08b0d7c3f54d6573c65decfaab7c081da4bad8ebe865674d150fee%2Fimage.png" alt="image.png" /></p>
<p>How did we get that there are (99 choose 39) sets containing 40 and (99 choose 40) sets not containing 40?</p>
<p>Are these two different definitions? If so, can you explain the difference?</p>
<p>Are these two different definitions? If so, can you explain the difference?</p>
<p>Two sets are said to be disjoint if they share no elements in common. That is, $$A$$ and $$B$$ are disjoint when $$A \cap B = \emptyset$$. The term &#34;pairwise disjoint&#34; has a definition that <strong>builds off</strong> the definition of &#34;disjoint&#34;. We say a <em>collection </em>of sets $$A_1, A_2, ..., A_n$$ are pairwise disjoint when $$\forall i, j$$, we have $$A_i \cap A_j = \emptyset$$.</p>
<p>So all of the sets have no elements in common?</p>
<p>correct</p>

<p>I asked about WLOG in office hours and they said that unless we are doing symmetrical casing we shouldn&#39;t need WLOG. <p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkyaswwcgamr1et%2F097b925cb735d86a12db1b9e77c5842eed59cb821f8786a349a40bb15743a0b9%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" width="743" height="161" /></p>
<p>Why is not written as (66 &#43; 88 - 1) choose (88 - 1)? I know they equate to the same answer, but in the formula (n &#43; r -1) choose (r - 1), I&#39;m not sure how with r being distinguishable, the boa is put at the bottom in the solution. </p>
<p></p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkyaswwcgamr1et%2F097b925cb735d86a12db1b9e77c5842eed59cb821f8786a349a40bb15743a0b9%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" width="743" height="161" /></p>
<p>When doing stars &amp; bars, we can think of an arrangement of stars and bars such as $$***|**|*$$ as an &#34;assignment&#34; of the indistinguishable items to distinguishable containers. But note that the distinguishability of the containers is determined by <strong>an implicit ordering</strong>. That is, the first container comes before the first bar, the second container comes before the second bar, etc. But also note that the <em>bars</em> in this arrangement are indistinguishable. In other words, we are using indistinguishable bars to define distinguishable containers.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Suppose you have $$n$$ stars and $$r-1$$ bars. When counting the number of arrangements of stars and bars, you can think of it as a two step procedure where in the first step, you choose the locations for the bars and then in the second step, you place the stars. Notice how there is no &#34;arrangement&#34; of these stars or bars necessary since they are indistinguishable. The first step can be performed in $$\binom{n+r-1}{r-1}$$ ways, and the second step can be performed in $$1$$ way. So we get the formula for stars and bars as $$\binom{n+r-1}{r-1}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>We could have equivalently counted the number of arrangements by following a different procedure where in the first step, we choose the locations for the stars and then in the second step, we place the bars. This gives us $$\binom{n+r-1}{n}$$ which is an alternate, equivalent solution.</p>
<p></p>
<p>So this kind of explains why $$\binom{n+r-1}{r-1} = \binom{n+r-1}{n}$$ and why both can be used in a stars &amp; bars setting.</p>

<p>Do we need to show Y is a subset of X for this to be a valid proof (do we need the first paragraph of the solution)?</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Flcsbg530lhi7gv%2Feac57b05a6958d65442f3264ad0b056adec48576fd723bb58beee1526e93696a%2FScreenshot_2023-02-16_at_12.50.40_PM.png" alt="Screenshot_2023-02-16_at_12.50.40_PM.pngNaN" /></p>
<p>Do we need to show Y is a subset of X for this to be a valid proof (do we need the first paragraph of the solution)?</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Flcsbg530lhi7gv%2Feac57b05a6958d65442f3264ad0b056adec48576fd723bb58beee1526e93696a%2FScreenshot_2023-02-16_at_12.50.40_PM.png" alt="Screenshot_2023-02-16_at_12.50.40_PM.pngNaN" /></p>
<p>Yes, you need to show that $$Y \subseteq X$$. Recall that $$Y \subsetneq X$$ means that $$Y$$ is a <strong>proper</strong> subset of $$X$$, meaning that it is a subset of $$X$$, but it is not equal to $$X$$.</p>

<p>Is the given question transitive or not transitive? As in was the example given was it for a transitive situation or non-transitive? The wording got a bit confusing.</p>
<p>Is the given question transitive or not transitive? As in was the example given was it for a transitive situation or non-transitive? The wording got a bit confusing.</p>
<p>The example is showing how the relationship can <strong>not </strong>be transitive. If Kristina beats Sana and Sana beats Zoe, then <em>if the relationship was transitive</em>, we would have Kristina beating Zoe. The example is showing that this is <strong>not always</strong> the case, and we <em>can</em> have Zoe beating Kristina.</p>

<p>I am using induction for this problem, but found that I&#39;m stuck in a logic recursion that is analogous to the OCaml recursion -- long and redundant. (there&#39;s is this case that I kept going deeper into all the way to base case) Is there a solution like how we used tail call in OCaml for mathematical proofs like this? </p>
<p>There is a solution! And the solution ties into why this is a mathematical/theory class rather than a coding class. The solution is... creativity! Often, when stuck on one way of thinking in a proof, it is worthwhile to pursue a different trail of thought. So that&#39;s my suggestion for you. Try approaching the problem in a completely different way, but use what you have learned in your first attempt in the process!</p>

<p>We say that a TA t is the supreme TA if for any other TA s, either t is a winner over s, or t is<br />a winner over some third TA u that is a winner over s.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Does this mean that the status of supreme TA only checks if there was a winner up to the third TA or does it extend down through all the TAs? For example, if A is a winner over B and B over C and C over D, would A be considered a supreme TA?</p>

<p>For question 4, lets say that T won against A but lost to S, and S won against both A and T. Is the relationship between S and A consider to be transitive? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Thanks in Advance! </p>
<p>no. To clarify what we mean by &#34;transitive&#34;, we mean that the result of one match <strong>is not</strong> determined (i.e. can be inferred) by other matches.</p>

<p>For Q4, I have a solution that works as follows (very brief explanation):</p>
<p></p>
<p>Choose arbitrary TA t1 out of the n possible TAs. Denote set W to be all the TA&#39;s t1 directly wins over and set L to be all the TA&#39;s t1 directly loses to. Then 2 cases:</p>
<p></p>
<p>Case 1: every element in L lost to at least 1 element in W so therefore TA t1 is supreme since either directly or indirectly beat everyone.  Done!</p>
<p></p>
<p>Case 2: there exists some TA t2 in the set L that beats every TA in the set W. From here we can restart the process considering TA t2 to be the new potential supreme TA, the set W to be the same set as before &#43; t1 &#43; any number of elements in the set L that t2 directly beats (key point is that |W| can increase from before as it only gains new elements and can not lose element). The set L will be the same as before but will lose t2 and any elements that were initially in L that t2 directly beats (key point is that |L| decreases because L can only lose elements not gain any. </p>
<p></p>
<p>From there repeat the two cases with TA t2 as the new potential supreme TA with the new set W and the new set L. Since W can only grow, and L can only lose elements then we can continue the process until Case 1 reached or |L| becomes 0 and therefore case 1 reached. </p>
<p></p>
<p>So sorry for the long explanation but hope that made sense. My question is can I use this form of proof here? Am I allowed to simply say continue the process until case 1 is reached (therefore defining a supreme TA) or |L| = 0 which also defines a supreme TA?  </p>
<p>For Q4, I have a solution that works as follows (very brief explanation):</p>
<p></p>
<p>Choose arbitrary TA t1 out of the n possible TAs. Denote set W to be all the TA&#39;s t1 directly wins over and set L to be all the TA&#39;s t1 directly loses to. Then 2 cases:</p>
<p></p>
<p>Case 1: every element in L lost to at least 1 element in W so therefore TA t1 is supreme since either directly or indirectly beat everyone.  Done!</p>
<p></p>
<p>Case 2: there exists some TA t2 in the set L that beats every TA in the set W. From here we can restart the process considering TA t2 to be the new potential supreme TA, the set W to be the same set as before &#43; t1 &#43; any number of elements in the set L that t2 directly beats (key point is that |W| can increase from before as it only gains new elements and can not lose element). The set L will be the same as before but will lose t2 and any elements that were initially in L that t2 directly beats (key point is that |L| decreases because L can only lose elements not gain any. </p>
<p></p>
<p>From there repeat the two cases with TA t2 as the new potential supreme TA with the new set W and the new set L. Since W can only grow, and L can only lose elements then we can continue the process until Case 1 reached or |L| becomes 0 and therefore case 1 reached. </p>
<p></p>
<p>So sorry for the long explanation but hope that made sense. My question is can I use this form of proof here? Am I allowed to simply say continue the process until case 1 is reached (therefore defining a supreme TA) or |L| = 0 which also defines a supreme TA?  </p>
<p>we cannot comment on the correctness of a proof</p>

<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fke1rq2fbuxip3%2F83e39290ac6efb13a799440d066626fdbadd3d6babe4efefaf038ecc6e27af2e%2Fa32cd1cafef27ca8994ea738e1cedca9.png" width="1344" height="652" alt="" />could someone point me in the right direction for figuring out the algebraic manipulation to make it equal to the RHS? Having a bit of trouble seeing it. </p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fke1rq2fbuxip3%2F83e39290ac6efb13a799440d066626fdbadd3d6babe4efefaf038ecc6e27af2e%2Fa32cd1cafef27ca8994ea738e1cedca9.png" width="1344" height="652" alt="" />could someone point me in the right direction for figuring out the algebraic manipulation to make it equal to the RHS? Having a bit of trouble seeing it. </p>
<p>$$Pr[A] + Pr[B] - Pr[A] \cdot Pr[B]$$</p>
<p>= $$1 - (1 - (Pr[A] + Pr[B] - Pr[A] \cdot Pr[B]))$$</p>
<p>=$$1 - (1 - Pr[A] - Pr[B] + Pr[A] \cdot Pr[B])$$</p>
<p>= $$1 - (1 - Pr[A])(1 - Pr[B])$$</p>
<p>$$Pr[A] + Pr[B] - Pr[A] \cdot Pr[B]$$</p>
<p>= $$1 - (1 - (Pr[A] + Pr[B] - Pr[A] * Pr[B]))$$</p>
<p>=$$1 - (1 - Pr[A] - Pr[B] + Pr[A] * Pr[B])$$</p>
<p>= $$1 - (1 - Pr[A])(1 - Pr[B])$$</p>

<p>I&#39;ve just been listing the set of outcomes initially and then declaring the necessary probabilities later. Is this sufficient for declaring the probability space? Or do I need (omega, Pr)?</p>
<p>I&#39;ve just been listing the set of outcomes initially and then declaring the necessary probabilities later. Is this sufficient for declaring the probability space? Or do I need (omega, Pr)?</p>
<p>We recommend you supplying $$(\Omega, \Pr)$$</p>
<p>What exactly is Pr? I&#39;m confused about how you&#39;d write this in parentheses considering Pr has multiple values that are defined later in proofs generally?</p>
<p>you don&#39;t need to provide it in parentheses format; you just need to define $$\Omega$$ and $$\Pr$$. Note that $$\Pr$$ is a function on outcomes. As an example: suppose I was rolling a dice and looking at what side faces up. Then, I would have $$\Omega = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$$ and $$\Pr$$ defined as $$\Pr[\omega] = \frac16 \quad \forall \omega \in \Omega$$</p>

<p>I think I heard from a TA that we cannot define a sample space as &#34;number of possible ways..&#34; of something. For example, is it right to define omega as picking 2 number out of n numbers and wrong to write the number of possible ways to pick 2 numbers out of n numbers?</p>
<p>I think I heard from a TA that we cannot define a sample space as &#34;number of possible ways..&#34; of something. For example, is it right to define omega as picking 2 number out of n numbers and wrong to write the number of possible ways to pick 2 numbers out of n numbers?</p>
<p>The TA is correct. $$\Omega$$ is <strong>not</strong> a number, it is a set. So we could define $$\Omega$$ as &#34;the set of all possibilities of picking 2 numbers out of n numbers&#34;. <strong>It would be wrong </strong>to define $$\Omega$$ as &#34;the <em>number</em> of ways to pick 2 numbers out of n numbers.&#34;</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedxgblvppr1vj%2F696e69732c67c9451156fe985450aa7788fb345d8a14f611295289bab95c15ce%2FPNG_image.jpeg" alt="PNG_image.jpegNaN" width="877" height="82" /></p>
<p>So this is correct because it is &#34;all the possible ways&#34; and not &#34;the number of possible ways&#34;? If we state the sample space as &#34;picking 5 cards from 52 card deck&#34;, is this wrong?</p>
<p>yes to the first question. For the second question, I would say that it is technically incorrect because the wording of &#34;picking 5 cards from 52 card deck&#34; seems to describe an <em>action</em> rather than a set. </p>
response time: 0:03:06

<p>We know that every other number from 1 to $2n$ is even, and the rest are odd. Thus, half the numbers in $[1..2n]$ are odd, so there are $2n / 2 = n$ odd integers and $2n - n = n$ even integers.</p>
