<p>this is for personal understanding only and in no means related to required material, but can expectation be thought of as a linear operator? More exactly, $$\hat{E}:\mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}, $$ $$\hat{E}(X) = \vec{x} \cdot \vec{p}$$, where $$p_i = Pr[X=x_i]$$ and $$x_i \in Val(X)$$</p>
<p>this is for personal understanding only and in no means related to required material, but can expectation be thought of as a linear operator? More exactly, $$\hat{E}:\mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}, $$ $$\hat{E}(X) = \vec{x} \cdot \vec{p}$$, where $$p_i = Pr[X=x_i]$$ and $$x_i \in Val(X)$$</p>
<p>sort of. We can see that the canonical equation for expectation of $$\mathbb E[X] = \sum_{x \in Val(x)} x \cdot \Pr[X = x]$$ is indeed a linear function. </p>
<p></p>
<p>I wouldn&#39;t say that the domain of your provided $$\hat{E}$$ is $$\mathbb R$$ because we define a random variable to be a <strong>function</strong>. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Otherwise, sure. You&#39;ve basically described expectation as a dot product between two vectors, which is exactly what a summation of the product of two entities is. </p>
response time: 18:49:48



<p>Below is a screenshot from 10.3. Does the converse hold true?<img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Flcslyhhojpq2v4%2F7c772ee48ce55ea2e5ea7dfcb2ddb92d439212a639b6ea62d108680b425ae28f%2FScreen_Shot_2023-03-08_at_2.21.22_PM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2023-03-08_at_2.21.22_PM.pngNaN" /></p>
Why are we solving for when we are returning the ith pair of sock? How does this lead us to find the expected pair of socks
Why are we solving for when we are returning the ith pair of sock? How does this lead us to find the expected pair of socks
<p>The total amount of socks being returned can be thought of as a sum of a bunch of $$1$$&#39;s and $$0$$&#39;s, where a 1 indicates if the sock has been returned and a 0 otherwise. For example, suppose we put in 3 pairs of socks (we&#39;ll label these pairs A, B, and C) and only received 2 back. And further, suppose that we didn&#39;t receive pair B back. Then, it is true that we received 1 &#43; 0 &#43; 1 = 2 pairs back (1 for A and 1 for C). This is essentially what indicators are. So if we were to define an indicator for each pair of socks, and sum them all together, we would get the total amount of pairs returned.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Thus, if $$S = I_1 + I_2 + ... + I_n$$, then $$\mathbb{E}[S] = \mathbb{E}[I_1 + I_2 + ... + I_n]$$. And by using Linearity of Expectation, we have this being equal to $$\mathbb{E}[I_1] + \mathbb{E}[I_2] + ... + \mathbb{E}[I_n] = \sum_{i=1}^n \mathbb{E}[I_i]$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>So our problem has been reduced to finding the expected value of an indicator, where the indicator is whether or not the $$i$$th pair is returned. By finding this value, we can easily obtain $$\mathbb{E}[S]$$ using the math above.</p>

<p>When finding the cardinality of when X=1 <br />why does this method not work:<br />step 1: choose any sock (4 choose 1)<br />step 2: choose the other sock from that pair (1 way)</p>
<p>When finding the cardinality of when X=1 <br />why does this method not work:<br />step 1: choose any sock (4 choose 1)<br />step 2: choose the other sock from that pair (1 way)</p>
<p>Because you are imposing an ordering on the socks. So suppose $$\{s_1, s_2\}$$ and $$\{b_1, b_2\}$$ are the pairs. Then, we consider receiving $$\{b_1, b_2\}$$ the same as receiving $$\{b_2, b_1\}$$. But these are considered to be different cases in your procedure.</p>
response time: 0:02:43

<p>Just checking, do we need to prove by ourselves in the HW that E[X] = np when X is a Bernoulli RV?</p>
<p>Just checking, do we need to prove by ourselves in the HW that E[X] = np when X is a Bernoulli RV?</p>
<p>Careful: that is not the equation for expectation of a Bernoulli RV. It is the equation for expectation of a <strong>binomial random variable</strong>. And no, you do not have to prove this. </p>

<p>I was wondering if what 1c meant by &#34;is it possible to have an assignment of variables such that all the propositions are true?&#34; is, does there exist an assignment following rules 1-3 where all propositions are guaranteed to be true, or whether it means that there exists an assignment where the propositions may be true (i.e. have the possibility of being true)?</p>
Is it fine for me to attend an interactive session during the other section of the class if the interactive sessions are full for my section?
<p>So we are given a definition of mutual independence in Lecture Notes 8.3.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Meaning if we know $$Pr[A_{i_1} \cap ... \cap A_{i_k}] = Pr[A_{i_1}] \cdots Pr[A_{i_k}]$$, then the conclusion is the events are mutually independent.</p>
<p></p>
<p>But does the converse also hold? Meaning if we know the events are mutually independent, then we can say $$Pr[A_{i_1} \cap ... \cap A_{i_k}] = Pr[A_{i_1}] \cdots Pr[A_{i_k}]$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Also, if we have $$n$$ Bernoulli trials, each with the same probability $p$ of occurring and no trial affects the other, can we conclude mutual independence?</p>
<p>Can we freely use LOE as an abbreviation for &#34;Linearity of Expectation&#34;?</p>
<p>Can we assume that $$b \leq N$$, meaning there are at least as many Helenadryls in the bag as she selects?</p>
<p>I was wondering if an outcome of an r.v. can be considered an outcome if there is no/zero probability of it occurring?</p>
<p>I was wondering if an outcome of an r.v. can be considered an outcome if there is no/zero probability of it occurring?</p>
<p>I&#39;m unsure what you mean by &#34;outcome&#34; of a random variable. Remember, a random variable, say $$X$$, is defined to be a <strong>function: </strong>$$X: \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb R$$. This means that for each element of your outcome space, the random variable assigns it some real number value via some function you have defined. It is possible for there to be an $$\omega \in \Omega$$ such that $$\Pr[\omega] = 0$$, but since $$\omega \in \Omega$$, $$X(\omega)$$ must have some real value assigned to it (since $$\Omega$$ is the domain of $$X$$). </p>
response time: 0:02:45

<p>Do we have to identify a probability space for this question? If so, do we have to identify an uniform probability space for this question?</p>
<p>in the problem there are n medicines, and theyre equally likely to be chosen -- do we have to prove the following or can we just state it?</p>
<p></p>
<p>There is uniform probability on the space, with a $\dfrac{1}{n}$ probability that a medicine is chosen.</p>
<p>... please make sure you study all the material, and especially the self-paced segment on correlated rv&#39;s.</p>
<p>For example, I may have a probability space $$(\Omega, Pr)$$ where I&#39;m rolling 2023 dice. But let&#39;s say I want to focus on the first 10 dice. Can I define $$(\omega, Pr)$$ within $$(\Omega, Pr)$$ to &#34;zoom in&#34;? Or should I say these are two separate probability spaces?</p>
<p>For example, I may have a probability space $$(\Omega, Pr)$$ where I&#39;m rolling 2023 dice. But let&#39;s say I want to focus on the first 10 dice. Can I define $$(\omega, Pr)$$ within $$(\Omega, Pr)$$ to &#34;zoom in&#34;? Or should I say these are two separate probability spaces?</p>
<p>the short answer is &#34;probably&#34;. The long answer would require a lot more conversation about what you are intending to do by &#34;focusing&#34; on the first 10 dice rolls. </p>
<p></p>
<p>In general, I would try to avoid a &#34;sub-probability space&#34; and rather just define an event. Most ideas I can think of that involve &#34;focusing on the first 10 dice&#34; can be solved by just defining an event and giving its corresponding probability.</p>
<p></p>
<p>For example, I could define $$E$$ to be the event that the first 10 dice rolls are all even numbers. And this would be a perfectly fine event definition since $$E \subseteq \Omega$$. And then we could go about computing $$Pr[E]$$ in whichever way fancies us.</p>
response time: 2:35:25



<p>For example, are G and P on the same probability space? They have the same probabilities and outcomes, but are in different realms if that makes sense.</p>
<p>Is the relationship between the Indicator random variable of an event and linearity of expectation the same as something like the induction hypothesis and proof by induction. like is the indicator random variable of an event necessary to define when using linearity of expectation?</p>
<p>Is the relationship between the Indicator random variable of an event and linearity of expectation the same as something like the induction hypothesis and proof by induction. like is the indicator random variable of an event necessary to define when using linearity of expectation?</p>
<p>There is <strong>not</strong> an obvious analogy between Indicators/LOE and IH/Induction. If you choose to use indicator random variables in a problem, you should definitely define them. However, LOE does not require you to use indicator random variables, as it is defined for <em>any</em> collection of random variables</p>

<p>$$\land$$ and $$\lor$$ are not the same as intersection and union. $$\land$$ is your logical AND operator, and $$\lor$$ is your logical OR operator.</p>
<p>Yes, I see! I meant are allowed to redefine those terms as events, so we can use intersection and union?</p>
<p>I&#39;d avoid redefining terms as events. However, you are free to define events in terms of those variables. Those two sentences may seem contradictory, but I assure you that they mean different things!</p>

<p>Or, do I negate the entire expression, so it becomes an &#34;or&#34; and then I just need to do proof by contradiction on a single term (either P =&gt;Q or Q =&gt;P)</p>

<p>I am really struggling with how to conceptualise it and would really appreciate your help.</p>
<p>Hi, for qs 7 I had a query about proof by contradiction.</p>
<p></p>
<p>P iff Q would mean P =&gt;Q and Q =&gt;P</p>
<p>so If I want to prove this by contradiction, do I have to do it on each term (both P =&gt;Q and Q =&gt;P) due to the &#34;and&#34; sign</p>
<p></p>
<p>Or, do I negate the entire expression, so it becomes an &#34;or&#34; and then I just need to do proof by contradiction on a single term (either P =&gt;Q or Q =&gt;P)</p>
<p></p>
<p>I am really struggling with how to conceptualise it and would really appreciate your help.</p>
Proving $$p \implies q$$ and $$q \implies p$$ can be thought of as doing two separate proofs. You do not need to do the same proof technique for both directions. So, for example, I could show $$p\implies q$$ by contradiction and then show $$q \implies p$$ directly

<p>Why is the second line true based on the first line? How do we get it from the first line?</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7ga3way2da7hz%2Faa28b2d4fdbdd4d1409888b72ced123da23b3d3aa43157e81633f0d3ea0ec73c%2Fimage.png" alt="image.png" /></p>
<p>Why is the second line true based on the first line? How do we get it from the first line?</p>
<p>$$j \cdot \Pr[Y = j] = \underbrace{\Pr[Y=y] + \Pr[Y=j] + ... + \Pr[Y= j]}_{\text{j times}} = \sum_{i = 1}^j \Pr[Y=j]$$</p>

Is it necessary to explicitly define any graphs we mention in our proofs, such as through something like “Consider an arbitrary graph G=(V, E)”? Or is it fine to explain graphs without explicitly defining the sets of vertices/edges and just thoroughly explaining everything?
Is it necessary to explicitly define any graphs we mention in our proofs, such as through something like “Consider an arbitrary graph G=(V, E)”? Or is it fine to explain graphs without explicitly defining the sets of vertices/edges and just thoroughly explaining everything?
<p>If you introduce a graph, you should be explaining what the vertex set is and what the edge set is. You do not have to give perfect set definitions, but you should explain what the vertices are in relation to the question and what the edges are in relation to the question</p>

<p>In MT2 Practice Q8, the solution justifies the set portion of the answer by Euler-Venn Diagram (&#34;By Euler-Venn diagram, (E \ F ) ∪ (E ∩ F ) ∪ (F \ E) = E ∪ F)&#34;), I was wondering if proofs of this nature are valid for the exam or if there would an alternate proof for this?</p>
<p>In MT2 Practice Q8, the solution justifies the set portion of the answer by Euler-Venn Diagram (&#34;By Euler-Venn diagram, (E \ F ) ∪ (E ∩ F ) ∪ (F \ E) = E ∪ F)&#34;), I was wondering if proofs of this nature are valid for the exam or if there would an alternate proof for this?</p>
<p>In general, you should avoid using Euler-Venn Diagrams as part of your proof. Instead, you can show $$(E \setminus F) \cup (E \cap F) \cup (F\setminus E) = E \cup F$$ via set proof (consider an arbitrary element of the LHS and show that it appears in the RHS and vice versa).</p>
<p></p>
<p>You could also try to explain it in words.</p>
<p>Do we have to prove this if it was in the exam?</p>
Probably
<p>Today in lecture it was stated that we could use Euler-Venn Diagrams as justification, so do we go off of what was stated in lecture?</p>
<p>yeah I guess so.</p>

<p>Is this a wrong method? Also, if it is not explicitly stated, can we still write answers in open form? How would we write the below answer in closed form? Thank you</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedxgblvppr1vj%2F6eef9248d8d80563edc66ccb375ac008551b673ae841b57948238e8adc21fcc6%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" width="560" height="715" /></p>
<p>Is this a wrong method? Also, if it is not explicitly stated, can we still write answers in open form? How would we write the below answer in closed form? Thank you</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedxgblvppr1vj%2F6eef9248d8d80563edc66ccb375ac008551b673ae841b57948238e8adc21fcc6%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" width="560" height="715" /></p>
<p>Yes this is a valid solution. You can simplify this by first noting, from Pascal&#39;s triangle, that:</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$\binom{2n}{0} + \binom{2n}{1} + ... + \binom{2n}{2n} = 2^{2n}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Then, we see that $$\binom{2n}{0} = \binom{2n}{2n}$$, $$\binom{2n}{1} = \binom{2n}{2n-1}$$, etc. so the above simplifies to:</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$(\binom{2n}{0} + \binom{2n}{2n}) + (\binom{2n}{1} + \binom{2n}{2n-1}) + ... + \binom{2n}{n} = 2^{2n}$$</p>
<p>$$2 \cdot \binom{2n}{0} + 2 \cdot \binom{2n}{1} + ... + 2 \cdot \binom{2n}{n-1} + \binom{2n}{n} = 2^{2n}$$</p>
<p>$$2 \cdot \left( \binom{2n}{0} + \binom{2n}{1} + \ldots + \binom{2n}{n-1} \right) = 2^{2n} - \binom{2n}{n}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>And thus, $$\binom{2n}{0} + \binom{2n}{1} + \ldots + \binom{2n}{n-1} = \frac{2^{2n} - \binom{2n}{n}}{2}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>So then your final answer would become $$\frac{\frac{2^{2n} - \binom{2n}{n}}{2}}{2^{2n}} = \frac{2^{2n} - \binom{2n}{n}}{2^{2n+1}}$$ which is the correct answer.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Your answers should <strong>always be in closed form</strong> unless we explicitly mention that open form solutions are allowed.</p>
<p>Yes this is a valid solution. You can simplify this by first noting, from Pascal&#39;s triangle, that:</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$\binom{2n}{0} + \binom{2n}{1} + ... + \binom{2n}{2n} = 2^{2n}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Then, we see that $$\binom{2n}{0} = \binom{2n}{2n}$$, $$\binom{2n}{1} = \binom{2n}{2n-1}$$, etc. so the above simplifies to:</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$(\binom{2n}{0} + \binom{2n}{2n}) + (\binom{2n}{1} + \binom{2n}{2n-1}) + ... + \binom{2n}{n} = 2^{2n}$$</p>
<p>$$2 \cdot \binom{2n}{0} + 2 \cdot \binom{2n}{1} + ... + 2 \cdot \binom{2n}{n-1} + \binom{2n}{n} = 2^{2n}$$</p>
<p>$$2 \cdot \left( \binom{2n}{0} + \binom{2n}{1} + \ldots + \binom{2n}{n-1} \right) = 2^{2n} - \binom{2n}{n}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>And thus, $$binom{2n}{0} + \binom{2n}{1} + \ldots + \binom{2n}{n-1} = \frac{2^{2n} - \binom{2n}{n}}{2}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>So then your final answer would become $$\frac{\frac{2^{2n} - \binom{2n}{n}}{2}}{2^{2n}} = \frac{2^{2n} - \binom{2n}{n}}{2^{2n+1}}$$ which is the correct answer.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Your answers should <strong>always be in closed form</strong> unless we explicitly mention that open form solutions are allowed.</p>

<p>So sorry, but I think that I am having trouble with understanding Q1&#39;s answer/logic. I know that we are pigeonholing on the values of the codomain, but don&#39;t see how this guarantees f(1) = g(1)? Is the pigeonhole H where all functions in this hole have all their domain values are mapped to the codomain value 1 (or 2 or 3 WLOG)? Or would someone mind pointing me to the question that I remember we did that was similar to this in either one of the lectures or extra practice problems, if they can remember it?</p>
<p>So sorry, but I think that I am having trouble with understanding Q1&#39;s answer/logic. I know that we are pigeonholing on the values of the codomain, but don&#39;t see how this guarantees f(1) = g(1)? Is the pigeonhole H where all functions in this hole have all their domain values are mapped to the codomain value 1 (or 2 or 3 WLOG)? Or would someone mind pointing me to the question that I remember we did that was similar to this in either one of the lectures or extra practice problems, if they can remember it?</p>
<p>No need to apologize -- I agree that the wording of Q1 is a bit odd. </p>
<p></p>
<p>The argument here is that we have $$3^3 = 27$$ possible functions, and we will assign them to holes based on where they &#34;send&#34; the value 1. That is, we will have holes labeled 0, 1, and 2 (for the three possible values of the codomain, and for a function $$f$$ (which is a pigeon), it will be placed in the hole labeled $$f(1)$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>By PHP, you we can conclude that there exists a hole with at least $$\lceil \frac{27}{3} \rceil = 9$$ pigeons (functions) in it. But we notice that for two functions $$f$$ and $$g$$ to be in the same hole, it must be the case that $$f(1) = g(1)$$. In other words, suppose we have two functions $$f$$ and $$g$$ that both landed in hole (WLOG) 0. Then, by construction, it MUST be that we had $$f(1) = 0$$ and $$g(1) = 0$$, so we can say that $$f(1) = g(1)$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Since our hole has $$9$$ pigeons, it must be the case that the output of all of them on input $$1$$ is equal. So we take any $$9$$ of the pigeons/functions that landed in this hole.</p>
I&#39;m still confused on how you know that it is f(1) = g(1).
What are the holes and pigeons defined?
<p>The pigeons are the functions. The holes are $$0, 1, 2$$, which are the possible values of $$f(1)$$. A function $$f$$ &#34;flies&#34; into the hole of $$f(1)$$.</p>
I&#39;m still confused on how you know that it is f(1) = g(1).
What are the holes and pigeons defined?
Why is it that f(1)=g(1) if f,g, are  any 2 pigeons that flie into H?
I&#39;m still confused on how you know that it is f(1) = g(1).
What are the holes and pigeons defined?
<p>Because we said that a function goes into hole $$H$$ if $$f(1) = H$$. So if both $$f, g$$ are in $$H$$, then $$f(1) = H$$ and $$g(1) = H$$, so $$f(1) = g(1)$$.</p>

<p>How can you know that Pr[X=-1] is equal to 1- Pr[X= 1] if there could be more than 2 outcomes in this probability space? <img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Flcply0liip97hz%2F0c654be3596c5e79edef4bb3f80be1d07d61cc0f2d21e38aec81ac604c86e8fe%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" /></p>
<p>In the practice problem, sometimes P() is used to denote probability and other times Pr[] is used. Are these interchangeable?</p>
<p>How did you respond so fast?</p>
<p>the irony of this situation is hilarious.</p>
<p>Based on the given recurrence relation and intuition (one cut would split the pizza into 2 pieces), I&#39;m confused about why C(1) is 1 in the recursion tree? Am I missing something?</p>
<p>Based on the given recurrence relation and intuition (one cut would split the pizza into 2 pieces), I&#39;m confused about why C(1) is 1 in the recursion tree? Am I missing something?</p>
<p>The tree isn&#39;t saying that $$C(1) = 1$$, but rather that $$C(1)$$ will <em>&#34;contribute&#34; </em>or <em>&#34;add&#34;</em> 1 when we encounter it. In other words, it adds 1 to the value of the sum of the previous terms. This value comes from the recurrence relation being $$C(n) = C(n-1) + {\color{red} n}$$ where the $${\color{red} n}$$ is the &#34;addition&#34; part. This is also why the tree is called a &#34;tree of additions&#34;.</p>
response time: 0:14:51



<p>i&#39;m a little bit confused on the solution for 6a -- what does {w1, w3} mean as a solution? is it event w1 happening, then event w3 happening? or is it a sample space of events consisting only of w1 and w3?</p>
<p></p>
<p>then, would E and F mean the events that are in both E and F sample spaces which is why it is {w3}?</p>
<p></p>
<p>thank you!</p>
<p>i&#39;m a little bit confused on the solution for 6a -- what does {w1, w3} mean as a solution? is it event w1 happening, then event w3 happening? or is it a sample space of events consisting only of w1 and w3?</p>
<p></p>
<p>then, would E and F mean the events that are in both E and F sample spaces which is why it is {w3}?</p>
<p></p>
<p>thank you!</p>
<p>$$\{\omega_1, \omega_3\}$$ is defined to be equivalent to $$E$$, which is an event. Recall that an event is defined to be a subset of the outcome space. In words, we would say that &#34;E is the event that one of $$\omega_1$$ or $$\omega_3$$ occurs&#34;. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Since an event $$E \subseteq \Omega$$ (that is, $$E$$ is a sub<strong>set</strong>), we can perform set operations on it.</p>
<p></p>
<p>So $$E \cap F$$ is the <strong>intersection</strong> of events $$E$$ and $$F$$, which is the outcomes that are described by both $$E$$ and $$F$$.</p>

<p>How is it that A is a subset of both B and C when B and C are independent - and from there, since B and C are independent, how can the intersection of A B and C be 1 (I thought it would be 0)? </p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fktc6vywygd7hb%2Fedc79349ccb36775c0a9b9b421e00e5577a9ccfeb94e74c2708ac2f035cbbbbc%2FScreen_Shot_2023-03-27_at_11.42.38_AM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2023-03-27_at_11.42.38_AM.pngNaN" /></p>
<p>How is it that A is a subset of both B and C when B and C are independent - and from there, since B and C are independent, how can the intersection of A B and C be 1 (I thought it would be 0)? </p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fktc6vywygd7hb%2Fedc79349ccb36775c0a9b9b421e00e5577a9ccfeb94e74c2708ac2f035cbbbbc%2FScreen_Shot_2023-03-27_at_11.42.38_AM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2023-03-27_at_11.42.38_AM.pngNaN" /></p>
<p>In general, events $$B$$ and $$C$$ are independent if $$\Pr[B \cap C] = \Pr[B] \cdot \Pr[C]$$. This <strong>does not mean that </strong>$$B \cap C = \emptyset$$ or $$\Pr[B \cap C] = 0$$. These <em>could</em> occur, but do not <em>have</em> to. </p>
<p></p>
<p>This implies that we may have $$B \cap C \neq \emptyset$$, which means we can have a non-empty $$A \subseteq B$$ and $$A \subseteq C$$</p>
response time: 0:14:16



<p>Why do we need base cases for both n=0 and n</p>
<p>Why do we need base cases for both n=0 and n</p>
<p>If we only showed $$n = 0$$, then in our IH, the value of $$k$$ would be bounded as $$k \geq 0$$. So in the induction step, we would consider $$k + 1$$, which could take on the value of $$1$$ (when $$k = 0$$). Then, we would not be able to say that $$P(k-1)$$ holds by our IH, and we would thus be stuck.</p>
response time: 0:13:39



<p>Why exactly can we conclude that Pr[X &lt;= (a&#43;b)/2] = Pr[X=a] when a &lt; (a&#43;b)/2?</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fktc6vywygd7hb%2Fad03dd080e71fd205e4b2bd1539e0680b889a423d457f909ef51bffe6e209154%2FScreen_Shot_2023-03-27_at_2.33.25_PM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2023-03-27_at_2.33.25_PM.png" /></p>
<p>Why exactly can we conclude that Pr[X &lt;= (a&#43;b)/2] = Pr[X=a] when a &lt; (a&#43;b)/2?</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fktc6vywygd7hb%2Fad03dd080e71fd205e4b2bd1539e0680b889a423d457f909ef51bffe6e209154%2FScreen_Shot_2023-03-27_at_2.33.25_PM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2023-03-27_at_2.33.25_PM.png" /></p>
<p>Because $$\mathrm{Val}(X) = \{a, b\}$$, which means that for any $$\alpha \neq a, b$$, we would have $$\Pr[X = \alpha] = 0$$. Therefore, to calculate $$\Pr[X \leq \frac{a+b}{2}]$$, we can take the following sum:</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$\Pr[X \leq \frac{a+b}{2}] = \sum_{\alpha \leq \frac{a+b}{2}} \Pr[X = \alpha]$$. But all of these probabilities will be $$0$$ except when $$\alpha = a$$. So the sum reduces to $$\Pr[X = a]$$.</p>
response time: 0:24:14



<p>Since in induction we use p(k) to derive p(k&#43;1), our assumption contains some relation with k and k&#43;1 (or more). Then is it almost always the case that our base case would need to have more than just P(0)? Also, is it wrong if we just write more than one base case all the time?</p>
<p>Since in induction we use p(k) to derive p(k&#43;1), our assumption contains some relation with k and k&#43;1 (or more). Then is it almost always the case that our base case would need to have more than just P(0)? Also, is it wrong if we just write more than one base case all the time?</p>
<p>No. In ordinary induction, we almost always need only one base case. This is because we only &#34;rely&#34; on one prior term. It is not wrong to have more than one base case, but from a convention/proof writing standpoint, it is better to have just one base case than multiple unnecessary base cases.</p>
response time: 1:00:46



<p>Here, we see a relationship with n-1, n, n&#43;1. I thought that for cases like this we needed 3 base cases to prove the relationship holds. Why do we only need to show one base case here?</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedxgblvppr1vj%2Ffed95834acff4071380b31d63a915b355f3aec509a787169100d9d9fb0f070fe%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" width="733" height="474" /></p>
<p>Here, we see a relationship with n-1, n, n&#43;1. I thought that for cases like this we needed 3 base cases to prove the relationship holds. Why do we only need to show one base case here?</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedxgblvppr1vj%2Ffed95834acff4071380b31d63a915b355f3aec509a787169100d9d9fb0f070fe%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" width="733" height="474" /></p>
<p>This is because we want to prove it for all $$n \geq 1$$ and the recurrence is defined for all $$n \geq 1$$. In other recurrence relations, there are usually some base cases defined <strong>outside</strong> of the recurrence relation, and we would need multiple base cases in induction so that in the induction step, we are working with values of $$k+1$$ that we can use the recurrence relation on.</p>
response time: 2:00:53

<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedxgblvppr1vj%2F2a91ddc55416d635f3add7f3896454b2d95bb96e7cc2e068e653f8aeb52b30ea%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" width="729" height="62" /></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedxgblvppr1vj%2F2a91ddc55416d635f3add7f3896454b2d95bb96e7cc2e068e653f8aeb52b30ea%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" width="729" height="62" /></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>If $$E \perp \overline{E}$$ then $$\Pr[E \cap \overline{E}] = \Pr[E] \cdot \Pr[\overline{E}]$$. But note $$E \cap \overline{E} = \emptyset$$ and $$\Pr[\emptyset] = 0$$, so this would mean either $$\Pr[E] = 0$$ or $$\Pr[\overline{E}] = 0$$ (which would imply that $$\Pr[E] = 1$$)</p>
<p>If $$E \perp \overline{E}$$ then $$\Pr[E \cap \overline{E}] = \Pr[E] \cdot \Pr[\overline{E}]$$. But note $$E \cap \overline{E} = \emptyset$$ and $$\Pr[\emptyset] = 0$$, so this would mean either $$\Pr[E] = 0$$ or $$\Pr[\overline{E}] = 0$$</p>

<p>When using strong induction, do we base the bounds for k based on the base cases? So for this question, is k ≥ 1 because we tested 1 in the base cases?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Additionally for j, why is it that 0 ≤ j ≤ k? Is this because the first value of n in S(n) is 2 so we have S(2) = S(0) &#43; S(1), so we need 0 to be included in the bounds for j?</p>
<p></p>
<p>thank you!</p>
<p>For the first two questions, the answer is yes.</p>
<p></p>
<p>For the last bit, you almost have it. We do $$0 \leq j \leq k$$ because we bound $$k \geq 1$$, which mean when we are in the induction step and considering $$k+1$$, we have $$k+1 \geq 2$$. Since it is possible for $$k+1 = 2$$, we would need $$S(1)$$ and $$S(0)$$ to be assumed in the IH if we were to use the recurrence relation.</p>
<p>Should k &gt;=1 here then, instead of k &gt;= 0?</p>

<p>Hi! I was just wondering how we got from n! - | B1 u B2 ... u Bn | to the final equation of the form n! (1 - 1/1! ... &#43; (-1)^n/n!). Thank you so much!!</p>
<p></p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Flcurid8u1toap%2Fb42d6f5db0b559c2459e1e7d80980de02fe12685eb6d1ad8bb7631b8f623649c%2FScreen_Shot_2023-03-28_at_7.07.23_PM.png" width="1444" height="568" alt="" /></p>
<p>Hi! I was just wondering how we got from n! - | B1 u B2 ... u Bn | to the final equation of the form n! (1 - 1/1! ... &#43; (-1)^n/n!). Thank you so much!!</p>
<p></p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Flcurid8u1toap%2Fb42d6f5db0b559c2459e1e7d80980de02fe12685eb6d1ad8bb7631b8f623649c%2FScreen_Shot_2023-03-28_at_7.07.23_PM.png" width="1444" height="568" alt="" /></p>
<p>We are just doing PIE to get the parenthetical part. We have:</p>
<p></p>
<p>$$|B_1 \cup ... \cup B_n| = \sum_i |B_i| - \sum_{i, j} |B_i \cap B_j| + \sum_{i, j, k} |B_i \cap B_j \cap B_k| - \ldots + \sum_{1..n} |B_1 \cap B_2 \cap ... \cap B_n|$$</p>
<p></p>
<p>Consider, for example, the third summation of $$\sum_{i, j, k} |B_i \cap B_j \cap B_k|$$. In words, for a single $$i, j, k$$, we have that $$B_i \cap B_j \cap B_k$$ being the permutations in which $$h_i$$ <strong>does </strong>appear in position $$i$$, $$h_j$$ <strong>does </strong>appear in position $$j$$, and $$h_k$$ <strong>does </strong>appear in position $$k$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>To find this cardinality, we do a simple counting procedure:</p>
<p>Step 1: Place $$h_i, h_j, h_k$$ in positions $$i, j, k$$ respectively (1 way)</p>
<p>Step 2: Arrange the remaining elements ($$(n-3)!$$ ways)</p>
<p></p>
<p>So for a <strong>single </strong>$$i, j, k$$, we have $$|B_i \cap B_j \cap B_k| = (n-3)!$$. For the summation term , we have $$\sum_{i, j, k} |B_i \cap B_j \cap B_k| = \sum_{i, j, k} (n-3)!$$. The question is, how many $$i, j, k$$ triples are there? Well, there are $$\binom{n}{3} = \frac{n!}{3!(n-3)!}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>So this summation term reduces to $$\frac{n!}{3!(n-3)!} \cdot (n-3)! = \frac{n!}{3!}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>You can do a similar thing for all of the other summations, plug it back into the PIE equation, and factor out an $$n!$$, and you will get the desired expression.</p>
response time: 0:59:47

<p>For the answer of this question, why are there only 1 way to include the ith spade but not $$13\choose 1$$ ways to include it since there are 13 spades to choose from?</p>
<p>How come for the induction step we&#39;re checking for j&#43;1 and not k. <p>Let there be some non-empty set $$A$$ and some criterion $$p$$. We partition $$A$$ by $$p$$ or $$\neg p$$. Let $$P=\{a\in A|a$$ satisfies $$p\}$$ and $$\overline{P}=\{a\in A|a$$ does not satisfy $$p\}$$. Let the above be statement 0) where</p>

<p>Do we have to define sample space for every question, if not explicitly asked to?</p>
For HW 7 Q3, would something along these lines also be a correct solution?<div><br /></div><div>Let X be the RV denoting the number of non-drowsy Helenadryls drawn. </div><div><br /></div><div>We number the b Helenadryls selected from the bag 1 through b, and define indicator random variables I_i (where i is 1 to b) to be equal to 1 when the ith Helenadryl selected is non-drowsy (and 0 if drowsy).</div><div><br /></div><div>It follows that E[X] = summation of expectations of I_i from i=1 to i=b by LOE, since LOE applies regardless of independence/dependence of events.</div><div><br /></div><div>E[I_i]=Pr[I_i=1], or the probability that an ith Helenadryl selected is non-drowsy, equal to |E|/|Omega|, where E is the event that a nondrowsy Helenadryl is selected from the bag. The sample space consists of the ways to draw a singular Helenadryl from the bag of N Helenadryls, so |Omega|=N. There are N-r nondrowsy Helenadryls, so |E|=N-r. So E[I_i]=(N-r)/N, and E[X]=(b*(N-r)/N).</div>
<p>why is the second line Ni・Nj, isn&#39;t is 2Ni・Nj?</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksyzahev9h02j4%2F096cecc42f610e969ebacee473adde9ab1bbb89be0a948ca1cf133c1e6a49caa%2FScreen_Shot_2023-03-29_at_9.44.51_PM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2023-03-29_at_9.44.51_PM.png" width="392" height="153" /></p>
<p>why is the second line Ni・Nj, isn&#39;t is 2Ni・Nj?</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksyzahev9h02j4%2F096cecc42f610e969ebacee473adde9ab1bbb89be0a948ca1cf133c1e6a49caa%2FScreen_Shot_2023-03-29_at_9.44.51_PM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2023-03-29_at_9.44.51_PM.png" width="392" height="153" /></p>
<p>Because the pictured summation treats $$N_i \cdot N_j$$ different from $$N_j \cdot N_i$$. So you could equivalently write it as $$2 \sum_{i < j} N_i \cdot N_j$$</p>

<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7ga3way2da7hz%2F930fd4553c8b6563bededf9d03af41ba812c3a592577923bda6062d35f0bcaab%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" /></p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl750inz2wr81ow%2F3edcaf6c0257f630e5cb33218cd9ff9f85e03ec53941cbec1b34082a97267fd7%2Fimage.png" alt="image.png" /></p>
<p></p>
<p>For this question in the midterm review, why are j and k bounded at 2? I understand that the question introduces n &gt;= 2 as the range, but I thought that j and k should be bounded at the base cases (0 &lt;= j &lt;= k)? And can j and k always be defined in the same range like in the example shown above, or are there some cases where k is &gt;= 0 and j is &gt;= 2 for example? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Just a more general question: are there any general rules to where/how to define j and k for strong induction? Or just k for ordinary induction?</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl750inz2wr81ow%2F3edcaf6c0257f630e5cb33218cd9ff9f85e03ec53941cbec1b34082a97267fd7%2Fimage.png" alt="image.png" /></p>
<p></p>
<p>For this question in the midterm review, why are j and k bounded at 2? I understand that the question introduces n &gt;= 2 as the range, but I thought that j and k should be bounded at the base cases (0 &lt;= j &lt;= k)? And can j and k always be defined in the same range like in the example shown above, or are there some cases where k is &gt;= 0 and j is &gt;= 2 for example? </p>
<p></p>
<p>Just a more general question: are there any general rules to where/how to define j and k for strong induction? Or just k for ordinary induction?</p>
<p>It seems as if this was a mistake. You should refer to the official posted solutions for an accurate solution. We should have $$0 \leq j \leq k$$ and also bound $$k \geq 1$$. We bound $$k \geq 1$$ by referring to the largest base case (which in this case, is $$1$$).</p>
<p></p>
<p>In terms of how $$j$$ and $$k$$ are defined in a range, you should always specify a lower bound for $$k$$. And it will always be the case that $$j \leq k$$ (as specified by our assumption). This is because we need to assume everything up to and including $$k$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>To address your last few questions, $$k$$ should be bounded by the largest base case. We should have $$j$$ spanning in between the lower bound and the upper bound of $$k$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>In ordinary induction, we simply assume the claim &#34;for $$n = k$$ where $$k \geq \alpha$$&#34; where $$\alpha$$ is the value tested in the base case. </p>
<p></p>
<p>I think the document posted in @823 would be a great reading to get more clarifications.</p>
<p>^^I bound k by 2 in homework and got points off for it. Would love for this to be clarified!</p>
<p>see above.</p>
<p>Would also love clarification on when to use j and when to use k in the induction step for strong induction! Some examples prove P(k &#43; 1) while some examples prove P(j &#43; 1), so just wondering if there&#39;s a general rule to follow for that?</p>
<p>In the induction hypothesis, you need to do a change of variables. Say, for example, a question is posed in terms of $$n$$. Then in the IH, you should be changing the variables to whatever variable you choose. We commonly choose $$k$$, but it could be anything. </p>
<p>Would also love clarification on when to use j and when to use k in the induction step for strong induction! Some examples prove P(k &#43; 1) while some examples prove P(j &#43; 1), so just wondering if there&#39;s a general rule to follow for that?</p>
<p>When we change variables for strong induction, should we change the variable to j or k assuming that the bound was 0 &lt;= j &lt;= k for example?</p>
<p>Would also love clarification on when to use j and when to use k in the induction step for strong induction! Some examples prove P(k &#43; 1) while some examples prove P(j &#43; 1), so just wondering if there&#39;s a general rule to follow for that?</p>
<p>If you have the bound $$0 \leq j \leq k$$, then that means you are changing the variable <strong>to k. </strong>You also are introducing a <em>separate</em> variable $$j$$ that is spanning through all values that you are assuming the claim for.</p>
<p>Would also love clarification on when to use j and when to use k in the induction step for strong induction! Some examples prove P(k &#43; 1) while some examples prove P(j &#43; 1), so just wondering if there&#39;s a general rule to follow for that?</p>
<p>Gotcha; so if we are changing the variable to k in this case, then the only place that j gets used is in the definition of the bound? The actual IS would be completed proving that P(k &#43; 1), not P(j &#43; 1)?</p>

<p>yes exactly</p>

<p>Do we have to explicitly cite chain rule and write the middle steps Pr[A|B \cap C]Pr[B|C]Pr[C] or is it okay to calculate [A \cap B \cap C] directly by multiplying numbers? If we cannot, can we do it if A B C are independent events?</p>

<p>If we let j,k be arbitrary integers with 0 &lt;= j &lt;= k and k &gt;= largest base case, is it equally valid to WTS either P(k&#43;1) or P(j&#43;1) in the IS or is only one of these correct? If we can show P(k&#43;1) and need to apply IH to P(k-1) is that ok because k - 1 can be expressed as a j for which we know P(j) holds? Thanks!</p>

<p>r.v X, Y independent --&gt; E[XY]=E[X]E[Y] but not the other way around right?</p>
<p>I am confused because for (a) - this is not a conditional probability? How do you define &#34;all the other cards you drew are aces, twos, threes, or fours&#34; as a separate event from &#34;event that you draw 4 of spades&#34;? </p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedxgblvppr1vj%2Fac2d7bc58b51e5d76a388bb03e9976951aa507679e3f791fb7332063c5b2e3be%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" width="868" height="482" /></p>
<p>I am confused because for (a) - this is not a conditional probability? How do you define &#34;all the other cards you drew are aces, twos, threes, or fours&#34; as a separate event from &#34;event that you draw 4 of spades&#34;? </p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedxgblvppr1vj%2Fac2d7bc58b51e5d76a388bb03e9976951aa507679e3f791fb7332063c5b2e3be%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" width="868" height="482" /></p>
<p>You could solve this using conditional probability.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Let A be the event that the 12 other cards in your hand are Ace, 2, 3, 4. Let B be the event that you drew the 4 of spades.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Then, $$\Pr[A | B] = \frac{\Pr[A \cap B]}{\Pr[B]} = \frac{\frac{|A \cap B|}{|\Omega|}}{\frac{|B|}{|\Omega|}} = \frac{|A \cap B|}{|B|}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>To calculate $$|A \cap B|$$, we need to find the number of hands that have the 4 of spades and all the remaining cards are Aces, 2, 3, 4. Consider the counting procedure:</p>
<p></p>
<p>Step 1: Include the 4 of spades in your hand.</p>
<p>Step 2: Out of all remaining possible Aces, 2&#39;s, 3&#39;s and 4&#39;s, choose 12 cards to include in your hand.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Step 1 can be performed in 1 way. Step 2 can be performed in $$\binom{15}{12}$$ ways. So by MR, $$|A \cap B| = \binom{15}{12}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>To calculate $$|B|$$, we need the number of hands that have the 4 of spades.</p>
<p>Step 1: Include the 4 of spades.</p>
<p>Step 2: Choose 12 remaining cards.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Step 1 can be performed in 1 way. Step 2, since there are 51 cards left to choose from, can be performed in $$\binom{51}{12}$$ ways.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Substitute, and we get the same answer.</p>
response time: 0:06:39

<p></p>

<p>Hi everyone!</p>
<p></p>
<p>Applications to be a CIS TA for 1100, 1200, 1600 or 1210 are now available at: <a href="https://forms.gle/D6VphTavVSMtetBN9" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://forms.gle/D6VphTavVSMtetBN9</a></p>
<p></p>
<p>Applications are <strong>due Tuesday, April 11th at 11:59pm</strong>, and interviews will take place soon after. There are no prerequisites to be a TA, other than a zeal for teaching! You do not need to have taken the course you are applying for, although it helps. You also do not need to be a CIS or Engineering major; our students come from all over the University, and our TAs do too! As a TA, your duties may include leading weekly recitation, grading weekly homework assignments, holding office hours, and attending a weekly staff meeting. New TAs may also be required to attend a weekly TA training on Fridays.</p>
<p></p>
<ul><li><em><strong>Note that you must fill out the CIS 1600 supplemental application if you wish to be considered. You should receive email confirmation that your supplement was successfully submitted.</strong></em></li></ul>
<p>We’ll be having a TA Application Panel for students to ask about the TA experience <strong>Wednesday April 5 from 7-8:30pm in Wu &amp; Chen Auditorium</strong>. We will also be answering questions about what we look for in the application and interview process. Hope to see you there! If you have any additional questions about what it’s like to be a TA, feel free to reach out to anyone on the course staff. We would love to read your application!</p>

<p>Can we cite the Maximal path strategy from recitation or would we need to cite Well-Ordering Principle to use that strategy?</p>
You don’t need to cite anything if you are using maximal path, as it is simply a graph property. You should only cite if you are making a nontrivial conclusion that we have proved elsewhere, and for that, you do not need to cite WOP

<p>Do I need to add more proof to question one before saying it is a tree?</p>
<p>Do I need to add more proof to question one before saying it is a tree?</p>
A graph that is connected and acyclic is a tree, so if you show that a graph has those two properties, then you can immediately conclude that it is a tree without additional proof

<p>We made a mistake and when we reposted the homework to fix something minor, we included the solutions too! We were alerted to this by many wonderful students among you, and we thank them.<br /><br />So now, the instructor, that’s me, Val, has to make a decision what to do with this homework. Working on this problems is going to be very very useful for you all as you prepare for the final exam. The final is cumulative  but graph theory problems will constitute most of its content. That’s why I do not want to take the easy way out (for me) and just cancel this homework. <br /><br />While I am persuaded that that best thing students could do for their preparation is to ignore the solutions if they accessed them, some possibly will not. Others, who did not access the solutions, will feel that those who did have an unfair advantage.<br /><br />So we will continue with this homework and we will grade it very carefully. The students whose submitted solutions appear to be copied from those we published will not be able to use the score of this homework to improve their average. This homework simply will not count for them (we still drop their two lowest).<br /><br />(If you worry about how we can tell, it’s the same as when we see common solutions among students.)<br /><br />What to do to avoid this as you submit this homework. If you do not have the solutions, nothing. Including not trying to procure them from another student who might have them. If you have the solutions, don’t read them (I know, I know, easy for me to say it…)<br /><br />I am very sorry to add these concerns to your work in this course. Please believe me that I am only thinking of the benefits for the students and  the fairness involved.<br /><br />Val</p>
<md>Given that an induced subgraph of a tree is connected, do we need to prove that the induced subgraph is itself a tree?</md>

<p>Are sample space and probabiliy space the same thing?</p>
<p>Are sample space and probabiliy space the same thing?</p>
<p>A probability space is an ordered pair $$(\Omega, \Pr)$$ where $$\Omega$$ is the sample space. So they are different!</p>

<p>Multiple TA&#39;s told me this. Am I allowed to use this?</p>
<p>The question in the video is:</p>
<p></p>
<div>How many cycles of length 4 are there in $$~K_4$$?</div>
<div>
<div></div>
</div>
<p>How is the correct answer of 15 obtained?</p>
<p>The question in the video is:</p>
<p></p>
<div>How many cycles of length 4 are there in $$~K_4$$?</div>
<div>
<div></div>
</div>
<p>How is the correct answer of 15 obtained?</p>
<p>Let $$K_5 = (V, E)$$ where $$V = \{v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4, v_5\}$$ and $$(v_i, v_j) \in E \quad \forall i, j$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Step 1: Choose 4 vertices. This can be done in $$\binom{5}{4}$$ ways.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Suppose, WLOG, the vertices we chose were $$v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Step 2: Create a cycle out of them. We can do this in three ways:</p>
<p>1. $$v_1 - v_2 - v_3 - v_4$$</p>
<p>2. $$v_1 - v_3 - v_2 - v_4$$</p>
<p>3. $$v_1 - v_3 - v_4 - v_2 $$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>By MR, we have: $$\binom{5}{4} \cdot 3 = 15$$</p>
<p>Let $$K_4 = (V, E)$$ where $$V = \{v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4, v_5\}$$ and $$(v_i, v_j) \in E \quad \forall i, j$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Step 1: Choose 4 vertices. This can be done in $$\binom{5}{4}$$ ways.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Suppose, WLOG, the vertices we chose were $$v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>Step 2: Create a cycle out of them. We can do this in three ways:</p>
<p>1. $$v_1 - v_2 - v_3 - v_4$$</p>
<p>2. $$v_1 - v_3 - v_2 - v_4$$</p>
<p>3. $$v_1 - v_3 - v_4 - v_2 $$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>By MR, we have: $$\binom{5}{4} \cdot 3 = 15$$</p>
response time: 3:47:18

<p>title</p>
<p>you should</p>

<p>Are we allowed to use both constructive and non-constructive proof for existence?</p>
<p></p>
<p><strong>Existence proofs:</strong> To prove a statement of the form ∃x ∈ S,P(x), we give either a constructive or a non-contructive proof. In a constructive proof, one proves the statement by exhibiting a specific x ∈ S such that P(x) is true. In a non-constructive proof, one proves the statement using an indirect proof such as a proof by contradiction. Thus, one might prove that the negation ∀x ∈ S,∼ P(x) is false by deriving a contradiction.</p>
<p>Are we allowed to use both constructive and non-constructive proof for existence?</p>
<p></p>
<p><strong>Existence proofs:</strong> To prove a statement of the form ∃x ∈ S,P(x), we give either a constructive or a non-contructive proof. In a constructive proof, one proves the statement by exhibiting a specific x ∈ S such that P(x) is true. In a non-constructive proof, one proves the statement using an indirect proof such as a proof by contradiction. Thus, one might prove that the negation ∀x ∈ S,∼ P(x) is false by deriving a contradiction.</p>
Yes -Ishaan

<p>Question 3 asks us to &#34;prove that there exists 2 distinct pairs of bunnies that do not have a partnership with each other&#34;. </p>
<p>Is it valid to prove that there exists <strong>at least</strong> 2 distinct pairs of bunnies (2 or more) without a partnership or do we have to prove that there are <strong>exactly</strong> 2 pairs? </p>

<p>we know the theorem ( S is a clique of G iff S is an independent set of ~G).<br />Can this go the other way around by switching G? (S is a clique of ~G iff S is an independent set of G) ? Do we have to prove that or can we just use it?</p>
<p>we know the theorem ( S is a clique of G iff S is an independent set of ~G).<br />Can this go the other way around by switching G? (S is a clique of ~G iff S is an independent set of G) ? Do we have to prove that or can we just use it?</p>
<p>you can go the other way. This is because in the theorem, $$G$$ is just an arbitrary graph. We can rewrite the theorem in an equivalent way as: &#34;$$S$$ is a clique of a graph iff $$S$$ is an independent set of the complement of the graph&#34;.</p>
<p></p>
<p>In this way, we see the arbitrary-ness of the graph!</p>
response time: 0:09:23

for the induction step, if we want to show that a claim holds for a full binary tree of height k&#43;1, do we need to start with the tree of height k&#43;1, or can we start with a height of k (and then add vertices to get to a height k&#43;1)?
for the induction step, if we want to show that a claim holds for a full binary tree of height k&#43;1, do we need to start with the tree of height k&#43;1, or can we start with a height of k (and then add vertices to get to a height k&#43;1)?
<p>Usually in graph induction, you should start with the $$k+1$$ case, reduce it down to the $$k$$ case, and then build back up to the $$k+1$$ case.</p>
<p></p>
<p>This is because when starting from $$k$$ and going to $$k+1$$ directly, we may not consider every single graph that has $$k+1$$ things.</p>
response time: 1:58:53

Does a road in between a pair of locations mean that the locations are directly connected by an edge or are they connected by a path? The question first states that each pair of locations is connected by <strong>1</strong> one-way road but later states that for locations u and v, v is reachable by u and vice versa by a <strong>sequence </strong>of roads.
Does a road in between a pair of locations mean that the locations are directly connected by an edge or are they connected by a path? The question first states that each pair of locations is connected by <strong>1</strong> one-way road but later states that for locations u and v, v is reachable by u and vice versa by a <strong>sequence </strong>of roads.
A road refers to a <strong>direct</strong> connection between a pair of locations. Two locations could be reached by following a <strong>sequence </strong>(one or more) of roads.

What&#39;s the definition of a root in a rooted tree?
What&#39;s the definition of a root in a rooted tree?
It’s just a special name that we give some node. It is used to “organize” the tree, and describe relationships (such as distance) between other nodes to that special node

<p><br />#pin</p>
Where can I find the spreadsheet with the review sessions?
click on the word &#34;Here&#34; in the post
how do we know whether we should induct on vertices or edges?
how do we know whether we should induct on vertices or edges?
<p>What you induct on really depends on the problem. Also, both induction on edges and induction on vertices have their own separate issues, so it just depends.</p><p></p><p>For example, inducting on vertices can sometimes be annoying because when you remove a vertex, you also have to remove all incident edges. But at the same time, inducting on vertices can be nice when you can guarantee existence of a specific type of vertex in a graph (i.e a leaf in a tree)</p><p></p><p>What&#39;s nice about edge induction is that when you remove an edge, you don&#39;t <em>have</em> to remove any vertices, but removing edges can disconnect the graph, and removing edges in general may not be as easy to generalize as removing vertices.</p>
response time: 0:21:23

In the first part of the proof, when we delete at least 2 nodes, why don&#39;t we consider the case of bringing these nodes back? same for the second part, when we add, why we don&#39;t remove it after it?
In the first part of the proof, when we delete at least 2 nodes, why don&#39;t we consider the case of bringing these nodes back? same for the second part, when we add, why we don&#39;t remove it after it?
<p>We can equivalently re-write the solution as follows:</p>
<p></p>
<p>&#34;The resulting tree, call it $$T'$$ has height $$k$$. By the IH, $$T'$$ has $$\geq 2k + 1$$ nodes. Since we removed $$\geq 2$$ nodes, our original tree $$T$$ by re-introducing the nodes we removed, has $$\geq (2k + 1) + 2 = 2(k+1) + 1$$ nodes.&#34;</p>
<p></p>
<p>For the second part of the proof, we are starting from the $$k$$ case and building up to the $$k+1$$ case, so there is no need to remove the nodes.</p>
response time: 0:06:35

I wonder if it would be possible to prove this with induction on the number of strings? Thank you so much
I wonder if it would be possible to prove this with induction on the number of strings? Thank you so much
Yep induction would be possible albeit a bit overkill. In the IS, you would split the nodes into two groupings of size $$2^k$$, apply IH on both groups and argue that there are no coloring conflicts between the two groups. You’d realize that the induction proof and the solution we have provided have high overlap.

<p>I thought that since our base case is 3, we can only assume that V is greater than or equal to 3. </p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedxgblvppr1vj%2F04a8fb5df8425a81fe0d5791c8d4a5ba75ca65aa5040b4da76f15b94add86ac6%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" width="1076" height="933" /></p>
Our graph $$G$$ has $$k+1$$nodes. Since $$k \geq 3$$, we have $$k+1 \geq 3+1 = 4$$, so our graph has at least $$4$$ nodes in the IS.

If a directed walk contains the same vertice repeated twice, does it mean the the walk contains a directed cycle? I am confused on the terminology and the relationship between walks and cycles here... Also is it different for undirected graphs?
If a directed walk contains the same vertice repeated twice, does it mean the the walk contains a directed cycle? I am confused on the terminology and the relationship between walks and cycles here... Also is it different for undirected graphs?
Yes to the first question. The second question almost has an answer of &#34;yes&#34;. The only thing you would have to watch out for in the undirected setting is that your walk is length 3 or longer. Because in undirected graphs, you cannot have a length 2 cycle.
response time: 12:06:14



What is the standard of isomorphism? If you can flip, stretch, and manipulate the graph just that we don&#39;t break or add new edges, is it okay?
What is the standard of isomorphism? If you can flip, stretch, and manipulate the graph just that we don&#39;t break or add new edges, is it okay?
That is the correct intuition of an isomorphism is. Formally, two graphs $$G = (V, E)$$ and $$G' = (V', E')$$ are isomorphic if there exists a bijection $$\phi: V \mapsto V'$$ such that $$\forall (u, v) \in E$$, we have $$(\phi(u), \phi(v)) \in E'$$
response time: 1:06:12

<p>you can just use WOP, but it would also be a good idea to note that the set is finite and non-empty. A full explanation is probably not needed.</p>
<p></p>
<p>You can use WOP to conclude that a finite, non-empty set has a minimum element and a maximum element.</p>

<p>Here, aren&#39;t the two instances the same if you rotate one? For colorability, do you assume that there is no isomorphism?</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedxgblvppr1vj%2F2cd567d4388106e6b5aad78788e42dbad08fb8a136e00b5e855fa8bb9771ce83%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" width="864" height="282" /></p>
<p>Here, aren&#39;t the two instances the same if you rotate one? For colorability, do you assume that there is no isomorphism?</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkedxgblvppr1vj%2F2cd567d4388106e6b5aad78788e42dbad08fb8a136e00b5e855fa8bb9771ce83%2Fimage.png" alt="image.pngNaN" width="864" height="282" /></p>
You do not consider isomorphisms with colorings, because a coloring is defined to be a function $$f: V \mapsto \{1, \ldots k\}$$. So having vertex $$a$$ colored with color $$2$$, for example, would be different from vertex $$a$$ being colored with color $$1$$.
response time: 0:31:20



<p>To those that attended my review session earlier today, here&#39;s an example when events are pairwise independent but not mutually independent.</p>
<p></p>
<p>We roll 2 dice, and let:</p>
<p>A = event the sum of the die is odd (Pr(A) = 1/2)</p>
<p>B = event the first dice is even (Pr(B) = 1/2)</p>
<p>C - event the second dice is even (Pr(C) = 1/2)</p>
<p></p>
<p>If we work out the probabilities, we see that the A, B and C are all pairwise independent.</p>
<p>However, Pr(A∩B∩C) = 0, which is not the same as Pr(A) x Pr(B) x Pr(C).</p>
<p></p>
<p>Also note that mutual independence implies pairwise independence, but not vice versa.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Best of luck!</p>

<img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkxaroeu1gmk2e6%2F49fbe4b361be255a42b6846f21029c39e9fdf72ae5c3f9649fb17fbee76b9b32%2FScreen_Shot_2023-04-27_at_2.44.06_PM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2023-04-27_at_2.44.06_PM.pngNaN" />
<img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkxaroeu1gmk2e6%2F49fbe4b361be255a42b6846f21029c39e9fdf72ae5c3f9649fb17fbee76b9b32%2FScreen_Shot_2023-04-27_at_2.44.06_PM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2023-04-27_at_2.44.06_PM.pngNaN" />
<p>This only works for $$P_4$$. You should try drawing it out and seeing the bijection. If $$P_4$$ is the graph $$V = \{v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4\}$$ and $$E = \{(v_1, v_2), (v_2, v_3), (v_3, v_4)\}$$, then the complement is the graph with vertex set $$V' = \{v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4\}$$ and edges $$E' = \{(v_1, v_3), (v_1, v_4), (v_2, v_4)\}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The bijection $$\phi: V \mapsto V'$$ is defined by $$\phi(v_1) = v_2$$, $$\phi(v_2) = v_4$$, $$\phi(v_3) = v_1$$ and $$\phi(v_4) = v_3$$</p>

<p>In a tree $$G=(V,E)$$ (undirected), adding one more edge will result in a cycle, by the minimally acyclic property (and hopefully we don&#39;t have to prove this on the final...?). Following this logic, do we know that with each edge we add, the number of cycles in $$G$$ will increase by exactly 1? If so, do we have to prove it, and how might we approach this proof?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Related, if a connected undirected graph with $$n$$ vertices has exactly $$k$$ cycles, does such a graph have exactly $$k$$ extra edges compared to its spanning tree?</p>
<p></p>
<p>This question is inspired by Final Review Q11 for reference</p>
<p>In a tree $$G=(V,E)$$ (undirected), adding one more edge will result in a cycle, by the minimally acyclic property (and hopefully we don&#39;t have to prove this on the final...?). Following this logic, do we know that with each edge we add, the number of cycles in $$G$$ will increase by exactly 1? If so, do we have to prove it, and how might we approach this proof?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Related, if a connected undirected graph with $$n$$ vertices has exactly $$k$$ cycles, does such a graph have exactly $$k$$ extra edges compared to its spanning tree?</p>
<p></p>
<p>This question is inspired by Final Review Q11 for reference</p>
<p>It is NOT true that with each edge we add, the number of cycles in $$G$$ will increase by exactly 1. Take, for example, $$G = (V, E)$$ with $$V = \{v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4\}$$ and $$E = \{(v_1, v_2), (v_2, v_3), (v_3, v_4)$$. This graph is a tree with zero cycles. Adding the edge $$(v_4, v_1)$$ creates a single cycle. However, if we were to add another edge (while still including $$(v_4, v_1)$$), say $$(v_1, v_3)$$, then the resulting graph has $$3$$ cycles.</p>
<p></p>
<p>It follows that the answer to your &#34;related&#34; question is no.</p>
Then do we have that &#34;in an undirected tree, with each edge we add, there will be<em> at least</em> 1 new cycle formed&#34;?
I believe so

<p>For any tree if we add one edge between any two existing vertices the resulting graph is not<br />bipartite.</p>
<p></p>
<p>- I am a bit confused about this phrasing. Is this the same as for any tree adding an edge between EVERY any two existing vertices at the same time?</p>
<p></p>
<p>- or is it just when this edge is added separately in different scenarios/</p>
<p></p>
<p>- Also, can we choose which edge is added. For eg could I give a particular example of a tree where I add an edge and it remains bipartite to disprove the claim? (or should the statement hold for any selection of vertices?)</p>
<p>For any tree if we add one edge between any two existing vertices the resulting graph is not<br />bipartite.</p>
<p></p>
<p>- I am a bit confused about this phrasing. Is this the same as for any tree adding an edge between EVERY any two existing vertices at the same time?</p>
<p></p>
<p>- or is it just when this edge is added separately in different scenarios/</p>
<p></p>
<p>- Also, can we choose which edge is added. For eg could I give a particular example of a tree where I add an edge and it remains bipartite to disprove the claim? (or should the statement hold for any selection of vertices?)</p>
<p>This claim is saying that if you start with a tree, no matter which edge you add to it (so long as it does not already exist), the resulting graph will be not bipartite.</p>
<p></p>
<p>To prove this, you would need to show that for ANY edge you add to the tree, the graph will not be bipartite. Thus, you cannot just give a single example of an edge.</p>

<p>In the proof on the solutions, it says:</p>
<p></p>
<p>\\</p>
<div>
<div>With this we can say that the graph must<br />have an even number of vertices because there are only odd degree vertices.</div>
<div>\\</div>
</div>
<div></div>
<div>What is the broader logic behind this?</div>
<p>In the proof on the solutions, it says:</p>
<p></p>
<p>\\</p>
<div>
<div>With this we can say that the graph must<br />have an even number of vertices because there are only odd degree vertices.</div>
<div>\\</div>
</div>
<div></div>
<div>What is the broader logic behind this?</div>
$$\sum_{v \in V} \deg(v) = 2|E|$$. This tells us that the sum of the degrees of the vertices must be an even number. If there were an odd number of vertices, then $$\sum_{v \in V} \deg(v)$$ would be odd (the sum of and odd amount of odd numbers is odd), but that&#39;s a contradiction.
response time: 0:01:54

<p>When this problem says for any u, v, w distinct vertices, does that mean the entire triplet of vertices needs to be distinct from every other triplet of vertices in the graph, or that no pairing of three vertices can exist with the given property with any repeats of vertices (i.e would {u, v, w} and {a, b, u} be considered distinct vertices)?</p>
<p>I am asking because of the response to @1331 and @1382 defining distinct pairs.</p>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<p>For arbitrary n ≥ 2, give an example of a set X and a function g : X → [1..n] that is not</p>
<p>injective and moreover | Ran(g)| = n − 1.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p></p>
<p>The answer is</p>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<p>DefineX=[1..n]andforeach1 ≤ k ≤ n define</p>
</div>
</div>
<div>
<div>
<p>g(k) =</p>
</div>
<div>
<p>k if 1 ≤ k ≤ n − 1 n−1 if k=n.</p>
<p></p>
</div>
</div>
<p>--</p>
<p></p>
</div>
<p>Are we able to say that the range of the answer is n - 1 because the nth term is not getting mapped to. Does this mean that range is how many values in the codomain are getting mapped to? Not just how many values are in the codomain? Thanks!</p>
<div>
<div>
<p></p>
</div>
</div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<p>For arbitrary n ≥ 2, give an example of a set X and a function g : X → [1..n] that is not</p>
<p>injective and moreover | Ran(g)| = n − 1.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p></p>
<p>The answer is</p>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<p>DefineX=[1..n]andforeach1 ≤ k ≤ n define</p>
</div>
</div>
<div>
<div>
<p>g(k) =</p>
</div>
<div>
<p>k if 1 ≤ k ≤ n − 1 n−1 if k=n.</p>
<p></p>
</div>
</div>
<p>--</p>
<p></p>
</div>
<p>Are we able to say that the range of the answer is n - 1 because the nth term is not getting mapped to. Does this mean that range is how many values in the codomain are getting mapped to? Not just how many values are in the codomain? Thanks!</p>
<div>
<div>
<p></p>
</div>
</div>
The range is the set of values in the codomain that are being mapped to. That is, for a function $$g: X \mapsto Y$$, we have $$y \in Ran(g)$$ if $$\exists x \in X$$ such that $$g(x) = y$$. And we see that $$Ran(g) \subseteq Y$$.

Let P′ be the part of this walk that starts at v and then returns to v, and let v′ be the second-to-last vertex in P′. Since we have a walk from v to v′, we must also have a path from v to v′, so this path plus the edge v′ → v creates a directed cycle, contradicting the fact that slugs are acyclic.&#34;</p>

<p>Can we use proof by contradiction with cases on the number of cycles in the graph to prove that G has exactly 1 cycle?</p>
<p></p>
<p>AFSOC: # of cycles in G \neq 1.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Case 1: # of cycles = 0</p>
<p>Then, G is a tree, and |E| = |V| - 1. Contradiction.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Case 2: # of cycles \geq 2</p>
<p>Case a: Cycles don&#39;t share edges. Then the graph is disconnected. Contradiction.</p>
<p>Case b: Cycles do share \geq 1 edges(s). Then |E| &gt; |V|. Contradiction.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Hence, G has exactly 1 cycle.</p>
<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fld0r4fd0w5f3rx%2Fa25ae8b6f6f79029e5c59fa3590c9f376d28bf5c442b3aa78002c8ace39b9993%2FScreenshot_2023-04-29_at_4.38.25_PM.png" width="1466" height="966" alt="" /></p>
<p> For case 2, can we simply say we can place u at the front of the topo sort so that the condition u-&gt;y is satisfied?</p>

<p>if a vertex in a digraph has outdegree 1, can its 1 edge be directed towards itself?</p>

<p>if a vertex in a digraph has outdegree 1, can its 1 edge be directed towards itself?</p>
<p></p>
<p>also, if a vertex has 1 directed edge pointing to itself, would it be considered neither a source nor a sink?</p>
Such a vertex-edge combination would be called a “self loop”, and such a vertex is neither a source nor a sink

For 4b, why is the answer not 6n(n-1) &#43; 6n(n-1)(n-2)? Would the paths of length 3 be different if you started the path with a blue vertex instead of a red vertex, which is why you would also add 6n(n-1)(n-2) to account for paths starting with blue vertex?
I might just be drawing a blank, but how do we count the number of subgraphs in a graph given n vertices, or is this not something that we can immediately do.
I might just be drawing a blank, but how do we count the number of subgraphs in a graph given n vertices, or is this not something that we can immediately do.
uhhh this is not something that is super easy to calculate, because the standard counting procedure would be to count how many vertex sets we could have (which would be $$2^n$$), but determining the number of subgraphs for a particular subset of vertices is kinda hard. If you want a really trivial bound, we could say that the number of subgraphs is $$\leq 2^n \cdot 2^m$$ for an n-vertex graph with m-edges. But this is not super useful.

for 1, something like @1626 would be fine where you provide a coloring and justify why it is bipartite. For 2, the answer is 4.
why is #2 4, not 5? when you remove 2 edges, isn’t there still a vertex with a degree of 4 in G? 
The maximum degree of a graph is not the lower bound for the amount of colors needed to color a graph. Consider a graph that is a tree with a central vertex which has a bunch of neighbors and nothing else. The max degree is much larger than 2, but the graph is 2-colorable
why is #2 4, not 5? when you remove 2 edges, isn’t there still a vertex with a degree of 4 in G? 
I see, how do you get to the answer 4? What is the general process to find chromatic number for a specific graph?
why is #2 4, not 5? when you remove 2 edges, isn’t there still a vertex with a degree of 4 in G? 
It turns out that computing the chromatic number of an arbitrary graph is extremely difficult computationally (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_coloring" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">check this out for further reading</a>)! For our purposes, trial-and-error usually works best. But it&#39;s always good to keep in mind some facts we know about coloring (i.e. trees are bipartite, even cycles are bipartite, etc).

<p>Checking if an alternative approach works</p>
<p>- prove that a friendly cant duel another friendly</p>
<p>- hence all friendly has only one edge and that edge is to a feisty </p>
<p>- so sum of edges from feisty to friendly = number of friendly</p>
<p></p>
<p>- hence, asfoc, each feisty duels max 2 friendly. max edges = 2(l/2 - 1)</p>
<p>- max friendly nodes = l - 2</p>
<p>contradiction and friendly = l</p>
<p></p>
<p>Checking if an alternative approach works</p>
<p>- prove that a friendly cant duel another friendly</p>
<p>- hence all friendly has only one edge and that edge is to a feisty </p>
<p>- so sum of edges from feisty to friendly = number of friendly</p>
<p></p>
<p>- hence, asfoc, each feisty duels max 2 friendly. max edges = 2(l/2 - 1)</p>
<p>- max friendly nodes = l - 2</p>
<p>contradiction and friendly = l</p>

<p><img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fjqzrec0dbz24vc%2Ff2ce175c04578ab7e9d06e62401b7f136c6f91f08cfaab056902d6f0d661cfac%2Fimage.png" alt="image.png" width="943" height="33" /></p>

Regrade endorsements must be received from a TA at office hours or after recitation. Regrade requests will not be endorsed over Piazza. Any TA can endorse your request.</p>

<p>In lecture on 3/23, we counted number of paths of length 2 in a $$K_n$$ graph. The steps are as shown below. However, I couldn&#39;t get how $$n\cdot {n-1\choose 2}$$ gave $$\frac{n^2(n-1)}{2}$$(bottom of screenshot) instead of $$\frac{n(n-1)(n-2)}{2}$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>More over, as a test I tried to find number of paths of length 2 in $$K_3$$ (which clearly is 3), and $$3\cdot {3-1\choose 2}=\frac{3(3-1)(3-2)}{2} = 3$$ but $$\frac{3^2(3-1)}{2} = 9\neq 3$$. Therefore, I wanted to check is this was indeed an error or if I&#39;m missing something. </p>
<p></p>
<p>In addition, would it also be valid if we first chose the 2 vertices for path endpoints and then chose the intermediate vertices from the rest of $$n-2$$ vertices? (yielding $${n\choose 2}\cdot (n-2)$$ for length $$k=2$$)<img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Flcslyhhojpq2v4%2Fdaa163ec387393905cae59636c13cdbeb481924a1b96dca1cf90f1571fe98ac8%2FScreen_Shot_2023-04-30_at_12.12.16_PM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2023-04-30_at_12.12.16_PM.pngNaN" /></p>
<p>In lecture on 3/23, we counted number of paths of length 2 in a $$K_n$$ graph. The steps are as shown below. However, I couldn&#39;t get how $$n\cdot {n-1\choose 2}$$ gave $$\frac{n^2(n-1)}{2}$$(bottom of screenshot) instead of $$\frac{n(n-1)(n-2)}{2}$$. </p>
<p></p>
<p>More over, as a test I tried to find number of paths of length 2 in $$K_3$$ (which clearly is 3), and $$3\cdot {3-1\choose 2}=\frac{3(3-1)(3-2)}{2} = 3$$ but $$\frac{3^2(3-1)}{2} = 9\neq 3$$. Therefore, I wanted to check is this was indeed an error or if I&#39;m missing something. </p>
<p></p>
<p>In addition, would it also be valid if we first chose the 2 vertices for path endpoints and then chose the intermediate vertices from the rest of $$n-2$$ vertices? (yielding $${n\choose 2}\cdot (n-2)$$ for length $$k=2$$)<img src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Flcslyhhojpq2v4%2Fdaa163ec387393905cae59636c13cdbeb481924a1b96dca1cf90f1571fe98ac8%2FScreen_Shot_2023-04-30_at_12.12.16_PM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2023-04-30_at_12.12.16_PM.pngNaN" /></p>
<p>The math is just a bit wrong. $$n \cdot \binom{n-1}{2}$$ simplifies to $$\frac{n(n-1)(n-2)}{2}$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Yes to the second question.</p>

<p>In homework10 we proved that the chromatic number $$\chi(G)$$ is greater or equal to the size of the largest clique in $$G$$, $$\kappa (G)$$. The example we used to disprove $$\chi(G) = \kappa(G)$$ for all $$G$$ was the case of any odd cycle in $$G$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Therefore, would any graph $$G$$ that doesn&#39;t contain any odd cycle necessarily have $$\chi(G) = \kappa(G)$$?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Or, in other words, would $$\chi(G) = \kappa(G)$$ hold for any $$\chi(G) \geq 3$$?</p>
<p>In homework10 we proved that the chromatic number $$\chi(G)$$ is greater or equal to the size of the largest clique in $$G$$, $$\kappa (G)$$. The example we used to disprove $$\chi(G) = \kappa(G)$$ for all $$G$$ was the case of any odd cycle in $$G$$.</p>
<p></p>
<p>Therefore, would any graph $$G$$ that doesn&#39;t contain any odd cycle necessarily have $$\chi(G) = \kappa(G)$$?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Or, in other words, would $$\chi(G) = \kappa(G)$$ hold for any $$\chi(G) \geq 3$$?</p>
<blockquote>
<p dir="ltr" style="padding-left:40px">Would any graph $$G$$ that doesn&#39;t contain any odd cycle necessarily have $$\chi(G) = \kappa(G)$$?</p>
</blockquote>
<p dir="ltr">We have shown that a graph without an odd cycle is bipartite. So it would remain to show that a graph with no odd cycles would have max clique size of $$2$$. It&#39;s pretty easy to show why this is true via contradiction (suppose you had a clique of size 3 or larger...)</p>
<p dir="ltr"></p>
<p dir="ltr"></p>
response time: 5:49:16



<p>&#34;Prove that any grid is bipartite&#34; was a question on IS19. Would the below coloring procedure work?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Consider numbering each column and rows with positive integers $$[1..n]$$. So, the upper-left most vertex would have the coordinate $$(1,1)$$, the neighbor immediately to its right would be $$(1,2)$$, etc. We color any vertex with coordinate with the same parity as red, and any vertex with coordinate with differing parity as blue. </p>
<p>&#34;Prove that any grid is bipartite&#34; was a question on IS19. Would the below coloring procedure work?</p>
<p></p>
<p>Consider numbering each column and rows with positive integers $$[1..n]$$. So, the upper-left most vertex would have the coordinate $$(1,1)$$, the neighbor immediately to its right would be $$(1,2)$$, etc. We color any vertex with coordinate with the same parity as red, and any vertex with coordinate with differing parity as blue. </p>
yeah that&#39;s a valid coloring

For which induction problems do we need to remove than add a certain vertex or edge?
For which induction problems do we need to remove than add a certain vertex or edge?
You should almost always consider the $$k+1$$ case, then reduce to the $$k$$ case, apply the IH, then reintroduce to get back to $$k+1$$

If we want to distribute n stars to r people but we want all of them to have at least 1 star and exactly 3 of them to have at least 2 stars, how do we solve the problem? Also, what would happen if it was at least 3 people instead of exactly 3?
If we want to distribute n stars to r people but we want all of them to have at least 1 star and exactly 3 of them to have at least 2 stars, how do we solve the problem? Also, what would happen if it was at least 3 people instead of exactly 3?
<p>If there are $$n$$ people, and exactly 3 of them must have at least 2 star and the remaining $$n-3$$ people must have at least one star, then it must be the case that the $$n-3$$ people all have exactly one star. So give those people all one star, then do stars &amp; bars with the remaining stars amongst the 3 people left. </p>
<p></p>
<p>For the second question, you could probably do some complementary counting PIE type stuff.</p>
Sorry I don&#39;t understand - I have r people. I want all of them to have at least 1 star so I distribute them by subtracting r from n. Then, I want exactly 3 people to have at least 2. Does it suffice to just subtract 3 more from n-r? And then we do stars and bars?
well, when you do this, the remaining people will have 1 star (that they received from the first step) &#43; more that they get from the last step. This would mean that you would have more than 3 people with at least 2 stars (whereas you wanted <strong>exactly </strong>3 people with at least 2 stars).
response time: 2:26:40





we only consider colorings of undirected graphs in this course. In general, $$K_n$$ refers to the undirected complete graph. Similarly, $$K_{m, n}$$ is the complete undirected bipartite graph.
response time: 3:11:10



Hi could you please help me understand the difference between sufficient and necessary in terms of logical notation and how it is related to if-then statements. I am still a bit confused about this.
Is an edgeless subgraph of a graph containing all the vertices a spanning subgraph? If we have k vertices, then would the number of spanning subgraphs be 2^k?
Is an edgeless subgraph of a graph containing all the vertices a spanning subgraph? If we have k vertices, then would the number of spanning subgraphs be 2^k?
Yes to the first question. If you have $$k$$ <strong>edges</strong>, then the number of spanning subgraphs would be $$2^k$$
